So, I finally got around to playing Blasphemous, and it's a bit of a mixed bag for me. Let's start with the good stuff. The game looks absolutely stunning! The pixel art is beautifully detailed, and the environments are dripping with atmospheric goodness. The smooth gameplay is a real highlight; the controls are tight, and combat feels satisfyingly impactful. And let's not forget that OST – it's a masterpiece. The haunting melodies really set the tone for this dark, twisted world.

Now, onto the not-so-great parts. The bosses – I mean, seriously? They could have cranked up the difficulty a notch. I was expecting more of a challenge, but most of them felt a bit too easy to defeat. A little more complexity and variety in their attack patterns would have been welcome.

And can we talk about those instakill spikes everywhere? I get it, the game wants to be challenging, but sometimes it just feels unfair. I found myself more frustrated by unexpected deaths from spikes than by actual enemies. A bit less of that wouldn't hurt.

Another gripe is the lack of quick travel options. Come on, in a game where backtracking is part of the deal, a quick travel system is almost a necessity. It gets a bit tedious having to traverse the entire map repeatedly, especially when you just want to explore different areas.

Despite these issues, Blasphemous does have its charm. If you can look past the frustration of spikes and wish for tougher bosses, there's a beautifully crafted game with a captivating atmosphere waiting for you. It might not be perfect, but it's worth a playthrough, especially for those who appreciate a visually stunning and smoothly playing experience.

Inconsistent controls and game mechanics keep this game from being among of the best Metroidvanias.

Some enemies and attacks you can parry, some you cannot. Sometimes an enemy can be dodged through, other times the same enemy cannot. Some pits are bottomless while some require you to drop down to progress. You're literally flipping a coin first to see whether you're jumping into a pit of death, and some spikes are instant kills while some are not. Sometimes you are able to grab onto a ladder in poison fog, sometimes it doesn't register. 

Even after the major patch and expansion that attempted to address major issues with the game, stun, heal and attack animations continue to lock you in while enemies big and small barely flinch to your assaults. Magic is therefore still moderately useless, as is parrying because they all lock you into vulnerable frames with inconsistent benefits. Even healing yourself is dangerous because you're vulnerable and stationary for many, many frames.

There's no visual cues to let you clue in when any of these mechanics are meant to be used and when not to. Rather than feeling natural, the game is full of artificial difficulty, which is infuriating.

[i]Blasphemous[/i] is a solid metroidvania game. The art style is beautiful, and the combat is fun, but there are some questionable design choices. Namely the ladders are extremely annoying and I often ended up accidentally grabbing them when I was trying to attack upwards, while I failed to grab them when I was actually trying to. There are also a few bosses that can just chain hit you until you die, but that didn't bother me much because it felt like part of the challenge. Certainly takes a lot of inspiration from [i]Hollow Knight[/i]; runes, arena, respawn points, secrets/collection style etc. The world is really large and I was excited that the map kept getting bigger even when it felt like I was approaching the game's ending. Genuinely had a lot of fun, but some of the enemy designs require a lot of patience to take down properly, and the game doesn't give much direction in terms of unlocking new abilities. It's also a pretty short experience– I beat the main story in about 8 hours of gameplay, then spent about 5-6 more getting my file to 100% completion and unlocking another ending. [i]Blasphemous[/i] is good, but the few poor design choices stand out and hurt it a bit. Though artistically it's amazing, and I enjoyed my time with it.

Never would I have thought that mixing metroidvania with souls-like game-play would make such a banger of a game. The pixel art is amazing, the over-world is breathtaking, and of course the executions are just flat out beautiful to watch. I do however have three main issues with the game. 

  Number one, I don't like how you have to spend precious tears to unlock fast travel between shrines. I know there are fast travel points, but I feel they should have just stuck with shrine travel in general. 

  Number two is how upgrading flasks work. You have to sacrifice a flask charge in order to make healing stronger. There's ten in total, but upgrading to the max only gives you 5 in the end. I just think that's plain dumb, you shouldn't have to lose flasks to upgrade your healing. 

  Number three is side missions. there are a few missions in the game where if you progress to far in the story you'll miss out on gaining really useful items. None of them are even related to bosses so I don't know why it would matter when I do a mission. 

  Overall I do think this game is well worth the money if you like a good challenge. Since honestly, when it comes to souls-like games. This is one of the better ones out there. 8/10

I have completed the game, but looking back it was a mix of great combat and some annoyances.

Pros:
* Movement and combat are smooth and satisfying.
* The setting is unique and great.
* Very nice pixel art.

Cons:
* It's disheartening that some well known nearly game breaking bugs have never been fixed (for example the tizona bug).
* To get to "good" endings you have to do things in specific order. If you miss something, you have to start the game from the beginning.
* The plot is weak like in most soulslike games. Yeah you can just learn about the world from surroundings, but I prefer a proper storytelling.

This is a good game. Interesting story, great artwork, fun boss design and pretty good mechanics. The problem I have with it is that it is extremely convoluted from a certain point onward as it forces you to backtrack the whole map in search of things you may have missed along the journey. This gets tedious real quick as you are not given barely any hints to go on, the item descriptions being extremely esoteric and no quest log/journal system. The biggest issue I have to is that I had defeated one of the core end game bosses of the game without beating one of the DLC bosses first which led to me being unable to unlock the 3rd proper ending...I had gathered the items from the DLC snake and crypt boss before reaching the game's final boss but it was too late. This is simply lackluster game design as I had no idea of the order I was supposed to follow in order to get a very good weapon buff (+25% damage) and unlock the 3rd ending. I ended up having the quest items in my inventory and not being able to use them (on the 4th Visage) and complete the questline, simply because I killed a (rather difficult) boss before the game intended me to...This really took a lot of the joy out of my experience.

Blasphemous, developed by The Game Kitchen, is a masterwork of atmospheric storytelling and challenging gameplay that plunges players into a grim and unforgiving world. With its haunting visuals, precise combat mechanics, and deep lore, Blasphemous offers an unforgettable experience that beckons players to return time and time again.

Visually, Blasphemous is a dark and atmospheric marvel. The handcrafted pixel art style creates a nightmarish realm filled with grotesque creatures, haunting landscapes, and stunningly detailed animations. Every frame is dripping with macabre beauty, evoking a sense of unease and awe. The attention to detail is remarkable, immersing players in a world that feels both hauntingly familiar and utterly unique.

The gameplay of Blasphemous is challenging but deeply satisfying. As the Penitent One, players engage in precise and skill-based combat, mastering a variety of weapons and abilities to overcome the horrors that lurk in Cvstodia. The combat mechanics are tight and responsive, rewarding well-timed parries, dodges, and devastating counterattacks. Each encounter demands focus and strategy, making victories feel hard-earned and exhilarating.

What sets Blasphemous apart is its rich and enigmatic lore. The game's narrative is intricately woven into every aspect of its design, from the haunting environments to the cryptic item descriptions. Exploring the interconnected world of Cvstodia reveals fragments of a dark and tragic history, inviting players to piece together the truth behind the land's religious fervor and suffering. The lore is deep, engaging, and leaves players hungry for more.

Replayability is where Blasphemous truly shines. The game offers multiple paths, secret areas, and hidden collectibles, ensuring that each playthrough unveils new discoveries. The interconnected nature of the world encourages exploration, as backtracking to previously inaccessible areas with newfound abilities reveals hidden secrets and alternate routes. The sheer amount of content and the desire to uncover every hidden secret make Blasphemous a game worth revisiting.

Furthermore, Blasphemous provides additional replay value through its New Game Plus mode. After completing the game, players can start a new playthrough with their upgraded abilities and equipment, facing even greater challenges and uncovering additional story elements. This mode adds a layer of depth and longevity to the experience, enticing players to test their skills and unravel the mysteries of Cvstodia once more.

However, it's worth noting that Blasphemous may not appeal to everyone. Its difficulty level can be punishing, demanding precise execution and patience. Some players may find the steep learning curve frustrating, but for those willing to persevere, the sense of accomplishment is immensely gratifying.

In conclusion, Blasphemous is a dark and atmospheric masterpiece that combines haunting visuals, challenging gameplay, and a captivating narrative. Its intricate lore and interconnected world draw players into a realm of religious anguish and macabre beauty. With its high level of replayability and New Game Plus mode, Blasphemous offers an experience that keeps players coming back for more, uncovering new secrets with each playthrough. It is a must-play for fans of atmospheric action-platformers seeking a deeply immersive and rewarding journey into darkness.

Blasphemous is a fun game, but not without its flaws. I personally enjoyed it and would recommend it to people who have played souls-like games or metroidvania games like Hollow Knight or Dead Cells, or any other metroidvania game out there.

It has a dark and atmospheric world, with amazing and detailed pixel art. The challenging combat, combined with platforming sections and boss battles, is a highlight. The game draws heavy inspiration from Christianity and Spanish folklore, and while I'm not a Christian, the deep-rooted religious themes might be off-putting to some players. The grotesque elements, though fitting the dark atmosphere, can be intense.

Exploration in this game was really confusing at times, but also very satisfying to explore the map. The soundtrack was alright, I didn't really care much about it. During gameplay, I am more focused on finding the next boss, relic, or loot.

I rate this game 8/10. It was fun, however, it is not without its flaws. For example, it was very confusing to figure out what to do, the map is just so big, there are things not explained to you, and finding certain items can significantly impact exploration or boss battles.

The questing is really confusing, you don't know how or when you are supposed to progress each quest. You don't even know how many items you need to collect, and the absence of a journal in the game is a bummer because questing would have been more efficient.

Brutal and divine experience, a fun and difficult metroidvania with a focus on religious symbolism. 

The gameplay is very challenging, even right from the start, as the game gives you only it's basic tools for you to master: parrying, dodging, aerial attacks, combos...
The progression system is focused on exploration. Don't worry, a basic amount of exploration is needed to play through the game for the first time, but the more you explore the easier it gets... until you realize that the game offers you enough possibilities to properly challenge yourself even with your new upgrades.

What I always didn't like about some other games of the genre is the amount of time used to find "the next major main part" but this game doesn't have that problem. The map is digestable enough so that you always know what you didn't explore and the map layout doesn't require much effort to travel to many areas more than you want, which is amazing. I also unlocked like 95% of everything without looking up a guide, but the remaining amount is something completionists will still enjoy as a tough challenge.

The combat is tight and satisfying and it gets enhanced with more possibilities the longer you play. There are some insane builds you can pickup (again based on exploration) along the way. And parrying bosses in this game feels so amazing.

The story and world is a deep dive. At first, everything seems just weird, gory and occult but you will learn to love it eventually. Every item has a huge paragraph  that tells you a little more about the story of the game, but you can also just sit back and take in the environment without reading it all, and it's still good due to the presentation. And the presentation of this game is one of the best aspects! It's a weird blender between 2d and 3d combined with a renaissance-like stylization and is perfect to transfer the medium.

And everything I told you about scales very well, you can have as much as you want in this game. Every person I know that played this game has at least played through it twice, likely even more, made possibility by the depth and satisfaction of everything.

I had some minor bugs when I played it but nothing really awful.

Es curioso. Escribo esta reseña mucho tiempo después de terminar la secuela de este juego. Y mucho mas aún de haber terminado esta entrega. 

A estas alturas estoy seguro de que, si me permitieran elegir un solo género o subgénero de video-juegos, lo mas probable es que "Metroidvania" sería la respuesta. Y Aquí es donde comienzo con el gran Blasphemous. 

Este juego desarrollado por un estudio español, toma a manos llenas los elementos que hacen grande a un Metroidvania. Entonces, ¿Qué es lo interesante? ¿Por que tanto Hype? ¿En serio requería de una secuela?

Si bien no termina de renovar ni reinventar el género, es notable su increíble apartado gráfico. Ese mundo que crearon los de "The Game Kitchen" es sumamente bello. También es único. Finalmente, es horroroso lo que sucede en él, y el viaje al que nos lleva.

Tomamos el control de "El penitente" un guerrero silencioso cuya misión es especificada al inicio del juego. Sin embargo el reto que conlleva es mas difícil de lograr que lo esperado. Los personajes que aparecen ante el protagonista (ya sea para ayudarle, o intentar detenerle), están animados de una manera que se siente orgánica en ese lugar.  En serio, solo apreciar lo que está sucediendo en el mundo y sus alrededores vale la pena.

A esto se le suma un increíble soundtrack que fue hecho a la medida para cada zona, enfrentamiento contra jefe, lugar seguro, menús, etc.

Y hablando del "pequeño" detalle de los jefes, Blasphemous si que sabe lo que hace. Luchas brutales, victorias pírricas y probablemente muchas derrotas nos esperan a la hora de medirnos contra estos seres, que tienen mecánicas tan particulares y animaciones tan bien hechas que, simplemente son todo un viaje por si solos.

Los diálogos son impresionantes y este es uno de los pocos juegos que recomiendo jugar en Español de España. La narrativa podría no ser la mas extensa y el Lore es un tanto confuso. Si no estamos familiarizados con ciertas referencias católicas es posible que de entrada se sienta raro. Sin embargo conforme te dejas envolver y absorber por el mundo de Cvstodia y su fervor enfermizo, vas comprendiendo que es lo que sucedió y por qué es necesario llegar hasta el final.

Es un juego difícil. Muchos dicen que no se compara con Hollow Knight en este apartado. Sin embargo, subestimar a tus enemigos es un gran error. Pero no hay por qué preocuparse. Ellos estarán contentos de recordarnos eso. Por lo tanto, hay que volverse mas fuerte, y este es otro de los puntos fuertes del juego. Tenemos a nuestra disposición una enorme variedad de poderes, accesorios y técnicas que (por supuesto que las pagamos con fervor) nos ayudaran durante nuestra penitencia.

No hay tantos juegos de un solo jugador a los que le dedique tantas horas. Pero este si se lo merece. Altamente recomendable. Buen valor de re-jugabilidad y mas de un final por desbloquear.

Pros: [list]
[*]Unique, grotesque, excellent art and designs 
[*]Great music and sound
[*] Good, but not excellent, combat gameplay. 
[*]Character and vibe 
[*] Manageable play time for a first game, with the option to NG+ if you're into that. 
[*] Excellent on Steam Deck.
[/list]
Cons: [list]
[*]Finicky platforming combined with instant death spikes and pits. Would often miss a platform for no clear reason, and I felt that some hazards that alternated between foreground and background were easy to misread (the bells in Mother of Mothers). 
[*]I found the balance quite bad - the only boss I really struggled with was Lady of the Charred Visage who I felt was very random. Every other boss I was able to defeat in 1-2 tries, especially after unlocking [spoiler] the spell Debla and the two +100% spell damage items [/spoiler]. That combination trivialized the bosses in the second half of the game. 
[*] In general, too many spells. No reason or easy way to switch between them in combat. 
[*] Sword arts in general were either incredible (dash strike), niche (ranged attack), or useless (charge attack, downstrike)
[*] While the world building was interesting and vibey, the actual plot and directions I found very opaque. Side quests particularly I needed a guide. 
[*] The bone collectibles were meh.
[/list]

The first time I played this game, I played for about 3 hours, beating the first 2 bosses and then I was bored. I decided to come back to it recently, and I am very glad I did. 

This is a great Metroidvania with great progression, a beautiful art style, and mysterious story telling. 

There's a lot of content here, even when you complete your first run there's more to experience after. The game offers a good amount of challenge but there are really challenging options available if you're looking for something more difficult. 

I played Blasphemous 2 straight after this and having completed that game at nearly 100% (currently sitting at 97% completion banging my head against a wall) I personally think that Blasphemous 1 is a stronger and more enjoyable product.

There are plenty of reasons but mainly B1 feels more mysterious and less linear. B1 also has years worth of extra content whereas at the time of writing, B2 is still a recent release and has no extra content beyond the core game, so it might be worth waiting until there's more if that bothers you. 

Whilst B2 was a great experience, I think B1 is better and I am still tempted to come back and further explore the game.

While I would recommend this game I can't overstate how disappointed I have been playing it. I genuinely wanted to love this game, but it just didn't do it for me. The team that worked on it is obviously very talented, especially in the art department. This game's sprite work is gorgeous and it's aesthetic is inspired. Exploration was good and the game didn't run me ragged with content like Hollow Knight did. But the gameplay was extremely disappointing on several fronts.

1. The parry sucks. It is fine against normal enemies but against most bosses there is little advantage to using it over dodging or jumping. You will be pushed back out range to do a retribution attack or even a regular one. This is despite the fact that parrying attacks requires slightly more skill and planning than jumping over or dodging attacks. 
2. Movement speed is too slow. The penitent one trudges along slowly for most of the game this makes platforming, which there is a considerable amount of in this game, a chore. That is unless you get an optional  rosary bead that increases your speed, at which point movement starts to feel like a dream. 
3. Many of the bosses are mid, especially in the early games. In the later game there are a lot more competently designed fights but I was left with a bad taste in my mouth compared to Hollow Knight's or SotN.
4. The level design is mean spirited at times. I get this game is about "suffering" but I can't tell you how many times I jumped to a platform only for an enemy who was previously off screen hit me we with a projectile that sent me flying back into a spike pit or back down the ground causing needless tedium and repetition.

I am not a fan of old school Castlevania games though, only SC4, SOTN and AoS so a lot of my gripes probably ring hollow to fans of the original trilogy. 

I am glad this game did well and I hope improvements have been made in Blasphemous 2.
This game is not the most challenging that I have played (such as Lilies Ender). But I appreciate it for its artistic value and symbolism.

Blasphemous is a stunning 2D action-platformer with metroidvania elements, crafted by The Game Kitchen. The game immerses players in the dark world of Cvstodia, where the Penitent One, the main protagonist, explores a gothic landscape, battles horrifying enemies, and solves puzzles to atone for their sins.

The unique retro-pixel art style is visually captivating, creating a mystical atmosphere that complements the gripping narrative. The gameplay is intricate and tactical, with each battle serving as a challenging trial. Diverse locations unfold progressively, inviting players to embark on an exhilarating exploration of the mysterious corners of this intriguing world.

The somber music and sound design seamlessly blend with the overall atmosphere. Blasphemous is not just a game; it's an immersive journey into a unique and enigmatic realm that is sure to leave an indelible impression.

Donate 20k to the church to unlock fast travel. There, I've made your first run 50% better. No need to thank me.

Apart from that, it's ok I guess, a pretty average battle-focused metroidvania. I'm not sure it was good enough to warrant buying the sequel, but it's not out of the question at least.
The art and atmosphere are nice. I couldn't get it in me to care about the actual story after the first two hours. Stopped reading the lore dumps in the item descriptions around the same time. 
The platforming clearly isn't a major focus here so it's barely worth mentioning really. It is a bit approximative and buggy, but thankfully it's only very rarely challenging, so you don't notice it much. Combat is ok. Both bosses and normal enemies are quite well-designed and can't be fought efficiently by just mashing the attack button. You'll have to jump, roll and parry. 
The difficulty is adequate. I'd say I died about once per boss and per zone. It's enough to feel somewhat challenging without getting frustrating. After beating the game once you unlock four different NG+, each with slightly different mechanics. Two in particular are tweaked to force you to use magic instead of your sword. I think it's a nice way to add some replayability to the game. I enjoyed doing that magic-only run after basically ignoring this whole aspect of the game during the first one.

Of note, the game has a bad habit of trying to waste your time. Dialogues before bosses that keep getting repeated everytime, that platform that you need to wait on for a whole minute doing mostly nothing during one of the few platforming challenges of the game, the fast travel being locked behind the donation box... It's not too bad, but I hope the developers will stop doing that on their next games.

There is perhaps no Spanish painter more influential than Francisco Goya. Although he was immortalized as one of the post-renaissance masters, the Primer Pintor de Camara’s life was anything but happy. It’s almost certain that the tragic death of his children and the turmoil of his country inspired the nightmarish works of his late career. Combine this with his relationship with Catholicism and you have the principal inspiration for Blasphemous.

Blasphemous is not a classical Metroidvania a la Symphony of the Night, and it’s not quite a Souls-like. To define it: it is a hack’n slash platformer with strong presentation. While the combat is rather simple, the visual design is anything but. The world of Cvstodia features some of the finest pixel art in the industry, ranging from grand cathedrals to grotesque abominations. Enemy variety is great and boss designs are reminiscent of the finest from series like Dark Souls. Complimenting this is strong world building and a macabre story dripping with religious symbolism. For el amor de Dios, please play in Spanish with subtitles on.

Not all works are blemish-free. Blasphemous' difficulty curve is bumpy, loot is unexciting, and magic is overtuned. There are also a few bugs, including Guilt Fragments in unreachable areas and the player getting stuck but they are rare. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2934161524 

Like Goya’s works, Blasphemous is uniquely beautiful and disturbing, and while it does not reach the lofty heights of the painter’s career, it is certainly worthwhile.

I’m not really into Metroidvania-styled games, but this one kept me gripped, and I found it very addictive. I originally bought this game a while back for Steam, but it wasn’t until I picked up the game along with its sequel on disc for the Xbox that I thought I would really give it a go, and I’m so glad I did because it is great.

The game has some stunning Spanish-themed artwork, which I would go as far as to say is the star of the show. Ok, I might be overstating it just a little, but it is truly brilliant artwork. The real star is the brilliant combat system; there is nothing more satisfying than performing a well-timed block, then doing an execution afterwards. 

I think for me, I can find some Metroidvania games a bit difficult. I like to chill, take my time, and just have fun. If the boss fights are too hard, I’m not coming back to play again. But I found I’m a lot better at these types of games than I had previously thought. I would say Blasphemous can be more frustrating than difficult. I think if you get your timing right and learn the enemies' patterns, you will progress through the game; this, for me, was all part of the fun. I would recommend anyone to check it out.

I’m now currently playing it through again on my Mac, as well as playing the sequel on Xbox.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Channels the spiritual energy of Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. If you're a fan of that kind of game, Blasphemous is a must buy! That said, it was through Blasphemous that I found out I'm more of a fan of the lush art style than I am the gameplay. I don't shy away from difficult games, I've enjoyed and completed Dark Souls, Cuphead, Hollow Knight, and am always looking for similarly difficult games, but never quite got the same kick out of Blasphemous. The game is much more linear (at least in it's early-mid game, I left off at the 18th level/area, [spoiler] the archcathedral ramparts [/spoiler] ) and has a VERY slow beginning. I'm glad I didn't quit then, because once I got a few more upgrades the game loosened up a little and was a somewhat fun challenge. The boss fights and the attention to detail in the art were my biggest incentives to push through the constant death and backtracking through difficult enemies and areas. At a certain point, the multiple times at which I realized I wasn't enjoying myself took over and I've decided to put the game down for now.

I want to emphasize this was my personal experience with Blasphemous, and my level of enjoyment was not reflective of how well made this game really is. It may have been punishing, but the love invested into Blasphemous shines through every aspect of its design. The menus, backgrounds, characters, and effects all are styled with a fantasy Spanish Gothic flair that makes the look and feel of the game REALLY stand out in the best way possible. Another thing I really appreciated having just finished Jedi: Fallen Order is that it was immediately refreshing to have a set of controls that operated responsively and with precision!

Overall, I don't want to give this game a rating because I don't feel like I've gotten the full experience-- the game is objectively well made but my time playing it was mixed emotionally. I always felt like it was just about to click with me but after the better part of ten hours I just think it isn't for me.

This is where the review was going to end but out of curiosity I looked up how far I got into the game. As it turns out, the 18th area is one of the final areas in the game, and I was beating it at a pretty steady pace. Now that I know that I've seen most of what the game has to offer, I can say confidently that everything else I wrote here holds water for at least a majority of the game. 

I still recommend to anyone enticed by the art style, fans of Castlevania, or those diagnosed with depression, anxiety, and paranoia due to their deeply ingrained religious guilt. An objectively-well-made-game-that-didn't-quite-click-for-me/10.

Wait for any sales on this game to end; when you buy Blasphemous you're buying into an artistic masterwork about the disturbed history of Catholicism in Spain, and a genius blend of some of the most compelling genres on the market. Regarding gameplay, combat is snappy and engaging, and despite the fact that you're bound to one weapon---the Mea Culpa---leaves a lot of room to establish your own playstyle while always staying high-stakes. Blasphemous also trusts that it has your full attention during its entire runtime; while it isn't entirely necessary to pick apart everything you can about the lore behind every location, collectible, or character, it's fairly easy to lose track of what's going on if you haven't been engaging with the world at every story-beat.

Objectively, it's a bad game. Subjectively, it is also a bad game.

Blasphemous 2 is a much better experience than this.. and The Last Faith is better than both of them. Combined.

NOTE: appreciation of this game and its attendant recommendation in no way communicate support of any religious organization, nor does it offer any support of said organizations actions, be those actions historical or contemporary. 

In a word: brilliant.

Not since watching Kevin Smith's "Dogma" have I beheld such a clear, poetic, and powerful observation of, and commentary about, Christianity in the modern era, specifically Catholicism. The world of Cvstodia is a fully rendered fever dream of Purgatory well-realized in a bleak, bloody fantasy space that closely mirrors certain periods of feudal Europe.

The cup of "Blasphemous" runneth over with metaphors: guilt is the game mechanic built around punishing the player for death, because it's a memory of our mistakes; the Penitent One can lose health to gain fervor (the means by which a player can power 'prayers', which are the games spell-effects), because paying in blood is how one demonstrates dedication to the cause; players are largely free to choose their own path through the game, because the workings of the Miracle are inscrutable and unique to each person. Those examples are but a fraction of the ways "Blaspemous" explores and in many cases deconstructs the faith it examines. With only the most superficial of understandings regarding the source material, you'll appreciate a great many of the articles. For those more versed in the mythology and practices of the Church of Rome, though... It's quite a feast. Delicious, even.  

You don't need to be religious to enjoy the game, though you may be inspired to a religious fervor once you're a few hours into it. Between the excellent platforming, beautiful art, inspired soundtrack, and Souls-like combat, you might touch upon the sublime during your journey with the Penitent One. But don't take my word for it. Each persons penance is as unique as the sins for which they are born; each persons guilt shapes each persons world. Experience the Miracle in all its grandeur and all its glory; to know its grotesque blessing is to know a path toward absolution.

Recommended for: metroidvania aficionados; those who enjoy their action in pixel-form; fans of 2D Souls-like combat with lots of platforming mixed with their exploration; lovers of art, as the game has some haunting imagery and music. Two thumbs way, way up.

For me, this game is a tentative recommendation for a few reasons. Blasphemous is a platformer souls like with an absolutely beautiful and unique art style. However, it suffers from a number problems that make it fall short of a truly fantastic game. It is however, a very good game if you have the patience for it's quirks.  

First and foremost, this game is filled to the fucking brim with instant death pitfalls and spike traps. There is no way to move the camera to look around at your surroundings; thus, you are going to have a lot of pointless frustrating deaths and resets to these traps. Dying also inflicts a debuff that reduces your mana till you collect your bloodstain (ala dark souls). If you die in a spike trap, that stain will be in the trap and you can't collect it. So you have to farm the currency of the game and go to a shrine to pay to fix it. These shrines are infrequent though not completely irritatingly inaccessible.

Enemy design is also pretty good for the most part. Most enemies are unique and the game does possess the occasional execution which is quite satisfying. Bosses seem very fair and fights are mostly skill based. This category however has a few of its own problems. Among them are enemy placement, and certain magic wielding nastiness. 

in a few places enemies  are placed in ways that pretty much force you to get hit by them; and if not hit by them, you get driven into traps. I understand were trying to be souls like here. But, every souls like game I've ever played (all of them mind you as a fan) do not setup scenarios that force you into damage. the spacing is setup in a manner where there is a learnable and appropriate response that where you can come out on-top unharmed. This is not going to be the case with Blasphemous. You are going to eat the damage, there is nothing you can do. Pick one or the other, and try not get frustrated by it. 

On the topic of certain magic wielding enemies who circumvent the blocking and counter system. I hope you enjoy spam, teleporting out of range, attacks that inconsistently for no reason either miss or hit  you. Furthermore, air borne enemies are difficult to combo, and are given enough health to make them difficult to kill. So far, most magic enemies are airborne. These are going to kill you a lot horribly. They usually show up with other things that also stop you from running past them or being able to carefully engage them.

Next and quite important to mention are controls. I haven't tried the game with a controller, but I assume it is far better than mouse and keyboard, which is what I use. If you decide to use a keyboard, be forewarned:
there is no mouse input. WASD for movement, J for block, and K for attack. Q for prayers (Spells that use this games mana system). Easy enough but the game doesn't tell you that you use Y and H to scroll descriptions on items in the inventory. I actually had to check steam discussions to figure that one out. 

All this being said, if you can tolerate instant death non skill based traps, sometimes poor enemy placement or design, and sometimes miserable map design. Then I fully recommend the game to you. It's worth full price. You are going to die in very non skill based ways. They are going to punish you. You will learn to like it, and adapt to it, or you are going to hate the game. Good luck Penitent One. You are going to need it.

Blasphemous is one hell a game, both literally and figuratively. If you have ever played any souls-like game, then this is right up your alley as not only is the combat challenging yet fulfilling but with the lore of custodia being the cherry on top to the stories intrigue and mystery. It's through the lore that that I felt motivated to explore and revisit areas I already discovered, and even when I play it again, I never get tired of rediscovering the same areas as the Metroidvania style of this game let me choose a different path to go through making my experience being more different than the last. It reminds me of how I played dark souls the first time, that just like Blasphemous, was a world that was broken by divine forces and it's up to me, the player, to stop this suffering once and for all by exploring the world and discovering new clues along the way. Though unlike dark souls, Blasphemous' pixelated artistry truly gives the games brutality as the designs from the gameplay, npc's, cutscenes, and bosses, are not just detailed but very grotesque as the gore and style can be a bit disturbing. But all thanks go to "The Game Kitchen" in creating something truly masterful and personal as not only creating their own twist into the souls-like genre but taking inspiration from a rich history of catholic folklore and teachings from Spain, which is where The Game Kitchen was first established. All in all, when it comes to metroidvania and sous-like games Blasphemous is a step up and to not considered a fantastic game would truly be blasphemous.

I feel like most things in this game are rather forgettable. I haven't leveled my guy in so long because it's all stuff I'd never use or maybe forget I even had. I first unlocked a charge up power attack, but the time it takes for it to charge and the damage it does... You're better off just using the time to get like 3 or 4 regular hits in! What's the point?? And the little gains from beads/weapon mods also have so little impact that I find it doesn't really matter which ones you choose. But if it says you'll take extra damage, do believe that one.

The levels are pretty alright I must say and the art is pretty snazzy, but the game lacks shortcuts. It has them, just many aren't practical or very beneficial.

Back to forgettable aspects, the game teaches you how to counter on very counterable enemies. But soon you find one that if you counter, you just get knocked back without damage. Guess which method they chose to move forward with? Most mid to later enemies can't be countered or they just knock you back, so why bother trying to counter if I can just avoid the hit? Another forgotten aspect. And the ability to just dash through some enemies is hit or miss (literally). This is a huge bummer in some areas where you struggle and the walk back is lengthy and dangerous. 

The items you find are so obscure that I never know where anything goes or who is what. I'm swimming in quest items with no idea who wants what. I just roll up to someone, show them me stash, and see if they want anything I've got and if they'll give me something new.

Mechanistically I've found I both enjoy and dislike it. Sometimes you SWEAR you should have made that jump just fine, but here you are falling. Ladders are very finicky and I don't recommend rushing them. Which for a game that has sparse shortcuts... 

The game was fine but I doubt I'll come back. I might or might not play the second... I may just watch a stream. I've played a lot of metroidvanias and this one is just kinda meh on the design. Art is great, delivery is meh.

the enemies are also very well designed, some of these enemies may beat your ass pretty bad and most of the time that means its better to explore the other areas first as every part of the game, theres atleast 2 - 3 bosses you can beat in any order so its great to explore. personally, some of these bosses are way more unfair than the other bosses. the secret boss isidiora took me about 2 hours to beat meanwhile the last boss took me less than a hour to beat which was dissapointing but the last boss was pretty fun and mostly required skill instead of just dodging and tanking random projectiles.
TLDR; blasphemous is an amazing game, a few flaws doesnt make this game bad. its really fun and i had my time with it, i might play NG+ if i dont have anything to play. its certainly a must play for everybody who loves metroidvanias and also people who love souls-likes and want to change it up a bit

I have been trying to like this game out of sheer stubbornness. I bought it because I heard it had amazing lore and I like souls/metroidvania games. I wanted to like it so much but at this point I'm not sure it's worth the pain. This game reminds me of Dark Souls 1 but for the worst reasons. This game has combat and platforming but the combat is uninteresting and the platforming is janky as hell. An example is needing to enter an up input on ledges but it seems like if you're off  by 15 degrees with the joystick it decides it wasn't good enough. Then in combat there are situations which just feel silly like when you parry certain enemies their hitbox ends up inside you and you inevitably take damage which just feels weird. The combat is basically that every enemy has a specific way you can kill it and you should stick to that every single time or you usually get punished. Once you learn that parrying that enemy means you take damage for some god damn reason then you have to adapt to something that feels like a silly design mistake or something. That reminds me of souls games but it was not something I think is fun. As far as I saw the game has like two combos you can use, one weapon, no armour, one ranged attack and one slide attack. Then there's these relics which replace movement abilities I assume but one of the ones I got seems just like a lore revealer which is not great. My character feels almost identical to how he was at the start. I'm never excited by an item drop because 85% of them are lore related and speaking of the lore, I am not getting it. I started off reading all the item descriptions and exhausting npc dialogues but it feels like unless you're prepared to have google translate open for spanish to english, got a bible handy and a few essays on the spanish inquisition, you're not getting fucking anywhere. I watched a video after to explain it for me and to be honest it was just ok. Didn't seem as amazing as I had heard. So the character progression elements are non existent and unsatisfying, the platforming is janky and uninteresting, the combat is equally uninteresting (I'd like to add I've first tried every boss after the first couple and I really dislike games with piss easy bosses when you struggle on a little guy with a knife), and the lore is mildly intriguing at best. 

I will say that the art and music is very nice but the actual gameplay has been little but frustrating and if I have to TRY to like a game and still struggle then I can't possibly say good things about it. Additionally I've heard one source that said the reason the game pushes you and tests your patience so often and frustrates you is because the gameplay is meant to be like the suffering and hardship the penitent one is going through but this feels like a weird defense. 

If they want the game to literally feel like a frustrating pilgrimage that you would rather give up on then they succeeded in their weird artistic endeavour, I just don't get why they'd pick that creative hill to die on. They could've just made a more satisfying game.

I wish I could give this game a neutral review. The art style and atmosphere is amazing, the boss fights are fun, and it's the perfect level of challenging. However, without giving away spoilers, some of the cons are:

- Some of the quests (Redento's statue) are nearly impossible without looking up the solution, while others I think are pretty fair (like the chalice quest). I wish the game gave adequate clues for all the quests.
- If you don't visit a certain area before a specific boss fight, you can be blocked from a bonus area, requiring a new start. Granted, there is a new game+, but this was discouraging on my first playthrough.
- This game would really benefit from a quest log. Sometimes after taking a break I wouldn't remember what I had done already in specific quest lines.

Those are my biggest gripes, but I'm giving this a positive review because I can't say it's a bad game exactly, it just has some flaws. I personally prefer to not look up quest/puzzle solutions but you really have to with this game unless you want to backtrack for dozens of hours. If you don't mind looking up solutions then this won't bother you, and overall it's still a fun game regardless.

I'm probably refunding this. Despite having several content updates over the years, many extremely annoying bugs exist in the game that, while not game-breaking, are most likely going to stop me from playing it ever again.

For one, this game falsely advertises full controller support. In reality, controller support breaks when alt+tabbing, and doesn't work at all on the death screen. Given this is a soulslike, you are going to die a LOT, so controllers not working on this screen is a colossal oversight if you don't want to go through the headache that is playing platformers on keyboard. I guess the devs just never thought people would play a platformer game on devices originally built to play platformer games.

Furthermore, despite being a multiplat game (which the sequel doesn't even bother with, so much for 
the effort lmao), they managed to screw up cloud saves and make them platform-specific, leaving Linux users forced to use Proton which is prone to instability and Mac users just stuck with Mac. I used to have some restraint criticizing games for this until I learned how pathetically easy adding this feature is, ESPECIALLY in games made in Unity, like this one. They just didn't bother. By the way! The Steam Deck verification thing is supposed to have a notice if games don't support cross-plat saves! This game doesn't have that notice despite not having cross-plat saves. Because of this, I expected this game to have cross-plat saves. Thanks for that.

All and all despite great visuals and (I'm assuming) good gameplay, the game feels unfinished. They had THREE content updates to fix ANY of these issues and never did. They still had time to fix them after, and STILL never did. I'm not keeping this game in my library because I know if I do I will never play it, because these issues however minor they may seem truly make this game more of a chore to play than it needs to be. I just can't be bothered to play more than I have right now. Finish the thing you sold me, then we'll talk.

A grim, horrifying and bleak Soulslike Metroidvania, Blasphemous is a brutal and uncompromising challenge not to be undertaken lightly, but one which is well worth the effort if you're up to it. One of the most ghastly examples of religious horror in gaming, the Penitent One is forced to carve a bloody path across a blasted landscape of unending despair as you seek to unravel the origins of the dreadful Grievous Miracle, a quest not for the squeamish. Compared to a lot of other Soulslikes the story is more upfront and open, with multiple cutscenes and expository characters directing you forward, but there's still a great deal of worldbuilding to be learned from item descriptions and conversations with missable NPCs, and the story itself is gripping in its sheer remorseless bleakness. The addition of 3 extensive DLCs, released completely for free, that added vast amounts of extra content to the game (including a new true ending to lead into the upcoming sequel) makes the game (which was initially a bit short) vastly better value and cements my respect for the developers.

The gameplay is sharp and the control precise, with as much of an emphasis on platforming as combat, with a lot of ledge hanging, wall clinging, dodging past traps and bounding across collapsing floors. The combat, by comparison, is a bit streamlined, with only a handful of combat maneuvers at your disposal, some of which are quite unbalanced (the parry and riposte is far too generous and the dash stab is absolutely devastating, while the charged attack is just too slow to be much use), but there's an impressive array of equippable items you can use to help customise your combat style.

Technically, the game is a standout. The pixel art is some of the finest the style has produced in years, with every enemy (and their hideous, gruesome deaths) rendered in fine, bloody detail, particularly some of the gargantuan bosses. The voice acting is surprisingly high quality (although apparently a few poor performances were rerecorded with new actors before I got around to playing the game), and the soundtrack deserves special mention for its quality, variably tense, atmospheric, even beautiful in places.

Blasphemous, while not for everyone (either because of its brutal challenge or its nightmarishly-gruesome appearance) is a standout title in the 2D Soulslike Metroidvania genre which is an easy recommendation for anyone who enjoys exploration, challenging combat, and bleak religious horror. An excellent game.

Mechanically this game is very competent. combat is relatively simple, but well animated (and quite brutal). The world you get to play in is surprisingly vast as it opens up. Backtracking is common, but helped by shortcuts and warp points. The game allows for a fair bit of customization with the use of different rosary beads (similar to hollow knight badges but without different costs), prayers (like spells), and sword cores (usually does makes one thing better and one thing worse). The game isn't easy, but I didn't find it especially challenging either; many bosses I beat on my first try, and most of my deaths were from falls and spikes (which instakill) instead of any combat scenarios.

Aesthetically, the game utilizes amazing pixel art to portray a desolate and depressing Catholicism-inspired world, where everyone seems to be confusing suffering and salvation.

Story-wise...I feel like it's a hot mess. It talks a lot about guilt and suffering and 'miracles' and it doesn't really tie it together very well. The game gives you an early direction on some things to collect, but after you do that, there's the whole other half of the map to go through and I never really understood what the in-game reason was for doing so.

The religious stuff here is kinda weird; it's clearly inspired by Catholicism, but they focus on guilt, punishment, sin, and pain, and ignore almost anything else; you won't see any biblical figures or rituals in the game. It feels like the devs were trying to walk a narrow line between calling out the dark side of how the Catholic church handles resolution of guilt and sin, but keep some plausible deniability about their opinions on the rest of it. This leads to the game having a lot of religious 'window-dressing' (imagery and language), but it doesn't have as much substance as you might expect. It's kind of surprising given the game's title.

The music in this game is a lowlight imo. It's not bad, but it's entirely unmemorable compared to castlevania or metroid. Which is odd because it feels like the perfect venue for some epic chorale and organ stuff. It's mostly either highly atmospheric or variations of Spanish guitar music.

Overall, if you want to play a well-made metroidvania with some clear Souls inspiration and a unique (but hollow) religious theme, this is a good way to spend your time. Just don't expect a story with the same coherence of other games in the genre.

[b]Blasphemous[/b] is a game that is so close, yet so far from greatness. For every great decision made in regards to atmosphere, there's a complete miss gameplay-wise.

Presentation? One of the greatest in gaming history. It's the main thing this game has going for it. The atmosphere is incredible. Switching to the Spanish dub is highly recommended. Sprites look great, stages are varied and beautiful too, animations are CRISP as hell.

The lore is very interesting but probably too sparse to fully dissect in a single playthrough. There are multiple endings, so replaying the game is encouraged.

Gameplay-wise? Very hit or miss. Combat feels punchy and impactful but basic at times, even after multiple upgrades. Platforming is not bad, just irregular. Some elements, like ladders, are very unreliable and sometimes lead to instant deaths by spikes. It's especially annoying when the game has time-based sections that are not exactly easy.

World design is GREAT. There are shortcuts and hidden passages everywhere. Going back to Albero through an elevator after 3 hours of struggle is awesome.

Bosses in general are decent. They're good enough, and very memorable visually. Some are annoying but nothing too bad.

Level design is good when traversing and exploring, but it has one fatal flaw: The worst aspect of Blasphemous in my opinion. Enemy placement. Some sections are very tolerable. Not easy, but manageable with some thought. Other sections took a page out of Dark Souls 2 and decided to throw around a f*ckton of enemies for no reason other than padding an already decently long game.

It's pretty good! It just feels like it needed a bit more thought put into combat to reach that extra quality. I still highly recommend it for the atmosphere alone.

[h2]7.5/10[/h2]

My biggest issue with this game is that certain boss mechanics do not individualize their telegraphs with other abilities. As a consequence, discerning which attack the boss is going to use next will often feel like a guessing game. I don't think the bosses are particularly difficult, but they can definitely become annoying for someone who wants to learn each individual boss mechanic and/or combos in order to learn, practice, and then execute.

Aside from that, I think the combat is fun, the game is aesthetically pleasing, and the music is fantastic.

UPDATE AFTER AN ADDITIONAL 59 HOURS:

Finishing up the DLC at the moment and in my opinion, the best bosses in the game are only available in NG+ - make sure to play NG+ if you're going to pick this game up.

I knew it was a "challenging" game going in, I unfortunately didn't know it was challenging for all the wrong reasons. Hollow Knight is an example of how hard meets fun in this genre and after a lot of hard work, I achieved everything that game had to offer. Blasphemous on the other hand is that brand of cheap "NES Hard" minus the technical limitations and rental culture those games had as an excuse for their design.  It's stiff, sluggish, unfair and worst of all, it simply isn't fun.

If you are looking for a challenging Metroidvania, there's a lot of options out there that also manage to be enjoyable games.

-Great mechanics

[h2] Cons [h2]
-This game forces you to check the internet for guides and tips since some hidden items are essential and some percs and buffs are hidden in secret rooms. Also some important game mechanics (like teleportation for example) are unlocked by doing some arbitrary actions that you won't do unless you check a guide or google some questions. There are some endings, and unless you follow a guide from the start, you will get the worst one.

[h1] Conclusion [h1]
This game is hard, addictive, fun, beautiful and a journey you won't regret and may even play twice. I would recommend asking a friend for a tip or two since it might make the game-play a bit smoother.

Seria só mais um metroidvania se não fosse essa história mto doida. 
A jogabilidade é boa, os graficos meio pixel art são bonitos, e tudo é muito bruto e difícil aqui. Não tem walljump, tem 'estocar a espada na parede e dar um pulo (!!)'. Esse tipo de coisa. 

A fluidez do jogo não é intuitiva, demorei um pouco pra entender que o jogo era de fato um metroidvânia. 
As fases e inimigos em geral são difíceis, então você acaba tendo que ficar bem treinado no jogo pra conseguir se virar. Espinhos no chão, por exemplo são fatais, assim como locais com 'nuvenzinhas' abaixo, indicando um precipício. Volta e meia somos atirados neles por inimigos.

Ainda não terminei o jogo, mas to vendo que tem mta sidequest, sem mta explicação.

A história é o que tem valido pra mim: Um mundo bizarro de sofrimento onde a culpa das pessoas foi materializada na forma de uma realidade severamente distorcida por meio do 'milagre', transmutando ela formas físicas em sofrimento extremo para expiação. 

Interessante lembrar que o jogo foi feito por espanhóis - país tão católico quanto o nosso - então é curioso testemunhar esse mundo distópico, quase uma mistura de céu e inferno cristãos, trabalhando com a tríade 'culpa-dor-redenção'. Quase todas as pessoas viraram monstruosidades horríveis, mas todo mundo diz estar satisfeito e até feliz, porque estaria espiando a própria culpa na forma de penitência. Sua própria espada chama Mea Culpa (minha culpa), isso aqui da um prato cheio pra qualquer psicólogo passar uns bons meses pirando na simbologia.

That aside, some of the enemies are more frustrating than challenging. The "Flying Bell People" and "Book Throwing Librarians", as I call them, are some of the most obnoxious enemies I've fought in any souls game.

I can see why many people would like this game and rate it positively, but I post reviews based on the experience I'm personally having at the time, and update my review as that changes. Right now I'm annoyed by [i]b[/i]ugs, [i]b[/i]ells, and [i]b[/i]ooks, so right now my impression is [i]b[/i]ad.

For those of you undeterred from getting the game by this review (most of you, I'm sure) I know many also dislike the wall statues. If this is you, and you recall this review while playing, you can handle them early on with attack then block at first, then 3 attacks and a block repeatedly until they die. I hope that helps, as I found them to be fine once I found a rhythm by throwing myself at them.

The game is good fun when the only thing your mind is focused on is the challenge of increasing your skill at overcoming the game's many obstacles, but there are many 2D Souls-like MetroidVanias out there, and many in my library. So, personally, I find it hard to play through this one with others waiting when I'd be having a better experience with another similar title. I'll likely come back to this game and update this review.

Blasphemous is your standard metroidvania, where you play a cone head and you'll be exploring the harsh world, fighting enemies with a variety of abilities, finding secrets, and doing a lot of backtracking. Where the game excels is its dark and grim atmosphere that's carried by its art direction, story, and sound. The art takes inspiration from Spanish Catholicism, which provides a lot of religious iconography that is both beautiful and wonderfully grotesque. The storytelling is a bit vague, similar to Dark Souls, where you have to piece things together through NPC dialogue, item descriptions, and visuals.

Even as someone who isn't religious, I found the visuals and story to be so interesting that I wanted to look more into the inspirations and references. I would definitely recommend it for those who like Metroidvania and the Souls games.

[b] Explore and purify a pixelated world ruined by religion [/b]

The world of Blasphemous is bizarre and magnificent at the same time, drawing most of its inspiration from the catholic church with Latin-gothic style. Fused with well detailed pixel art which also gives retro/nostalgic vibes.

Unfortunately, there are some badly designed aspects in the game design and level design that denies the full potential of the game's experience and enjoyment.

The combat is slow and heavily relies on parrying and dodging, which is fine since it is a souls-like game. But as the game progresses, the combat becomes repetitive and loses its charm. Same goes for the executions, they are fun to watch at first but eventually you've watch all of them several times and most of them are pretty long, so you'd just prefer to slay your enemies normally to make it faster.

There are items you can collect by exploring the game that will allow you to access new areas by manipulating your environment. One of the items allows you to drop down to 'bottomless pits' and then you can discover new levels and areas that are beneath. If you don't equip the item, you'll die from falling to the abyss. But there is no abyss, it is a path that continues to another section. That is very frustrating when you start the game and learn that pits are your doom, resulting in inconsistency of the game and confusion. Besides, these items have to be equipped in order to use them, but you only have 3 item slots and there are more than 3 items. That results in an annoying and unnecessary inventory management. Just imagine in Hollow Knight that you'd have to choose between an item that let's you dash to an item that let's you double jump because you don't have enough slots to equip them together and use them simultaneously.

Most of the intensity of the game comes from the level design. There are parts where you can walk to the next area and then face a pit and fall to your death. This can make you churn. Because this will happen most of the time when you travel from one area to another, like you mostly do in metroidvanias in order to explore new areas or revisit them. The level design doesn't support navigation from one area to another in a maximum pace, every time there is some obstacle or platforming that you don't want to deal with anymore but you have to do it again, that makes travelling around the game very tedious. Especially during the end game.

It's true that the game suffers some bad executions. But overall, I personally enjoyed the world of Blasphemous. There's some atmosphere that lies heavy on you throughout the game. The twisted world gives you a sense of danger wherever you go, there's something morbid in the air. The strange world building of Cvstodia was... different... and I enjoyed experiencing it.

Regretful be the heart, penitent one.  The cradle of affliction is what you seek.  Embrace Mea Culpa as your weapon to absolve the sins man through tormented lands...

Blasphemous is a Metroidvania:  A very dark and gruesome themed game revolving around Spanish religious folklore.  Its influences can be witnessed through its incredible OST, use of Latin, and its talented and haunting (in a good way) voice actors speaking the word of the miracle.  If you do mulitple play-throughs, do  yourself a favor and switch the voice over language to Spanish.
I'd describe it as a darker version of the marriage between Dark Souls and Castlevania.  The ambiguity presented in this game is similar to Dark souls.  Item quest lines for unlocking access to all areas of the map are also ambiguous, however finding all of them is not necessary for game completion.  Blasphemous is hard, but not "Dark Souls" hard.
Mechanics aren't perfect, but they seem fairly tight.  I've read some frustrations over map navigation;  I see merit in that, however if you compare this to a similar game such as Hollow Knight, this game is simpler.

I've previously beat this game on another platform and I'm back for more - and with more content through TWO free DLCs.  If you are into Metroidvania style of games that appreciates good music and a very mature, mysterious presentation, then the developers deserve your money.  You won't be disappointed.  This is one of my favorites.

This game is quite fun and the battle is quite engaging. But it has flaw that makes me cannot recommend it to people who like to squeeze all the achievement and things to do in the game. TLDR: I recommend it to people who just wanna have short fun engaging game and not searching for true ending/achievement hunting.

What this game do well? The combat and the boss battle is quite engaging. Especially the early bosses. It is quite interesting and have really nice attack telegraph, combined with dodge and block that can makes being aggressive/safe gameplay quite interesting to do redo. I first try it in the demo, and the first boss is actually the one that hook me and makes me bought the game. 

What flaw that this game has? The exploring part. The first time you come to an area, it is fun and you won't mind a clunky control because you learn about the map, the enemies, checking secret passage, etc. But when you need to comeback to get missing/previously unobtainable item, you will mind about the slow and clunkiness of the movement set. There is a power up that enhance your movement set, but it feels like a patch and just make it a bit better rather than game changing.

What worse is the wall jump ability. You can only wall jump in certain places and when this places have flying enemies that fly through wall, you cannot attack them. It will makes you cling to the wall and you cannot attack it. But this is perhaps a game design. If it is game design to make enemies seems harder than it should, then I won't critique it too much. Perhaps there's a community that likes it, but certainly it is not for me.

The last part that really feels bad is the DLC. It is free so it should be good, right? There is new area in the DLC that aimed as end game content, but it was placed and can be accessed from mid game. In my first playthrough, I accidentally come in to this end game area with my mid game equipment and they just whoop my ass hard. The difficulty level just spike really hard without notice. It seems that they did not think about the placement/normal progression and just put the new area in the edge of the map and calls it a day.

Also, from the DLC, there is called Miriam's Challenges. It is a time attack quest crossover with Miriam from Bloodstained. It is called time attack quest, you are timed with time limit, but it used moving platform. The quest is hard too, so you are expected to redo it a few times until you can finished it. There is times where I need to open YouTube videos or something while waiting the platform to moves to retry my attempt. No matter how good you are, there will be down time just to wait for the platform to move. Even with the shortcut it there will be a down time to wait for a platform to move.

All in all, It still is a enjoyful experience, but the endgame--which usually when a Metroidvania games is the most fun because all the power and upgrade--feel lackluster and disappointing. The exploration in the end game feels really bad. I hope this is not the way in Blasphemous II, and I cannot bring myself to be interested in buying/playing the next Blasphemous title in near future.

Your enjoyment of this game will come largely from whether or not you can stomach some of the most clunky and awkward controls for a game from this genre.

The character feels like it's actively fighting against your inputs. There is no mid air control, momentum, and the platforming just feels bad. There are multiple times where you will want to drop down to attack an enemy to gain a foothold only for your character to grab onto a nearby platform instead and insta death platforming sections to pad out long empty stretches between dungeons and bosses. Compared to recent games like Hollow Knight that do movement and controls 10x better it feels frustrating to play.

Combat is just fine and bosses are varied and cool looking but once you come to terms with the controls the difficulty tapers off fast. If you are somewhat familiar with Soulslikes or 2D hack and slash games you can pretty easily destroy most bosses in 2 or 3 tries which is disappointing since there's only a handful of them.

Overall, Blasphemous has some cool sections with it's world building and aesthetic but the controls and combat fall flat when compared to other modern Metroidvanias that just do those ideas better. I can only recommend this game during a heavy sale.

Blasphemous is really fun to play. It's interesting storyline, beautiful music and amazing pixel art make a very solid game. At times it becomes frustrating due to the challenging gameplay, but still doable and enjoyable. Definitely recommended!

A Divine Descent into Darkness:

Blasphemous, developed by The Game Kitchen, is a dark and atmospheric action-platformer that plunges players into a nightmarish world inspired by Spanish folklore and religious iconography. Released in 2019, this 2D side-scrolling game has garnered attention for its challenging gameplay, haunting visuals, and a narrative steeped in themes of redemption and penance.

One of the standout features of Blasphemous is its intricate and atmospheric world design. The game unfolds in the nightmarish land of Cvstodia, a place cursed by grotesque creatures and plagued by the echoes of a mysterious, divine calamity. The pixel art is stunning, bringing to life the twisted landscapes, eerie dungeons, and grotesque enemies in a way that is both horrifying and captivating. The attention to detail in the art contributes significantly to the overall immersion, making each area a visual feast for players willing to explore the unsettling depths of Cvstodia.

The gameplay is equally compelling, combining precise combat mechanics with challenging platforming elements. Players take control of The Penitent One, a silent and stoic protagonist on a quest for redemption in a world brimming with macabre adversaries. The combat system is punishing but rewarding, encouraging players to learn enemy patterns and master the use of a variety of weapons and special abilities. The level of difficulty may be a deterrent for some, but for those seeking a true test of skill, Blasphemous delivers an experience that is as unforgiving as the world it portrays.

The narrative is presented through cryptic environmental storytelling, religious symbolism, and haunting NPC interactions. The lore is deep and mysterious, with a narrative that unfolds gradually as players progress through the punishing landscapes. The themes of guilt, redemption, and atonement are woven into the fabric of the game, adding emotional weight to the dark journey of The Penitent One.

While the game has received praise for its atmospheric design and challenging gameplay, some players may find the difficulty level to be a double-edged sword. The unforgiving nature of the combat can be frustrating for those not accustomed to demanding experiences, potentially limiting the game's appeal to a specific audience.

In conclusion, Blasphemous is a masterclass in atmospheric design and challenging gameplay, offering a haunting journey through a nightmarish world. The combination of pixel-perfect art, punishing combat, and a deep narrative make it a standout title for fans of dark and atmospheric action-platformers. However, its high difficulty may be a barrier for some players, making it more suitable for those who relish a challenging and immersive gaming experience.

Not my first souls game, but it is my first metroidvania. Finished it after 18 hours with 87% of the content completed, got Ending B (blind playtrough).

The idea of using this old spanish catholic theme for game of this genre its just amazing, specially when the devs have no fear of showing gore or crude themes, it really is amazing. The atmosphere of the levels, the pixel art, the music, its all top notch.

The bosses are just a piece of amazing work one after the other, from the visual design, to the lore they imply and surprisingly... the mechanics, no boss is a copy of another, they all have different mechanics you need to pay attention to. Some are big enough to engulf the whole screen, others use the level/environment for an advantage, others summon minions to help em and others are just a normal sized character like you. They really feel like a piece of art.

The puzzles are varied and actual puzzles you need to figure out how to approach em, tho sometimes can be hard due to the lack of clues. For example, to open certain closed door you needed to use the lever of an elevator 5 times in a row and i literally have no idea from were that came from, i ended up looking at the wiki because there was no dialogue, hint, number on the walls, picture, anything that hints that.

Now the gameplay, i know nothing of metroidvania games and how they are supposed to be, so im gonna give my opinion on this from a souls perspective: the dashing sucks, simple as that.

The parry is good tho you can't use it on like half the bosses or enemies, which i understand since the game forces you to jump around, duck OR dash.... and thats the problem, the game itself tells you the dash has invulnerability frames and it does not feel like that at all. While i do understand that you can't spam it (one dash after another) and there's even dedicated items in the game to help you with that, the i-frames on the dash are either super tiny or they just don't work on some enemies. Plus the response from when you press the button to when it gets executed on the screen is long enough to go to the kitchen and make myself a cup of coffee... well, not that long, but after playing a souls game i think you can understand what i mean.

But oh well, those few cons are not even close to deprive you from enjoying and finishing the game, so give it a try.

Blasphemous is a captivating and brutal gaming experience, that combines the world design, atmospheric music and a unique storytelling in a good way.
The moment you enter the world of Cvstodia you're confronted with a dark and haunting reality that makes you keep exploring its depths. One of the standout features in Blasphemous is the world design. The landscapes are beautifully crafted, and have an incredible attention to detail, and some very challenging parts. The boss battles are a balance between challenge and fairness. The difficulty seems a bit lower compared to other games in this genre. 
Blasphemous has a unique storytelling approach. It invites the player to piece together the lore and history of Cvstodia through item descriptions and talking to NPCs. What makes Blasphemous truly stand out is its sheer brutality. The game embraces a visceral and bloody aesthetic. The concept of Pain is central to the experience, creating a world that is both disturbing and oddly satisfying. It is, in my opinion, what makes the game most memorable.
Overall, I'd say the game is definitely worth a try and another top game on my Souls-Like list

[h1]Frustratingly Obtuse and Unnecessarily Challenging[/h1]


Blasphemous is a game that seems to revel in its own obscurity and difficulty, [b]often at the expense of player enjoyment[/b]. While the game boasts stunning pixel art and a captivating atmosphere, it's marred by[b] frustrating-level design[/b], [b]unclear objectives[/b], and an [b]excessive amount of backtracking[/b].


From the outset, the game throws you into the depths of its unforgiving world [b]without much explanation or guidance[/b]. The map, while aesthetically pleasing, lacks clarity and often leads to confusion and frustration. The game's reliance on cryptic clues and hidden paths makes it [b]feel more like a punishment[/b] than a rewarding exploration.


The combat system, while initially engaging, quickly [b]becomes repetitive and lacks depth[/b]. [b]Enemies are easily dispatched[/b] with basic attacks, and bosses, while visually impressive, follow predictable patterns that make them more [b]tedious than challenging[/b].


The game's true frustration lies in its [b]excessive amount of backtracking[/b]. Progress often requires collecting scattered items or completing convoluted tasks, forcing players to trudge through the same [b]familiar areas repeatedly[/b]. This repetitive nature makes the game [b]feel like a chore[/b] rather than an enjoyable experience.


While the game's art style is undeniably impressive, its dark and gritty aesthetic can become overwhelming after extended play sessions. The oppressive atmosphere and constant barrage of grotesque imagery can make it [b]difficult to maintain interest and motivation[/b].


Overall, Blasphemous is a game that seems to prioritize difficulty and obscurity over accessibility and enjoyment. While it may appeal to those seeking a punishing challenge, its flaws outweigh its strengths, making it a frustrating and unrewarding experience for many players.
