[h1]Comentario Analítico: "Blasphemous"[/h1]

Blasphemous es un metroidvania plataformero de scroll lateral cuya temática y estética, así como su combate meticuloso y relativamente exigente, lo asemejan lo suficiente a un Souls-like como para poder formar parte de dicha categoría.

El trabajo artístico es fabuloso, cada escenario es una belleza, cada jefe es visualmente único y cada track de la banda sonora aportan a la atmósfera de esta fantasía oscura inspirada en el Cristianismo.

Sin contar unas tres o cuatro veces que quedé atrapado en un hilo de ataques consecutivos de los cuales no pude escapar, en su mayoría Blasphemous es una experiencia justa y bien planteada, cuyo diseño de niveles es generalmente demasiado formulario pero completamente efectivo, destacando por cuán bien guía al jugador por el camino correcto y ofreciendo la cantidad suficiente de secretos como para compensar la atención al detalle.

Y aunque el ritmo de su combate denoten un evidente aire a Souls, ni los escenarios ni los jefes son particularmente exigentes hasta el último tercio. 

Quizá hubiera trabajado más en el backtracking, que es demasiado constante y monótono. Mientras que en otros Metroidvania adquirir una nueva habilidad representa una forma completamente distinta de manejarte por el entorno, en Blasphemous el juego empieza y termina prácticamente igual.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Muy mejorable, pero fabuloso en algunos puntos clave.

(My main file is on PlayStation, on which I've 100%'ed the game.)

If you like any Castlevania or Souls-style game, especially Hollow Knight, then you'll love Blasphemous.

Incredible art, unique animations and secrets everywhere, plenty of questlines and rewards for thoroughness, and a lot of great bosses without any real dip to the game's pace. The design team wanted a game that felt like it could've been Symphony of the Night, and I think they far surpassed that goal.

I wholly believe that Blasphemous is up there with Bastion, Dead Cells, and Hades as one of the greatest indie games ever made.

I cannot recommend this game.It is...abnormaly frustrating.
-It is to to slow for a metroidvania, also it gets annoying having to always grab the edge of a platform then just being able to jump on it (as a side note, I find it funny that you can stand on the blood platforms but can't grab onto them)
-has a very simple combat system (which I know can be expanded but for 95% of the game you'll just be using the standard moveset ) which gets boring very quickly
-health and fevor upgrades are few and far between
- two of the most profitable quests require a guide to properly complete
-relics(I only have a complaint about one relics and its the one from the 3-headed creature,like, no casual player would have figured out how to progress their questline without looking up a guide and it is also one of,if not,the most essential relic when exploring cuz a lot of bone part,sword hearts and prayers require it)
-enemies either have infinite hyperarmour or none at all, some enemies  literaly cannot be ignored bc you MUST kill them to pregress further(looking at you humanoid statues in the ice area), the flying wizards can be knocked out of bound but they can still attack making the early game(when you don't have the holy blood throwable) very frustrating
-hit boxes are fine for the most part except for the nuns with the giant bell weapons
-OST's are solid ,nothing catchy but fitting
-early and mid game bosses are fun to fight but the late game ones are just frustrating(I am refering to the bell dude on the bridge ,the fire dude in the prison area,the last two bosses of the base game and the Gravetender lady where the bone collector is )
       -my main complaint about them is that it is near never clear when exactly the attack is going to happen due to the 
        animations being badly telegraphed and you will most certainly mistake one attack animation for another (take 
       a look at hollow knights attack animation and how very well telegraphed they are)
-fast travel locations are few and far between which wouldn't be a problem wasn't the games mobility so slugish
-prayer are either situational , underwelming, or down right busted like the one that creates two circling balls around you and the one that negates ALL DAMAGE for a couple seconds
-the fevor(mana) bar fills up far to slowly(it almost feels like they didnt want you to use it to begin with)
-no i-frames when after getting knocked down by an attack resulting in an easy stunlock
-having to waste a rosary slot just to be able to see the enemies health
-the jumping animation can feel incredibly slow for the fast humanoid bosses
-there are maybe one or two openings when you can safely heal up 
-healing animation is to slow
-i dislike the concept of having to sacrifice some of your currency AND heath to give yourself a chunk of fevor(which is pretty small if you want to use stronger prayers)
-the game is very unclear what you are supposed to do after entering the Mother of mothers
-sword hearts give mediocre buffs but give insane debuffs

These are all the things I can think of at the moment, wasn't really invested in the story but the visuals we stunning

Now,I don't want to make the game seem like it was made by the miracle(ha,get it) but ,taking into accountablilt everything  I have listed here, I really can't recommend this game to the faint hearted, more casual players

Some of my favorite games are the Souls games, Hollow Knight, Celeste, Dead Cells, every Castlevania game. 

Beautiful & some definite love has gone into Blasphemous. I just feel like the developers lost sight of their goal and embraced "sadistic outlet" over "fun challenge" for the player at some point.

The gameplay is slow/clunky, the platforming is poorly designed (platform hitboxes are not accurate to their sprites. Among other issues), the enemies encourage bad playstyles to circumvent their bad design (see: ghost aimbotting, shooting through things, & player inability to hit more than once per appearance. Forced combat pacing is LAME and anti-fun)

Player hitbox is awful. Tip of your hat bumps an enemy shield? Say bye to half your health. So immersive.

Enemy projectiles have precedence over your attacks EVERY TIME. You hit an enemy as they are throwing something, even though you are able to hit projectiles? They win. You must sit & wait. No aggressive play for you. Forced combat pacing is LAME and anti-fun.

Dialogue is ye olde flowery but says very very little. Cheesy & goofy all around. Especially coming from some random hermit that's been sitting in the dark for however long, but hot damn does he speak with the eloquence of a medieval academic!! I did enjoy the item lore quite a lot, though, even though things are re-used in some places (looking @ you linen cloth and evolved version), and some descriptions make zero sense on whatever item they were attached to. 

I can see why people would love this game, really, but for me it does not hold a candle to HK, Dead Cells, or literally any of the Souls games. It tries & it pays homage to many of them (loved the window quests), but it just felt like the focus was on making the experience painful rather than challenging. In my time played, I went through the northern area (village?), & the mountains. Both to completion. I had fun for the tutorial area before Albero but the following areas just felt like tech demo slogs. 

At the end of the day, I like this game for what it is, but I'd never recommend it to a friend. I did not have fun playing it. Total slog for me, which sucked because again, thematically, I really really really wanted to love it. I really had expected to honestly & maybe that's why I was so disappointed by some of the design choices made. My $0.02.

[h1] Metroidvania with a horrifying concept on Miracles [/h1] 
[I] “I wonder what’s going inside the Art Director’s head when he made this.” [/i] 
[hr][/hr]

[I] Blasphemous [/i] caught my attention when it reminded me of similar games like [I] Castlevania [/i], and how it’s talked along with [I] Bloodstained [/i]. So, I had my expectations high, and it delivered, the world of Blasphemous is horrifying and intriguing that it just makes you want to play more and find out more around this world. Characters, cutscenes, and Voice add more that it can make you play again, and the developers know and gives you more content to play around and achievements to achieve. 

For the base game, it’s an open-world, you are given quest locations that you can do in any order but certain quests can be missable, making you either load your previous save or create a whole new game, choices are permanent and sometimes the smallest actions can create a huge difference to how NPCs will end up, some only impacts the side quests but some can lock you out from achieving a certain ending. 

The choices you make, doing side quests, collecting collectibles reward you. You can see [I] Albedo [/i] improve as you continue to help them, certain NPCs reward and/or improve your character making things easier than the trouble you went through made it easier for later. 

I highly suggest using an interactive map, tracking collectibles and guiding where they are, the map is huge, and you might get lost going where next or lose count on how far you’ve progressed collecting. 

With that said, with such a huge map, every time you enter a new area or approaching a boss, it felt foreboding because the enemies and bosses you’ve went through were horrifying and grim that makes you say [I] “What the fuck” [/i] makes you more intrigued what this new area has in store for you. The music is amazing that you can feel how scary fighting against these enemies. 

[hr][/hr] 
[h2] DLCs / Extra Content [/h2]

I don't know when we started slapping "metroidvania" on every 2-d action platformer, but it needs to stop. This is not a metroidvania, it is a 2-d darksouls platformer. If there is no ability gating, it is automatically *not* a metroidvania. I even see fps, and 3rd person games with "metroidvania" slapped on, they aren't even 2-d let alone have no ability gating.  Metroidvanias have 4 key components. enjoyable, fun movement, a world that beckons you to explore, abilities needing to be discovered to explore and open the world up further a.k.a ability gating, and a story that mystifies you making your lust for exploration burn vigorously. some would argue good combat/ bosses are key too, and I agree, however, it is not as important as those four. Metroidvanias are like mini epics where you go on some great explorative adventure starting out weak with little movement/abilities, and become something awesome as you progress, whilst you learn about your localle, why you're there, who you are possibly, why the events are taking place in the game, how did you end up here. These are all questions the player should be asking, and as they recieve answers, those should lead them into more questions and leave them scratching their heads. All that said, I think this game so far meets all these requirements but ability gating. In conclusion, the game is not bad, however, it should not be considered a metroidvania. It is not like metroid nor castlevania, it is like darksouls.

[h1]“For twisted are, were, and will be, the paths of the miracle.”[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[b]This review is based on playing on the Steam deck.[/b]
[b]Blasphemous[/b] is a brutal 2D metroidvania/souls-like amalgamation about the burdens of devotion and honour and what it takes to achieve your goals despite a world cast against you. With a heavy focus on cerebral combat, precision timing and understanding your skills [b]Blasphemous[/b] attempts to take the mantle of genre classic, but does it have what it takes? So take up your blade, steel yourself with your faith and discover a land that seeks penance or be the one to make it fall to the hungering darkness that awaits the hopeless.

[table]
[tr]
	[th][b]🟩 Positives[/b][/th]
	[th][b]🟥 Negatives[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]🟩 There are few means of fighting the vast army of foes that stand in your way. You must become familiar with your limited arsenal and how to best utilise it to succeed.

🟩 The map is large but not overly. There are several biomes to explore, plenty of secrets to uncover and items in abundance to collect.

🟩 Bosses are not only significantly powerful beings. They are also unique experiences to discover, with each being vastly different from the last.

🟩 A wonderfully unique art style that depicts sadness through pixelated forefront and painted background scenery to create an immersive environment.

🟩 And lastly: an immaculate audio selection that accompanies the journey, with excellent sound effects and a song for every situation that captures the moment astoundingly well.
[/td]
	[td]🟥 Despite how fun the boss fights are, they peak in challenge very early into the game, and the title becomes substantially easier until the end.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The once prosperous lands of Cvstodia have fallen from on high at the hands of a foul curse that has come to be known as The Miracle.

You take control of the Penitent One as he awakens from the dead to bear witness to the massacre of his brothers and sisters for opposing the church he once served. With the sacred blade Mea Culpa, he must travel across this tainted world, purging it of its corruption and bringing penance to now-dying lands that embody it.

I genuinely adored the story written here. A tragic tale that cradles you from the moment you start the journey to the moment it ends, delivering you an account of betrayal and vengeance, and as the screen goes dark for the last time, you are left to contemplate if the fight was worth the victory.

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[h3]Requiem Aeternam[/h3]
You will spend most of your time in Blasphemous fighting against the people and creatures that call Cvstodia home, so it is best to become acquainted with the mechanics of how to do so effectively as quickly as possible.

🟩 You have very few means of self-defence early into the game, so you will become familiar with dodging, parrying and counter striking at opportune moments. Firstly, evading is the most straightforward and useful tool because completely removing yourself from the path of danger is the safest method to keep living. The alternate approach that is far more critically timed is the parry mechanic, where you remain at risk to perfectly time a block, stun the enemy and allow a window for you to counterstrike.

🟩 You will slowly build an array of magical abilities as you discover them in hidden and secret places that can be useful in giving you an edge in combat. They vary from buffs to more versatile damage spells.

🟩 Lastly, and probably the most important tool on your belt, is the sword you have in your hand. The Mea Culpa is a sacred blade that starts pretty weak despite how it looks but will gradually get stronger until it becomes as feared as it should be. You upgrade its versatility at shrines located across Cvstodia and by spending Tears of Atonement, which serves as the currency in Blasphemous.

🟥 Boss encounters will be your greatest challenge in testing your growing abilities, as they vary from relatively simple in both method and style to far more complex and challenging. My one major bugbear lies here as there is a rather steep difficulty curve early on, but once past that, the rest of the game becomes spectacularly easy.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3014195123

[h3]Detestatio Sacrorum[/h3]
🟩 The remainder of the experience will entail you exploring the world, and there is a literal plethora of secrets across the game to locate, varying from collectibles to story-related key items and lore-related entries, to name a few.

🟩 These items can help you unlock some seriously invaluable powers which will greatly assist you on your travels, and for the truly vigilant, it can deliver you a new ending.

🟩 Thankfully throughout your journey you will have access to an ever updating map that provides a lot of helpful information you can utilise to traverse the world and locate those pesky hidden items you may have missed. The map also marks specific places of interest and allows you to add your own custom markers as points of reference.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3014194923

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
[b]Blasphemous[/b] is probably one of the more eye-catching Metroidvania games I have ever had the chance to experience as it has a firm grasp on a very classic retro style in both how it looks and plays, but at the same breath, the beautifully drawn backgrounds are astounding to take in. 

It is also extremely graphic despite its style, and I would not recommend anyone drastically underage to play this title as many of the themes are extremely adult in nature.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3014195305

The audio is much the same, and it wasn't till about 5 or 6 hours into the game that I realised how amazingly the sound effects coupled with the sad, down-trodden music that echoes through your ears in each new biome.

[h1]Deck Performance and Specifications[/h1]
The deck delivered the seamless experience I've come to expect of the device whilst playing [b]Blasphemous[/b]. The game had no graphical or technical issues to report whatsoever.

With the game set to default for the deck, the battery consumption was fair, giving about five hours of life from a full charge.

[h1]Final Thoughts - Excellent[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
To say that I have played a lot of Metroidvania games in my life would be a severe understatement, and I am an avid and appreciative fan of the souls and souls-like genre, I wanted this to be clearly known, so when I say that [b]Blasphemous[/b] for me was amongst the best experiences, I've had within either of these genres in the past. The whole formula just worked really well for me, and despite some rather small difficulty issues, this was an exceptionally compelling journey that I hope to re-experience numerous times over the years. A worthwhile purchase at any price.

I think the game is fun, has great metroidvania exploration and collectibles. Elevated by deeply engaging thematic content. 

Despite what an initial look (and the title) might suggest, I would say this is only partially about religion. Far more substantively I believe this is a game concerned with the way we conceptualize pain. Most specifically the virtue of pain, expressed here through the lens of holiness, but more widely applicable in what we find beneficial pain culturally. The idea that someone must be punished with pain or suffering for their wrongdoings, whether it would be best to relieve someone of their pain or if it would be more virtuous to let it continue.

Religion mostly occurs here to convey the idea of a standing dogma that idolizes pain. The language of religion here is partly exaggerated to convey an extreme reverence for pain. Partly though, it is indicative of the idea that religion is often the lens used to justify what pain is good pain and what pain is not. In that way, I think this game has a lot to say about religion. It would be, however, quite short sighted to limit this critique of pain being a means of virtue, when the same narratives are so prevalent in general cultural understandings.

I mean to say this game doesn't merely say "look at these antiquated religious zealots" and go "religion bad," the bigger ideas say that suffering is an ugly thing, and relegating the blind worship of suffering to being antiquated practice would only be a way to put off examination of our own ideas about pain and how we feel about the pain of others.

I thoroughly enjoy this game for its exceptional soundtracks, captivating art style, engaging combat mechanics, intriguing story, attention to small details, extensive exploration, and diverse array of items. However, it's important to note some aspects that might not appeal to everyone, as well as my own experiences and what I've heard from others.

Hack and Slash: This game leans towards the hack-and-slash genre, which might not be everyone's cup of tea. If you're not a fan of this style of gameplay, it might not be the best fit for you.

Abundance of Items: The game boasts a vast inventory of items, which can sometimes lead to the need for external resources or guides to understand their full potential and usage.

Early Game Challenges: In the initial stages, the game can be a bit demanding as you work to accumulate currency, explore, and avoid perishing.

Confusing Elements: At times, the game's intricacies and plot can become a bit perplexing, potentially requiring extra attention to fully grasp.

Complex Lore: The game's lore can be intricate, and not everyone may delve into it deeply. Some players might prefer a more straightforward narrative.

Multiple Endings: There are reportedly three different endings in the game, which might not appeal to those who prefer to move on to new experiences once they've completed a game.

Despite these considerations, I personally found these aspects to be engaging rather than off-putting. The hack-and-slash gameplay, adorned with visually stunning gore effects, was right up my alley. The music resonated with me, and the pixel art was truly captivating.

If you share my passion for 2D games, adventurous exploration, metroidvania mechanics, diverse item combinations, and varied combat styles, then I highly recommend giving this game a shot. It's well worth the $25 price tag, and you might even catch it on sale, as I did.

Blasphemous is a _very_ good exploration platformer with well-paced, fulfilling combat.

The atmosphere is top notch all the way. The writing, the visuals, the music. Everything fits together perfectly. Also, while it's very bloody and somber, it doesn't feel feeling gimmicky nor does it feel like the devs going "omg look at what we did here!"

Blasphemous is in every way I can think of that matters, a 2D souls-like.  Of course there are many games you could call similar to souls games, such as Hollow Knight, but that game didn't necessarily contain the spirit of a souls game. Many games take the functional part of those games, without also considering the narrative or artistic style that From Software has achieved during the making of the souls series.  This is what blasphemous does.  Game mechanics wise, it's a competent, smooth 2D metroidvania with sparse checkpoints, perilous platforming and out of this world artistic  style.  But what it incorporates that truly make this game an achievement, is a comprehensive and thought provoking narrative about blind faith.  This pairs up with the art style really nicely to create a brute, unforgiving world where your goal is to do something of meaning.  Whatever ending you choose, in this game, what really matters is the fact that you did it and reached the end.  The confusing story makes it difficult to understand if you had any impact in the world, but that's irrelevant.  You gain purpose because you went through the game.  That I think i the heart of souls narratives, and this game does it better than any 2D metroidvania I've seen (yes, including Hollow Knight).  However, the game play left too much to be desired. It didn't pair up as well as other metroidvanias do with their story.  There is of course a narrative reason for everything that you have at your disposal, but what didn't pair up well is a really important part of these type of games: character growth.  This game has  a leveling system, but it didn't feel as satisfying to actually get to the end in 2 ways:

1. A game like Hollow Knight makes you feel much more powerful if you find specific items in the game, since it almost always means an upgrade.  But specifically, it constantly mixes gameplay styles you can choose from.  Blasphemous has only 1 weapon, and that's it. It has lots of spells, but it takes too long to use one of them, and their effects are not all that different at the end.

2. Typical souls games made by From Software pair up the upgrade system with character growth. A great example of this is Elden Ring, where you feel a bigger sense of achievement because you get materials needed to perform an upgrade.

Of course, Blasphemous is like neither of these games.  It's a 15-20ish hour game which doesn't need such complicated mechanics. The problem is though, that those mechanics are essentially just wishes that were left by me when I finished the game.  I wanted more.  But Blasphemous didn't show that much gameplay. It being short was not a problem, mind you, but the big problem is that the game could have become much braver when it came to the part of conceptually designing gameplay mechanics.  It kind of is already, there are for example many death pits in this game which would confuse and frustrate players, but they were done carefully such as to never be as annoying as platforming sections in Castlevania games.  The real problem for me though, was that it didn't do enough of these things: The gameplay lacked the variety and beautiful color to truly represent the narrative of this game.  Therefore, it's easier for you to struggle understanding why this  this game is entertaining you. I did, but that's only because I came into this game knowing it was going to be a 2d souls game. 


In conclusion, this game is a beautiful, well built game which will likely be very fun for most that play.  However it's arcane narrative may be lost to some players not because they hadn't tried to get the feel of it, but due to the game not having gameplay complex enough to warrant people reading, or caring enough to explore it more.  The thing that truly sets this game apart though is that it successfully reinvents in my opinion the most important aspect of a souls game (narrative-visual-gameplay loop) into a 2D metroidvania. So overall, it was a really great time for me.

I feel sorry to say this, but I do not recommend this game. I had high hopes for the game, especially considering the themes it was going to tackle: religion piety, dedication, mystery, striving for greatness. But after spending 15 hours of play on this game, I just could not bring myself to finish it.
I'll start off with the good - graphics look amazing, and each boss is an artwork deserving of presentation in a church or a monastery as an icon. The map is rich and full of secrets. The enemy variety is enough for its purposes.
That leads to my criticisms: the gameplay is way too simple. Yes, you can unlock many different attacks, spells, upgrades, but for the most part the game consists of Dodge, Spam attack, Dodge, Spam attack, sometimes use Spell etc.. And to be honest, that might've been enough for a recommendation, but the story (or lack there of) is what snuffed out my interest completely.
I was hoping some sort of integration of game mechanics and story themes, where the symbolism, the metaphor is intertwined with the gameplay, but the gameplay and the story seemed to begrudgingly shake hands when absolutely required. The only mechanic I can think of that had any sort of symbolism behind it was 'cutting' yourself to open a locked gate, and then there was no use for it. (I am aware that you can cut yourself to fill your Mana/Penance, but you can easily ignore that).
Honestly, at that point in the game I felt like the developers (who have done a great job of making this game) made a good, but a bit standard, metroidvania, and then chose the setting of near-catholic world, where sin is manifested in real world. And even then, just as so many other storytellers before, came up with the idea of making the church/gods/saints the bad guys/corrupt.

TLDR: a good, if not standard, metroidvania with a fine gameplay loop, but the story-mechanic dissonance kills all interest

When it comes to the atmosphere and the general aesthetic Blasphemous is near perfection. The grimy and visceral visions of grimdark catholicism is, beyond the cyclopean richness of Warhammer 40k, pretty much an underused setting. Everywhere we go we are bombarded by gnarled roots and roses, twisted gothic architecture with an overdose of skulls, death, spikes, and holy symbols. On top of that we have a gameplay revolving around the meticulous collection of various anatomical features of dead geezers and crones, prayer beads and suffering to increase our everlasting torment.  

The story takes place in Cvstodia, the epitome of Catholicism gone haywire where we play as the last of a fraternal fellowship of coneheaded penitents sworn to silence. On our quest to topple the chosen one of the miracles we encounter fellow blasphemers, saints, sufferers and dogs. Honestly this game reeks of atmosphere and I guess the artwork and setting is somewhat of an acquired taste. If you find blood, gore and weird pseudo christian symbolism a bit too much, you might want to pick another game.. 

At íts core Blasphemous is a classic Metroidvania, albeit a rather cryptic one. The nonlinearity of the maps are spot on and to traverse the twisted landscapes we need to gather relics to alleviate our mortal forms limitations. Sometimes I found this to be a bit too cryptic, almost to a fault. However the gameplay in large is hugely satisfying and combined with the lovely worldbuilding I would say that this is a fantastic game! The boss fights are a mixed bag, I loved some of them, others were, well, way too harsh or way blander than expected.. All in all the gameplay is a slightly worse Hollow Knight, take it or leave it..   

In the end I highly recommend Blasphemous to anyone into great Metroidvanias. This is an instant classic and I really love when a game dares to not include an obvious double jump in the list of potential upgrades.. Enjoy it for the handcrafted images if nothing else, I never thought i'd be this intrigued by reinvented Catholic liturgy.

This is honestly a tough review. There's no denying I was addicted to this game during my first play through. I couldn't put the controller down as I wanted to continue to progress through this 2D metroidvania. Most of the game seemed pretty linear in terms of the progression. The story was compelling and, as the protagonist, you wanted to learn more about this world you were immersed in. The combat is simple to pick up and mobs are not egregious. Save locations are placed fairly distant from one another, giving a fair challenge. Variety in buffs allow some semblance of choice within the game as well. 
The longer I played however, was when the flaws started to peak out. This became especially apparent with NG+.

From a completionist stand point, there are achievements that are completely miss-able, which includes the 100% achievement. There are absolutely no indication within the dialogue of NPCs to guide players for certain key items (such as the item for double jump or the wall climbing vine) that halt progression (if I am incorrect with this, I accept the possibility that I may just be an idiot). There were instances where mini bosses, who are in there own rooms, would bug out after parrying (this can be extremely frustrating having to backtrack back to the boss and any semblance of progress is loss. Not to mention these mini bosses can be tough, forcing you to replay the instance several times over). DO NOT GET ME STARTED ON SOME OF THE PARRYING. Call me a bad gamer but I don't know what estranged Spanish saint I have to pray to but Christ theirs some bosses that are absolutely broken. It all just feels some what...clunky? 

Long story short: Not as good as Hollow Knight. Fun game, SHITTY to complete.

Blapshemous is a great game plagued by a few poor design decisions. The moment to moment gameplay feels great, navigating the world, uncovering its secrets, and fighting bosses is intensely satisfying, with the religious imagery of Spanish Roman Catholicism tying it together. 

A couple poor design decisions mar the experience. There's a fair amount of platforming in the game, all of which features spikes and endless pits that insta-kill the player. This results in a death screen, load screen, and then walking back to the platforming section to try again. This very easily could have been replaced with a quick respawn and some health lost. This is especially apparent in one of the DLC quests with Castlevania crossovers. Being a veteran platformer player, I enjoyed these lengthy speedrun challenges, but they definitely felt out of place. 

The second issue is more deep-seated. Several points in the game lock you out of content and bosses. In order to see everything Blasphemous has to offer, you must do atleast 2 playthroughs. Normally, this would be no issue, but the length of Blasphemous and the nature of its unlockables left me with a sour taste upon seeing this. There are a few other quests that have hidden triggers for progression, which will lock you out of happy endings and Achievements if you are interested in that. 

I didn't have it in me to do a second playthrough of Blasphemous, but for those up for it, it offers plenty of new content, story, secrets, and unlockables. The continued support in the form of small DLC packages helped make Blasphemous into a more complete experience.

[h1]Blasphemously good[/h1]
Awesome game, love the theme, the concept the whole thing but it is hard, like Sisyphos hard.
As an old Metroidvania player since the dark ages, I feel familiar and a bit comfortable until I realize this is a game that touches the OG Castlevania level of difficulty. After exploring and poking and smacking around, getting tons of very holy items and equipping myself with everything extremely holy and sacrosanct until I felt extremely saintly with a sword, I managed to delve further into the sins of the inhabitants and remove that said sin with the help of mea culpa and a little bit of force. The creativity of this game and the obvious catholic inspiration is so much fun to explore, everything from visuals to sound and music to the lore.

However, it is a very difficult game, that does get a little bit easier down the road when you get used to it, explore and find power-ups and equip yourself with some of the items you'll find. Still hard despite that, and you better get good with the controllers and enroll in a plat-former boot-camp to improve your reaction time. 

In short, it's a game made by sadists, for masochists.

[h3]Some Good Points[/h3]

[b]Music[/b] - Love it, beautiful iberian themed music, you can feel the Inquisition around the corner.
[b]Sound[/b] - I actually find it well put together - it feels right most of the SFX effects and work with the overall theme.
[b]2D graphic design[/b] - Absolutely fantastic I loved every inch of the game world's graphical design and all the characters as well!
[b]Content[/b] - absolutely enough for the price-tag, for sure. Some of it is good, some is better and some of it should've been thrown into a dumpster fire while in concept stage of their design ... imho (see below)
[b]Difficulty[/b] - It is very difficult and very much so in the beginning until you gradually learn how to play the game and avoid some dangers, handle the controls and how to deal with some enemies. I can say for sure I'm not the best platformer player, and I struggle with some bosses so I won't be able to beat some of them without flasks, for now. I don't know how many times I've died (least hundreds of times for sure) in the game and how many times I simply quit the game in the mid of it and had to do something positive to counterbalance the frustration.
[b]Creativity[/b] - I'd say it is exceptional, it is so fun to take it all in visually and audio-visually the whole game, the story is absurd as well but the fun part is that people really were nuts back then when it came to the whole sin-concept going into overdrive in Catholicism (especially).

[h3]Some Less Good Points[/h3]

[b]Quest Design[/b] - Really convoluted and obscure. I ending up checking a guide because I got stuck and it took too much time to keep running around and around not understanding the triggers of some of the quests, and yes I was right they were really convoluted.

[b]Glitches & Bugs[/b] - There are some moments albeit very rare the player char is stuck for some reason or can't dodge (end-game areas), thought my controller was bad but no it was an in-game glitch. There are also icons not displaying properly in the map, particularly the blood fountain in the second last area.

[b]Genre Content[/b] The Strife & Ruin content is something I'm not happy about since it is a type of a genre that I don't like playing, it wasn't what i wanted when I bought the game but it isn't game breaking to skip it, however it annoys the hell out of me since it locks me out from getting a full completion of the game. If I want to elevate my stress levels and enjoy masochism then I work double-shift while being screamed at, then play Meatboy while blindfolded and have my bare feet pressed on sharp glass shards while playing a recording with someone hating you non-stop on 150% volume after work, and no food or water. 
Not sit through another 2-3 hours TRYING to get the two last pieces by clearing the death-trap courses within given time. I hope it isn't in the sequel, seriously I pray to the Miracle it isn't, otherwise I'll skip buying it.

= = = = = =

[h2]Summary[/h2]

Buy it without a doubt, but be mentally prepared, have a sturdy controller of at least Nokia quality and an anger-management tool ready beside you and be ready to accept you'll have to skip content so you don't lose sanity.

[h1] Great combat system, not a great metroidvania[/h1]
Blasphemous is a game I got enough out of I'd feel bad giving a thumbs down for, but I'd give a thumbs in the middle if I could.

I really enjoyed the games combat, especially the parry system made dodging and timings for boss fights and enemies fun. I typically find enemies in games more annoying than fun, so the fact that Blasphemous made me enjoy fighting and learning them is a huge plus. (Though some enemies were really annoying to fight)
There were 3 bosses I really liked, 2 I thought were good, and then the rest were kinda forgettable/mid (Final boss kinda sucks). This was the highlight of the game, though even with the bosses I thought were really good I felt like I was put into situations I just couldn't dodge. But for the most part I really liked the difficulty.

I really wasn't a fan of the exploration of the game. I went 15 hours not finding a single ability, just waiting to find the one ability that clearly every single path was locked behind, just for it to be locked behind some weird convoluted quest I had to be told how to do AFTER I already beat the game. Making the majority of the game just feel like I was just mapping out dead ends with no real reward the entire game. Because I was locked out of most of the map until after finishing the game and had to look up every single ability, everything just felt like some clean up fetch quest that just took all the fun out of the metroidvania exploration for me, that eventually I just gave up trying to find most of the stuff because it was basically meaningless at that point. The map is also really big and most areas just felt kinda pointless to fight your way through because bosses were so spread out and you rarely find something useful.

Unlike most metroidvania's the abilities are also not anything the player can actually use like a movement ability or something, they just spawn platforms and walls, or just immunity to some hazard so you can go through an area. Basically just keys to a door with lack of player interaction. Which makes it especially confusing as to why you can only have 3 equipped at a time? Just made it so when I saw something I could interact with I had to go into the menu and change what I was wearing for that room to interact with it. 

Spikes and pits killing you instantly (which you usually fall into because you just walked into a room or they're off screen) are extremely annoying and made exploration especially tedious at some points. 

Fast travel in the game is very tedious with how spread out it is. You do get an upgrade for this hidden behind some random donation that doesn't tell you what it does or how much it takes, or even how much you've put in. This is where the most important upgrades in the game are hidden behind. 

There are many side quests you can get locked out of if you don't follow the very strict requirements and look up exactly what to do before ever progressing which can lock you out of certain upgrades which is really lame. 

There's also an INSANE amount of money grinding if you want to get all the upgrades, because stuff costs way too much for how much money you get by just playing casually.

There are 5 dedicated platforming segments and they are horrendously awful. They're speed challenges with no control over how fast you can go due to just waiting for really slow cycles to carry you over to the next platform. On top of which the last couple are really long, and an attempt is over in an instant because falling into spikes 1 shots you.

I encountered a bunch of small little bugs here and there, mostly graphical, a couple that just made me fall through the ground and died when I shouldn't have, or where I lost horizontal control of my character, or just fell through a platform I clearly landed on. Only really effected game-play during the already awful platform sections. 

Though it clearly had a lot of work into it, which I appreciate, I gave up pretty quickly trying to understand the story, there was just wayyy too much reading that's in old English, that was too difficult for me to really decipher, and would have just taken too much time away from actually playing the game. [h1]Sorrowful be the heart, Penitent One.[/h1]
Blasphemous. The game that I bought and immediately forgot about a thousand years ago. The game that I didn't expect much from upon my return, but ended up having a whole lot of fun. 

I never considered myself a hardcore fan of the Metroidvania genre: for various reasons, I couldn't beat Hollow Knight and Ori, and the more "classic" games like Bloodstained didn't click with me at all. However, this game sucked me in literally an hour after starting, and didn't let go until the very (true) ending.

🟢 [b]Well-Paced Exploration[/b]
Amazingly smooth difficulty curve combined with the non-linearity of the world and abundance of secrets, from items to entire locations, provides an extremely enjoyable gaming experience. 

Character stat progression is absent in the game at all, and currency is spent on rare weapon upgrades and potions. In the case of potions, there is a permanent loss of one for each upgrade. Cool decision, design-wise. 

The meta elements here are quite interesting, as the most useful upgrade the player receives is obtained through donating currency at a local church, which, upon reaching a certain threshold, grants the most convenient fast travel in the game. Although initially, it may seem that these donations are pure flavor.

🟢 [b]Awesome Combat[/b]
The combat system is simple and quite intuitive. In most cases, opponents — regular mobs and bosses alike — are perfectly readable. Their animations are clear and well-optimized, with precise timing that allows the player to parry or dodge in time. 

I would also like to mention the boss fights. In the worst cases, they are... pretty standard. In the best cases, they are astonishing. I swear, I will remember Sierpes and Crisanta for a long time. Especially the latter’s second phase which is mostly based on perfect parrying.

🟢 [b]Lore & Aesthetics[/b]
The reason for my return to Blasphemous was its absolutely unique style, which is emphasized by an intricate and complex story with Spanish cultural and religious references. The imagery is so cool that it stays in my mind long after I close the game. And it will stay, I’m certain of it.

All of this is conveyed through pixel art. As a simple human being, I love pixel art. I draw pixel art. I am inspired by it. Here it is of high quality only. Some backgrounds are begging to be used as wallpapers. And certain music tracks will definitely make it into my playlist and serve as background music for role-playing games.

🟡 [b]Well, Platforming[/b]
To me, the only problem this game has. And it is highly subjective. The only thing to ever compete with the bosses is… iron spikes. Carefully placed literally everywhere, they are ready to annihilate you the moment your reflexes go numb for a single second. And considering how much jumping this game offers… 

However, suffering is the way. The Souls series told us.

Great Metroidvania/Soulslike hybrid, really good music, fun gameplay, varied and interesting bosses and locations but it is let down by some frustrating platforming mechanics at times, I swear I died more to the terrain and gravity than I did to bosses! The story is the usual having to read item descriptions and the like but you get enough from cutscenes and dialogue to get the basic gist of it.

I would advise to take a peak at the wiki before leaving an area to make sure you haven't missed anything and to save you the hassle of trial and error for NPC quests. New Game+ is in this game which has a new quest (leading to a third ending), new bosses and three challenges you can enable which each give a unique reward.

All in all it got multiple free DLCs after the initial release with the final one adding the ending which leads into it's sequel. I couldn't have asked more for my money and am very happy with this game, it's not perfect and can be frustrating at times but it's a solid 8/10 and a great time.

However, I can think of a few things I'd like to see changed for improved QoL:

  - Some of the relics should be equipped by default. There's no reason to have to waste a 
    slot/pause and switch just to be able to talk to the dead or be immune to poison.

  - Names and descriptions should be simplified. Extreme verbosity is part of the world but it's 
    a pain to have to sift through so much cruft to find out an item gives you increased health.

  - Checkpoints in the Miriam platforming sections would be nice because falling into instant 
    death spikes feels unfair considering how awful the ladder hit boxes can be here.

There are a few other slightly clunky mechanics, but I can overlook most of them. Good buy on sale.

It's one of those games that makes me wish Steam had a "star" system instead of a simple "recommend/don't recommend" system. 
The Pros:
-The environment and art design is pretty cool, with some unique character concepts. 
-Thematic music and character voice acting
-A cool-looking level up and upgrade system that seems to naturally scale. 
-Some fun bosses each with unique mechanics

The cons:
-The platforming just sucks. It is absolutely atrocious. The wall-jumping mechanics are the weirdest I've ever experienced. In order to jump "up" the wall, you have to jump up, out, and back in in a crazy arc. Jumping from ladder to ladder is brutal; there's an almost full second delay from where you press 'up' and your character actually grabs on to the ladder. 

-Level design is pretty poor. There're either no save points anywhere or three save points all clustered together in one spot, making each one kind of useless. So when you inevitably die far away from one when doing some exploring, it's just absolutely brutal to have to go all the way back through trap-valley to try and collect your dead body. 

-The traps placed, while unique, are often brutal with janky hit frames. The spikes in this game are the absolute worst. If even your pinkie toe touches the spikes, your character suddenly teleports to an impaled state. 


I'll probably finish the game if I get the time, just because I spent the money on it. But yeah, wouldn't recommend. The gameplay mechanics just suck. They're clunky and obviously need refinement.

Update: My above review stands as is. I'm reaching the end and the platforming is just the worst. They're not trying to make it difficult, they're just trying to be annoying and kill you. Floors crumble out of nowhere and lead to spike pits, every improper jump is punished with an insta-kill spike pit. Very disappointing, especially since the boss fights are so good.

Blasphemous is a solid action metroidvania style game with an intriguing story, extensive lore, brutal combat and full of challenging moments both in it's exploration, combat and boss encounters. Though the game felt frustrating at the start of it all, once you get to learn to understand the mechanics and the importance of backtracking, you will be well on your way to being the ultimate Penitent One. 

[h2] The Story & World [/h2]

The story was quite solid in it's execution, going for a more dark souls like way of telling the story rather than telling you exactly what happens. In a way, it kept me well engaged. Many metroidvania games exceed at creating such unique worlds and Blasphemous doesn't disappoint in this regard, being heavily inspired by Spanish Religion, you will be going through many churches that all feel unique, in addition to snowy mountain plains, desolate hellish undergrounds, a toxic sewerage system or a ghastly Library. This is all accompanied by an amazing OST to represent the world/boss. Connected level design is also another positive thing about these types of games, providing ease of access to the player as a reward to prevent tedious linear backtracking. 

[h2] Gameplay & Progression [/h2]

How does the gamplay hold up? well as I mentioned before, it is truly a challenging game, every enemy you encounter after the Holy Line is unique with it's own attack patterns and behaviour with a total of 37 unique encounters (not including the bosses). Some enemies are stronger variants of each other (such as Acolytes) but all in all are unique to the area you are fighting them in. You will die a lot if you do not learn about the encounter or study the attack patterns of the enemies. By learning about what each enemy does within the encounter, you will have a better chance at succeeding and dying less. That being said, there is going to be a time where certain rooms filled with certain enemies can frustrate you and perseverance is the only answer.

The Penitent One has a decent array of movesets with his sword the Mea Culpa from a uppercut slash, a slow but powerful ground twirl, a plunge attack, a charged attack, ranged blood projectiles and a powerful dash lunge which can setup for perfect executions which are all satisfying to pull off. Along with upgrading your moveset, you can upgrade your healing items (as in the amount you can obtain/amount you can heal). Parrying and Dashing are your defence mechanics but iframes are not that frequent especially in boss fights, relying on reading the patterns of the boss you are fighting. All the bosses are unique to fight and range from powerful warriors to abominations. 

Progressing the game in order to become more powerful is tied to the world itself and exploring it deeply for secrets. You can obtain tears of atonement which is currency earned through killing mobs/bosses and progressing quest lines. By unlocking relics, they can help open new paths to explore and further expand your arsenal, such as and is not limited too: health upgrades, fervour upgrades, rosary knots/beads to give buffs/defences for certain scenarios, Hearts for your sword which will provide a huge buff along with a debuff, prayers and consume fervour to unleash powerful buffs, defences or attacks, collecting bones that unlock a new boss and cosmetic and finally finding Children of Moonlight to track down. 

[h2] Replayability [/h2]

After I was able to 100% my New Game file, the only thing left to do was play True Torment (NG+) which resets all of your progress while retaining most of the stuff you found already in that file. In NG+ as expected, you will fight enemies that are stronger and deal more damage but in return you earn more tears to make the grind less tedious and elongated. In addition you get 3 traits to choose from. Red turns the game into an old school side platformer where instead of a health bar, you get health orbs, which can help with annoying boss fights/traps/enemies. The Blue one weakens your sword attacks by half but allow your fervour to regenerate passively rather than having to earn it through attacks only. Finally the black one turns the game into dark souls in a sense where if you die, you lose all of your currency, cant use prayers and have to collect the guilt where you died and your flasks no longer heal health but fervour, making for a more punishing playthough but a good challenge nonetheless. by beating the game with each trait, you will unlock a new bead/skin. 

In addition to NG+, there is new content to play, such as fighting 4 skeletal bosses each with a unique weapon that has a unique attack pattern all to progress to a final boss that uses all 4, testing your skills and knowledge on the bosses you fought prior. A new ending is also unlocked where you have to explore the new areas to find it, as well as paying attention to the NPCs you encounter. Thee there is content is one I personally dislike as they are platforming challenges and that is the Strife and Ruin which was a collaboration with the Bloodstained series protagonist Miriam, as I found it to show a lot of the frustrating parts of the platforming in this game when presented as a challenge but thankfully that is just optional and you get a decent prayer as a reward so up to you.

Once you are done exploring all of the base game, you can challenge the bosses again in a progressive style known as Sacred Sorrows which will rank you based on many things and serves as a challenge.

Overall, I enjoyed my time with Blasphemous, so much to the point I wanted to 100% this games achievements and I'm glad I did, It provides a satisfying gameplay loop, allowing the player to discover a unique world where they are rewarded for paying attention to the little details and explore every nook and cranny to further progress the penitent one to become stronger than ever. A vast array of beads, prayers and hearts allow for extensive customisation and variety, all wrapped together with a story that is mysterious but extensive. Awelcome addition to action metroidvania games.

[h1]Joyful be the heart![/h1]
There are some video games that can be easily said that they go beyond being the source of entertainment. That they reach further, into the field of a fine work of art. One of those games is definitely Blasphemous. Astounding atmosphere and lore, coated with totally beautiful and detailed pixel-art graphic and climatic music, both fitting the in-game world they represent and portray.

This could be enough to classify Blasphemous as a work of art, but one mustn't forget about something equally important as the things I mentioned earlier, which is gameplay and everything surrounding it. It is as polished as the audiovisual side of this game, meaning that we have a lot of abilities and combos to perform, challenging bosses to defeat, various platforming sequences to go through. Level design is superb and, combined with a minimap allowing to put markers etc. on it, makes a player accustomed to the whole area they are currently in.

Cherry on the top are achievements. They are fair, rewarding, and definitely doable. Some of them are easier to get, some are harder, but with enough practice getting 100% achievements doesn't seem like an impossible task at all.

Any cons? Sometimes it's not clear, at least on a first glance, what to do exactly to reach a particular ending or finish a quest, often bound to an achievement. It's a minor inconvenience, in my opinion. It might seem annoying at times, but doesn't take the joy of playing this game. At least it did not in my case.

I definitely recommend Blasphemous. As a fan of the metroidvania genre, playing it was truly a gaming feast and pure pleasure.

[h1] Disclaimer for those in India [/h1]
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME at its current price. If you check steam's price history, Blasphemous saw a roughly 350% increase in its price, putting it at just about on par with the American USD rate. This is ridiculous as far as regional pricing goes and the game most definitely is NOT worth the current amount of Rs. 1999 (as of Sept. 2023). Buy this game when it's on heavy discount, if at all. Otherwise, just go for something else.

[h3] Ok, game review [/h3]
I could not bring myself to finish this game, there just was not enough of a motive for me to keep playing. I got to around the final boss and though I did have some late game stuff left to explore, I couldn't muster the enthusiasm to invest time into it.

[h3] The Good Stuff [/h3]
The art style is beautiful, especially the creature and character designs. If you're someone who is a fan of gore and just super weird shit, then you're gonna at least have a good time staring at your screen. The environment design ranges from fine to amazing, but the creature designs are definitely what stands out the most. Blasphemous's art is heavily rooted in religious iconography most notably taken from Christianity and it plays around with that concept in some extremely gruesome ways.

The sound design is what really carried the experience for me. It is so good. The OS, combat sounds, creature sounds, and just about everything is top-notch and really helps to immerse in Blasphemous' weird universe.

[h3] The Bad [/h3]
The game tries too damn hard to be edgy, it's gory, gruesome, biblical, and weird, and it'll beat you over the head with it. 

Also why would you use a Blackletter font for a pixel art game?? I get why it was used thematically, but it just made reading item descriptions such a chore, especially considering a lot of the terms are very specific to just Blasphemous. I often misread many words and mostly could not be bothered with reading more than two lines or until I understood what the item did in-game.

The combat and platforming were by far the weakest aspects of the game for me, the combat is just fine when it comes to the regular enemies, other than a few of the enemies which just bring the gameplay down to a halt and sometimes require you to simply tank hits. The boss fights were just okay, I think it took me only about 2-3 tries for most bosses, though some of the late-game boss fights were A LOT better than those in the early to mid-game.

The platforming is my main gripe with this game as the tools given offer such a poor experience while traversing the levels and a majority of this game requires you to traverse large distances to get anywhere. I don't think I enjoyed even a single instance of platforming. A lot of the ledges you need to jump to are also this 2.5D thing which made it confusing to know when you've actually landed on something. There is no flow to the character's movement.

[h1] In Conclusion [/h1]
I had a little bit of fun playing Blasphemous, it would have been an okay experience were it not for the awful platforming. The game progression is also way too obscure and half the time you don't even know where you're supposed to go. It's somehow like Dark Souls 1 but without the beautiful world, lore, and characters. If you're looking for a similar experience to this then I'd suggest Ender Lilies, Ori, Hollow Knight, Dead Cells, Salt and Sanctuary, Shovel Knight, Furi, Katana Zero. Though Blasphemous is a competently made game, I had a lot more of an enjoyable experience playing these other game.

As a big fan of metroidvania and soulslike genres alike, this along with most 2d soulslike games miss the mark by a large margin. While difficulty is the name of the game for soulslike and exploration/world connection is the same for metroidvanias this one falls short in that the difficulty is placed almost completely on the clunkiness of the character. The dash most of the time places you into the hitbox of the enemy you are trying to dash stab, and to not attempt a dash stab and get a execute is essentially wasting time. The obstacles are almost unavoidable at certain points in the game so you are bound to get damaged from SOMETHING. Getting hit from an enemy that walks into you is absolutely frustrating, and you cant dash past most enemies that you feel like you should be able to. A handful of the boss fights are ok, but ok at best. There is no flow, and many times the obstacles require you to wait an excruciatingly long time (looking at the fog clouds in the tower). The parry is ok, but parrying larger enemies leaves you staggered, knocks you back a bit, and does not reward you in the slightest, so whats the point? I'm probably only halfway through this game at the moment, and did not want to leave a review until after I beat the game, but I feel like my intolerance for the game has reached its peak.

Although I recommend Blasphemous, there are a few caveats that you need to be aware of before jumping in. 

The story the story some how makes Fromsoftware's video game stories as coherent as a children's book. You'll have NPCs spouting terms and events that make no sense in what your'e trying to do in the game, so if story telling is your thing, and you're not into figuring out what the heck went down, this game isn't for you. Also brief aside of the story, ending C, the game's canon ending that apparently leads into the events of the sequel, is missable and missing it requires you to start over or play New Game Plus, but the latter is recommended due to a few bosses in the game are exclusive to New Game Plus. 

Too many of the upgrades are too far off the beaten path and require the usual affair of not being able to access them until you get a tool to reach them, but you get these tools so late that you'll forget about them unless you remember to mark them on your map to come back later. If you expect the game to hand you upgrades, the ones that the game naturally gives you, or the ones that you can immediately get as soon as you stray off the beaten path is minimal. I ended the game with like two magical abilities (Prayers) and one or two passive abilities (Hearts). So don't expect to have that many toys to play with unless you either take the time to go back every now and then to look for them when you get a new traversal tool, look them up, or play New Game Plus since all traversal tools that you unlock (some are optional, but required to get certain items and abilities) are carried over, so you can just go to every side path and get nearly everything in the game.

FInally, the movement and platforming is a bit clunky, not the most terrible thing I've played, but it feels a little jank at times. 

With all those caveats out of the way, the combat is fun, parrying feels very good, and presents a fair challenge. The design of the enemies are cool especially the bosses. Environments are cool as well, even though a bit boring sometimes (looking at you Jundo).

Blasphemous is rough around the edges in terms of story, upgrade progression, and movement, but if you can get passed that, then I recommend you give it a try.

Today was the last drop. I wanted to like this game, really did. But these beginner game developer/designer mistakes are simply intolerable.

1) Not all the controls are taught to you through-out the course of the game. When you pick up and item and want to read the description of it to determine whether it's worth equiping or not, sometimes the part of the description that's important is off-screen. If you want to read that part, you'll have to know how to scroll that description. Hint: scroll-wheel does NOT work. Oh and if you wanted to check the controls mid-game?

2) There is no pause menu, no settings menu, you have no ability to adjust anything regarding the game while you're in-game, only in the start-up screen. Want to adjust the audio? Restart the game. Video settings? Restart the game. Check or change controls? Re. Start. The. Game. Alternatively you have to alt-tab out of the game to google the controls.

3) Speaking of alt-tabbing, don't. The game does NOT care whether it's in focus or not. It will continue to accept input even if another application is in the foreground and focused. This means that if you alt-tab to write a message to your friend or type anything anywhere, some of those letters you're typing may be accepted by the game as input. In my case, which is today's last drop, I started up the game, and while waiting for it to load (which takes absolute ages given the relatively tiny size of the game) I was chatting. The game accepted those inputs, navigated to the game save menu AND DELETED MY ENTIRE PROGRESS.

Aside from the meta problems above, the gameplay is okay for the most part. I'll just point out a couple of them that negatively stood out.

4) Mechanics seems to be misnamed or just poorly implemented sometimes, specifically parry. It's not really a parry, it's a block. For all the encounters I've had in the game (about 25% in) there were only 2 enemies against which there was an actual parry response, everywhere else it's just a block. Misnomer at best but still slightly annoying.

4.1) More nails in the coffin for parry, it has basically no place in this game. The timing window for some attacks seem intuitive but when you use that same intuition for other attacks, it just let's the attack through either before you even take the parry stance. You simply have to get hit or die a couple of times to memorize the timing window for each parriable attack, but still annoying. In any case, there's almost no point in using this instead of dashing behind the enemy whenever possible, you'll probably forget you even have this ability.

5) Sluggish controls in general. There's no chaining or cancelling actions. There seems to be a cooldown a little bit after almost every action you can take during which you may not start another action. Pacing of the game strongly focuses on the platforming, for which the deficiencies the controls have are most apparent (and abhorent). For some this might be the "real" experience, to me this is just annoying.

6) The hitboxes are completely broken. There's just no regard to what is shown to you on screen. Oh a projectile flew 2 player character heights above you? Yea that hit you. A lazer passes through you? Nah you're good fam.

The Righteous:
[list][*]Good level design.
[*]Creative art direction with some truly curious boss designs.
[*]Balanced combat difficulty with minimal penalty for dying. 
[*]Good number of secrets and some clever puzzles.
[*]Fitting soundtrack that is generally quite good.[/list]

The Profane: 
[list][*]A couple of important progression items require very convoluted steps to find.
[*]Some encounters trigger during very specific windows of opportunity that can be missed. There are at least two situations where accepting or equipping an item is irreversible, which locks you out of completing certain objectives.
[*]Some objects have weird hit boxes. Ladders can be tricky to grab while jumping and to avoid grabbing during combat.[/list]

Final Judgement: 

Blasphemous is worthy of its positive ratings. Like any successful Metroidvania its level progression is fun and complex, with plenty of secrets to uncover. Boss fights are simple but challenging, though not as punishing as Hollow Knight or Souls games, which I personally appreciate. Combat is pretty standard: mostly hack n' slash with some semi-useful prayer spells that I frequently forgot to use.  

On the other hand there are disappointingly several ways that the designers lock you out of accessing certain content in a given run due to some very unclear or needlessly strict conditions.

People can be very opinionated about "metroidvanias". And they're very subjective; some people like specific types of combat, movement, upgrades, and exploring. But for me, Blasphemous checks all the boxes and keeps me coming back year after year thanks to the creepy and beautiful Catholic and gothic art style. The music, while atmospheric and blending in, fits the game perfectly. 

It's worth multiple plays through; the only complaint I really have is that to 100% the game and get all achievements can be confusing (specific order of operations and ignoring certain things is a requirement) -- I had to use a guide to make sure everything fired.

I wish Steam had 50/50 option for review because Blasphemous isn't a bad game.
Actually it's pretty good. 
Art direction is amazing.
Sound design and music is great.
Level design feels a little disjointed.  Go through a door and your in a whole different zone. No lead up to so it can be a little jarring. 
So why am I giving it a negative review?
The controls are terrible.
Everything feels clunky. Movement feels sluggish, jumping has no real momentum and ledge grabbing is a 50/50 chance of grabbing when you want and a 100% chance of grabbing when you don't.
And ladders... wow. Ladders are the most frustrating thing in this game.
I got to this point where I spent 45 minutes trying to get past the same spot since you have to jump from one ladder to another and since it's so janky I just fall into a spike trap and die.
Now the first few times I can blame myself. User error.
But again and again and again I would die in the exact same spot and at some  point you have to start thinking that it's the game.
After looking it up too see if I was just bad it turns out that this is a complaint from many people going back two years.
If Team17 tightened the controls and fixed the issues with the ladders I could recommend Blasphemous but right now it's more frustrating then fun.

Edit*
Decided to give it another go since the second game has just been released and man this game really annoyed me to no end.
Controls have been worked on it seems and I didn't have a lot of issues with ladders and ledges even though it's still janky sometimes.
My issues is with items and quests.
There is no direction with these "quest" items and it's so convoluted for no reason. 
It doesn't make the developers smart and it just comes off as try hard.
I got so annoyed I just alt+F4'ed and took it off my hard drive.
Even looking at the wiki it's convoluted.
For example.

There are these vines around the world so obviously I need an item to activate them.
To get said item these are the steps.
Get the Black Grieving Veil.
Get the Torn Bridal Ribbon.
Get the Melted Golden Coins.
Then find the the big hairy egg. (Not a joke it's an actual big hairy egg)
Place the items and get the Egg of Deformity.
Then go to a tree where you fought Perpetva and place the egg.
Leave the area and come back to get the Hatched Egg of Deformity.
Then take the egg to the statue in the lake of silence to bless it and get the item to grow the vines.
What the actual eff...
If I didn't look it up I would never have figured this out. 

The place with the black egg just has plates on the floor with no clear indication as to what goes there. Am I supposed to go back when ever I pick up an item?
The only thing I think I would have pieced together would be the actual egg.

Look I don't like hand holding in games and can figure most things out on my own but when it's something like this I just can't wrap my head around how this was approved.
Obviously Blasphemous is not for me but I still don't recommend this to anyone.

This game has great lore and worldbuilding, and a significant number of glaring fundamental issues. The combat is pretty decent, but it is hampered by mediocre hitboxes and gameplay issues. This game heavily relies on artificial difficulty, where they increase the number of enemies or the number of environmental hazards in an area to make it harder. There are also enemies in a later area that spawn out of thin air and can spawn directly on your character, making you take free damage from an enemy that you cannot even see. Similarly, the boss encounters are incredibly weak imo. Most bosses have a very small moveset of 3-4 moves that they relentlessly spam and later in the encounter, the bosses will just increase how quickly they use this repetitive moveset. It makes most fights very boring and while most bosses are very well-designed, their fights don't have the same effect. One simple gameplay mechanic that frustrated me to hell was the fact that your character is knocked down when taking damage in most cases. The bosses take advantage of this knockdown by spamming more of their attacks while you're knocked down, which in most cases would be fine, but it seems like the knockdown is an animation lock causing you to not be able to move or parry while you're down. You also will likely need a guide for this game because all of the item descriptions or questlines are incredibly cryptic and its often near impossible to determine what to do with specific quest items. Finally, while lorewise the final boss of the game is interesting, the actual encounter is a massive letdown due to the fight being terribly boring/uninteresting in phase 1 and gimmicky to an extent that it becomes frustrating in phase 2. Overall, I still enjoyed my time with this game, but I think that there are many gameplay aspects that don't feel right and I hope that they are fixed in Blasphemous 2.

Edit: After going back and actually completing the game, I wanted to go over this review again as I felt I was a bit harsh at first. While I do still agree with my original points, I still think this game is worth playing. I think what initially deterred me was that It took me some initial time to get used to the game's mechanics/controls. Your attacks and overall speed are slow, meaning you have to really find these moments inbetween enemy attacks where you can get some hits off. While you can probably get away with not using it, the block/parry is also a large part of combat. If you can time these correct you can get in large amounts of damage by mitigating the amount of time youre trying to dodge things. Though as I originally stated, the game's unique art style and ambiance is it's strongest feature, with many areas and enemies have really cool designs to them. Overall I really enjoyed the game when I came back to it and look forward to trying the sequel sometime.

After finishing the game WITHOUT a guide, thus being part of the whopping [b]SIXTEEN[/b] percent of players who got the (brutally unceremonious and objectively disrespectful) "b" ending, I can't help but being puzzled by the overwhelming appreciation this game got.

I think too many people hastily recommended this game for what it [i]promises to be[/i], rather than for what it really is.

This game is obsessed with two concepts
1) difficulty for the sake of difficulty (the sorry embarassment that is the "new game+", with its plethora of contrived handicaps, is a further and laughably blatant indication of this)
2) the less information is given to the player, in order to advance in a meaningful way in the game, the better

If these two points sound like your cup of tea, by all means feel free to indulge, for about 25 to 30 hours, in a competently written metroidvania, set in an ultra-bleak world, filled with religious atrocities ad nauseam.

Otherwise, well... feel free to look elsewhere for better ways to spend your time.

Of course, not everything in this game is perplexing: for example, pressing buttons on your controller will prompt a corresponding action performed by the main character.

People will say this is a "soulslike" and I suppose it is in theme and certain elements, but this is far more a metroidvania (with more Metroid than Castlevania) with a keen-eye towards old school difficulty. Tough but rewarding, this is a very fine game.

This game isn't perfect, but trust me when I say that Blasphemous is a good sack of beatiful artistic direction and relatively simple, but fun gameplay that perfectly mixes the dark fantasy of Dark Souls with some hardcore platforming and a side of Metroidvania vibes. Skip forward to the list for the TL;DR

Before making a pros/cons list, I have to express that Blasphemous isn't nor a lot of Dark Souls nor Metroidvania, but it's clearly inspired by either. As I mentioned, the Souls-like vibes are mostly given by the dark fantasy setting, the which is inspired by the Spanish obscurantism (more on that in the digital art book. Highly recommended a read by the way!) and the way we are given no more than a setting and an brief introduction to the land of Custodia, all the other lore is printed on the items for you, it is up to you to have a read or not, the same way you'll have to pay attention to the NPCs quest lines.
It's Metroidvania vibes on the other hand come from the good share of platforming that is the whole game and the wide variety of areas you visit, with that precious background design that truly submerges you into a room despite being printed behind platforms and enemies in a 2D setting, and the numerous secrets you can find with a little intuition, observation and the use of the skills that let you move around the world, although here they are relics that will give you access to those secrets and aren't precisely mandatory for the game.
With those two in mind is where Blasphemous makes its own soul: A wide world of platforms that feels naturally connected between areas, hardcore and rightfully frustrating platforming, combat that requires you to be deliberate and accurate, and a "two phase story" that gives you some freedom on how to tackle the game; although it does misses the "being stuck in a room, find skill to get you unstuck after exploring and finding your way" that Metroidvanias demand, this is reserved for secrets, and I think it does for the better.

There are plenty of enemies, with one or two attacks each, something I think could be improved but that isn't precisely out of the formulas it takes inspiration from, boss fights are all distinct and unique (Fuck that baby you saw on the trailer though, I hate that thing) and you get a decent amount of techniques to fight with, skills become extensions and upgrades of those but the feeling of repetiveness is scarce, also akin to the games it was inspired by. I'll stop here and go on with the list, what I had to put in words has been said.
