Great metrovania/dark souls game but the way the game is laid out is off. Every upgrade in this game is gated by secrets that can be missed. If you play this game mark your map so you know where to go back from.  The dlc content can be convoluted and it all requires back tracking. Also very little is explained which is ok if the mechanics are intuitive. For the life of me I dont understand why Dark souls like games don't adopt the same system of if you unlock a shrine you can port over there. Stop making porting to shrines something you have to earn! Good grief! PS tithe at the church because it provides considerable upgrades. 

The end bosses/dlc bosses that provide the hardest content are can be a bit cheap and shows the developers honest attempt to recreate dark souls like bosses but what they miss is that in dark souls those bosses have many ways to be beaten. In the game that dynamic is missing and most likely to be said bosses will require you to find secrets to upgrade your character like certain prayers or beads. Or of course you can just git gud and became a no hit player. 

Ultimately I dont like that power level of the character is gated by discovery more than combat and challenging battles. Hopefully they struck a better balance in the sequel. 

In conclusion, a solid game that misses being truly great due to the above design issues. However if you fight the DLC bosses and the ending C bosses and put the work in to discover your power level you will have a great time.  The developers are close to making something special. Looking forward to the sequel to see if what they have learned.

Including a dedicated lore button and actually labeling it "Lore" breaks the fourth wall in the worst way for me. The world itself isn't bad, and I like the concept of Christian pain and suffering being virtuous; it's great as an aesthetic, but Blasphemous seems to go a step further and make me actually suffer the longer I play.

The art style and animations are beautiful, but the deeper I get into the game, the more tedious it becomes. From the overly methodical combat and wait-move-wait platforming, backtracking quickly becomes a chore. When your inspiration comes from games like Dark Souls, Castlevania and Metroid, replaying the same areas should be engaging every time, or at least less tedious.

Calling the protagonist the Penitent One, will only ever remind me of the Negative One from the Countdown episode of I.T. Crowd, it's spoken with the same tone and cadence. I know a lot of effort went into creating this game, and I remember looking forward to it for at least a year prior to its release, but so much about it seems to have missed the mark for me, and I always come back in an attempt to change my mind, because it does have a lot going for it. But the long-winded npc speeches soon have my eyes glazing over.

Also, prompting me to press any button to continue when I die should include the buttons on the controller I'm using; Needing to press a key on the keyboard while I have a controller in-hand is just one more thing to frustrate me with tedium.

It's a very cool game that just isn't very fun to play.

A great game well worth the money especially with the free updates. An extremely solid Metroidvania with a beautiful art style, great music, and fluid gameplay. Tons of side quests and extra things on the side to keep you entertained throughout. New game plus and boss rush mode also help extend the play time. If I could describe the gameplay in one word it would be satisfying. The executions are brutal and fun to pull off. The combat is fluid and great. The enemies have great designs and all have different patterns to memorize. The bosses are incredible and are a blast to adapt and conquer. Their designs have a great warped monster feel that intimidate you. All areas of the combat and abilities have great depth and multitudes of options. Barely any complaints other than the game itself being somewhat vague in terms of gameplay and story. Be prepared to look up certain things  as there are a decent amount of stuff that gets overlooked in a first play through, but maybe that’s where the beauty of multiple play throughs  come in. The bosses do seem to come out of nowhere to me and I would’ve liked a little more build up, but that’s just me. The atmosphere and world it tries to build up is intriguing and breathtaking  but they seem to give a lot of questions and it leaves a good bit up to the player for interpretation.  I wanted to know the backstory how everything happened and there was just times I felt I was not being shown as much as I wanted. And while the final boss is great both endings felt slightly underwhelming and too cryptic, which is a fitting word for the story in general. Overall, I would definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys metroidvanias or a challenging video game with a great style. And while the story is a little too vague for my liking, the pros EASILY outweigh the cons. What’s great is REALLY GREAT and the cons are really just tiny nitpicks that don’t really dampen the experience a lot at all. For the price this game is a no-brainer for the enjoyment you’ll get. I cannot recommend enough.

If you don't have any though, it will simply tell you, "You are rid of guilt." 

And it just... clicked. The statue in question is in the pose of forgiving you, and somehow my weird brain internalized that. I bowed before the statue, and I am rid of my guilt. You have no idea how good that feels.. Now when I start to feel bad, I close my eyes, and I bow. And I am rid of guilt. 

No more hating myself for stupid little things, no more constant pain in my head. My heart feels so good right now. I can't even describe how amazing and life changing this is. And all from some random little in game moment out of nowhere my weird stupid brain decided to just, keep. 

I'm free... I'm finally free. And I can't stop crying tears of joy. thank you. Thank you.. Thank you.. thank you.

Oh, let me tell you about Blasphemous! It's a dark and twisted action-platformer that's a feast for fans of challenging gameplay and atmospheric storytelling. Developed by The Game Kitchen, this game immerses you in a macabre world inspired by Spanish folklore and religious imagery.

The first thing that strikes you is the stunning pixel art style. The visuals are incredibly detailed, with intricate animations and beautifully designed environments. Every corner of the game is dripping with grotesque and haunting art that adds to the eerie atmosphere.

Gameplay-wise, Blasphemous delivers tight and responsive controls, which are crucial for a game that demands precision platforming and combat. The combat system offers a satisfying variety of weapons and abilities that can be upgraded and customized to suit your playstyle. The boss battles are particularly noteworthy, offering challenging encounters that require strategy and skill to overcome.

One of the game's strongest aspects is its narrative. Blasphemous tells a cryptic and disturbing story through its world, characters, and collectibles. Every interaction and discovery adds to the lore, leaving players intrigued and hungry for more insight into the game's dark universe.

However, keep in mind that the difficulty level might be a turnoff for some players. The game doesn't hold back in challenging you, often requiring precise timing and execution. This can lead to moments of frustration, but the feeling of accomplishment when you finally conquer a tough section is worth it.

In a nutshell, if you're a fan of challenging action-platformers with a captivating and grim narrative, Blasphemous is right up your alley. The game's stunning art style, tight gameplay, and haunting atmosphere create an experience that's both visually striking and emotionally engaging. Just be prepared for a journey that tests your skills and patience as you navigate through a world steeped in dark fantasy and lore.

Simply the most complete indie game I've ever played.

Since the first days of release, when I played it for the first time. The game surprised me too much for its art, atmosphere, soundtrack and especially for the emphasis on the suffering that the characters are in such a complete story.

The game's story comes in bits and pieces. Every NPC you meet gives you something to think about and relate to others who live in the same world. Its conclusion is satisfying as well as the beginning of the game.

The artistic part of the game is impeccable. I recommend everyone who likes pixel art and game direction to acquire the art book for this game. The shorts in which the story is heavier make you imagine how the vision of this world is different from 2D. The in-game combat animations, such as executions and interactions with objects, are one of the best I've ever seen.

The work of the voice actors is good and creates an atmosphere that refers to the story. Of people's suffering.

The combat and movement of the characters is very fluid and that's what made me want to play more than twice and complete the game 100%. Very challenging to beat the second time with the DLC content.

Speaking of them. The game's DLCs are proof that the work with love still exists in some production companies. Especially the Independents who value the quality of the product. The sheer atmosphere of this game is a triumph. The depictions of religion and penance or punishments were awesome to see. The enemies disfigured, maimed but somehow still retained beauty. Not to mention Angels. The bosses are a highlight too. Not only are the designs good, but the telegraphs and feel of them was amazing. For this world alone, this game is worth playing. The voice acting is brilliant too. Not one actor stood out as being worse. It feels like the team that made this poured everything they could to make it stand out from its peers, but sadly, I think they could have done more.

Platforming really stands out as being undercooked. You never really get any upgrades except for QoLs like being faster or dashing faster. You don't get a double jump, inversion, speed or something more unique. The gates of this game are mostly held in the Relics. When you obtain one it helps in areas by revealing secret paths. 

Weapon variety is nonexistent. By itself. that isn't a problem, but even the upgrade system leaves a lot to be desired with most upgrades not providing much to the sword except more damage and some basic moves. The 2nd game will remedy this, as has been seen in trailers. 

Puzzles and hints can be insanely hard to figure out at times. Usually context is given and you can figure it out, but for things like why you should invest in the Church for no apparent reason or painting puzzles, it was really confusing and hard to know without a guide. Most of the time I didn't need a guide at all, but for those few specific times, it kills the enjoyment. I never use wikis or guides in games and I avoid them like the plague.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Apart from the problems listed this game shines. Trust me, those problems go by the wayside once you're in the loop of exploring and connecting paths. The atmosphere will carry you so hard that you won't even think about anything except this game until you finish it. If you're a fan of metroidvanias and you're even thinking of getting this, don't. Buy it, can't go wrong.

Its a good metrovania game.

The artstyle is gorgeous, the world is dark and brutal, seriously, you brutally kill the enemies, OST is perfect as well, it fits the tone, going from calm, to unnerving to epic.

The gameplay is solid, specially the combat, its fair for the most part, you will struggle a lot at the start, but has you acquire more abilities and upgrades, you'll truly see the full potential of the combat system, your main method of dmg is your sword Mea Culpa, which you can upgrade and unlock several abilities for, like plunge or lunge attack or stronger combos, you also obtain Prayers which are essentially spells, and theres a lot of them that can be either offensive or defensive, fitting the situation. 

Bosses are well done and balanced, with some really creepy designs as well, they're challenging and you can use your many tools to approach each encounter.

The DLC bosses are far harder than the base ones, so anyone looking for a challenge has that to look for.

Speaking of, once you complete the game youre allowed into NG+, which increases the difficulty, you get to keep your abilities and items, but you lose all your HP and Fervor (magic) upgrades, as well as your healing Flasks, near the start of the run you can also choose a specific challenge, which changes how the run will play, such has halving your melee dmg but increasing your Fervor potential, making you a spellcaster essentially.

General difficulty of the game, not too challenging, its a lot easier than the similar game Hollow Knight, having played both i can say this for sure, buts its not easy by any means, this game will pull no punches for mistakes. 

One particular complain i have to mention is that i often ran into bugs that hindered my progress and forced me to reload the game, the most common one was related to an enemy that resembles a naked ghost woman with a rapier bugging out and becoming unkillable, and shes sometimes used in rooms where youre forced to kill all enemies, so you can guess what happens there. 

Also yeah, this game has quite a bit of nudity. 

Final thoughts, its an excellent game, you can see the devs put a lot of passion into it, specially with the world building which from my understanding was heavily inspired by religions from Spain, i think there was a guide on steam that went into detail in that regard. 

Anyway, i give it an 8/10, cant wait for the upcoming sequel in a couple of weeks.

[h1]Blasphemous[/h1]
[i]Finding equal parts redemption and frustration in this pixelated purgatory[/i]

[b]Blasphemous[/b], developed by The Game Kitchen, offers players a visually striking and deeply atmospheric journey into a twisted world of religious fervour, grotesque monsters, and unforgiving challenges. While it excels in certain areas, it falters in others, resulting in an experience that is both captivating and equally frustrating.

[u][b]Visual Splendour[/b][/u]: [b]Blasphemous[/b] immediately captures players' attention with its hauntingly beautiful pixel art style. Every frame is meticulously crafted, portraying a macabre world that is equal parts unsettling and captivating. From the grotesque enemies to the intricate level designs, the game's visuals are undoubtedly its strongest asset, creating an immersive atmosphere that draws players into its dark narrative.

[u][b]Devout Combat[/b][/u]: The combat in [b]Blasphemous[/b] is a double-edged sword. On one hand, the game offers a diverse array of weapons and abilities that allow players to customise their approach to combat. The brutal and visceral animations make each encounter feel impactful. However, the combat can often feel clunky and imprecise, leading to frustrating deaths that feel more due to the game's mechanics rather than the player's skill. The difficulty curve can also be uneven, swinging from manageable to downright punishing in a matter of moments.

[u][b]Penitent Progression[/b][/u]: [b]Blasphemous[/b] introduces a unique progression system that ties into its grim narrative. Players accrue "Mea Culpa" points to unlock new abilities and improve stats, allowing for a sense of character growth. Exploration is rewarded with hidden secrets and challenging platforming sections that test players' dexterity and problem-solving skills. However, the lack of a clear map and navigation system can lead to confusion and endless backtracking, especially towards the end of the game where it's not clear where the player is supposed to go which really dampened my enthusiasm for it.

[u][b]Narrative Ambiguity[/b][/u]: While [b]Blasphemous[/b] boasts a captivating world and intriguing lore, the storytelling can be frustratingly opaque. Much of the narrative is left to interpretation, and important plot points are often obscured behind cryptic symbolism. While this approach can create an air of mystery, it can also leave players feeling disconnected from the overarching narrative, especially if they are seeking a more concrete understanding of the world they are navigating.

[u][b]Soundscapes of Suffering[/b][/u]: The audio design in [b]Blasphemous[/b] enhances the eerie atmosphere, with hauntingly beautiful music and eerie sound effects that contribute to the game's sense of foreboding. The sombre melodies and chilling ambient sounds combine to create an auditory experience that complements the game's visual aesthetics.

[u][b]Conclusion[/b][/u]:

[b]Blasphemous[/b] is an ambitious endeavour that brings players into a dark and twisted world brimming with religious iconography and brutal challenges. Its mesmerising visuals and unique progression system are definite highlights, but the occasionally clunky combat mechanics and narrative ambiguity hold it back from achieving true metroidvania greatness. If you can weather the storm of frustration, and trust me it gets incredibly frustrating towards the end of the game, and embrace the game's haunting atmosphere, [b]Blasphemous[/b] offers a rewarding experience that will stick with you long after the credits roll despite its many shortcomings.

[u][b]Pros[/b][/u]:

- Captivating pixel art visuals
- Unique progression system
- Atmospheric audio design

[u][b]Cons[/b][/u]:

- Clunky combat mechanics
- Narrative ambiguity
- Lack of clear navigation tools

[h1]One word or phrase to sum up the experience[/h1]
[i]Twisted metroidvania that takes players through the madness of religious fervour.[/i]

[i]None experienced during my playthrough of the game.[/i]

With the second game coming, I decided to finally leave a review.

Blasphemous is a game that I was aware even before it came out, due to the marketing, and have been played the game almost since its release. It might not be the best metroidvania out there, but it's almost everything that I'm looking for in a game of the genre: a game that I can have fun playing and exploring fully without the need of becoming a pro at it.

The combat is engaging, although you only have one weapon, you can also parry (with a perfect parry option), dodge, and you also have a ranged attack and a special move, called Prayer, that you can choose from over 20, counting the ones that were added with the expansions. One of the biggest selling points when the game came out was the violence, which can be seen through the executions of the enemies, with almost everyone having their own animation.

The graphics are not gonna make your PC explode, but it's very well done, everything looks like a work of art, and I really felt that they were getting better with time, as the last expansion has some absolutely beautiful imagery. I didn't find the soundtracks as remarkable as the visuals, and never really felt the need to listen to it after the first time I beat the game (with the exception of the new stages and bosses that are fought in subsequent playthroughs). It's definitely good and matches the game perfectly, but experiencing it one time was enough for me.

The story is... certainly one of the parts of this game. It can be very confusing, trying to understand everything that is happening, as the information is presented very cryptically at first, at least Ionly felt like I really understood the story after playing the final expasion. But the gist of it is easy to get, just the details that take a little more time to wrap your head around. It's very much like dark souls in that aspect.

As for the difficulty, it was easy in the first playthrough, but hard after. So, here is how the game goes: you have that first time you play through it, then you can start a new game plus, in which you will have the content of both of the expansions available, as well as the option to impose certain 1 out of 3 restrictions on your character, that after being beaten, will grant you some equipment that'll give you positive effects, some really good, some kinda worthless. The first time is kinda ok, you might die, but it's hard to get stuck, as for the ng+ stuff, you might get hard stuck on some of it, but the method of hitting your head against the wall till you break it works every time.

After having beaten everything, with the exception of the boss rush mode, I can say that the game is one of the best and most accessible metroidvania out there, although the sudden increase in its price makes it hard to recommend buying it out of a sale.

Overall I would recommend it... but with some notable caveats and warnings.
First, the good. The art style is fairly standout, it's not something everyone will like, seeing guys junk, old bloody disfigured corpses, and everything in the older style that they use, but it's different from most games, and generally most will probably find it interesting.
The world is fairly big and the game decently long, there's some replay ability as well. It's not too short or anything.
Some interesting lore and story, not personally my cup of tea as much, but still present and for many it may be good.

Now the bad...
The bugs, first and foremost OH GOD THE BUGS! Dropping from a ledge or platforming, or jumping in a fight? Well I hope you don't mind losing controls on your character, getting stuck in mid air randomly unable to move, having all inputs locked, or countles other things. I've had these happen in boss battles, or while exploring over half a dozen times, some requiring game restarts and losing progress.
Never alt tab out during jumping, or elevators, or various other conditions, it wont end well, if it ever ends...
Or just the simple ones like not being able to press a button to respawn on the gamepad when you die, and needing to go tap it on the keyboard instead for some reason (when you were using gamepad to play, only ever was able to respawn with gamepad once my entire 30 hours so far).

Next, input queuing, and combat. It's bad. They only seem to really queue inputs on the sword. So slash, slash... you'll double slash. Slash, jump, slash... you'll just stand there double slashing, no slash then jumping to air slash. No slash then sprint to slash, only attacks queue so if you ever want to do anything other than stand still, learn to never spam the attack button. That said, it's outright bugged here in areas, multiple cases I've input other commands before, or done other things and it ignores them, seeming to prefer having my character stand still and just swing out of range of the enemy but readily dying. Overall this is my biggest complaint of the game, the controls are just insanely unreliable feeling for a game where you're trying to not take a single hit, or do perfect actions. I loved challenging myself in hollow knight, and even did some dumber challenge runs in dark souls or Sekiro, but no way I'm ever trying that in this game. 

The platforming, it's also kind of odd. Sometimes you'll walk near the edge of a ledge, but not fall good, you weren't over the edge yet), but walk back away from the edge and suddenly fall/slip down through the ground? Or the air jump via attacks thing, seems very inconsistent and unreliable, overall a number of problems here on the movement side, but not too bad since there's not much of real platforming challenges in this game that use these all, so constantly annoying, but not a game breaker.
That said, it adds to frusteration early on when falling in some places is instant death, and for a sometimes long run back.
Later on there's the bloodstained ritual of the night co lap and challenges... that's the real problem, that's where it hurts, and I just gave up on the last challenge because the movement/platforming was just not reliable/consistent. At least in Hollow Knights house of blades, I just failed a ton because I still sucked, eventually got gud... here... changing controllers or trying mouse and keyboard just in case my main one was failing... nope, it's just their input and control system having issues and bugs and stuff.

Bosses, some are good, overall mostly towards the easy side. Though also again with the bugs or oddities and lack of polish. One got stuck, another crashed the game, another got locked and I couldn't hurt him once, others just jump/get outside the visible screen and make it very hard to really deal with that when you can't see their tells or stuff, and then some attacks do seem rather... lacking for consistent ways to evade them, but honestly that might just be me not having found them yet, again, not like I was retrying these all 10 or 20 times to learn all their details, nor did I ever look online for guides, most I beat first time, others generally less than three tries until the final two of sorts, took a few more on them. At least on my first play through.

So overall... so many problems that keep it from really being one I can highly recommend, but the world and core stuff is there, so if you've dealt with the other main games and want a new decent metroidvania... it's still worth it to try at least I'd say. Despite it's issues better than some other ones, but again because of them still held back. Given how long it's been out, don't expect these issues to get bug fixed. Heck, they just released a new update today, and I immediately noticed it had broken some more things with it.

---{ The Good }---
Blasphemous kept me engaged much longer than I expected. The gameplay is great with the right amount of challenge (for me) that really feels fulfilling when overcome. I played it on my Steam Deck, which is just perfect for metroidvanias like this, and it runs great! Encountered slight bugs here and there, but nothing major. I LOVE the art style, it has really good world-building that sucks you right in. I also really liked the music, but some areas did not have any which is a bit of a bummer.

---{ The Not So Good }---
I'm really not a fan of missable achievements and blasphemous has multiple of them that are also associated with story lines. It's really easy to miss these as the steps required are quite obscure and I have no idea how I should've known these without looking them up. I also missed a lot of main unlockables, [spoiler] called relics in this game [/spoiler], for the gated progression while finishing the story and gaining those can also be obscure, which I wasn't a fan of. After ending the story there was a lot of backtracking that I felt I wanted to "finish off" as the story had already ended. There are also different endings, but I've read that you would be able to get all endings in one run. If you want to get all achievements, be prepared to play the game 2.5 times WITH GUIDES. Finally I'm not a fan of how the pogo mechanic works in blasphemous.

---{ The Verdict }---
A great game, definitely a recommed for me, but be prepared for some challenges (and annoyances) along the way!

and my god, this update changed my initial 7/10 feeling to a solid 9/10. map clarity, rest point teleportation, absolutely LEGENDARY spanish dub, bonus bosses in ng+, penitences that changes your playstyle in ng+... and they could've just stopped there and it'd still be an amazing game, but no they went beyond. the true ending got me super hyped for the sequel and i can't wait to go back in and sin even harder.

[b][u]positives:[/u][/b]
+ gothic gruesome catholicism is lit
+ extremely high quality pixel art
+ OST with great boss music (also on spotify)
+ highly replayable with ng+ penitences, different prayer/rosary builds
+ bonus round: penitence of true guilt is the correct way to experience the game. no healing, one health bar and that's it, makes you really think of your approach to fights. shame that it's ng+ only
+ game length is just enough to where it doesn't feel like it's padding your game time
+ able to inherit relics that allows for some sequence skipping in ng+
+ spanish dub is god tier

[b][u]negatives:[/u][/b]
- backtracking can feel really awful early on until you invest 20k into unlocking rest point teleportation
- some prayers are simply better and stronger than the rest. debla of the light and tiento to your thorned hairs can breeze you through the game
- having to rediscover the map upon ng+, not a problem for me personally but might be for some
- collectible tracking is kinda awful unless you abuse map markers. i wish there's an easier way that isn't "run through every possible spot to see if you've missed one"
- true ending has two(!) points of no return and if you miss it you have to go through a playthrough again
- when i tried the "requiem aeternam" achievement back in 2020 i needed to start a fresh playthrough, ng+ didn't count, found out the hard way, seems like they fixed it upon some googling, sadge

[b][u]tldr: [/u][/b]
to put it bluntly, the game isn't really doing anything 'new' or groundbreaking, but i ended up doing 6 playthroughs and getting all achievements, so i will go with "yes it is pretty heckin' good".

While Blasphemous attempts to capture the spirit of Dark Souls and Castlevania, it fundamentally fails to achieve what it sets out to. Both the lore and gameplay try to hint at a level of depth that they lack. Many attacks give no indication that they hit through your parry or dodge, making these critical tools unreliable, and even simply evading attacks is inconsistent due to awful hitboxes. Additionally, enemies have colossal health pools, needlessly slowing down the simple movement from area to area. Furthermore, the game's fundamentals are lacking. Level design ranges from inoffensive to atrocious, and combat is much the same. Most secrets are either out in the open or behind an undisguised progression gate, or else behind the game's various breakable walls, many of which lack any sort of indication and are simply discovered by luck.

In conclusion, Blasphemous takes a lot from its inspirations, but fails in its own additions and furthermore fails to replicate their strengths. I have many more criticisms, but this review is long as it is so I'll leave it here. I hope for the developers' next project, they focus more on fundamentals and less on copying their inspirations.

My complaints are minor. Firstly, there are a handful of advanced movement mechanics that feel really finnicky to pull off. To be very forgiving this game is a 2/5.

Thematic, visuals, sprite work, music, voice acting, and story all get a resounding 5/5. Genuinely some of the most interesting concepts I've seen in a video game and very well executed might I add. However all these factors simply cannot pull this game together for an enjoyable experience.

While the movement and platforming in this game feels pretty good for the most part, the combat is some of my least favorite I've experienced. For starters you are forced to stay still for string attacks while grounded, meaning that once you swing your sword if you're character is on the ground, you are forced to stay there until the attack or combo is over. This makes positioning against enemies absolutely atrocious, not to mention that your attacks will push some enemies backwards out of your attack radius so you can't even land a full damage combo on them. The spacing and positioning against a lot of enemies is horrible due to this so you're usually forced to use jump attacks or the high damage plunging attack. Another factor that greatly affects your boss fights is that your character and enemies all have a hitbox which means if you get too close to an enemy/boss you will take damage. This would almost be forgiveable if it didn't also stagger your character and completely interrupt your movement and attacks. Keep in mind that a lot of these bosses are either very large and take up a big portion of the screen or are constantly on top of your character attacking you so you're not only getting attacked but you're being staggered by their model's hitbox. The parry function works effectively on maybe 4 enemies in the whole game and is genuinely unintuitive to use if not entirely ineffective and a waste of a combat tool. After successfully parrying most attacks you're usually unable to attack in time afterwards our you're just sent backwards away from the enemy you parried. There is almost never a reward for a properly timed parry even though you're forced to use it in certain fights even when it's clearly disadvantageous. Your recovery time for a lot of attacks and or dodges is egregiously long and leaves you open far too often as well.
Straying away from combat a little bit I'll mention that some of the boss fights are just genuinely horrible. They do not strike any balance between difficult and just outright unfair. Half of the bosses are just out of reach and don't allow you to do any meaningful damage with a combo so you're instead getting one aerial attack in every minute or so. The bosses do not have very meaningful "patterns", where you do not feel like you're actively learning a better way to fight them. Instead you slowly realize that strategy is futile and you have to resort to getting single hits in when you can. I want to mention that the second to last boss was far more difficult (unintuitive) than the actual final boss, which granted isn't a cardinal sin in the gaming community but after spending upwards of 30 minutes on one boss only to have the final boss be over in 5 seems a bit ludicrous.
To sum up combat I would say that there is absolutely no flow to it and it feels clunky and unrewarding. Upgrading your combat skills really doesn't feel impactful except for when you first unlock them. Every upgrade after that seems trivial and doesn't impact gameplay whatsoever.
Onto the world/map layout I want to say that the first hour of the game can feel a bit frustrating to explore and understand but after clearing a few areas it all starts to connect really well. I think the teleporting function could've been introduced earlier or just in a better way as the backtracking can feel very exhausting. You should be able to teleport more directly to where you need to go but I'll be forgiving since at least there is a teleporting function at all. The map however is next to useless if you're looking for any specific thing. Sure it shows you the rooms and ways to get into them but none of the npc's that are crucial are actually marked with a name. They simply have a vague icon and do not give any context when you hover over them making it a bit of a guessing game the first time around.
Lastly I'd like to say that the upgrades to your characters stats (health, mana, etc.)  All seem pretty substantial. HOWEVER, there is almost no reason to upgrade your bile flask as it forces you into a certain play style. When upgrading your flask it will increase the amount of health replenished but in turn will reduce your amount of flasks with no option. This means that instead of healing when you can you have to heal when you're close to death. You don't get to pick and choose when you heal to avoid high damage attacks just to top your health off, you have to either waste half your flask topping off or wait until you're very low health. It's a blatantly horrible trade off with no advantage nor do they mention that upgrading your flask will permanently change it.
Overall I did not have a good time playing this game and would've sooner refunded it had I known how it would play out. I don't think the story and visuals made up for the experience at all and I ended up forcing myself to beat the game in the hopes that the final boss and ending would've been incredible and redeemed the whole game. They did not. 
Don't buy this game for a good time OR for a challenge as it does neither. Instead I would read up on the lore and such and check out the awesome artwork via pictures and videos instead of forcing yourself to play it.

I kept getting this game recommended on steam when I was looking for more of a "souls" itch. I was never really a big metroidvania guy. I haven't played one in a decade and a half. After giving this game a shot, I bought 7 more soulslike-metroidvania games. 

It's really fun. That being said, it's not Dark Souls. I would not go in with the expectation of building your own class or having weapon variety. I think of this game as more of a slight nod to the Souls series while doing its own thing with its own spin. It's only really comparable to Dark Souls in the vague sense that parry and dodge are core combat mechanics, has a fragmented story with lore in the item descriptions, no hand holding side quests, and rest spots. 

The gameplay is dodging and parrying in a 2D Metroidvania. Blasphemous has a nice twist on the Dark Souls 2 death mechanic. In DS2, when you died you lost bits of your max health bar until 50% max health. In Blasphemous, it's your skill bar/magic that will lose up to 50% depending on how many times you die. I say it's nice because losing your skill/magic bar is not even remotely detrimental like DS2 half health was.

Another twist Blasphemous does for the soulslike genre is instead of chasing after your souls when you die like in DS, you chase after bits of your skill/magic bar.

[h1]Catholic castlevania for comeheads[/h1]

It’s time to brush up on your Latin, polish that statue of St. Bartholomew, and bust out the cat-o-nine-tails for some self-flagellation, Blasphemous is here to remind you of what Catholics have known for nearly 2,000 years: suffering is not only a part of life, it’s the entire point.

Developer The Game Kitchen teamed up with Team 17 to release what can only be described as a Medieval Catholicism-inspired metroidvania, and the themes, setting, and general atmosphere hit the nail on the cross…I mean head. Oozing with brutal, grotesque, and ultra-gory visuals and lore, Blasphemous is also a tight, fluid, side-scrolling ARPG that plays incredibly well. While mechanically the game doesn’t do much to break the mould, thematically it’s like nothing out there, and I am actually shocked that this type of setting has never really been fully explored in a video game before. Catholicism, especially in the Middle Ages, was, quite literally, all about guilt and suffering, and Blasphemous takes this theme and brilliantly merges it with a game formula that perfectly suits the idea: die in violent and vicious ways, get resurrected, and do it again.

Players take on the role of “The Penitent One”, allegedly the survivor of the “Silent Sorrow” wreaked by “The Miracle” who must collect (and suffer) through various humiliations and deaths in order to save the land. Similar to games like Dark Souls, the lore in Blasphemous is handed out in vague, obfuscating methods like item descriptions and cryptic conversations with NPCs. The Game Kitchen went all out with committing to the themes of the game, and if you didn’t spend your whole childhood going to church or Catholic school, you may need to brush up on your terminology and history. The dedication to this idea, from the writing and level design to the enemies, weapons, items, and menus, is staggering and I loved every second of it. Your abilities come from customizable a customizable rosary with slots that can be unlocked to fit rosary beads that grant bonuses like extra health, stronger attacks, better dodging etc. and all come with thematically appropriate lore and reasoning. Collectibles come in the form of relics, AKA bits and pieces of the bodies of Saints that have been martyred in various savage and sadistic ways—another point for historical accuracy—and your “magic” spells/abilities are found in various prayers that can also be equipped. You can even essentially buy indulgences to remove the levels of “guilt” that are obtained during each death that lower your health and fervour (power meter for prayers). I can’t gush enough about how each and every gameplay mechanic is built to fit with the themes and setting of the game. Sure, the mechanics are similar to other titles, but the manner in which they’re implemented and the style choices make Blasphemous a truly unique creature.

As far as gameplay goes, it’s a 2D side-scrolling action platformer with non-linear levels full of branching paths and secrets. You’ll spend ages exploring the levels, especially once you begin to unlock new traversal abilities that allow you to backtrack and access areas previously locked or inaccessible. Combat focuses mainly on Mea Culpa, the giant thorny sword wielded by our hero, which has its own tree of upgrades and unlocks with more complex and powerful movesets. Combat itself is both challenging and satisfying, with a solid sense of progression and visceral impacts and executions. Did I mention how gory this game is? Right from the get-go in the tutorial when the Penitent one fills up his conical helmet with blood from a vanquished foe and slaps it onto his head, you know this game is going to be brutally violent and messy. Players can jump, dodge, and parry enemy attacks, and the slow-drip stream of upgrades and gradually increasing difficulty keeps things interesting but never overwhelming or stagnant. From low-level goons to boss fights, you’ll be using every tool at your disposal to hack and slash your way to the end of the game.

Now while the level layouts are excellent, and combat feels great, what truly makes Blasphemous stand out from the crowd is, again, the focus on (or inspiration from) Medieval Catholicism. Enemy design is top notch, including self-flagellating monks that heal by whipping themselves, women chained to angelic statues that are used to smack the player, floating bishops in gaudy golden chairs that stab downwards, and so much more. Suffering, guilt, and blood coat the game from top to bottom, and almost every major character in the game has been through some form of mental and physical torment that then becomes the stylistic choice for their movesets and attacks. One of the characters is notorious for being so beautiful she melted her own face off with hot oil because people were paying too much attention to her and not enough to worshipping The Miracle. The level design also mirrors this, ranging from standard snow mountains and dungeons to gothic churches and sewers rife with floating miasma. This game also has my favourite achievement ever in a game, awarded after killing 666 enemies—how perfect.
 
I enjoy studying history and theology, and I went to Catholic school for most of my life. I also love metal and gory horror flicks, and this combination of bias led to me appreciate Blasphemous on multiple levels while also being consistently impressed with the amount of research that went into the game. I am in love with the aesthetic of this game, and it’s honestly a bonus that it plays as well it does. The level design, the various little details squeezed into each enemy and character, the visuals, the music, the lore…it all adds up to being a game that will be fun for any fan of the genre, but even better for players who are familiar with the history and iconography of the Catholic church. This game wasn’t on my radar until my Editor send the code my way because he thought I’d like it (and I did), but I am super grateful it found its way into my living room. Blasphemous is an excellent metroidvania with a fantastically realized setting and gorgeous, albeit barbaric, aesthetic. Highly recommended.

Originally I wanted to wait until the end to give a review, but for the sake of my own mental stability preventing me from finally killing myself, here's a review of Blasphemous.

At first I was introduced to this game through the music which had popped up in my playlist. For the summer sale the price of $25 down to $6.24, it seemed like a great deal. I had played Hollow Knight, all the big From Soft games, so I was looking for something challenging and I had heard good things about this so I figured why not. I blew through a lot of the game, and have like 45% completion after 6.6 hours. It was going good until it became abhorrent shit. I reached the Archcathedral Rooftops and found the worst shit I had ever seen in any game. Enemies that blocked my attacks while standing in idle. Becoming a penitent plinko as I would just get chained by attacks, all from one enemy who is just a reskin of Esdras.

Now, I would be willing to go explore more in case I was missing something, but moving around is so god awful, I would be able to make better progress walking around outside in real life. The lack of mobility is one of the worse parts about this game. The fastest way to move is spam the dodge, which I'm pretty sure doesn't even give immunity since of all the times I've used it I've found 0 immunity. This would be fine if I had some other form of movement, but nope, just a left, right, and jump. Anything like a constant sprint or just faster movement would make me want to backtrack and find new things, but one running pace through an entire area is my definition of tedious for the sake of being tedious.

Now I don't completely hate everything. The music, story, setting, artstyle, all masterpieces. The only catch is since everything is pixelated, telegraphs become so hard to read, you can't tell if you need to parry or dodge before your ass is already blasted in. An hour of my playtime is easily attributed to the hammer wielding fucks in the rooftops just spamming shit so I can't do anything.

I know my opinion will mean nothing given the very positive reputation this game has, I'm hoping to have new people who want to play this before the sequel comes out see what this game truly is. If you were wanting a fun, challenging game that puts a neat twist on the genre of 2D platformers, just play Hollow Knight. If you already have played Hollow Knight, play it again. I got this for 75% off and still feel ripped off. 

Also, why does it say "skilled hack'n slash"? Hack and slash is the worst strategy to have since enemies can just ping pong you to death, so you can't just go in and fight. Your best bet is turning to God and praying that you don't have a reskined enemy chain attack you until you die.

Edit: Well, 14 hours and 19 minutes, 81.5% completion later and I finished the game. Now I am legally able to criticize all I want. The major issues I had still remain, spammy enemies just kind of thrown together at times to make up for the lack of difficulty were very much present in the archcathedral rooftops, but I didn't know that was almost the end so it could have been worse. Still lazy design. I did more side stuff which made my main issue very clear, that being one dimensional combat. The lack of effective vertical attacks makes it so your best bet is parry and dodge and swing. Granted this comes at the cost of when the game lets you do it. I experienced several times my attacks would just not hit, most often on the Esdras ripoffs in rooftops just walking past my prayer spells attacks. This brings me to my next major issue, the lack of telegraphs. This mainly applies to Esdras and Crisanta who I found to be really hard to tell what attack they were doing, so I would just either parry or dodge and hope something good happens. Speaking of combat, hope you don't have anything like ladders or climbable walls near you, or you'll grab them involuntary and be open to get knocked off. Again, very present in archcathedral rooftops.

Again, I want to say I don't hate everything. They did good since the final boss was probably my favorite. Despite taking only 3 tries, it had neat pacing, cool visuals, and a puzzle aspect that didn't feel overused. It's a shame the rest of the game couldn't be like that. Sadly while I love the art in this game I'm going to have to give it a negative review purely off the the lack of quality in the enemy design and general gripes i have with metro games. The enemies in this game for the most part are annoying over quality or engaging. 90% of the monsters in the game are put in places that more of like make them environmental hazards than anything which is super annoying. The DREAD BACK TRACKING IS INSANE IN THIS GAME. PERIOD. While I don't find this in games normally, the annoyance of backtracking rears its head so much due to the enemies being awful quality. Now I may have been overpowered but most bosses I basically felt like I tanked with healing over actually caring for their attacks. The Boss are the highlight of the game but during my play through there was a huge lull where there were none until I fought many of them back to back after of course backtracking. Now I went in blind but 90% of the time I had no idea where to go but the fact that places are kept away from the player with little or no explanation via items and relics is extremely annoying. The fact that a ton of the game is gated by a key you can just pass up if you don't have the money and forget about is mind boggling. Another extremely annoying feature I hate in all metros that have it, insta kill spikes and collision damage. Hollow knight is the best metro in the world and guess what.. no insta kills. Wanna know why? Insta kill hazards and the most annoying time wasting things i despise in all games. I have no idea why games include "spike insta kills" like who even likes these? I have never had someone die to spikes full hp with full health pot or fall of a cliff and be like " yup I'd prefer to die than just tp back 5 seconds before missing a quarter to half my hp for the whoopsie daisy i just did." Now let's talk collision damage. This game shouldn't have it at all. While this would make the game far easier as I swear most of the damage I take is collision and not actually getting hit, it's just super annoying to have an enemies knock you back with their attack and sit on you with collision damage. It also makes small area fights feel the worse. 

All in all I'm very mixed on the game but I'm sticking with a 5/10 with a negative. The game's annoying game play qualities and backtracking with little automated map marker make this game really rough to play blind and actually finish.

Metroidvanias aren't really a genre I do well with so buying this was a risk, but it was $6 bucks so fuck it!

Blasphemous seems to take a much more open approach to it's world map than other games in the genre gating off not progression but mostly [i]optional[/i] content and items. So with the tools you start with you can go where you want when you want to. Another thing I really appreciated was the placement of some of the more important powerups, with the item to make a level less of an obstacle usually found within the area itself instead of halfway across the giganto-maze-world! The areas standout from eachother and if you're a fan of the Souls game, grimdark, or Spanish Catholicism aesthetics you're gonna love this pixel art.

Only real negatives that stood out to me was teleporters for faster world travel seem few and far between, maybe a couple more sprinkled in would have made long treks back to levels less of a slog(although even then there's usually some side content or secrets you'll inevitably find along the way). Another thing I didn't like was how the free update content was added to the original game's map. This might be a niche problem since players who played day one wouldn't have experienced this, but the worst time I had with the game was entering the post-launch content area unbeknownst and getting my shit kicked in by a boss that was clearly meant for players more late game. In a game where you can tackle the available bosses in any order and still do decent damage to them regardless of where you are in the game this boss felt like a brick wall the game had promised never to construct. Another thing that came up a bit too often were odd bugs usually caused by colliding with an enemy while doing another action. I had bugs as annoying as not being able to jump, zooming down ladders 4x faster than possible, and even one where all of the breakable items on the levels turned invisible! Even with these complaints they were minor moments for me and only slightly fudged up my time with an otherwise fantastic game!

In an era where violent, brutal, and stylish games are dying, Blasphemous was made for all of those who enjoyed classic 2d Metroidvania platformers. The game oozes with a Spanish Catholic styled art direction. Its grim and dark like Warhammer 40k /Berserk levels of grim dark. That being said the game itself inst inherently edgy or cartoonishly immature with how it handles these elements. The game play is reminiscent of a hybrid of Castlevania and Megaman Zero with difficulty that matches. The first two bosses of the game can come across as brutal due to the open world aspect of the game. You are given no direction and are free to traverse wherever you wish so long as you have the upgrades necessary to do so. It is addicting as it is fun. This game has its fair share of bugs and some crazy difficulty spikes at time, but if you are diligent you can finish a starting play through mostly blind. There are multiple endings all of which require different routes to take in game, so you will need to do multiple playthroughs. The dlc fights also are easily some of the best highlights and the ost is nothing short of immersive. I didnt think much of it at first but it grew on me to the point that the songs have become some of my favorite vieogame tracks ever. This game is a must play

I was cruising along until I hit about 79% with a total play time of 20 hours and the last 20% took another 30 hours and I thought I was almost done, so I spent an entire weekend working on finishing it, grabbing some achievements on the way. This required a lot of back and forth running across the huge map, even with all of the teleports unlocked, which is kind of an agonizing way to play because it does get a little tedious. I couldn't break away from playing it though and before I knew it, I spent nearly 28 hours collecting stuff for collection achievements - time I will not get back, I lament. I feel a little guilty. I was becoming impatient because I knew I was right at the end but because I was missing *that one thing* to help me make actual progress, I had to give up trying to figure it out on my own and I turned to a guide. I loved the world of blasphemous and often would reflect on the little animations taking place on the screen if they were done in a first person perspective - what a bloody, disgusting, good game it would be. The combat was synced really well through and through, but of course, as in any RPG, as your character gets stronger and stronger, the game becomes easier and easier. Less time is spent trying to figure out how to survive and more time is spent enjoying the boss encounters.

As an avid Hollow Knight fan, Blasphemous had been suggested to me several times due to also being a Metroidvania. And with the announcement of Blasphemous 2, it was a sign that it was finally time to take the plunge into the world of Blasphemous. 

I can say for sure that the presentation was easily the strongest part of Blasphemous. The visuals, the music, the symbolism, the lore, everything is absolutely flawless. The environments and characters are all beautiful with gothic, religious themes, and despite a somewhat dreary and de-saturated color palette, it makes everything in the game look hauntingly beautiful... and also really bizarre at times, but in a good way. The music perfectly fits every moment, from the ominous treks through the levels to the clashes with the game's bosses. Every visual, every theme, it all is crafted beautifully to create a very unique feeling that few games could hope to replicate. 

In standard Metroidvania fare, the game has deep lore that really isn't spelled out for you, but if you're willing to do a deep dive you can definitely get lost in the expansive lore. Perhaps what most intrigues me is the fact that everything in the game feels very deliberate. Every name, every image, every symbol, all of it was designed with purpose. If something seems like a coincidence in the game... it definitely isn't. 

However, somewhat ironically... I actually found the gameplay to be the weakest part of Blasphemous. Now, don't mistake my words; Blasphemous's gameplay is by no means bad. It's just that the gameplay is fairly standard compared to the excellent aesthetics. Combat has a somewhat "heavy" feel to it, being a bit slow but methodical with standard attack, jump, parry, and dodge mechanics. While I appreciate that it's a slower speed by design, i will say that it sometimes made the combat not flow as well as it could have, as it can be very stop-and-go at times and lacks a bit of oomph. The one thing that I do think is a little BS though is that knockbacks and knockdowns are a major issue in this game, as lack of recovery iframes and a very slow getting up animation can result in stunlocks from certain groups of enemies and even certain bosses. This wasn't game-breaking, but it was a frequent annoyance. 

Level design is excellent, as you'd expect in a Metroidvania, with plenty of inter-connected areas and secrets to discover, and your character progression is rewarded by exploration. That said, it does feel like environmental hazards are more of an issue than the enemies, as by far the most damage I took while discovering came from environment rather than combat. This isn't necessarily a bad thing as it does create tension, but I'd be lying if I said certain areas weren't a slog to go through at times due to the game's slower pace causing platforming to be a little clumsy at times, especially since climbing up ledges takes a bit longer than I'd like. And yes, I have to mention; insta-death spike pits are a pain, but not an insurmountable one. 

Most of the bosses in the game were... fairly average, honestly. I found the bosses more memorable for their bizarre designs than for their mechanical value. Out of the 10 bosses I fought, only about 2 of them were ones I'd say I thoroughly enjoyed for their mechanics. A lot of the bosses felt very RNG-dependent, or too basic from having very repetitive AI. And without spoiling too much... I can definitely say the final boss was the one I enjoyed the least. I'm all for a fair challenge, but sometimes the bosses either felt too simple or felt difficult for the wrong reasons, and there weren't many bosses who reached that desired middle ground. That said, I didn't outright hate any boss (except the final one), but they just felt like a somewhat flat note at times. 

However, despite the criticisms I found myself excited for Blasphemous 2 after playing this game. The mechanics of this game are solid, and with a bit of fine tuning they could reach even greater heights. The presentation of the game was already top notch, so I'm immensely curious to see how the devs can improve the sequel to follow up on this game. Blasphemous definitely feels like a work of art, and while some mechanics could use some refining, it's still a fun game throughout.

The art direction is immaculate and fits perfectly with the main focus on gritty yet mystical religious horror, making it stand out among its similarly-pixelated brethren. The combat feels as weighty as the guilt that festers within our pointy-headed protagonist. There are some bizarre design choices, and oddly I enjoyed it more on replay, but those nitpicks pale in comparison to a unique concept delivered well. Strong recommend.

I am not really a Metroidvania player. People rave about Hollow Knight, but it did nothing for me; I did not make much progress with it, Rogue Legacy or Dead Cells. But something about Blasphemous engages, haunts and utterly captivates my mind. I love it. I may never beat it, and that's OK: I literally play and re-play areas in multiple save files just to explore and [i]enjoy[/i] the dark, twisted, compelling world of Cvstodia.

The world-building is sublime. The concepts, themes, pixel art and music are all absolutely [i]gorgeous[/i]. The boss fights are both interesting and fair, and the occasional frustration -- there are many opportunities for falling deaths -- is more than compensated for by the overall Zen flow of the game. A lot of reviews complain about sluggish controls, but that has not been my experience: the Penitent One handles smoothly with mouse-and-keyboard (which is how I play, exclusively). By comparison, I actually found Hollow Knight controls to be too "floaty" and Dead Cells a bit too sensitive.

Huge value even at full price, and the DLC adds further to the overall experience and is well worth it (in my opinion). I cannot wait for Blasphemous 2! :D

Let me start out by saying this is my favorite game ever and I have played a lot of games. I bought it simply out of curiosity and I have never been happier with a decision. The art is beautiful, the story is amazing, and the combat, to me, is awesome and rewarding to learn. The game is hard, yes, but what better way to make you invest time and really sink in to this masterpiece. I have seen a lot of reviews talking about the hitboxes and bugs but I personally never had any negative experiences with hitboxes, nor did I experience any bugs at all. Some may find the hitboxes clunky but I feel it adds to the arcade feel of the game if you know what I mean. I do not want to sound like I'm praising this game while it has no flaws because that is just not true. 

Pros:
- visuals
- controls
- boss fights
- skill tree
- items that improve powers and skill (again showing that playing the game makes you more powerful
- fun and atmospheric platforming
- hidden quests
- get better as you progress (meaning health and overall skill)
- lots of content and paths after beating the game the first time
- amazing voice acting
- fun puzzles and parkour
- fun collectibles
- multiple + secret endings

Cons:
- poor map makes it kind of hard to know where you are in the first playthrough
- some mechanics can go unexplained which requires some tinkering on your end
- (some may consider difficulty a con) but it really gets easier as you play
- lack of any new weapons throughout the game
- while enemies differentiate per area they stay in the exact same spot

Off the top of my head, those are the main cons that I feel should be addressed, however, I MUST EMPHASIZE that this game is amazing and you should really give it a shot if you are curious just like I was. The game is very addictive and you will definitely be surprised by how deep the game actually is with its themes and takes on religion and identity. Do not worry about any offense given toward certain races, genders, or religions. This has nothing to do with that. Please buy the game (which is very fairly priced for its free add-ons) and simply enjoy the ride. You will fail many times but once you can get the hang of it the game is so much fun and makes you beg for more. (the sequel is coming out btw)

Such a disappointment,
I really wanted to like this game but the gameplay is just so awful.  Don't get me wrong, the art and aesthetic is incredible, which is why its so upsetting that it's wasted on a game that plays like this.  

The main gameplay is combat and platforming.

Platforming:
The platforming is boring and unoriginal, its been done so many times before and most of the time, much better.  The movement is stiff and joyless, it feels like someone just tried to program the most generic basic jump, dodge, and walk physics possible.  
Obviously a game like Celeste has masterpiece platforming so I don't expect it to be on that level.  But even a game like Hollow Knight which focuses more on combat and exploration has way better platforming than this game.  That being said, Hollow Knight's platforming is still great, but not only is Blasphemous's platforming not great, it isn't even mediocre.  Hell, most flash games I've played have better platforming than this.

Combat:
The hitboxes make no sense and your dodge is janky and inconsistent.  You can't move while attacking unless you're in air, so you're either going to be jumping around swinging over your opponent's head or stuck on the ground locking into an attack animation.  Your parry is generic and lame, just hit the parry button a second before getting hit and you do a block and counter attack animation.  This part is definitely a nitpick but even the parry and counter attack animation feels like it takes too long to finish, made me want to avoid even parry because of how tedious it felt.  That wouldn't be that bad except for the fact that everything else feels slow in this game too, the attack, the dodge, casting a spell, healing, your walk and jump speed.  Having slower paced combat can be fine if done well, for example maybe if you compensate for the lack of speed with more complexity in the combat system.  But the combat is very surface level and plain, there's very little you can do to get better, so from the start you've pretty much "mastered" it since you can't get much better at such a shallow system.  And as I mentioned a ton of hitboxes make no sense, one enemy drags a bell behind them and swings it at you.  If you dodge behind them when they swing, then they just immediately go back to dragging the bell behind them.  And since you're also behind them, you get hit by the bell, even though it's not an attack.  It's the enemy going back to a neutral position from an attack.   Also even after the attack, when the bell sits on the ground, if you touch it youre taking full damage.  Thats only one example of course but that rough, unpolished, feel fills the entire game.  So all the difficulty is super artificial and due to simple jank, inconvenience, and tedium. 

Misc:
Other than that, the game is missing a ton of basic quality of life settings.  You can't customize much, like the controls and unless you're on controller, you're going to struggle to even read the description of items.  You also can't access settings while in game.

Overall just a very disappointing game.  Sucks to see so much amazing art wasted on such a dumpsterfire of a game

I don't normally write reviews but for this game I just had to. 

This game quickly went from being something i was having a hard time getting into to one of my favorite games of all time, and i haven't even finished it yet. I was initially intrigued by the art style and pixel art, and the fact that its a 'vania with souls-like death mechanics, but then became so immersed in the world and characters and my curiosity in the lore has since not been quenched. Not only is it an impressive and challenging game but it is built around a setting that is equal parts haunting and beautiful.

The platforming controls well, combat is tight. New enemies constantly make you rethink your approach and suggest you use different skills.

Level design is smart and creative, puzzles are difficult enough to feel challenging but never impossible.

The Metroid/Vania influence is apparent, yet it is obvious this game was made in admiration of those games and never feels like it ripped them off. That being said your Super Metroid play experience will transfer practically 1:1.

The setting of Blasphemous is where the Dark Souls influence takes shape. The world has been plagued by something referred to as the miracle, tearing society apart and some people believe it to be an act of God. The main character is known as the Penitent One, meaning if you die in-game you break your state of penitence and are therefore guilty. The more you die the more guilt you accumulate (which reduces your mana bar) until you can find a means to cleanse it. 

I think what really blows my mind about this game is how the developers worked the themes and symbolism of religion into the mechanics and overall game-play of the project, really solidifying the art direction into its core. Rosary beads and relics function as perks and abilities and every item you collect has its own page where you read about its lore, leading you to piece together the story as you collect. Collectibles never feel tacked on or felt like an after thought, and you will always be rewarded for putting in the work to find them.

The feeling i get when i play this game is the same one i got when i first played Metroid as a kid and really cant get enough of it.

The soundtrack is great as are the visuals and I really do feel the despair in the world around me as I travel through each area. The lore is pretty interesting too. The movement isn't the smoothest but the game is aware that the Penitent One isn't super agile and the platforming challenges and enemies are designed accordingly. 

If I'm going to nitpick, Jondo was a bit of a pain, the shrines/fast travel are just a little too drawn out, and a lot of the items aren't useful. Those are really the only complaints I have with this game, and they don't majorly take away from the overall experience or enjoyment (or at least they didn't for me).

This game is incredible. The writing, the environment and the character designs are all so immersive - the mixture of all these result in characters that feel so alive. The presentation is SO METAL.

The gameplay (combat and platforming) is very punishing, but rewards patience, perseverance and (some) creativity. It does a good job of making it clear that your failure is your fault (although sometimes it will feel like a boss' attack pattern is bullshit, but that's few and far between, IMO). Exploration in this game is very rewarding, as is proper for a metroidvania. Progression also feels great because you get stronger and enemies that you've had more trouble dealing with in the past become much easier eventually.

As an aside, if you are a fan of Shin Megami Tensei games, then the narrative in this game is probably a good fit for you. It's not the same, but its a good flavor. Blasphemous is like Catholicism fan fiction taken up to 11.

One tip:
* If you find yourself having difficulty with a boss, try to spend some time looking for more things that will make you stronger. There are items that [spoiler]will give you resistances to certain types damage[/spoiler].
* [spoiler]Aim for the true ending. It's much more challenging, but sticking with it is going to be worth your while![/spoiler]

As a fan of the metroidvania and soulslike games, I can say this game is a great addition to both genres, and you will enjoy exploration and combat. Breakdown on best and worst aspects of the game below:

Pros:
-Exploration, like most Metroidvanias (i.e. Hollow Knight), is the heart and soul of this game
-Beautiful level design and artistic style. Anyone with a Christian background will find this game especially interesting (or blasphemous [lol])
-Large amount of enemy variety, Each enemy type has different optimal ways to approach and beat them (parrying, dodging, etc.) keeping things fresh
- Good combat system
-Fun boss fights

Cons:
- The main con, is that near the end of the game, things can become a slog. Meaning you have to take X Item to Y Person, but it is not obvious at all, and there is a lot of backtracking.
-  The lore and messaging is cryptic (they were clearly inspire by Dark Souls). To some, this is a good thing, but I can find it somewhat tedious, To avoid wandering around aimlessly trying to figure out where to go or what item you need next, would recommend looking up some guides near the end if you ever feel stuck.
- Similar to the above point, there are fast travel rooms, but they are not everywhere, meaning you often have to traverse large distances to get from Point A to Point B

Overall, would definitely recommend this game: 8/10 Game (Great!)

As London goes into hysteria over putting a hat made with stolen diamonds on an old man sitting on a throne made of gold, I figured this would be a perfect time to play Blasphemous and Wow. It's A brilliant metroidvania but with flaws. I Finished the base game over 2 days with 15 hours in total, 80% completion. 

My 3 main gripes are in its sometimes questionable level design and often noticeable control unresponsiveness. Enemies are placed in certain environments that just made me think "how on earth did they think this would be a good idea?" And you'll often find yourself getting annoyed at hitting buttons and nothing happening or responding due to strange recovery times and hitbox collision, sometimes consequently putting you in stun-lock situations which is never enjoyable. Thirdly, there is a game mechanic that is horribly implemented. It's never stated at or hinted at, and involves getting to out of reach places that you would normally expect to access with a double-jump power up that doesn't exist. There is also a well known glitch that forced me to quit the game which still has not been fixed.

Despite these issues, man what a world they built. It is incredibly intense. It's very grim. In the world of Blasphemous, self punishment is virtuous. The themes and the aesthetic and the music all combine to draw you into this abyss that you just want to keep playing so you can get the hell out of there. It really sticks with you. 

When the aforementioned criticisms don't horribly present themselves, it's a tight and beautiful game that will leave you in contemplation for a while. 
It's probably on the high A tier below S tier metroidvanias such as Hollow Knight, Symphony of the Night and Ori 2. I imagine Blasphemous 2 will be up there if they figure out these imperfections and clean it up.

Highly recommended if you're into metroidvanias, for casual players try it out with the 2 hour refund window and if you like it then get it on sale as there are spikes in difficulty where the criticisms really begin to show that will be very frustrating to get through unless youre experienced with the metroidvania genre.

*Update*

Finished base game at 21 hours with 98% completion and both base endings. The latest free DLC gives an entirely new and canonical ending which requires a brand new playthrough which I will save for another day. I'm exhausted with this game, it's intense and miserable lol.
Solid Metroidvania with cryptic backstory (which I like!), amazing artwork and great atmosphere. Controls are tight, platforming is challenging, bosses are difficult. What more could you want?

Solid 15-25 hours of souls like fun.  Some issues but no deal breakers.

Art Direction/Story/World - This game is honestly worth a buy just for the art direction.  The world, players, npcs, animations are all incredibly well done.  Music is solid.  Story is very abstract and hard to follow, some will like it some won't.  The world is compelling to explore but gets stale with backtracking.  I had a good twenty hours but the back tracking to get items / finish quests / corpse runs just kill the mood for me.   Corpse running is a thing and it's sometimes ok and sometimes not.

Combat - Solid 2D souls like combat which is mostly good.  Relies on basic attacks.  Parrying/Dodging/Jumping is required to win.  No Unga Bunga.   Few gripes about combat:  as the game progresses landing combo's becomes a bigger and bigger part of your damage profile and poke damage gets weaker.  many enemies seem coded to punish you for going for combo's with attack windows that always seem just shorter then your combo animation.  at times ranged combat and platforming mix and it can be very cheap.    your parry always protects you from damage but many strong attacks will knock you and it feels bad as you can't counterattack and sometimes will get knocked off a cliff and die.  Unlike other games you can't dodge through projectiles.

Progression is bad.   You use the same weapon the whole game, it does more damage but there's no visual changes and enemies just die in 1 hits instead of 2.  Most items are weak passives that are not interesting.  ie you take less fire dmg.  they cant be used to create fun 'builds'.   opening the UI to tinker is immersion breaking and tedious.  magic spells are so expensive they might as well not exist, they mostly useless except to 1 shot trash.   Too late for a redesign now, hopefully the sequel gets it right.

Blasphemous is a metroidvania souls-like in which you play as The Penitent One with goal of murdering the Pope. Let me get one thing clear: the game's pretty damn rough. In my personal experience, the game started off impossibly difficult and felt really unrewarding, I was being reintegrated into the soil every 5 minutes, later though, after getting the hang of controls, it started getting pretty fun. Just keep in mind the fact, that it's my personal experience, and I might have a skill issue.
The gameplay feels really good and the attacks are diverse and actually useful. There are some bugs here and there, which made me reset the game because I, or an enemy got stuck in the wall for some unknown reason. The lore of this game is very deep, but let me tell you: it does an awful job at telling you what's going on or how to finish a side quest, so I feel like some sort of in-game list would be something very helpful. I love the variety of enemies, bosses, said quests and especially stunning graphics. The soundtrack is great, though to be honest, I have not paid a lot of attention to it. In terms of replay value, the game will blast you into the shadow realm again and offer way more content after you already finish the game, so you are rewarded for going for it again. 
To conclude, give this game a shot if you played a metroidvania before and enjoyed it. I found this game fun enough to do all the achievements ;)
