Blasphemous is a captivating video game that immerses players in a richly religious aesthetic, drawing inspiration from Christian-esque symbolism to create a mesmerizing and thought-provoking experience. With its dark and atmospheric world, the game manages to strike a delicate balance between reverence and blasphemy, offering a unique exploration of faith and redemption.

One of the standout features of Blasphemous is its impeccable attention to detail in depicting the intricate religious imagery. From ornate cathedrals to haunting statues and somber rituals, every element of the game's environment contributes to the overall sense of religious mystique. The symbolism is deeply ingrained in the gameplay mechanics, story, and character design, enhancing the thematic depth and immersing players in a world filled with spiritual connotations.

Beyond its aesthetic appeal, Blasphemous excels in gameplay mechanics and level design. The combat is satisfyingly challenging, requiring precise timing and strategic thinking. As players progress through the game, they uncover a meticulously crafted narrative, gradually unraveling the mysteries of the world and their character's role in it. The lore is engrossing, blending elements of religion, mythology, and dark fantasy, keeping players invested in the unfolding story.

Blasphemous is not only visually stunning but also succeeds in creating an atmosphere of contemplation and introspection. It prompts players to question their own beliefs and assumptions, as well as the nature of faith itself. The game's ability to provoke deep thought while providing an engaging gameplay experience is a testament to its excellence.

In conclusion, Blasphemous stands as a remarkable achievement in the world of video games. Its skillful incorporation of Christian-esque symbolism, captivating aesthetics, and thought-provoking themes make it an unforgettable journey for players seeking an immersive and intellectually stimulating experience. Whether you're a fan of dark fantasy or simply appreciate games that delve into profound philosophical questions, Blasphemous is an absolute must-play.

The Greatest 2D 'Metroidvania' of All Time. (Have about another 50 hours on PS5)

Blasphemous captivated me, even back in 2019 before any DLC had dropped; visually and aesthetically the game is captivating from the opening moments. A bleak and rich world inspired by Andalucian culture, myths and history; a fact that already makes it far more unique than most other games you'll play.

The pixel art is stunning, every back drop is a painting and every character is bursting with lore.

The music by Carlos Viola is beautiful, crafted to capture the mood of every area and boss - and is super relaxing to boot!

Aesthetics aside, the combat is the star of the show; far weightier and complex than any other 2d Metroidvania. The game has some great areas to explore, and backtracking.

The DLCS just expand upon this incredible experience, fleshing out the lore, bosses and replayability with some NG+ only content.

Blasphemous is an unforgettable experience that will haunt you long after you put it down.

Blasphemous is a classic-style metroidvania that isn't weighed down by a bunch of different systems. It has a great setting with intriguing lore, brought to life with unique art design and accompanied by a good soundtrack. The combat is tough and takes some getting used to, so along with the difficulty of many of the bosses it makes for many satisfying moments when you overcome a hurdle.

Regardless of the occasional bugs that you may encounter and frustratingly obtuse nature of the quests, Blasphemous is a strong recommendation from me for any fan of metroidvania games.

I am Deogracias, witness to and narrator of the acts of the Grievous Miracle. Such is my penance, as yours is silence.

The Cradle of Affliction is what you seek. This can be found in the Mother of Mothers of the churches.

It is a remote place separated from the rest of these lands by a great sacred and forbidden door.

Even a wise penitent like me knows nothing of what lies beyond those high walls.

However, what I do know is that, according to The Rule, one must carry out the Three Humiliations to gain access to what they guard.

One of them must be performed in the high mountains, covered in thick blankets of snow and ice.

Another in the depths of a dark, entombed church, where the sleeper lies.

And the last one at the end of the trail carved by moans that claw their way out of an iron spiral. In the bowels of the bell named Jondo that grows into the earth.

Take this thorn and place it on the handle of your sword.

If, when the time comes, as you grip your weapon firmly, you notice that it wounds you, and makes you bleed...

Having grown, with more thorns sprouting from it, writhing over the figure of the Father carved into the knob...

That will mean that you are at the mercy of the Grievous Miracle, whether for its punishment or its forgiveness.

I did everything right. I saved the right people, did the right things, everything. Except at 97% complete on the game, after spending 3hrs searching up the final goods before heading to the last boss, I find out I'm locked out of the true ending not because I made a mistake, but because I didn't deliver some goods to a character before accidentally fighting another character I had never seen before (and not even killing said character off). Just like that, my interest was gone in the game, and it will remain at 97%, and here is my review.

This game certainly has a lot of charm but can also be somewhat of a drag. The game's graphics are utterly terrific and it's dedication to style and form are incredible. The enemy character design (especially of the bosses) is so artistic and gruesome that it's impossible not to feel immersed. I really don't hate the combat, although it is definitely meant to challenge you are force you to adapt most of the time it doesn't feel unreasonably difficult, once you understand how the combat runs it is very rewarding to be challenged by seemingly impossible odds that force you to cleverly apply the skills you've learned. 
My problem is entirely with the progression and recovery after deaths. Progression in the game is so obscure and difficult that it will seem at times like it is utterly stagnant. You don't level up by winning battles with enemies and gaining experience; you level up by exploring. Which would not be a huge problem if the game didn't make exploration so hard. There is no practical fast travel system for one, and the map which you are given is hieroglyphically difficult to understand because entire rooms are represented by boxes, which means you could have a room with a thousand enemies and inescapable traps look the same as a perfectly innocent room with an item you want. If you want to level up you have to find hidden Mea Culpa alters strewn throughout the map in increasingly obscure locations. If you want more healing potions you've got to discover more blood alters which are incredibly hard to find. 
As far as recovering from successive deaths the penalties for dying in the game not only stack but alleviating the penalties will require you to hunt out each individual location at which you died and recover all of your corpses. This may result (as it did for me) in you dying in the poison gas and not being able to recover your body until much later in the game or in your body somehow ending up on the other side of a wall which you won't be able to access until much later in the game. 
I would recommend this game only to the incredibly patient or immensely masochistic because it certainly has redeeming qualities, I just don't think I could describe it as a 'fun game' in good conscience.

Throwing the cons out at the beginning:

There are some enemies that just feel way too tanky, regardless of how many upgrades you have which makes backtracking to do quests a bit of a slog. 

Another save point or two in certain areas would be really beneficial. 

It's easy to get into areas you really shouldn't be in yet and run up against a huge difficulty spike. 

The platforming can be....hit or miss with insta-kill spikes and bottomless pits like we're suddenly playing Megaman again which doesn't feel great in a game with long run-backs and some tanky enemies. 

The quests, the items, the triggers for stages of certain NPC quests, and what you have to do can be really incredibly cryptic. I usually try to avoid using a wiki the first time through a game but I couldn't avoid it this time to figure out what certain items or for or what certain NPCs are asking me to do.

Powerups are kind of a mess with lots of weird limitations like: why so many types? you've got sword skills that are different from sword hearts which is different still from sword level. Magic Spells. Combat relics, which are different from exploration relics. The latter have no combat impact but we can only ever equip three so you constantly have to juggle them - why not let us equip them all at once? The combat relics sometimes have cryptic or poorly written descriptions and it's hard to know which are good or worthwhile. 

THAT SAID, I am enjoying it quite a lot. The challenge is there. The enjoyment is there. The music is wonderful - I feel like you don't hear many games that rely heavily on spanish guitar. The visuals are excellent. The boss design is creative and astounding (even if the actual difficulty of them is all over the place). 

Definitely recommend it if you like Metroidvanias OR Dark Souls-style games.

If you're considering playing Blasphemous, but you haven't played Hollow Knight, go play that instead. The two games play pretty similarly, but Hollow Knight is the much better game. 

That's not to say that Blasphemous doesn't have anything going for it. The art direction is incredible. The music is great. It's overall a fun and satisfying experience. 

But this game has some problems. 

The biggest issue I had with this game was my inputs getting eaten constantly. I can't tell you how many times I tried to jump,  attack, or use a prayer, and the game refused to register it. This got me killed quite a few times, and it never felt fair. 

The platforming in this game is pretty bad. For me, that's mainly because the player character automatically grabs ledges instead of requiring an input be held to trigger this interaction. This takes away player agency and results in your character grabbing ledges when you want to fall or grabbing ledges with poor timing. I hate it. The platforming really stands out as frustrating during the (optional) Miriam challenge rooms. These rooms are poorly designed and frustrating messes. The reward you get for completing them isn't very good either, so I recommend skipping them if you value your sanity (I wish I had done so).

Playing this game after Hollow Knight, the combat feels really lacking, especially in the boss fights. Most of the boss fights are focused on spectacle, so you end up fighting a lot of things that are much bigger than you where it's just about surviving attack hell type phases long enough to land a few hits in when the boss becomes vulnerable for a couple seconds. The block / parry mechanic is horribly underutilized in the boss fights.

Has some flaws, like slow travel and some almost undodgeable attacks that make you tank damage, but nice gameplay, beautiful pixelart and music and great lore/story/atmosphere. Overall, I consider it one of the best metroidvania games ive ever played, up there with Hollo Knight. I totally suggest buying this game.

The amount of frustration and anger I experienced playing this game is countless. I won't elaborate on the positives, because a lot of people here have added very positive reviews that I agree with, but I can't get past how some things are just plain badly designed. I really liked one comment on Reddit that the game is designed to suffer, but that doesn't mean it should be specifically "badly" designed, well, unless that was 100% the goal.

Fighting mobs:

- when you deal the final blow to a mob, and at that moment the mob jumps/does an animation/attack, the mob will only die when the animation ends

- some mobs can not be dodged at all, I totally do not understand why, some mobs can be dodged by dodge, and some can not. I understand that some of them can be jumped over, but there are mobs, impossible to bypass

- sometimes I had the impression that the AI is sensitive to the moment when I finally press the button, which makes it impossible to avoid the attack (I may be wrong here)

- it often happened to me that mobs would shoot from off-screen

Character movement/attack:

- I don't know if it's just with me, but it often happened to me that the dodge + attack didn't work at all, it seems to me that when the dodge animation ends it no longer catches the attack for that, which is strange because the dodge animation is still going on

- if I did a dodge + attack on a mob that was on a ridge and you sat special then usually your character's animation was off the ridge and after the animation was over you would drop down

- when you get damage that knocks you down and you are lying on the ground then when you get up you don't have that momentary immortality, so if you fell somewhere where there are mobs you will be eaten

- I had the impression that the hit box on some mobs was much bigger and on others it was small and you had to get close to the mobs

- I don't remember the name of the boss, but it was a skeleton that was held by the hands, a few times it happened to me that half of the boss went beyond the screen which made it impossible to beat the hands so that the boss could fall down

Map design:

- personally, I'm not a fan of returning to the same location several times each, and I love to collect everything, here I had the impression that I really returned to the same locations several times each (this is my personal feeling, I know that a lot of people like this kind of map)

- some traps can not be avoided without receiving damage, as is the case in the map Mourning and Havoc, no matter how long I calculated and counted, there were moments that electric balls could not be skipped without damage

I really feel bad issuing a negative comment and frustration is certainly speaking through me. I love this type of game, "souls-like" 2D, but some of the things designed in this game are, in my opinion, bad, which led me to great frustration and dislike of the game. I felt completely different when I tried to progress some map or boss state in other games and knew what I needed to improve. Despite my negative attitude, I'm still very eager to make an approach to the second part, because the game is beautiful and made with a really cool idea.

This would be a 10/10 game if not for some GLARING issues. The art style is the best part of it. Other than that, the combat is a pain in the ass, the platforming is a joke, your character moves like they're stuck in mud, and there are far too many enemies that can hit you after dodging cheaply. At least with Souls games and most other action platformers (which this obviously tried to emulate) you know when you screwed up. I'll play it to say I beat it, but after that, I'll never play it again.
 I get being hard and punishing, but being badly designed with artificial difficulty based around blind jumps into insta-kill spikes and pits, having multiple enemies on screen that can stunlock you to death, and a dodge that is all but useless because if you happen to touch something after you take damage is different than hard. I know these issues will never be fixed, as the Devs got their money, and what I've said has been said before in some fashion, but on sale it's not the worst buy. I'd have refunded immediately at full price.

After not initially liking the game, putting it down for a while, and finally playing it to its entirety with the true ending: It's a great game in certain ways such as the art and story, but displays harsh failures for the responsiveness to combat controls, and especially for one platforming control: registering ladders when you're jumping. This becomes especially apparent for the later collaborative Bloodstained game challenges. The three challenges I've done so far aren't even bad considering prior experience with Path of Pain for Hollow Knight, but there's consistent spotty input for ladders when you're jumping onto them. This will ruin some of the later Bloodstained challenges. Ladder input is extremely exacerbated when you're required to jump from one ladder to another. You press UP on the ladder when Penitente's helmet/torso (both don't improve outcome for grabbing it) are in the same space, and it takes 5-6 times to register even after dying during each attempt. The best examples are early on during the ladder jump prior to Where Olive Trees Whither, and the initially locked climb to the Walls of Holy Prohibitions. I hope its resolved for the release of the second game if they desire to implement more platforming environments. A lot of people have complaints about the combat that I understand. I've done all existing boss fights without any real issues, until one of the final fights (Crisanta) that jacks up combat speed for the first time. The fight is one of the most poorly designed fights in the game so far (haven't done NG+) because while it's not difficult to parry the attacks, you very frequently end up auto riposting after a parry even when you're not pressing the attack button. The bug is very noticeable, and was honestly tempted to give up the game since I really doubt it's going to get fixed. The auto riposte on paper sounds alright. However, every time the bug happens Penitente's attack swings out of reach of Crisanta, in one of the few openings to attack after the constant parrying of attacks. The glaring issues from this fight alone make me reluctant to try the second game if their intention is to add more fast, challenging fights like Crisanta to the mix, without rectifying control responsiveness. It's definitely worth trying on sale for the art and story, albeit the plot draws many similarities to Elden Ring and Bloodborne. I just hope they do make improvements to controls/combat if they want the second game to be a certain improvement.

This game does everything right. Let me elaborate:

PROS
====
- Incredible, dynamic music.
- Amazing voice acting, it's just perfect for every character and for the story.
- Great lore and story. The whole "reason" behind what happens and why in Cvstodia is both interesting and shocking.
- Mechanics are smooth, easy to learn, evolving, and most important of all... fun!
- Environment and background are superb! Great thematic and scenery, which merges seamlessly with the music and the gameplay.
- Character design is super interesting! There's a little bit of everything and each level area (called districts) has its own set of unique enemies and bosses.
- Tons of content for us completionists! You can just chill and beat the game, or go for broke and collect every single thing you can! (rewards really help with tougher areas).
- Gameplay is enticing and challenging! A combination of Metroidvania + Dark Souls makes the game punishing but very satisfying to beat.

CONS
====
- Some of the quests can be tough to figure out w/o a guide.
- One of the quests is "timed" (kinda).
- The game CAN be a bit tough for certain players, since as you make progress the enemies/obstacles/mechanics become more challenging.
- The whole "retro" look and feel, VFX, cinematics and pixel-style can be off-putting for players who value realistic/modern graphics over gameplay.
- That stupid speedrun that one of the DLCs add (fu Miriam level 5!!!)

Conclusion
========
Blasphemous has an incredibly well-written and entertaining story, delivers a very fun gameplay experience and amazing music/voice acting. All of this and more makes this a must-play title. This game is worth every penny, and I cannot recommend it more.

I found this game by once again seeing a video from Matt McMuscles (that's twice now you recommended a great game). Once I saw the amazing pixel art and goriness of the game, I knew I had to try it. I'm happy to say this is probably one of my new favorite games now, I had so much fun.

In a world full of strife and self harm (trigger warning), you awaken simply known as the Penitent One of Silence. Awakening in a mass of other penitent bodies, you fight off the warden, take his blood, and begin your journey on finding the next Miracle and breaking the curse over the land.

Blasphemous is a metroidvania that looks like the Castlevania and Dark Souls universes had a baby. While the pixel art and graphics look like Castlevania, the story and feel are akin to playing a Dark Souls game. You have good array of abilities once you start: Attack, Dodge, and Parry. Each of these moves are crucial if you're going to survive this game because it's tough...but fun.

Exploration in this game is so much fun and just like Castlevania, there are hidden rooms and paths for you to find. Tons of collectables, equipment that gives you active and passive abilities, and so much more. This was one of the few games where I actually looked forward to backtracking because you never know where a hidden wall was, or what new maps you can access now that you have new abilities.

Enemies are quite varied which was a cool thing in my book. You rarely see the same enemy in different areas as they each have their own theme. It's always fascinating to go into a new place and go like "Okay, how does this one fight?". It keeps the game fresh and exciting. Also, this game is quite bloody and gory. So another thing to look forward to is how does it look when I crush these enemies with my sword *grin*

The highlight for me was definitely the bosses. Every boss was memorable and so much fun. Upon first seeing them, they seem imposing and super hard. But after taking your time, learning their attack patterns, and LEARNING TO PARRY *hint* some of their attacks, it become some of the most rewarding parts of the game for me. Even when I found myself stuck on a boss for a few tries, I never felt mad at the boss, I was mad at myself. I never blamed the game and that always feels good to say. 

Lastly, the death system is really good in my opinion as well. When you die in the game, you gain guilt which makes your magic bar (fervor) gets smaller and it becomes harder for you to gain money to buy things and upgrade. You can go back to wear you died and absorb the guilt to get your fervor fixed, or you can find certain rooms in the game that will fix your guilt for a cost. Your money is never affected by death which made it so much better for me as a player. It gives you a Dark Souls like experience without the rough punishment. I know more hardcore gamers wanted it tougher upon death, but I personally thought this was fine for players who may have found it unplayable. Perhaps there can be an option they add later for players who want a challenge?

I personally had no gripes with the game. It was hard at points, but it was never so hard that I wanted to quit. It was just the right amount of challenge to keep me going. Even boss fights that had me sweating at first had me take my time and really play more patient and then I got the hang of it. Aside from a graphical glitch I had on an elevator in one area and sometimes my character clipping when grabbing a ledge during a challenge run, everything was perfect!

Final verdict? If you love Metroidvanias, you are doing yourself a disservice by not playing this game. This was the perfect game from beginning to end. Plus at the time of this review, it is spooky season. So it's an even better time to pick this up and enjoy all the gory and crazy action in this game. You won't regret it, I promise! Thanks for reading!

Another Metroidvania that's carried by its art design. The gameplay is serviceable, it just feels like a less smooth Hollow Knight with way less combat depth. The story is nonsensical bullshit, an attempt at creating world lore that falls short when you realize everybody is speaking in riddles with no clear distinction who they're even talking about. People want to compare this to Dark Souls NPC questlines but that's a stretch. This game does absolutely nothing to clue you in on any of the multiple sidequests or item progressions. Even when you do come across an NPC and manage to give them something the follow-up dialogue is always cryptic bullshit. "Take this egg with you, go see the tree, be with the father etc." it's all flavor text trash that serves no purpose for the actual game progression. Eventually I started skipping all the dialogue because I realized absolutely none of it was helpful or even mattered, Not to mention one of the VAs couldn't even pronounce pious correctly (come on if you're going this heavy with the biblical themes at least get your shit straight).

The game is rife with secrets and hidden items/questlines but fuck you if you think you're gonna stumble across one and actually finish it correctly. A lot of these boil down to "meet with X before Y but NOT BEFORE fighting boss Z, then take item A to NPC B then leave and come back, take new item A to random ass tree in early game area, receive new relic, re-explore the whole map looking for random blood platforms or vines, and finally oh look you found a wack ass bead that is totally obsolete by this point. If that wasn't enough I would later find that I fucked myself out of the "true" ending and that I'd have to do a whole other run for completion's sake. This all on top of the game crashing on me a couple times and also being wonky with Steam Deck cloud saves; I'm just soured on this whole game and I'm gonna leave it at 90% completion because I can't be fucked to care about it anymore, it stopped being fun and I don't care about a sequel.

I played this game on Switch, finished it a year ago and just recently, I came back to play the new DLC. I got it on Steam and it is as great as I remember it being, so I felt inclined to write a review. The best parts of this game, in my opinion, is the controls, gameplay and the lore. The controls are very tight an are very responsive, especially when the game asks you to pull off difficult platforming and maneuvers throughout the game. The gameplay loop is actually really fun because not only the combat very mechanically simple, but slowly gets more complex, the game acts like a Metroidvania at some points, asking you to come back later with a specific item or ability. However, it's only for collectibles and such, not progression, so it's not forceful with getting these items and abilities. Finally, the lore and the artsyle, which I want to pair together, is easily the best part of the game. Now, I love Dark Souls and the lore that you can choose to slowly unravel, learning about the world and the NPCs and characters in the game, absent or not. The way that Blaspehemous handles lore is that they give you a lot of information about your character and the world around you in the very beginning that you have to interpret for yourself and the NPCs you meet along the way add more to that lore and somehow feeling very interesting and complex after meeting them one time. Now, the artstyle is baffling. The way they portray gore, the intricate details of the NPC's designs and the many locations you encounter is crazy. You'll understand what I mean when you play it, hopefully. There isn't really any cons I would say about this game. The one thing I could say could be improved would be the bosses as they are pretty easy once you get used to the patterns and the gameplay, but that's not really a bad thing. Also, a few areas are kind of difficult in a way they are sometimes unfair, but these are just nitpicks. They're designed really well, so it's not a huge flaw. Before I finish this review, I want to give a disclaimer. This game is really graphic, like blood, guts, nudity and adult themes. It might not seem like it would be bad because of the pixelated artstyle, but it's really bad. I know Steam says this already, but you might not want to play this in public or around other people. Thanks for reading this review. I know it's long, but I'm glad you read to the end to see how much I adore this game and I hope it motivated you to play this masterpiece of a game.

When there is a decent enemy encounter that requires you to git gud it just goes back to the same old stupid bs that it's been doing for the previous 4 hours right afterward.
The platforming is pretty awful, the jumping feels slow and laggy and the platforms are so inconsistent when you connect, sometimes i'm standing right on top but i fall right through and the constant barrage of flying enemies and projectiles towards the end is so insufferable I want to break my controller. I'm gonna see it through to the end purely out of spite and the fact that I'm probably almost done. The area I'm in right now is essentially just Tower of Latria from Demon's Souls with even worse enemy design and level design.
Update: Christana might be one of the worst designed bosses I have ever fought. Why is she allowed to start the animation of her overhead swing then change direction 180 when you slide through her body to hit you? Is it a way of saying "you're supposed to parry?" why would that be a good idea, there should be multiple ways of dodging each attack, the boss literally punishes you for dodging her blow. Why is it that when I slide beneath her as she does her dive-bomb attack, she can cancel it before she hits the ground then immediately start it back up again and hit me with it the second time? Why is it that I can run to the other side of the arena wait for 3 seconds see her do nothing, drink my bile flask and then after I've regained the health but before I'm out of the animation lock of drinking the flask she can charge across the entire arena to hit me? Why make the bile flask heal you instantly but still animation lock you for an extra second and a half anyway if not to make it so that you take unavoidable damage by enemies when you have downtime in a fight but only after you heal? Why is it that I need to sacrifice my number of healing charges to barely increase the amount of healing that I get from those charges? It seems like everything in this game is meant to be an imitation of what Dark Souls difficulty is supposed to be like while missing the entire point of what makes those games challenging to begin with. Maybe I just don't understand the genre and will never like metroidvanias, I'm fine with that. But this game is one of the most poorly designed and balanced experiences I've ever had with a game in my life. The only things it has going for it are a great art style, beautiful music, and somewhat engaging lore. Stay far away from this game.

My gripes are that the game is super slow for an action platformer, the secrets are hidden behind just hitting random walls until you get the relic that tells you when there's a secret in the room. I think the game needed more movement options as the restrictive moveset was boring or agitating at many times. The game is a bit too punishing with platforming as well, the instant-kill pitfalls and spikes really made this game longer than it needed to be, especially when the stage design intended for enemies to hit you into instant-kill spikes. This game's relic system shouldn't even exist, all relics active all the time. There is no downside to only having 3 active at all, it just means that its less menu navigating, all the relics are passive abilities that are more or less required to progress or find secrets within the world. The combat feels good when it works, but oftentimes enemies won't let you finish your combo, so it's only really used in bossfights or on certain enemies. The combo should go off regardless if the attack hits or not. I also believe there should be more ways to view collectables within the map, scouring the map for them with no helpful indication of where they could be late game makes finishing up all the sidequests a very annoying ordeal. 

I do like the game's music and artstyle, it is a very pretty game, and the spritework is absurdly good. the world is interesting enough to keep me playing despite all of my gripes with it. The bossfights do feel good, and the map is quite large so there's a lot to do. I hope blasphemous 2 addresses alot of the core issues I had with this game since its a pretty good game already, with a few QoL tweaks and some more movement (which blasphemous 2 seems to address) the game could be extremely good.

Before the big wall of text my reviews are usually composed of, I need to say that I'm fairly neutral regarding Blasphemous. Steam doesn't have that, but I want to say it either way. I'm not recommending it mainly because of my own experience with the game.

I also wanna say that this game has an amazing story when you actually understand shit (thanks youtube) but a game can't be carried solely by its story.

Blasphemous is a great game that suffers from poor design choices. It's a good game but a bad metroidvania. You can play the game normally, finish the first ending and stop there and the experience will be pretty good. There are some issues here and there like annoying platforming but it's not that bad. The game is fairly quick with an average playtime of 14 hours (if you stop at the first ending), but it has a lot of good going for it. The art is disgustingly gorgeous, and the sound design doesn't disappoint. The music is very good and the pixel art works great. The voice acting is pretty good too.
Now, the story is complicated. The concept is great but I feel like it gets way more confusing than it should. I only realized a crucial part of the story after watching (not playing, btw) the true ending. And the whole "silent protagonist" thing doesn't really work because you can't really tell what is really happening or if it is good or bad.

The gameplay is pretty simple and again, I'm neutral towards this. The combat never really evolves, it's just "hit enemy, wait for parry, sometimes use spell when enemy is too annoying, heal after a few hits". The bosses are just very simple and all very similar, even if their designs would make you think otherwise. Upgrades don't really matter too, I barely touched my upgrades and I was fine through the whole game. Same goes for charms/rosary beads and spells/prayers. You're only ever gonna use a few that you find good and not change them much. 
One thing that is very annoying is how the map works. It's awful. It is good that you don't need to unlock anything to actually use it, but there is basically no information on where the stuff you need is. Every part of the map is composed of little squares, so important things that can be remembered because of how they look are impossible to identify just by looking at the map. The most it shows you is checkpoints and a few places where you can upgrade things like bile flasks or rosary beads. There are some babies in cages that you have to save and a place where you can get rewards for doing so and I genuinely forgot that it EXISTED or where it even was. It's like grubs from HK but done badly. You NEED to mark everything otherwise you're not gonna find what you want.

One thing that I personally find negative is that the game doesn't have any ACTUAL character upgrades like a metroidvania usually does. In Control, you can fly, throw objects and create shields out of thin air. In Hollow Knight you have Monarch Wings and Shadow Cloak and Crystal Dash. In Fallen Order you have Double Jump, Force Push and Wall Run. but here, you have nothing. Instead, the game gives you collectible (also optional) items that not only need to be equipped but just change the world around you, not really evolving the character in any way. And the worst part is that they are only useful for a handful of collectibles. Again, I'm not totally against this because it is very unique but it's also not very fun.

Also, and this connects with the map being shit, unlocking things here is VERY HARD without a wiki. I spent a good 4 hours just trying to get the vine relic (which again, I barely fucking used) and eventually I did but not after sweeping the ENTIRE map after it. Worst part is it was hidden in a remote part of the map which I didn't notice because the indication that there are access points in any given part of the map is a little hole inside the wall that is VERY easy to ignore. I could've done that in 10 minutes tops but the lack of information made it THE chore.

And then we have the endings. There are 3 in total, only the first 2 are actual achievements and while I LOVE the idea of following a different plot that absolutely changes the story and sets up a better ending for the game, the execution here is awful. Not only do you need to completely redo the game (which would be fine if the game played better) to get the true ending but everything is so specific I don't think I could've done any of that even after months of trying without online help. I get that it's big and it matters, but there is hardly any challenge here other than following specific steps from the wiki. You don't even get an achievement for it, so you can just look it up on YT and be done with it. And that's not the only thing that suffers from "restart syndrome", there are quests that can only be finished by playing the game's NG+ which just sucks. I'm fine with NG+ being different, I really like that, but you can't start something in one mode and the force the player to redo the whole thing because you can only finish it in a different one. And to top it all off, NG+ replaces your main save, essentially forcing you to redo anything you left undone on that save.

Also, platforming. Stop with the fatal damage pits and spikes, it's fucking annoying. There's this endgame room with a prie dieu on the middle surrounded by platforms and pits and it's intentionally made to trigger players. It doesn't make the game harder, and breaks the flow of gameplay by making you restart and die just because you mistimed a jump

Overall, I was able to enjoy the game at first even with a lacking combat system but trying to explore it and find secrets was very annoying. I'm leaving the review as not recommended because of my experience, but honestly it wasn't that bad and I'm fairly neutral towards it. 5/10

Pros: oh my god, this is glorious. The entire game has this specific vibe that is just wonderful and Gothic and lowkey horrific. Honestly, I would also recommend perching the Art Book as well if you're interested in that sort of thing. And the story, it's wonderful. The NPCs, interesting. I could praise the writing of this game for the rest of my life too. But as for the game game, the game itself. It honestly has this similar feeling to Dark Souls. And now I do want to share some cons about the game so that if someone is interested in playing they can be informed before hand. And to start, I personally don't like some of the enemy mechanics. Some enemies have the ability to stun lock you in areas. it's not fun. And I personally don't like how when you fall into spikes/the void you instantly die, it's not fun in the early game. Let me preface this review by saying, I do not think Blasphemous is a bad game. If I had to score it, I would give it around a 7/10. However, would I [i]recommend[/i] Blasphemous? No, not really.
[hr][/hr]
Lets start with the good:
- Artistically speaking, the presentation of this game is absolutely gorgeous. It takes an extremely unique setting and renders it beautifully. Every area, enemy, and NPC adds to the brutal atmosphere that encompasses the entire game.
- Adding to the above, the music. The OST is mostly atmospheric, with few tracks I would listen to on their own, but overall it perfectly complements the vibe each area is going for.
- With a couple exceptions, the bosses stand out as highlights. Each one feels different enough that they're each able to provide a unique challenge. I enjoyed optimizing my setup for each encounter and trying new things for some of the extra difficult DLC bosses. 

Asides from the above, standard enemy combat in this game feels OK. Some ranged enemies can be pretty BS, and certain enemies feel like they take ages to die, but overall the hack and slash combat is decent most of the time. When it [i]isn't[/i] decent, is typically when it overlaps with the platforming.

The bad really boils down to two major issues:
- The platforming. The Penitent One controls like he has stepped in molasses, and he basically stays covered in molasses the whole game. At best, the platforming is slow. When unimpeded, it's mostly just a lot of sluggish wall jumps and short hops over spikes. However when also fighting enemies at the same time, the slow platforming quickly turns frustrating, overshadowing the otherwise solid action gameplay. 
- Trying to figure out what anything does. Look, I get it. Dark Souls does it so why don't we do it here. NPCS speak in catholic riddles, key item descriptions often have [i]zero[/i] words describing what the item is actually used for, and questlines are easily failable by accident. I failed an npc questline before I ever met them, because I had the absolute [i]gall[/i] to walk into an area, then immediately leave that area because I wanted to complete it later. I quickly resolved myself to just looking stuff up, which sucks because this game has a lot of things that go best unspoiled.

Overall, Blasphemous is great when it's great, but it can be an obtuse, frustrating experience too. I have several friends who bounced off of the first few hours of Blasphemous and never came back, and I don't really blame them for doing so.

Great Metroidvania :)

Art Design? Good.

Atmosphere? Good.

Everything else? Takes what should have been an enjoyable game for me and ruined it. 


[list]
[*] The controls feel like utter garbage. A game that's three parts platformer, metroidvania, and Souls-like [i]needs[/i] to have fluid, tight, responsive controls. Blasphemous fails to get anywhere near close to that for me and playing it was an act of frustration, exasperated by what felt like pure RNG on whether the PC would properly latch onto a platform or plunge into an insta-kill abyss and/or insta-kill set of spikes, or properly execute an ability.
    
[*] Speaking of insta-kill traps, why? In this style of game? In any style of game past the NES era, 37 years ago? This isn't an arcade game, the developers don't get a quarter every time a player falls victim to OHKO traps, there's no reason to have them other than to infuriate the player as they fight against the controls trying not to die to them. They don't even have the good graces to disable once you clear an area, so all the backtracking you're going to do? Have fun navigating that tedious padding [i]every, single, time.[/i] 

[*] Areas seem designed with how frustrating they can be first and foremost. From trap and enemy placement to simple navigation, it wasn't satisfying, fun, or rewarding for me to explore the world. The bare-bones map exasperated this, especially since if I didn't neurotically cover the map in icons (that you can't label) when there were items I couldn't reach yet or if I found an NPC, off I'd go ALT-TABing to make sure I was limiting my exposure to the pure, condensed extract of misery that is playing this game.

[*] The font style sapped my usual passion for delving into a setting's lore and world building. It's painful-looking and hard to read, bordering on illegible. Low-res, pixelated art can be great, and a lot of Blasphemous [i]does[/i] look good, but committing to that bit to the point you make reading as arduous as possible, which you're going to be doing a [i]ton[/i] of in this game, is baffling to me.
[/list]

I don't know whether to be impressed or disappointed a game inspired by and exemplifying the self-hatred and self-flagellation brought on by religious fanaticism manages to emulate those concepts with every fiber of its being, but I do know that there's an innumerable amount of other platformers/metroidvanias/Souls-likes out there that are [i]actually[/i] fun to play, and I recommend spending your time with them instead.

I *want* to like this game.  It's a Metroidvania with some challenging combat, voice acted lore bits, and subversive christian aesthetic.  However, three aspects of the game teamed up to make sure that it resulted in an unfun experience.
1) your character is not a good platformer and is not speedy.  More NES Belmont, less Ori/Hollow Knight.
2) the world is full of platforming mechanics with instant-death like pits and spikes.
3) every death requires a backtrack from a save point, and remember, your character is not speedy.

This turned exploration into a trudge.  At best you make it a little further each time and eventually get to another save point.  At worse, you backtrack just to fail the jump again because, remember, your character is clunky.

I went from invested and interested in the art, lore, and combat to deciding it wasn't worth the backtrack.  This game needs either a sands of time rewind or the ability to restart at the screen you died on in the event of a platforming issue.  The combat being hard is just fine.  It feels fair, it feels good.  But your character is not built well for the navigation it is being asked to do.

Nailed the main game out in about a day, but playtime is fine for me, personally.
My main gripe about the game is just how disappointed I am in it. As someone who is a fan of both the metriodvania like games and dark fantasy genre, I had hoped that it would be just a little more fulfilling. And while Blasphemous definitely meets that expectation, if you plan on getting this game, prepare for a noticeable difficulty spike in the midgame and lategame areas.

Gameplay for the exploration and mob fighting is fairly rhythmic and slower paced than that of the bosses, which are far faster.
Speaking of bosses, all of them are unique, for better or for worse. The early game bosses are as to be expected, large monsters, slow attacks, making sure to dodge, and midgame bosses are probably the better fights of the game.
Endgame bosses [spoiler] - or boss - i suppose, is attrocious. A cluster**** of a fight consisting of nonstop dodging and RNG reliant platforms used to attack one specific part of the boss. Little skill is required for this as most of the fight is random.[/spoiler]  

Another thing to keep in mind is the amount of pitfalls, spikes, and other assorted deathtraps that seem as if they were designed only to torment the player rather than adding any kind of reasonable platforming challenge. At the very least, I can applaud the game on enemy placement. I cannot think of a single instance in my (currently) sleep deprived brain of mobs that seem to be placed to gank the player. Devs get an "A" on that.

All in all, I would get this game if I were a fan of the metroidvania genre and/or a fan of dark fantasy. Also wait until it is on sale like I did. But keep in mind that is is a pretty solid experience up till the end.
5/10: Take it or leave it.

The "Catholic Super Soulsvania" basically.

I'm the kind of guy who loves FromSoftware games (specially those directed by Miyazaki) but let me tell you: I've never found a "souls-like" game that really made me feel like the real thing (not even Ni-Oh, had to force myself through that crap tbh) but then I played Blasphemous and holy shit, it blew my mind.

Blasphemous ain't just some Dark Souls clone. No, sir. It takes some of the most iconic elements of that series and combines them with a game design inspired by Symphony of the Night. It's a bold game that truly understands the metroidvania genre. Unlike many other games this one here doesn't rely on standard mechanics like wall jumping or double jumping INSTEAD it introduces a lot of interesting alternatives that keep the experience fresh even for veterans in this genre.

The game's art is fucking beautiful, the world they've created is some next-level catholic nightmare, the gameplay is immersive and responsive, the exploration is rewarding, the bosses are some of the best designed fuckers I've ever seen... and the animations? The execution animations are the coolest violent shit ever, they NEVER get old. 

All in all Blasphemous is probably the best game I've played that's inspired by Dark Souls/Sekiro/Bloodborne... and I gotta say: it's easily one of the best "metroidvania" since Symphony of the Night. These Spanish cats really outdid themselves, amigo.

The game Blasphemous is brilliantly made, and it is well worth the money. The game tackles the concepts of faith, sacrifice, and atonement in a universe that draws inspiration from the Spanish Inquisition.

The game's eye-catching visuals are highlighted by gorgeous hand-drawn animations and intricate backgrounds. The game appears to be a piece of art because of its stunning aesthetics. The soundtrack, with its ominous and atmospheric music that perfectly complements the game, is similarly impressive.

Blasphemous provides a challenging and enjoyable gaming experience. Fast-paced battle calls for ability and planning to beat adversaries. As they advance in the game, the player can unlock a variety of weapons and skills, allowing for several play styles and fighting strategies.

The game's narrative is captivating and contains a rich lore that is discovered through exploration and the finding of undiscovered mysteries. The player is submerged in a sinister and dangerous world full of intrigue and amazing world-building.

Blasphemous's usage of the Spanish Inquisition as a setting for the narrative sets it unique from other games. The game creates a distinctive and unforgettable universe that is both fascinating and horrifying by drawing inspiration from the history of the Inquisition, religious traditions, and mythology of the time.

Blasphemous is, all things considered, a must-play game for fans of difficult action-platformers with a creative flair. The tale is given depth by the usage of Spanish Inquisition themes and legend, and the game's gorgeous visual design produces an unforgettable, immersive experience that you'll remember long after you've finished playing.

Nitroglycerine is an explosive liquid which was first made by Ascanio Sobrero in 1846 by treating glycerol with a mixture of nitric and sulphuric acid. The reaction which follows is highly exothermic, i.e. it generates heat and will result in an explosion of nitroglycerine, unless the mixture is cooled while the reaction is taking place. Liquid nitroglycerine is colorless if pure. It is soluble in alcohols but insoluble in water. Nitroglycerine is extremely sensitive to shock and in the early days, when impure nitroglycerine was used, it was very difficult to predict under which conditions nitroglycerine would explode. Alfred Nobel studied these problems in detail, and was the first to produce nitroglycerine on an industrial scale. His first major invention was a blasting cap (igniter), a wooden plug filled with black gunpowder, which could be detonated by lighting a fuse. This in turn, caused an explosion of the surrounding nitroglycerine.

Alfred Nobel worked hard to improve nitroglycerine as an explosive that could be used in blasting rock and in mining. He made one of his most important discoveries when he found that by mixing nitroglycerine, an oily fluid, with kieselguhr, the mixture could be turned into a paste. This material could be kneaded and shaped into rods suitable for insertion into drilling holes. He called his paste dynamite and went on to develop a blasting cap which could be used to detonate dynamite under controlled conditions.

This is a buy no matter what type of game.

It deserve an iconic spot alongside Super Metroid and Castlevania in my opinion.

Everything about it is unique. 

-The artstyle and color palets is some of the best out there. 
-The action is quick and reflects oriented. 
-Exploring the maps is easy due to a couple ways of teleporting. 
-100%ing the game is challenging yet possible without guides. Some puzzles are challenging.
-The lore is captivating. 
-Sounds and musics are a great part of the thrill.
-Length of a first playthrough hits the sweet spot.
-Replayability is motivating and engaging. You have a ng+ with the possibility of 3 differents 'handicaps'.
-Enemy variety is huge
-Boss diversity is great and progressively challenging, assuming you encounter them in order. Some bosses are very challenging and will take you 10+ attempts, if not more. 

My only critics is that the majority of spells/items in the game aren't useful compared to others so the lack of versatility is present. More often than not you'll be using the same set up except if you do ng+ with the spells option.

I've noticed a few bugs but nothing that affected my enjoyment of the game play except that my button configuration does not allow me to teleport so I had to reconfigure them every time...

In other word, it's a must play.

Oh how I want to like this game, but I can't unfortunately. As a passionate metroidvania lover and dark souls acolyte I was really catched by the game's match to what I look for. Unfortunately, this is a just bad game from game design point of view. Don't get me wrong - the art and lore are fantastic, but to me it's all there is to it. 
Platforming is just terrible - hitboxes of the platforms / walls are actually not where you expect them to be because there is slight "isometric" distortion for environments sprites. 
Hitboxes are weird, especially when it comes to wall jumps where you have to hit button to stick to the wall (which is another bad game design decision really for metroidvania) and when the character is in the animation state. 
Controls... are just bad. If the game aims to be relatively precision-based platformer, controls have to satisfy the following 3 rules (they are not set by me of course): 
1. There should not be similar inputs for opposite actions
2. There should not be enforced actions
3. If the game wants to seem fair, it should forgive small mistakes made by player
All 3 of the above rules are broken in Blasphemous, unfortunately
Moreover, the game breaks its own rules way to often so it becomes frustrating.
This is a refund.

My first impressions of this game were rather negative. Am I going the right way? Why is everything so "sluggish"? Is this game so hard or do I simply suck so much? 
It reminded me of my first playthrough of the original Dark Souls and that's when everything "clicked". I just had to take everything a little bit slower, learn first and act second. And because of that, I really enjoyed my time with Blasphemous (I have beaten all the bosses, got all the achievements, etc.).
The game has that Dark Souls 1 styled reverse difficulty curve, where everything seems awful at first but after you observe and play around a bit, you start to "know" and things get pretty easy. For comparison: on my first save file I died about 15 times to one of the first bosses before finally barely beating him with sliver of my health. On my second, "no healing flasks" save I beat him first try in about 30 seconds without losing any health. And it's not like my reflexes got better, no, I simply learned what to do. I really liked that.
The thing that stands out even more is the audio/visual side of the game. Simply astonishing. Blasphemous bases a lot of it's influences from Spanish Catholicism, Christianity inspired art and it really shines through, making an unforgettable atmosphere, boosted even more by the moody soundtrack. It might have been the first time I said "Hey look, it's 'Pietà'!" while playing a video game. I loved the enemy designs (except the last boss, kinda underwhelming), the backgrounds and the imagery. Pretty unique stuff.
As always, there are some caveats. The platforming... is there. It's not Boshy difficulty but it feels a bit janky at times, especially the wall climb move. The hitboxes suffer sometimes, noticable the most near enemies that shoot thin laser projectiles and when jumping over things. The bosses can rarely overlay their attacks in a way where you just get stun-locked to death, especially when in a corner and that sucked. And my biggest complaint - contact damage and the dodge move. I still don't know why it's in the game (I mean I do but I just think it's unnecessary). I still don't understand the rules for when you're allowed to dodge through enemies. The dodge should either have i-frames or should disable contact damage but for every instance, not just randomly for some enemies.
Those things were a bit frustrating but overall I had an awesome time with the game. The combat feels good, especially after mastering the parry and spell usage. The exploration was enjoyable, the collectibles, the secret rooms, the puzzle rooms, etc. There's a lot to do and see.
Pick it up if you enojyed games like Dark Souls, Hollow Knight, Dead Cells or even if you're looking for something new. I think you'll have a blast-phemous time.

What an AMAZING game. As a fan of the genre, thisis one of my top threeMetroidvaniafavourites. Everything is carefully and armonically set to absorb you into this dark and oppressive atmosphere: the music is so good that it never turns repetitive, the visual art is breathtaking and the character design is top notch (plus, some cameos by famous architecture like the Cathedral of Córdoba... which also appears in Berserk, to which Blasphemous also has some loving homages, so double whammy easter egg there). I can't properly describe how every aspect of this game plays together in a symphony of good taste and a very well achieved story. Every piece of lore that you find, every creature you encounter, are just so rich in storytelling that you just want to know more about everything. I also appreciate that the game is challenging and sometimes unforgiving, the game design is great. Plus, as native Spanish speaker, I am super happy that there is a Spanish speaking game in the market, and I'm only writing this review in English so that I can say: English speakers! Give the audio a try in Spanish! I always enjoy content in its original language =)

TL DR, I think it’s a great game with some flaws.

I think the art style is the prominent thing in this game. If you like these themes and designs, you’ll probably love it. If not, you may not be into it.

The music is ..eeh. I think there are good tracks, even one of them is among my favourite game soundtracks. But when I think of my whole playthrough (please note that I haven’t played the DLCs) I had a mixed feeling about the music. Sometimes it felt right, sometimes it felt wrong.

So, as I mentioned above, I haven’t played the DLCs, because there was none at my time of playing. But I played after they fixed some movement and controlling clunkyness. It still felt clunky, way clunky than many other side scrollers I’ve played. Especially platforming, which isn’t the main focus of this game. 
Combat was nice I guess.
I liked the world design, and the map was pretty big (though it kinda became a standard for a metroidvania to have a huge world), but the metroidvania aspects had some flaws imo.
First of all, iirc, in very early game, we have an option to go three different ways, directly accessible. But one is way harder than other two, and of course somehow I found myself going there and had some hard times.
Secondly, there wasn’t really any upgrades. I mean for the movement or metroidvania side. It’s been awhile since I played Blasphemous, but I remember that instead of getting upgrades or abilities to access to another place, you got items? instead which helped you getting somewhere you weren’t able to before by adding a perk when equipped, or give an access directly. I’m not exactly sure.
I heard good things about its DLCs, except for Strife & Ruin, I haven’t played them, but it was nice to see Miriam from Bloodstained. The thing is, DLCs came some time after I finished my playthrough in which I got multiple endings(two or three I guess?) and I didn’t really wanted to come back to it for the first DLC. I actually downloaded the game, and started for the DLC, but the clunkyness discouraged me from playing it again. If in my time of playing there were DLCs, then I would probably do all the content I could because I got used to its controls and clunkyness. After not touching it for a while, I didn’t want another shot at it.

Lastly, please don’t make insta death spikes or insta death falls, OR any way of insta death a thing. I don’t like it, I’ll never like it. And in a game which I have mostly concerns of fluidity, please don’t.

Oh boy, so I really wanted to like this game but after seeing what it has to offer I'm going to have to say that this game was more often a chore than it was fun. Here's a quick bullet point breakdown first:

Pros:
- Great art
- Fantastic Music
- Some of boss fights are good

Cons:
- Slow hit recovery that can leave you getting stunlocked
- Enemies that feel Intentionally annoying instead of challenging
- Levels that are a slog to navigate

My main gripe with the game is that everything in between the bosses feels like something I just have to get through to access the next big fight, and that's not to say the bosses are perfect either but they're still engaging enough to be enjoyed.. It's like the levels of quality in this game are all over the place. It's kind of jarring to go from a boss fight that feels pretty good to something like a hallway full of 5 random enemy types that serve no other purpose than to get in your way or an obstacle course sprinkled with death traps you have to slowly move through, and sometimes you get both of these combined. This is a big deal throughout the game since metroidvanias require a fair bit of backtracking and item collecting, and it's still just as tedious and annoying to go through older areas even after getting more movement options later in the game.

If you want to see how anti-fun this game can be at times just look up what you have to do to get the 7th mea culpa (sword) upgrade, it kinda sums up this game as a whole.

I see people comparing this game to Hollow Knight and if that's the kind of game you're expecting going into this then you're being mislead (as I was). Hollow Knight is charming, has great bosses that feel fair, respects your time, and has levels that are actually enjoyable to traverse and this game doesn't has much to offer that can stack up against that.

A beautiful and ruthless adventure in a world dominated by a distorted religion.

Blasphemous's most vital characteristic is its pixel art, which blends gothic art and the brutal style of the game. The scenes, although simple, are captivating. They are beautiful and often frightening, showing entities with a macabre appearance and other mysterious creatures whose appearance can be uncomfortable. Spanish culture inspires blasphemous's settings, the Middle Ages and Catholicism, represented by locations, enemies, symbols and more. These elements create a disconcerting but exciting universe.

"For twisted are, were, and will be, the paths of the miracle." 

The world is fascinating to explore, with its stone cathedrals, its leprosy-stricken village and its lost mountain-top convent. The artist's gory and morbid imagery considers violent Catholic iconography and Dolorism, a doctrine that exhorts to "suffer to atone for one's sins."
Just like waking hallucinations, some moments are so striking and unique; they're almost enough to motivate the continuation of your journey, to see what crazy visions are in store for you next.

"Make my chest hurt with regret. Forge your punishment and nail it deep." 

The level design is well-developed, with several shortcuts and secret passages. Something that might be a bother is the platforming sections, which often become tedious and frustrating because of instant-death thorns or bottomless abysses, forcing you back to the latest save point and requiring a lot of back-and-forth travel; it gets tiring after a while. Most of the time, exploration is a well-balanced challenge. The distance from save points forces you to progress step by step, concentrating on each confrontation to avoid fatal errors. From these moments comes a sense of achievement commensurate with the effort made and great satisfaction at opening shortcuts, which are plentiful throughout the levels; these mark coherent design thought as whole and intelligently connected parts; the game knows how to change things up by alternating between vertical rooms that focus on combat and horizontal areas more conducive to platforming. Exploration is an absolute pleasure in most of the game.

"Go fearlessly, Penitent One." 

As for combat, it is functional. Its action palette remains simple and is in its entirety from the start (only a few special moves remain to be unlocked). Besides a simple sword strike, you can parry (in the right tempo), dodge and jump over inevitable blows. Giving three responses to opposing attacks to each enemy corresponds to an ideal response, which will be learned through experience. However, some bosses' battles offer natural resistance and can only be defeated by learning their attack patterns. 

The game's combat and exploration mechanics are simple in their execution. It is complex regarding its inventory system - with several options that affect gameplay. An excellent example is the passive skill items that can be gained, called Rosary Beads. Some objects protect against poisoning, and things that allow them to deal more damage or gain energy by breaking items in the scenario. There are also Relics, which grant the ability to see hidden platforms and hear voices from specific statues; Prayers are spells within this game; Hearts of Mea culpa add buffs to the sword through items found during our journey; Quest Items are abundant because of the several side quests available throughout the game; finally, there are Key Items which serve specific purposes like opening doors or unlocking treasure chests.

 "Sorrowful be the heart, Penitent One, full of clemency."

Death is inevitable, but luckily the penalty is forgiving. Your Fervour bar, which is used for special techniques, will become capped more and more with each death. You will also receive a penalty to gain Tears (In-game currency). This can be undone by returning to the place of death or visiting a particular location.

On the one hand, there are many frustrating moments here caused by unfair platforming, glitching enemies and easily failed sidequests. On the other hand, the art and story are excellent throughout the entire journey; and after seeing the last ending I think the good outweighs the bad.

Getting every achievement boils down to collecting everything in the base game and completing every sidequest. This took me 4 runs in total, because sidequests are very easy to fail. DLCs are not tied to any achievement, which is a shame, because it's the best content the game has to offer.

Blasphemous is one of the most fun games I have played in a while.

As a big fan of the original Symphony of the Night, Blasphemous really hit the spot. It's like a darker version of Castlevania gone full turbo Catholic. The protagonist is a messed as as the enemies.

Please note, the game is not perfect. There are a few niggling problems, but they don't detract from the game enough to be a problem. There is an unfortunate bug with the steam version where a controller shortcut doesn't work and you have to use the computer keyboard.

- Our lady of the Charred Visage: It was the first Boss that made me struggle a lot. The second phase where he throws fire balls with both hands really made me sweat! Challenging & fun fight
- Quirce: The boss wasn't hard, but his patterns were just really engaging
- Crisanta: This fight relied heavyly on parrying, which I always love in Metroidvanias
- Isidora: Hardest boss in the game, and it also relies a lot on parrying. Hearing her chants during the fight was dope, and she has a cool design.

The exploration wasn't that fun and I barely remember any area theme. It's the third Metroidvania that I play, and I realize that I enjoy combat a lot more than platforming.
While I was playing Blasphemous, I was always looking forward to the next Boss fight, but I was often losing my patience during the exploration between each Boss. And the same can be said about Grime,
which I played a few months ago.

Just a nitpick, but some hitboxes were a bit clunky. There were weird ladders & spikes hitboxes in Miriam's platforming challenges.

Entry warning: the game is difficult. Being a soulslike/metroidvania, don't expect modest and inviting gameplay. In contrast, the game doesn't take advantage of complex progress features to hide mediocre development. In fact, all of the content on offer is frighteningly wonderful. From the art direction to the soundtrack, the experience turns out to be indescribable. If you identify with the genre of the title and the theme incorporated (with a strong historical-religious and symbolic allusion), buy it. It's so worth it!

Being a soulslike, I see that the game tends to go towards a side more dedicated to the diversity of tasks than, truly, to that of a free choice RPG (although there are few choices throughout the gamplay). Still, I think it caters to the entire audience of the renowned "difficult games". It is worth mentioning that the game has a very low graphic requirement and that you will hardly have problems in this regard.

Blasphemous is not a Souls-like despite popular belief, it's a Metroidvania through and through. And it's another one of those games I really wanted to love, but I just can't. It's a game with a really gorgeous aesthetic, with so much love and talent poured into its world and art, but I feel the gameplay falls so incredibly short compared to its surface elements that I honestly don't understand how the game itself got so much praise.

It's not all bad though, because when it's at its best it can be a ton of fun and most of the bosses are incredibly creative and really fun to fight that I didn't mind attempting them over and over again. But its issues permeate the entire experience  and thus severely hurts the game for me to the point I can confidently say I don't like Blasphemous very much. As usual I break things down:

Pros:
- Incredible artwork with a gorgeous dark fantasy aesthetic
- Excellent music, which really adds to the atmosphere
- Fantastic boss fights that all felt unique with interesting quirks and methods to beat them
- Highly explorable world, with tons of branching paths and secrets to discover and shortcuts going back to previous areas
- Interesting magic system. with a unique way of gaining more magic by damaging yourself
- Lore seems quite interesting and very in-depth
- Parry mechanic has a ton of usage compared to most other games
- A wealth of content, being reasonably lengthy with extra modes, difficulties and secret activities to find
- Sliding stab attack is pretty damn great

Cons:
- Combat is extremely basic and anaemic and takes a bit too long to get the interesting abilities
- Unresponsive controls where my inputs were actively ignored, especially in combat when I want to slash upwards but Penitent One continues to attack horizontally, or sometimes he doesn't jump when I clearly pressed jump
- Enemies can have attacks that are insanely difficult to avoid and have absurd damage outputs, made even worse when you have extremely limited healing compared to most games
- Terrible hitboxes; there have been many times where I was clearly out of range of many melee attacks but somehow I still  get caught and suffer huge damage
- Contact damage; in a game where you're learning attack patterns, dodging past enemies and trying to exploit their openings, this mechanic is incredibly dumb, runs counter to flow of combat and feels needlessly cheap, especially when the contact damage hitbox lingers after certain enemies and bosses teleport away
- The vast majority of even the most basic enemies will never stagger from your attacks even with your most powerful attacks, yet you're staggered and thrown off of ledges with every single attack which again feels dumb and cheap
- Not enough opportunities to use special attacks and combos that you unlock, with enemies having countermeasures against them or by simply being a bad idea to use as they open you up to damage and knockback
- Certain enemies have combos that are timed perfectly to hit you after getting knocked down, meaning you'll suffer multiple hits and unable to dodge away - this is especially prevalent with bosses that use lightning attacks
- A certain section of a game has you getting locked in arenas to deal with enemies, however one enemy type regularly bugs out and stops you from killing it, meaning you have to reset the game to continue and hope it doesn't bug out again
- Platforming can feel very wonky and inconsistent, sometimes you jump up to a platform high enough to clearly land on it but you just fall right through, and sometimes Penitent One will grab onto a ledge and sometimes he won't
- Certain ranged enemies and traps are deliberately placed to knock you off ledges and into instant death spikes, which itself isn't a problem but Blasphemous overuses this trope in many areas and is just irritating
- Teleporters are rather poorly placed, sometimes you go through huge swathes of the world map without a single teleporter to previous areas, while other parts of the map have two teleporters very close together

So yeah Blasphemous has some really great moments but it's so bogged down by all of the issues I've mentioned, so much so to the point that I can comfortably say that it just isn't a very good game at all. I cannot fathom why people love it so much unless they're a glutton for punishment, which is fitting for the themes of the game, I guess? So maybe it's doing something right.

It's a real shame because it has everything it needs to be a great game, fantastic even, maybe a full on indie classic. But I can't ignore the incredibly sloppy execution and terrible inconsistencies that actively plague the entire game from start to finish. So many issues that I am amazed that so many people either completely ignore or have just forgotten even exist. I'm one of those people who thinks "Surely a game this beloved must be loved for a reason and I just don't get it", but after beating the game my scepticism was proven true and I think it's just overhyped fluff and a great big disappointment. There are Metroidvanias out there that are so much better and far more considered than Blasphemous. Not to knock the developers as they clearly poured a lot of love into it but sadly that effort didn't translate into a fun game, I wish them all the best on their next project though.

I don't play sidescrollers often, much less platformers so I was pleasantly surprised to enjoy this one!
If you want to see Catholicism rewritten with a dash of Dark Souls, here you go.

[b]Biggest draw:[/b]
The main interest for me was the visuals and lore. 
The dark fantasy elements easily kept my attention. Exploring is my main interest in games like these. It's gorgeous to look at. I loved the way everything was designed, especially the characters and bosses. Visually I think it brought a lot of fun to the table and not once did I think the designs in this game were "trying too hard" or being disingenuous. I personally wasn't crazy about most of the skins, but I appreciate the playful nostalgia they have.
To me the world feels small but very alive and VERY worth the exploration! The dialogue is pretty heavy handed with its wide vocabulary, which made it hard for me to keep up with sometimes, but still kept me interested and wondering about the in's and out's of the world!

I only wish there were more cutscenes!


[b]Biggest gripes:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The backtracking was rough and made game progression feel like a chore at times. And what's worse is that the backtracking and grinding in this game just doesn't mesh very well. I like grinding in games, but when it comes to making expensive purchases (items, upgrades, etc.) the amount of work put in doesn't seem worth what you'll get in return. However, I found that for the most part if you play smart, you shouldn't have to grind too much.
    [*]Miriam's challenges overall felt really out of place and took away some of the game's magic for me. I know she is from another game but she just does not fit with the game's aesthetics nor the game's lore in general. The difficulty and reward (and lack of lantern jump explanation) in this DLC made it the most infuriating part of the entire game. I gotta say I've never felt like I wasted time playing a video game before... until I ran into this DLC. If its your first time playing I would completely skip past Miriam's challenges.
    [*][i]IF YOU'RE GOING TO HAVE LANTERN JUMPS THEN PLEASE EXPLAIN LANTERN JUMPS IN THE TIPS SECTION!!![/i] I spent hours doing them wrong and it caused a tremendous amount of grief when it came to Miriam's challenges. This is an issue many other players have had!
[/list]

+Challenging but fair combat.

-Cryptic.

Overall, I enjoyed Blasphemous but hope they change some of the negatives for their next project.

Why is it that I enjoy committing CBT in souls-like games but I just don't like From Soft? I think the answer lies in the fact that From Soft games feel grindy in a way that is hard to explain but is all too real of an issue for games like Dark Souls, Bloodborne, Elden Ring, etc. I know these games are heralded as the second coming of hard video game jesus but they just honestly start boring me after a while.
Games like Blasphemous, Hollow Knight, Olija, etc. make me enjoy the souls-like genre more, and I think that has to do with the fact that they have fun, simple movement abilities and attacks blended seamlessly into the metroidvania backbone that it makes them simultaneously frustrating but so dripping with incredible art and details that it keeps me playing for hours at a time. Where Elden Ring felt overwhelmingly long and unnecessarily difficult in even the tamest of areas (hence feeling like a waste of time and, funnily enough, feels like it has more empty space than the anti BoTW people would have you believe) Blasphemous has another secret area with some neat little trinket that has noteworthy impact in the way you play the game.
Overall this game is a banger and a 10/10 that I will be 100%'ing because of how incredibly fun it is.
