Blasphemous is a 2D action-platformer developed by The Game Kitchen.

Graphics: Blasphemous features hand-drawn, gothic-inspired graphics, with detailed environments and character designs. The game's graphics are both beautiful and dark, creating a memorable and atmospheric world.

Sound: The sound design in Blasphemous is excellent, with a haunting musical score and appropriate sound effects for combat and the game's world. The game's audio helps to create a memorable and immersive experience.

Story: Blasphemous features a deep and dark story, set in a world plagued by a curse known as "The Miracle." Players take on the role of the Penitent One, a lone warrior on a quest to uncover the truth behind the curse and bring an end to the suffering of the world. The game's story is told through the player's interactions with the world and its inhabitants, and is a standout feature of the game.

Gameplay: Blasphemous is a challenging 2D action-platformer, with fast-paced combat and a variety of weapons and abilities for players to master. The game also features a deep upgrade system, allowing players to power up their weapons and abilities as they progress. The game's world is filled with secrets to discover, and the game's difficulty can be adjusted to suit the player's preference.

Good Points: Blasphemous is a beautiful and challenging action-platformer, with a dark and memorable story. The game's challenging gameplay and upgrade system offer a lot of replayability, and the game's community is active and supportive.

Bad Points: Some players may find the game's difficulty to be too high, and the game's platforming elements can be frustrating at times. Additionally, the game's graphics may not be to everyone's taste, as they are intentionally dark and gothic in nature.

Overall, Blasphemous is a beautiful and challenging action-platformer, with a standout story and memorable world. Fans of the genre will not be disappointed.

If Velázquez, Goya and Murillo were indie devs this would have been the result. The first thing that will likely draw you to Blasphemous is its macabre aesthetics that will transport you into this nightmarish land where suffering is the status quo. The boss and enemy design is one of the most intricate and interesting I've seen in a long time. Yes, the inspiration is mostly taken from catholic iconography but this game takes that further and molds it into grotesque pitiable creatures. The OST also deserves praise because it perfectly complements the game but it's great on its own as well. There's no cheesy epic choir boss fights with faux latin lyrics. Every track fits the area and the boss, every track is distinct like the acoustic and electric spanish guitars, the flowing piano arpeggios, the unsettling ambient parts, the playful flamenco all of it suits the story it's trying to tell. 

Gameplay-wise you've got your sword and your prayers. Prayers are basically your magical abilities and with your sword you have a decent number of moves considering the 2D medium. You can also improve your character build with rosary beads and mea culpa hearts which you'll find scattered throughout your journey and also relics which will be crucial to traversing some areas and spots. Parrying and dodging are extremely important to master and my favorite out of the combat are the execution animations. They're so well done. So there's a decent amount of gameplay mechanics to customize your playstyle and I would suggest playing with them because they do make a difference. The locations are also diverse and there's a certain charm in navigating those labyrinthine areas although the platforming can get frustrating at times. There's going to be a small number of puzzles to solve and taking hints from your environment and reading descriptions is a good habit to have.

As for its story, you get fed bits and pieces of the lore in a souls style through sparse enigmatic dialogues, item description and visual storytelling. And while the game obviously derives inspiration from dark souls the game is entirely its own thing but those who enjoy souls (like) games will probably enjoy Blasphemous too.

All in all, this is now one of my favorite games even though I haven't played metroidvanias that much before. I'm greatly looking forward to Blasphemous 2 one of my most anticipated games at the moment.

nothing special. the art's pretty good, but there's a few pretty glaring issues. 1, despite the fact that the platforming (and movement in general) doesn't feel especially great, there are s o m a n y e n v i r o n m e n t a l h a z a r d s . so fucking many. half of them are instakills. with how spaced out the bonfires are, it makes for a real painful experience going through the same hazards over and over, all of them taking 30 seconds to get past just because of how they're timed. 2, even though parrying is supposed to be a main part of your arsenal, it doesn't work most of the time. it's only advantageous against light attacks, which become increasingly rare over the course of the game. it doesn't work on projectiles (or things the game calls projectiles, like enemies jumping towards you), and is objectively worse than dodging on heavy attacks. if there's a parry in a game, it's incredibly fun when it works on absolutely everything. take sekiro, ultrakill, or MGRR, for example. all incredibly fun games, all have the parry as a primary gameplay tool. you can parry projectiles, melee, even when something 10 stories tall swings its sword at you, you just need to have a steady hand to deflect it. there's a counter for everything if you know how to do it. in this game, someone throws a rock at you, and, despite your best efforts at defending yourself, it takes off a tenth of your healthbar. someone swings a sword too hard, you're knocked 10 feet away and given no opening. it just feels like a hastily added pile-on mechanic, something to make it seem like it's not just hollow knight but worse. really, that's all it is. i can't recommend it unless you really, really, really like the art style and hearing "penitent one" and "repentance" and "punishment" constantly chanted at you by the npcs.

This game has a lot of sins to atone for...

the most grievous one is....

...claiming that it's a Metroidvania.

I'd flog and Y-button whoever thought to put that tag up there....

It's a 2D Souls game (and a beautiful one), that's it. 

Your mobility doesn't change all game long (no, portals don't count) and backtracking is painful..also because...
Upgrades are very boring (make invisible platforms appear); items increase your strength only marginally; even at the end of the game you don't feel particularly powerful or different than in the beginning;  you still need to stay careful around enemies and they will keep slowing you down; the game speed never picks up, even for the most basic enemy from the beginning your pimped out pope-slapping buffed up endgame main will still need to wait for the attack animation...parry..counter...move on..

Item management sucks - some upgrades can only be changed at check points, but virtually all items feel so marginal/not powerful at all, that it feels random, how you can change some anytime you want and others only at save points. The truly game relevant items, that open new pathways eg., shouldn't be optionally equippable by the way..you have three 'special' slots for them, there's more than three in the game...and you can switch them in and out anytime. Why? What's the point? Just keep them activated all the time.

Now having played (and finished) a so-called 'souls-like Metroidvania' I'm convinced that these formulas don't match. The fun of getting ever crazier mobility, speed and combat ability runs counter to a souls game, which is supposed to remain challenging all the time and where you're supposed to play slowly and carefully.

Minor complaints: 
[list]
    [*]The religious/Christian/inquisition theme I wasn't a big fan of...but it gives license for the devs to come up with some crazy boss art. 
    [*]As much as I love pixelart, the pixelated interface/lore text was rather annoying and hard to read, I think it's fine to keep text ...you know..HD..readable..
    [*]Just like Souls games, even though Hollow Knight is guilty of this as well, the story seems to be an afterthought, or something that you need to piece together by finding items to read the lore...I'd prefer it when the story unfolds as you play it. One of the better/exciting parts of the game, was [spoiler] in the beginning, when you were followed by the red dude and there seemed to be multiple 'actors' involved in the story, After you kill him and his sister, you feel pretty much alone again in the world.[/spoiler]   
[/list]

So..I actually wouldn't recommend the game for a pure Metroidvania fan, in that regard the game is truly disappointing...but if you're just looking for a beautiful challenging 2D platformer with an open world, a crazy Christian theme and some gore, go ahead. The [spoiler]giant snake[/spoiler] fight alone is worth the money.

Visually the game looks really good and there is also a ton of detail in the animations. They even have a specific execution animation for each of the enemy types for which there are a pretty large amount of which is always fun to see when you try it on a new enemy. Music is also pretty solid and really adds to the fun of exploring the game. Ok, now the negatives. One major downside that nearly made me drop this game was the bosses which throughout most of the game, are pretty damn lame. I think there are other endgame bosses which are probably pretty good based on Isidora being a fun and challenging boss, but I think I'd need to do an entire other play through to get to them cause I think I locked myself out of it. [h1]Blasphemous does a lot of things very well, but sometimes makes really questionable decisions with how it plays[/h1]
[h2]The good:[/h2]
[list]
[*] Climate and setting.
This game has an amazing atmosphere. You really feel immersed in the world. Each location is very distinctive, with its own feel.

[*] Intricate story that you need a video explanation for to truly appreciate.
The story of Cvstodia and The Miracle is a simple, yet very effective one. Most questions are answered, but others aren't. Blasphemous really succeeds in making you want more of it. The worldbuilding is great, giving you tidbits of lore about everything, the only downside being that most of it is through text that you might not want to read through.

[*] The animation and OST
The art direction in the game is amazing. It gives out a retro vibe, while being mostly fluid and is very detailed. Character designs are very memorable and leave a lasting impresssion. The soundtrack only accents it, keeping you immersed through the whole playthrough. 

[*] The exploration
It pulls of the main appeal of metroidvanias really well. Exploring leads to rewards, as well as lore about the world. The map is very accessible, allowing you to mark locations from the start, which helps if you get a movement item later than you should.
[/list]
[h2]The not so great/subjective[/h2]
[list]
[*] The combat.
Don't get me wrong, the combat in this game can be rewarding, but sometimes it can be frustrating. If you're looking for Hollow Knight depth of combat, you're in the wrong place. It's possible for bosses to feel underwhelming or a bit unfair, and the flow is easily disrupted.

[*] The relics/movement items.
You can only equip 3 of them at a time, but you can change them anytime, so... what's the point? They're quite unique for your average metroidvania, and so is the way of getting them. It's usually not so obvious, meaning you might miss out on them and play half the game without a movement item, which might get a bit annoying. It ties well into the next point, being...

[*] The difficulty.
I'm not the one to complain about difficulty, but some might be turned away, especially since it isn't just the combat that is hard. Finding secrets, even the ones relevant to the story, is hard. It's not obvious what you have to do to progress through the story. This includes unlocking different endings. You work for them through the whole game, unknowingly. You will very likely [spoiler]get the worst ending[/spoiler] the first time you play.
[/list]
[h2]The bad[/h2]
[list]
[*]Some design decisions
It's possible for ingame sidequests to break, rendering you unable to complete them. If you hunt for achievements, this will be annoying. You also get locked out of alternate endings upon finishing a playthrough or if you kill a boss too early. One such occurence is the inability to complete an alternate ending sidequest after fighting a boss, but it's so vague that you might think it's a bug. The NPC will straight up refuse to talk to you for no reason, making you start a new save, if you want to attempt it again.

[*]The movement, or rather, one of the (free) DLCs.
The movement's clunky. Most of the time it won't matter, but a DLC added parkour sections to the game. They range from mediocre to atrocious. What's the point of a timed trial if there are cycles in it? Couldn't you just replace them with actual obstacles? It gets to a point where sometimes skipping a part will not start the further part of the course, meaning you have to wait for the game to catch up, standing in one place. And getting hit on a ladder will send you into freefall, most likely into a pit of spikes, but not if you are jumping? The movement system could've really used some polish. 
[/list]
[h3]If you enjoyed Hollow Knight, you'll most likely enjoy this game too. If it's your first metroidvania, I think you should play other metroidvanias first and see if they stick.[/h3]

EDIT - Beat the game for ending A. Additional details below

The first 20 minutes was okay. Then the platforming and constant walking became annoying (why is there no fast travel if the map is huge?!). Near the end of my gameplay it felt like a chore. I really disliked the combat as it felt less like "git gud" and more like "let's throw several enemies at you in small spaces while you try to not die from falling or spikes". I couldn't lower the difficulty so I just had to repeat several areas over and over again...while accruing guilt which is a punishment system set in place for dying too often. Why am I being punished for dying? That's so stupid.

Apparently the beginning is super difficult while the end-game is a joke but I'm too fed up with the game and don't think I'll return to finish it. It's a shame too because the visuals and story seemed interesting enough. Gameplay always comes before story and art for me though.

EDIT (original was 2h at playtime)

So I was bored and had nothing else to play so I ended up continuing. The game does (mostly) get easier with the final bosses being a joke. Thing is, I didn't feel powerful because all of that stuff is offset by insta-death from spikes and (if you don't have an item equipped) falling into pits. That's such a dumb mechanic imo. I can kill huge bosses, obliterate several enemies at once, even get incinerated and still come out okay, but a single touch from a spike and I'm straight up dead. This becomes even more annoying when you start doing time challenges as they are always filled with spikes. There aren't really check points so you end up being teleported back to the beginning of the time challenge. This can get extremely annoying when the challenges can be a few minutes long, meaning you have to repeat certain sections over and over again.

Which leads to the next issue, bugs. The game is generally pretty good at not being buggy but sometimes you can get glitched which requires a reload. This becomes especially apparent if you become frustrated enough with the time challenges that you enable invincibility (not gonna go into detail how to do this). I get that the game wasn't designed for invincibility in mind...I also don't think there should ever be a situation where dying would revive you in a pit of spikes, forcing a reload. Seems pretty simple to me to code a condition where dying teleports you to the last-visited prayer dieu or the beginning of the time challenge/checkpoint (I was fed up enough that I enabled invincibility for almost all of the time challenges so I don't know if the check points are intrinsic).

What can be incredibly frustrating is that this is supposed to be a platformer game yet you have to be very precise to grab the edge of a platform. It ruins the immersion when I'm playing with a controller and I slightly overshot the ledge. There should be some wiggle room, I don't think being overly precise was a good design decision. If the main focus was platforming then I guess I could sort of understand it, yet this is also a souls-like game so I don't know what's up. Even more annoying however are the possible stunlocks that can arise with no ability to escape once started. At least certain souls-like games have a poise stat, instead you can get hit by swinging axes that drop you into a pit of spikes with no hope of aerial recovery, or get hit by certain enemies that do follow-ups and take off a chunk of health, get mobbed to death if you're unlucky, etc.

Fast travel does become an option after a certain point, it doesn't seem like a good idea to put that mechanic behind a wall of progress though. First you have to deal with zero fast travel for a while, then you get access to a limited fast travel option that requires you to be in certain areas, then you need to pay a good chunk of money to access a new fast travel option (20k total which is a lot in the beginning) which is more accessible than the first but requires you to be at a shrine, and FINALLY you can stumble upon a prayer that teleports you to the last-visited shrine. Unfortunately this can make it annoying to reach your desired location since the method is 1) equip the prayer, 2) activate the prayer, 3) rest at the shrine, and 4) fast travel to your shrine of choice (with probably unequipping the prayer). The time wasted adds up if you fast travel a lot which you probably will at some point. Keep in mind that you can only reach this point after you've invested several hours into the game. QoL would be vastly improved if this was just implemented from the very beginning of the game, I don't see the value otherwise as it feels the game doesn't respect my time.

I have some other issues with the game but those were my main ones. I still think the art is great and the lore is genuinely interesting. I also appreciate the narrative direction to scatter the story among items, dialogue, and npc quests as it creates an incentive to read stuff over, increasing immersion. This was the main reason why I kept playing even though everything else started to feel like a chore to me. I'm probably going to watch a youtube video or two that goes over the different endings and lore since I don't have it in me to start ng+ in order to find out all the details of the in-game universe.

Overall I think the game mechanics are frustrating and unfair while the game's saving grace is its art and story, soundtrack wasn't bad either. I don't recommend this game, instead watch a few YouTube videos about it with the wiki handy.

The core game play constantly annoyed and bored me. I enjoyed the game the most when exploring new areas. The areas and scenery are amazing. The story is interesting to follow, although I found myself getting bored near the end with constant backtracking. Metroidvania's are supposed to excel with backtracking, but this game makes it feel like a chore. You will run all the way to the beginning of the game, just to open a door and have a single platform section while your expectations were much higher. The enemies are very well designed, but some become annoying walls that force you to stop and fight each time you want to pass. However my biggest gripe is with the bosses. I have played my share of souls-like games and I understand the importance of the bosses.  The bosses in this game are amazing visually, but the fight itself is very unsatisfying. You are basically fighting meat bags that  take hit after hit while you only have a few choices of attacks. Most of the late game bosses turn into hit-and-run strategies. You get very small opening of attacks and they punish you for going for a full combo. When it comes to the final hit that kills the boss, I felt more satisfied that it was over rather than satisfied that I killed a "hard boss." The worst thing about this was how contrast the final boss was to the rest. It was a literal pushover. After I fought it, I was staring at the screen saying "that's it?" The true ending at least adds on to the fight, but it only helps so much. 

-----------------------------------TLDR-----------------------------------

PROS: Amazing scenery, atmosphere, art style, character/enemy design

CONS: Boring repetitive combat, lack of mobility, unsatisfying bosses extremely underwhelming final boss fight.

Basically get the game if you don't need to have an engaging combat system. The story and world that you explore makes this game good enough for purchasing and trying out.

[h1]It is not the sun rising, but our sins[/h1]
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
I first heard of [b]Blasphemous[/b] from a few friends and my interest grew after learning about the setting and challenging gameplay, I like it when my skills are put to the test. It was an experience to behold, and I am excited to talk about my experience during my adventures throughout the game.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Complex and enjoyable story 
[*]Fun combat, with a good variety of enemies
[*]Unique upgrades and abilities to acquire
[*]Fun boss fights that are gruesome, fun, and challenging
[*]Lots of secrets to uncover and find
[*]Beautiful 2D art style that is both disturbing and beautiful
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Platforming can be a bit of an issue, mainly when it comes to wall climbing
[*]Climbing ladders can also be an issue
[*]Not all upgrades seem relevant or useful
[*]Sliding past enemies sometimes does not work
[*]The backtracking can be a bit of an issue
[*]Issues with enemy placement
[*]Bosses, while still challenging, are on the easier side
[*]Minor bugs as well
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story is set in a deeply religious world known as [b]Cvstodia[/b], a recent event known as the [b]Miracle[/b] that manifested itself to those who were pious or sinful. All the pain that a soul has is tangible with everyone everywhere, it could be a form of blessing for some, for others, a punishment. With a divine and unfathomable will, all a person can do is make penance.

Does the story for [b]Blasphemous[/b] make sense? No, did I explain it in any way that would make sense? No, will you enjoy the story anyway without really knowing anything? Yes. It’s a bit of an interesting take, as you won’t know what the story is even telling you, yet you may like it for its mystery in what the game may throw at you next. There isn’t really a whole lot to say about the story, so I’ll have to just leave it at that for the most part.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]Blasphemous[/b] has some really fun combat that I for the most part enjoyed very much, there are a wide variety of enemies to fight throughout the game. You can block and parry enemy attacks to stun them and then attack, sometimes you may even be able to perform an execution move on rare occasions. There are also a few upgrades for you to get and they have a variety of uses for you in combat or in movement. Some abilities you get allow you to access other areas in the game that you may have not been able to get to previously. It adds a reason to go back and get certain things if you strive to get 100% completion. They all have their own unique uses and I like how the game has a bunch of different options for you to try out. You can only equip a few abilities at a time, so make sure to try out different things to get the best benefits.

There is also a skill tree that will allow you to get permanent upgrades, like increasing your combo, or giving you access to different attacks for you to use. There isn’t a whole lot of stuff you can get but there may be something in the skill tree that catches your interest.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2918925804
The boss fights are really fun to challenge and can be gruesome at times, they can be a bit hard to fight and that’s what makes a boss a boss. They had their own attack patterns and ways to beat them. There are also a ton of secrets for you to go out and find, like extra flask bottles, getting extra health, or other power-ups that can aid your journey.

Now despite me saying good things about [b]Blasphemous’s[/b] gameplay, I have a ton of issues with it. [b]Blasphemous[/b] says that it’s a hard game but despite it just throwing the worst aspects of a 2D platformer at you, this game is surprisingly easy. Now, the difficulty is subjective to each person, but I have experience with these types of games. The platforming in this game has to be one of the biggest issues, yes you read that right, a platformer has issues with its platforming. When it comes to wall climbing, I will press the button at the right moment, for it to not register and I end up falling to my death. It starts to be more of a problem when enemies who fire projectiles come into play as well. Climbing ladders have an issue as well because when it comes to jumping from one ladder to the next it may not register either. This too has led to me dying a few times as well and it really starts to get annoying when I keep dying from things beyond my control.

Some of the upgrades I got from the skill tree I never used once, there is one where you can turn your blood into a projectile to help take out enemies, but I never used it. There is also one where you can use it to strike your enemies when going down in mid-air, which I only used for one secret. The only skill tree upgrades that I actually found useful, were the ones that increased the combo that I could pull off since that actually had an impact on enemies and bosses. There are also ones that you may find scattered throughout the game and even those ones may feel useless too.

Then there is an issue with the backtracking. Now, backtracking in [b]Mertiodvenias[/b] is common but [b]Blasphemous’s[/b] method of doing it is an issue - here, I’ll talk about an example. So, at some point in the game, you will need to get your hands on the [b]Key of the Inquisitor[/b] from the [b]Sleeping Canvases[/b], to get access to the [b]Jaw of Ashgan[/b]. To get this key, you need to buy it from this shop with 9999 of the game’s currency. These shops are not marked on the map, [b]Candelaria[/b], the shopkeeper does have multiple shops in the game but sells different things in each shop. So, you have to get it from that one area, these two areas I mentioned, aren’t really connected to each other so you have to go through other areas as well. 

On top of that, there isn’t really a way to fast-travel, except through these mirrors that are scattered throughout the game, or this one special move that will bring you back to your last spawn point. Suffice to say, that’s quite a tall order to get to that one area.

However, that’s not all either, as I have issues with the bosses. I did say they are challenging but some of them are actually quite easy. You may die a few times, but all you have to do is memorize the attack patterns and you have beaten the boss. Enemy placement is also an issue, sometimes, this is more of a minor issue but when it does come up, it’s an issue. Some enemies are obstacles that you can’t hit but have to avoid and let me tell you, avoiding some of them is not easy. Sliding away from enemies also sometimes does not work, there are some where you can slide but with big boss enemies, you can’t and are forced to fight them.

I also came across a point where an enemy got stuck on a platform and I had to restart from my last checkpoint.

[h1]Graphics and Performance[/h1]
[b]Blasphemous[/b] is very beautiful in a disturbing way, I love how the pixel art style was done and it made the game have a somewhat creepy feel to it with some of the enemies. The game should be able to be run on low-end PCs without issue. I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM. I should also give a small mention of the soundtrack, as I enjoyed that as well.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
Now, despite all of my complaints with [b]Blasphemous[/b], I still had a fun time playing it and I think that’s the most important part of the game. For some, it may be a challenge but for others, it won’t be as hard as some people make it out to be. However, there is still enjoyment to be found and I think it’s a good game, nonetheless, although I’d maybe wait for a sale before buying.

If you love Souls games and Super Metroid (you know for the masterpiece for SNES) you will love this.

It combines wonderful pixelated graphics and great leveldesign (Super Metroid) with the soulsborne style of gaming (learning how the enemy attacks and parrying/doding). This isn't a easy game, enemies strike hard and you will die. But rise again and learn new ways to attack or find items that will help you on your way.

Even if the urge to look up guides or explanations for what certain items is for, I highly recommend that you don't do that. Explore the game and find out for yourself instead, much more rewarding.

All it has going is the fantastic art work and pretty well done voice acting, outside of that it sadly falls flat.

-Game relies heavily on platforming for its challenge yet the controls and platforming detection isn't very tight

-Most of the mobs you fight aren't all that difficult to deal with outside of a few exceptions and usually as i mentioned above, it relies mainly on putting bad platforming around to make enemies a challenge.

-Boss fight vary from too easy to being kinda broken and poorly done, some bosses re-use animations for different kinds of attacks with very minor differences making it annoying to guess if this is the variant of the attack you can parry or if it's the one you're suppose to jump over/dodge through, so sometimes with some fights it just boils down to dying a couple of times trying to spot the minute differences as to what to parry, what to dodge and what to jump over. 

-Speaking of dodging, it's also a trial by error to figure out often at which animation intervals you can dodge through some enemies or their attacks. Some are obvious, yet some leave you confused as to why you couldn't dodge through it.

-Combat is not really satisfying, something is missing from it, it just feels very bland and average to play. Maybe cause there's not enough interesting moves or the fact you're locked to just one weapon and all you got mainly is just some trinkets to add some % modifiers, there are spells to find but they have limited uses and aren't all that earth shattering.

This game has fantastic atmosphere, story, voice acting, and visuals. The exploration is rewarding, with every item you find providing you with more lore that fills out the picture of this unique and intimidating world. It's commitment to its theme is just sublime to witness. This is what drags you forward until the end, even if the game is fighting you every step of the way.

The gameplay, especially in comparison to the other recent metroidvanias, is shit. It lacks precision, which leads to combat and platforming just feeling a little off. Furthermore, the instant deaths from falling into a pit of spikes (as apposed to games like hollow knight and grime, which teleport you to the last stable ground with some health lost) just make platforming challenges a nightmare of attrition. 

I understand difficulty is the point, but fair difficulty is clearly a challenge and you as a developer should brainstorm that properly before trying to develop a difficult game, instead of just relying on cheap shit that just ends up frustrating the player. I've spent entire days fighting Soulsborne bosses, because they are fair and I know the only thing lacking is my skill. In Hollow Knight, its hardest platforming challenges were a joy to overcome because, due to very precise controls, once again the only thing holding me back was skill. With Blasphemous, every success just feels cheap and almost unearned because the gameplay feel is just to lacking.

Yet, when you suffer through and find a nice juicy bit of lore, or a wonderfully grotesque looking boss or awe inspiring location, is all somehow feels worth it. 

If I could be bothered, I would cheat, but as it stands I'm either going to suffer through until the end or give up and replay Hollow Knight, the undisputed king of this genre.

What happens when you combine Hollow knight, the Spanish inquisition and Francisco Goya all into one video? Blasphemous, a game choking with the amount of style and character crammed into just a 663 mb package.

Blasphemous follows the traditional metroidvania style formula with many of the beloved tropes of the genre: branching paths, hidden content, equipment builds, time trials, etc. But where blasphemous really puts itself in the limelight is in the presentation of these timeless traditions of its genre. For example, your way of increasing your max HP is by taking on the sins of a naked female saint as she removes swords from her body which represent her own sins upon this earth. In other words, a high mediaeval interpretation of period cramps.

The game presents itself with the best pixel art I've ever seen in animation and general designs. All the characters both major and minor, friend and foe have received gorgeous animations with clear inspiration from Catholicism, Iberian culture and Francisco Goya’s works. The fact that with a firm knowledge of the time period and the culture it was pulling from, I was able to go “Wow! That is such a cool detail/interpretation” is both a joy to my inner history nerd and art nerd. It’s also just plain fascinating to see how such complex ideas can be turned into the forms of pixels, such as how one boss has each of it’s bejewelled hands gleam in the light of it’s magic (with the benefit that the outfit the boss wears is accurate to its position in the church). Overall the game would easily get a recommendation even if it was just an art book.

A fond highlight I found whilst playing was the combat. Whilst not on par with sole combat games like Sekiro, it consistently felt clean and responsive to inputs which is certainly a nice benchmark to have when starting the game. Loathe be the times when you have to think “I’ve got to exploit the combat to do this” rather than “I need to get better at the combat to do this”. In addition, I found particular enjoyment out of the parrying mechanic, or more accurately the portrayal of parrying. It’s become a joke across gaming that these little characters can counter giants without even budging an inch, but in Blasphemous your character slides across the floor and has to recover after parrying a colossal attack. You are still at the advantage in this situation, but it's certainly an appreciated detail.

The soundtrack was enjoyable, nothing too noteworthy I found but certainly not a game where I mute the music volume and load up spotify, so take that as you will. The main musical highlights are naturally the boss fights which range from grand orchestras to latin choirs, an interesting range of sound but all on brand for this zealous journey against the true miracle.

In conclusion, Blasphemous is a very strong playthrough with a good run length to match. Your average run will probably take around 6 to 7 hours with a fair bit of guide usage, raise that up to around 9 hours if you want to grab all the trinkets and upgrades. It has some flaws natural to the genre, such as backtracking for important items or how certain aspects/features can be missed due to either the wrong sequence of events occurring or just if the player doesn't pay enough attention. In short, a good purchase at regular £20  pricing and practically a must have at its sale price of £5.

Final score - 85/100

I'm editing my review on this because I feel like I was too harsh when I first played it.  That, or the game has gotten much better since the content updates it received.
I still despise the platform in this game.  It isn't satisfying, it feels clunky.  The worst moments I had in this game where I just wanted to alt f4 were doing the platforming challenges for the Bloodstained collab.  It's even worse when I have to fight and platform at the same time.
The combat in the game is very satisfying.  You have a very simple skill tree for your sword where no upgrade feels useless or like a novelty. 
While I rarely found prayers to be necessary, there are a large amount of them to find and use and almost all of them are very fun.  I would relate them to the powers in Bioshock Infinite, where you could pretty much go the whole game without using them, but they're there for you to have fun with.
I originally found the bosses in this game to be very lackluster and boring, and that still holds true for the original cast.  However, the bossfights added in Wounds of Eventide and the NG+ Amanecida bosses are really good.  Very challenging, and very fun to fight.  
The art direction in this game is fantastic.  The pixel art is beautiful, and drawing inspiration from Christianity to create a dreary, souls-like world was a good call.  Sometimes it feels like characters are just saying words that mean nothing, but that's not a big deal.  
It being a metroidvania, there is a lot of backtracking.  When I first played the game in 2019, the only form of fast travel was from using specific portals located throughout the world, of which there were about five.  This made backtracking incredibly tedious.  Since then though, one of the content updates introduced a way for you to fast travel between the bonfire shrines, which makes the game much less of an awful trek.
NG+ in this game is a lot more compelling than in others.  To go into NG+ you need to take on a gameplay challenge that will persist for the whole run.  There is also the secret NG+ bosses for you to find and fight.  Most games don't provide a good motivation for you to play again, this one does.

Seeing as a lot of things I had problems with were fixed or addressed in content updates, I felt it right to change my harsh review.  My second playthrough of this game was wonderful (save the platforming...) and I expect I'll play it a third time in the future.  7.5/10

Information up front: THIS GAME DOES NOT HAVE CROSS-COMPATIBILITY FOR SAVE FILES BETWEEN WINDOWS PC AND STEAM DECK/LINUX.  It supports cloud saving, but you cannot seamlessly switch from deck to PC and back again, as they are separate save files.  Looking into this, this is something the developer has to handle on their end.  So be aware that if you buy this game, your Deck saves and local/PC saves will be separate... unless you're running Linux on your PC, I guess.  It's really something that oughta be in the damned "great on deck!" info box... not a deal-breaker, but it was frustrating to learn about this the hard way.

ADDITIONALLY: This is NOT a "Souls-like" game.  It has some similarities to Dark Souls, most notably in the setting and how it tells stories, but in terms of gameplay mechanics it has a lot more in common with Hollow Knight than Dark Souls.  There IS a New Game+ mode that replicates a lot of Dark Souls concepts, however.

That out of the way, Blasphemous is pretty great.  Fantastic and weird art and aesthetics, excellent music and sound design, and while I would say the controls and gameplay aren't as refined as some of the finest examples in the Metroidvania genre like Super Metroid or Hollow Knight, they get the job done most of the time.

There are certainly frustrations to be found, but given that the game doesn't much punish you for failure other than being sent back to spawn/loading from save, they're not especially cumbersome.  There ARE some areas added in the DLC that are clearly intended to be tackled in New Game+ or otherwise very close to the end of the game when you're fully powered up, and they're very frustrating before that point... so that's something to keep in mind.  If you're seeing pirate ships, you might want to explore elsewhere until you're close to the end of the game.  I didn't learn about this until I buckled and decided to check guides/information on what to do about this seemingly "Nintendo hard" section.

Overall, the game's difficulty tends to be oversold, as these things often are.  Most bosses can be face-tanked through and through, once you recognize enough of their pattern to avoid at least SOME of the damage incoming.  There's plenty of space for challenge runs and one of the achievements does indeed require you to kill all of the core bosses without healing, so you can certainly make things tougher on yourself if you desire... but don't shy away from this game thinking it's "too hard for average players."

Character progression is quite a lot similar to Hollow Knight, with items and upgrades largely adding new abilities or gimmicks, rather than straight stat upgrades as in Castlevania-style games.  You do have a rosary that you can attach beads to that provide stat boosts or other adjustments to your parameters, and this functions much like the charms from Hollow Knight... although, sadly, you cannot over-charm in this game for extra risk-reward.  Also like Hollow Knight, your spells are fueled by damaging enemies, although you have a set number of heals rather than healing being one of your spells.  Similar to Dark Souls, you can find more empty flasks and pay an NPC of sorts to increase your stocks.  Another NPC, added via DLC, can increase the potency of your flasks in exchange for reducing your total number of flasks.

Side note - you can press and hold B (or whatever button you bind to your ranged attack) to cut yourself, sacrificing HP to gain mana (called Fervour in this game.)  I don't remember seeing this mentioned ANYWHERE in tutorial pop-ups, but it's a very useful ability and is required to access a few hidden items, so... yeah, weird it's not mentioned anywhere.

The (free) DLCs added a few new areas, a completely new "golden ending" route, and apparently numerous improvements to NPCs, so the game is quite good now.  There's also a crossover event with the excellent Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night (another Metroidvania that I'd highly recommend!  It's also got quite a nice selection of mods!), where you'll encounter Miriam in a mid-game area and unlock access to some challenge rooms.  These rooms are all pure platforming and, while challenging, aren't quite on the level of the ultimate White Palace runs in Hollow Knight... which is probably a good thing, as while Blasphemous' platforming is enjoyable, it's not the most precise.

Definitely recommend this game if you're into Metroid/Hollow Knight-style Metroidvanias.  Definitely one of the best entries into that subgenre I've played, and even at full price it's a great value.

If you like Dead Cells and Souls games, then I think you would like Blasphemous. You will die, a lot, but thats kinda the only way to get better. You will have to learn what attacks you can parry and what attacks you can only dodge. Some can be parried, some can be parried but you will not get to counter due to knock back, and most ranged attacks cannot be parried, most. Success through trial and error is the only way to go. 

The art is amazing, abilities and enemies are original, and the best part of all, the voice acting. Blasphemous has amazing voices for its characters. The story is good too, at the start you'll have no clue what's going on but things will make sense later. 

Blasphemous is challenging too, while I wouldn't say it's as difficult as Souls games the platforming can get annoying. Spikes insta kill, you can only get onto platforms from the sides or if you land on top of them. You can take quite a bit of damage from just one hit, and some attacks make you go flying into the air, often knocking you off a platform, or worse, into spikes. 

Some bosses are hard, some are surprisingly easy. 4 out of the 17 bosses I beat the first try, those being Lady of the Charred Visage, Perpetva, Esdras, and Ten Piedad. The rest took me some more tries.

One of the few things I don't like about the game is that if you literally touch any enemy, you take damage, I think this feature should be removed and only kept on bosses and certain enemies. Something else that has made me quit is the portal system. I actually think the system used is unique and good, what I don't like is how there are so few portals. I think they should just be removed and idk, add a purchasable item or one that can be found somewhere well hidden that allows you to teleport anywhere. Not literally anywhere, the same locations as the portals. But all that aside, Blasphemous is one of the best games I've played in 2022, I'd put it behind Elden Ring in second place. 9/10 would recommend!!!!

Disappointing.

[i]Blasphemous[/i] is for the most part a good game. It is pretty consistent in its themes, motifs, you name it. And though I would have liked it better to have it accessible in the first playthrough, NG+ offers amazing bonus content. The Amanecidas are simply *chefskiss*. The soundtrack has a couple bangers and is otherwise very decent. Although I was not fond of the English voices, the Spanish ones are superb. It is unsurprising that people enjoy and like the game so much.
And that is precisely it, not bad, but disappointing. The entire time I could not help but think that [i]Blasphemous[/i] never quite manages to shake off the influence of [i]Dark Souls[/i]. There are plenty of 2D attempts at copying the formula, [i]Salt and Sanctuary[/i] comes to mind, for example. Ultimately, I found that [i]Blasphemous[/i] disappoints exactly there, just “another one”. It is [i]Dark Souls[/i], but 2D, with a big helping of Catholicism.
I often kept wondering “Why?” about so many things. Certainly, the pixel art is good, as in well-made, but should that not be our base expectation? Sure, the Lady of the Six Sorrows is inspired by Mater Dolorosa and a certain painting, but now what? Mere reproduction does not make a point at all. And that is what I ended up with, realizing that maybe I get it and hey, I can feel clever about it now, but then what? Everything seems absurdly gratuitous, not just the general Catholic angst, for lack of a better word, just [i]everything[/i]. Mountains shaped like weeping women, for instance, could be good, because this gives the setting a very surreal, dream-like atmosphere (quite fitting all things considered), but on the other hand, it feels like just another thing that is in there just for its own sake. “Here, have another, have we reminded you yet that this is angsty self-flagellating Catholic land where no one is ever happy and everybody bleeds all the time?” Yes, you literally have a couple seconds ago, but thanks for the reminder anyhow. I found this to be not a decaying world of undead with the odd sentient being on the verge of hollowing, but instead a severe case of “Why does anyone even live there?”. Just look at the map with its depressing barren landscape of brown-greyish jagged rocks. I cannot find it inspiring and sad rather than simply trying way too hard.
Venture into another area and here we go again, everything is crucified, burning, impaled, or otherwise bleeding all over the place, maybe some mournful monster is bashing their head against a wall or whatever. As mentioned, gratuitous. And hopelessly edgy. Hell, the setting is called “Cvstodia” with a v, as not only is it more like a Latin inscription, but also very cvlt and black metal. Play on and I can only roll my eyes at yet another “brutal” custom execution animation for some enemy. “Eat your guts, come on, eat them!” Yeah, [i]whatever[/i], can I move on now, please? I really do not care.
The very first enemy had me sighing during the cutscene. Yes, I get it, he baptizes himself with the blood and it seeps from a wound just like the one of Christ on the cross. But it never improved from there. Instead, I found myself bombarded with imagery that was if nothing else consistent, yet seemed more like an infantile fantasy of how “mature” games work than anything else. It must be brutal, because so is [i]Dark Souls[/i], yes? Let us add some more anguish, why not. There is merit in holding back, if only to make the suffering we see that much more impactful.
On the flipside, we have platforming sections with dripping snot obstacles and breaking platforms that reform a second later much like a 90s platformer, but in a bad way, for these severely undercut the angsty suffering overload, as I could not help but imagine the character with a cartoon animal mascot skin. Petty it may be, but I had similar feelings about the Catholic laser magic. On a technical level, it all works, but when I am arduously climbing up inches at a time by ramming my sword into the wall only to get hurt by rancid pipe snot a moment later, I cannot help but become conflicted about the game’s direction.
I would wager the biggest offender to me was a severe lack of identity. This seems odd, as identity might be the one thing [i]Blasphemous[/i] is truly good at, if you look at people’s reactions. And I can relate, as I see the potential. The issue lies in the execution. Do not just bombard the player with angsty Catholic imagery and call it a day, do something with it instead. Yes, this is a gorgeous re-creation in pixel art, but then what? Gwyn is kind of like Zeus, but this is not what makes him interesting. Another “Ah, this is X in Catholicism/painting Y, you see!” moment adds precious little to the game if this is all we ever get. Meaning is function in context.
Why do we have a currency we lose and can retrieve upon death? [i]Dark Souls[/i]. Why are there “meaningful” item descriptions (even entire short stories of dubious literary merit hidden behind a confidently named “lore” button)? [i]Dark Souls[/i]. The game is so preoccupied with being “2D Catholic Souls” that it barely ever starts being [i]Blasphemous[/i]. The concept is there, but only every now and then executed in a satisfactory way – such as the DLC content, for instance. It is a shame, as it could be so very good, but ends up only rarely stepping out of the long shadow cast by [i]Dark Souls[/i].

I regret going for 100% on this game, if I had stopped after my first playthrough I could have remember this game fondly, but I wanted to give the game a chance to prove that it was as good as the games it was inspired by and see all endings. Now the aftertaste of the game became sour and I regret playing it further.

It started out so cool!! The graphics were awesome, the world felt mysterious and deep, and you wanted to learn all about the (in hindsight, overly) intricate lore and see all the skills and weapons you could unlock for your character. But +40 hours in and I still barely understand the lore at all (why do I have to kill the pope again?), you get zero information or even hints for the quests and literally HAVE to rely on guides and tutorials. God forbid you miss something, or you’ll be locked out of a questline or ending, even though there are zero hints to this. It’s like they don’t bother trying to bring the player into the world at all, no effort to make us understand and feel part of it. It’s just force feeding lore that is so obviously written to feel like Dark Souls but desperately tries to be edgier and deeper. This gets especially annoying when you have to read through a lot of text on every item just to decipher that the item gives +1 defense or damage, but you're never truly sure because of how vague it is. And the clunky movements have reeeaaally gotten on my nerve now, especially when the world is filled with instant death spikes and strategically placed groups of enemies. Also, the skills you unlock are not nearly as satisfying or useful as I was hoping for compared to the games that it’s inspired by either, you barely ever feel "upgraded". I can go on...

Anyway, the game is basically a mix between the Dark Souls series and Hollow Knight, but they haven't understood what made those games good and instead focused all their effort on drowning the the player in confusing lore. In short, it leans towards "all show and no substance" once you’ve experienced the entire game unfortunately. The game so badly wants to be Dark Souls with a retro feel, but it’s like they didn't truly understand what made the DS-series good to begin with.

Sorry for sounding so salty, trust me when I say that I really wanted to like this game because I adore the art style and worldbuilding they went for. It had incredible potential! If you want to give this game a try, stick to just one playthrough...

Enemies will go off screen and suddenly teleport in the middle and attack you, even the final boss goes off screen so you can't do anything about him until he comes back on the screen. There are multiple instances where characters will just disappear during cutscenes. Enemy AI that just stands there in a daze or sometimes gets stuck in the ladder. There was even one time when an enemy spawned twice even though I had just kill it. There are glitches where projectiles hit you even though you are outside the hitbox. 

The levels are raggedly designed, platforming are f tier at its best. This game will try so much to waste a lot of your time by adding a bunch of nonsense. There are multiple times wherein an enemy will just stand in the ladder or in the ledge and you can't do anything about it because the moment that you leap or try to climb the ladder, these enemies will throw projectiles at you that goes through anything and you fall and die by the spikes.

Now, let's talk about the save points, the save points are not thought so well, throughout the game I had to backtrack a hundred kilometers just to turn in a quest, or if I die from an enemy that I can't see that is firing projectiles from like 4 screens below, horrible placement. This game is absolutely phenomenal. The overall theme is just cool as fuck: Becoming the Pyramid Head equivalent of a Roman-Catholic executioner is seriously badass. The world itself is built really neat as there is a lot to dive into story-wise as well as level discovery. The gameplay itself is pretty cool in of itself as well. There's a certain set of trials that pop up later in portal sections that, unless you look up or discover by accident how to actually interact with, are godawful to deal with. Once you get the platforming down though this game becomes infinitely more fun. Another thing to praise real quick: The soundtrack. Absolutely to die for. It's definitely good, however Strife & Ruin is one of the greatest pieces of OST to ever grace the ears. That song alone is easily a valid sole reason to buy the OST even by itself.

Overall I say this game is well worth both your time and money. Even without a sale I say it is well worth the asking price. Definitely a thumbs up and many recommendations to anyone that is looking for a nice Metroidvania styled game.

I initially did not like this game very much due to a multitude of bugs and strange design decisions regarding how the player character controlled. I am happy to say that the developers put some work in and fixed most of my gripes, so much so that I would now highly recommend this game.

As you likely noticed, Blasphemous is one in a sea of souls like titles that flood the steam marketplace today. However, Blasphemous is the real deal and I believe is to date the best 2D iteration of souls like game play available. The difficulty is tuned (for better or for worse) to be right up to the line between rewarding and frustrating, and dances there for the entire game. While If you like Dark Souls, you might dig this game, if you don't like Dark Souls you will likely despise it.

Game play aside, the game does a fantastic job creating an unsettling and bizarre atmosphere that is carried through the entire game. The player is given just enough information to create intrigue but never enough that it feels our questions have been answered. Quests in this game are often cryptic and with multiple outcomes derived from actions that are less than obvious (or not obvious at all), and usually end in tragedy. The player will never feel at home in this world, and that is exactly what I enjoy about it.

For those who are interested and have never delved into "souls" difficulty, the game is not by any means insanely difficult and is instead designed to intimidate the player. Once you accept that death is part of the experience and push through your comfort zone, you will likely find conquering the many challenges in this game to be very rewarding.

I am likely in the minority here and thats okay. I will also update this review if my opinion changes. Im gonna start off with this, I am not opposed to the git gud mentality to a certain extend. I sl1 dark souls 1 and have done a couple Elden Ring challenges. I also understand that comparing to dark souls or a pure platformer is unfair but its really hard not too when it wears its inspiration on its sleeve that much. The platform is terrible even in its style, it was unresponsive, I dont think there any coyote time and it leads to a very clunk design that is only made worse by enemy placement. With some upgrades the combat gained depth but never to the point I would call it entertaining or engaging. I personally dont think the spikes should be insta kills, but if the game had better movement I would actually understand that. Bosses are generally speaking so far, although I am only in Jondo. Extremely dis interesting and tedious. This is more of a problem with the movement and combat than boss design. I guess you could say this a metroidvania in the same way dark souls 1 is a metroidvania. Despite it still being done worse here, a staple of metroidvanias is unlocking new movement abilities that make future combat encounters and platforming more intersting. I understand the grounded approach here however with how stale the gameplay is it is not for its benefit. even just a double jump or wall jump would have made combat and platforming so much more interesting. Some pros are I enjoy the lore somewhat although I find the story itself to not be engaging yet at least. The art is great, the executions are awesome although not frequent enough or I havent figured out how to get them more often yet. The background pixel art is quite good and its overall a pretty game. Back to it, "bonfire" placements are a little too far apart especially when you factor in everything else. A big tell for blasphemous is from the first boss to the second there is 40% drop for players. While there is nothing wrong with a game not being for everyone that is a substantial number that not only shows its niche audience which I considered myself to be in before actually playing it, but it also outlines that there are inherent game flaws there. Despite what I said I don't think it is a completely awful game I just think it could have been significantly better. Sorry but one last comparison here, blasphemous was what I thought Dark Souls 1 was going to be like, and not in a good way. I went into ds1 expecting absolute bullshit like spending my first hour in lordran running into the catacombs, but once I found my way and realized for the most part it is a fantastic and fair game. I was waiting for that here and while sure I don't have much playtime, it has not done anything to pull me in mechanically, and for the most part the narrative as well. If you like this array of genres you could 100% enjoy this game and I do recommend you try it, however don't go in expecting a 90% game. By doing that you are setting your expectations too high and undermining the game by setting expectations too high. Also in the description call this a skilled hack and slash is comical, it does not take all that much skill, and its sure as hell not a hack and slash. Still think the lore and setting is very cool though, just wish the game would've done it justice, at least in the beginning maybe it gets better.

As promised, I finished the game or at least one of the endings, mine is likely considered the bad ending but it was still quite great and I think it ties in with the themes of the game very well. Now that I am done I will keep this shorter. The story is very good, the art is quite good, I actually like the map design quite a bit although I feel it is brought down still with dis interesting and tedious level design. This mostly has to do with enemy placement in my opinion and some of the features the enemy has. There are lots of charms and relics I didn't play with I only found one and I actually believe that on may be necessary to actually complete a later part of them. The combat towards the end game does fell better however I feel it may take too long to get to that point and even then it ends up very repetitive, but it does get better and I feel that towards the end game it is actually a serviceable and sometimes engaging system. Out of all the bosses I fought which was probably just all the required ones not sure tbh, I think I found one or two both mechanically engaging and fun. Other bosses would either be mechanically engaging and tedious, or just tedious. This isn't a spoiler, just my opinion. The final boss is quite bad, definitely a huge letdown. Luckily it didn't place a stain on the story for me, but It really isn't great. The overall difficulty throughout the entire game varies greatly sometimes going from extremely easy to a little bullshit in minutes. After finishing the game I do actually have a more positive view of it over all. I think I would actually recommend this game if it is on sale, I think for the money on sale you are getting a lot of content and if you feel similar flaws that I do, well it was 6$ and there is still some great stuff in there so it is worth it. If i had bought this game at full price though it would be a much different story. Similar to what I said before Blasphemous is a game that needs to be judged alone on its own merit and not compared to other games (for the most part) however even in a vaccum, it is no 9/10 for me. Probably closer to 7, which still isnt bad at all for how miserable I was at the 3 or so hour mark.

This is a Souls-like Metroidvania / platformer hack and slash action game, which is the entire reason why I bought it as I am a huge fan of such genre. However, instead of making a fun game, the devs decided to take the worst out of every game it tried so hard to copy, just to fk with the players by making their life difficult for no reason. Before writing this review, I took a quick look at the reviews by other players to make sure that I am not the only one feeling this way. 

[b]Artstyle[/b] 
- High quality pixel art which is the main selling point. Love the pixelated ultra violence. 

[b]SFX/BGM[/b]
- Sound effect is okay, but background music is literally the same few notes on loop. Voice acting is garbage.

[b]Story/Lore[/b]
 - Tried way too hard to be DarkSouls. Everything is unnecessarily mysterious to the extend that I skip almost every dialogue since it would make no sense nor difference whether I read them or otherwise.

[b]Gameplay[/b] - Absolute garbage. Let's go through in detail:
- Controls - Clunky, unresponsive and buggy. There are a few occasions where my character would charge a strong attack for no reason, which I am pretty sure I did not long hold the attack button; Clinging on to ledges requires you to hold the attack button and the direction button at the same time, however when you attempt to jump on a ladder from a ledge, you need to release the attack button [u]before[/u] hitting the up button, else your character would just fall into oblivion.
- Stages - Incredibly unreasonable amount of insta-kill pitfalls all over the map. Most jumps require you to be extremely precise, whereby a 0.01mm difference can cost you your life. With the horrible controls, I would say that more than 50% of the deaths felt unfair, cheap and frustrating. 
- Enemies - Some enemies telegraph their attacks so badly that it's almost impossible to react to them while having to observe your surrounding to ensure you don't dodge into a insta-kill pitfall. Enemies are also very inconsistent, in the sense that you can't tell which attack you can dodge through, which can parry, which can interrupt etc. That is not the worst. There is this particular enemy's laser beam that is blocked by walls sometimes, and on other times it will pass through walls and peg you before you know it.
- Bosses - I have not met any yet in my 3 hours of gameplay. Why? Because the developers decided to artificially lengthen the game by making the players traverse uninteresting platforms while fighting the same enemies over and over again. Oh you died? Congratulations, now you have to repeat the entire process until you find the next bonfire. 

[b]Conclusion[/b]
- Punishing games are fun, simply because players feel a sense of achievement when they beat a certain stage/ boss. Every single death adds to the learning curve, allowing the player to "improvise adapt overcome" the situation and not to repeat the same mistake. This is what make games like DarkSouls, Hollow Knight etc successful to begin with.
- For the case of Blasphemous, the gameplay is just blasphemy. The game punishes you for deaths that are not entirely your fault. When you respawn and attempting to try again, the game punishes you for doing so, by shoving the sheer amount of repetitiveness in your face. When I finally clear a stage, instead of feeling a sense of achievement, I felt a sense of relief, which is the similar feeling I get when I manage to squeeze out a turd after stuck in me for days. In short, the whole experience simply left a sour aftertaste. 
- I won't recommend this game even with current deep sales of 75% off. For the same price range, you can get better and more fun games of similar genre such as Ori, Hollow Knight, or Ender Lilies. Just don't waste your time and money on this garbage.

[h1] Looks and sound [/h1] 
This game really doesn't have good first impressions. The first area looks fairly unimpressive, but if you give it just some time you'll see some very well done pixel art with a very unique aesthetic through its art direction and setting. I can't think of any game with a similar 'vibe'. One thing I noted here was how it used multiple layers of 2D backgrounds which moved around to give depth to environments, like how Castlevania Symphony of the Night.

The music is phenomenal. Like with the visuals, the game really holds itself back at the start but as you keep playing, you will see a lot of amazing tracks that lend to the atmosphere or create memorable boss fights. The DLC specific tracks are particularly memorable.

[h1]Gameplay [/h1] 
I like the combat. As you progress and make your sword stronger, you get some combos and moves, though it's fairly simple. The game takes a methodical approach with your timing of when to commit to a combo or special move to gain the right position, which makes figuring out a bosses pattern a fun experience. Through various items, there's enough variety for builds and playstyle.

I don't think the bosses in general are particularly hard, but some stand out, especially towards the end.

The areas are very well-designed for traversal. This game probably has my favorite implementation of the interconnected design that is found in metroidvanias. It is a massive map and seeing it all come together so well is an experience.

I see a lot of people comparing it to a souls-like and while there are some elements to it that seem that way, I would argue that the game borrows more from Castlevania Symphony of the Night in its movement, locations, bosses etc though it polishes up on it and removes superfluous elements.

[h1]Story and Worldbuilding[/h1]
Yeah, I do not know what happened here, but I am intrigued. There is a fair bit of dialogue in this game combined with a bunch of text you can read or find, but it is still a very baffling setting. Steeped in religious imagery, this is a world where the supernatural seems to be deified and venerated, while leading to seemingly negative effects too.

There is a lot I will not mention for spoilers and even more that I do not comprehend, but what I did get was an imaginative setting paired with some stellar art direction.

[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]
I finished the game before reviewing.
EDIT: 100% completion review in comments below.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
"Hey, this game looks great, nice pixel art, let me buy it!"

*several hours later*

Oh...

... it's bad...

Beautiful pixel-art and visual design, but also slogfest in jank-city. This game is a bit ass. It's biggest sin is seemingly deliberate inconsistency in mechanics.

It's probably the worst metroidvania that I still semi-enjoyed for at least some parts.

Not recommended, because 2D metroidvania genre is saturated with much better games. For some recommendations scroll down to the end.

[h1]Description[/h1]
Blasphemous is a 2D metroidvania. You play as a knight who's penance is not speaking. In order to repent he needs to defeat a bunch of baddies. That's about what you can get out of the story of this game unless you dive deep into analysis and interpretation.

You mainly run, jump, climb, slide and slash your way through the game in search of items to collect and bosses to kill.

Combat is simple, you have a sword, witch which you can slash. Hitting an enemy multiple times performs a combo, which can be extended through leveling. You can also parry attack and riposte some attacks after parrying. On top of that you get some magic spells, which are charged by hitting and killing enemies. You also have a dodge, which can pass through some enemies in some instances.

Kills give you points which can be spent on unlocking/upgrading skills like downward slash or charged slash.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+ Pixel art[/b]
From characters to backgrounds - everything has a lot of quality. There are some nice animations like finishers, which you can trigger sometimes when lowering enemy HP enough and pressing Y.

[b]+ Atmosphere/world design[/b]
It's interesting. The world is weird, but pretty original, although Dark Souls influence is obvious.

[b]+ Control customization[/b]
Wasn't planned, added post-launch. I appreciate it.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]- Inconsistent[/b]
Game does not react in a predictable manner.

Some enemies can be dodged through, others can't. Others let you pass through only during specific animations. Yet other can be passed but only from the back, while yet others can only be passed from the front. Game does not communicate this possibilites. So, fuck you, you have to try and risk getting hit by every scenario.

Likewise, some attacks can be parried, others cannot. Wanna know which ones? Fuck you.

Some enemies deal damage on contact. Some don't. Wanna figure out which ones? Do it by trial and error. Also, fuck you.

And a cherry on top - same enemies taking different amounts of hits from the same ability to kill, from as little as 1 hit to 5+.

Because. Fuck. You.

[b]- Unresponsive[/b]
There is some weirdness to the controls. For example: stopping to duck and attack takes more time than just ducking and attacking from stand-still. Trying to get on a ladder mid-air is strangely specific in which moment you need to press up to start climbing and the game puts 1-shot-kill spikes below in case you miss.

Hollow Knight dealt with this much better by just taking some HP on spikes/pits and letting you retry as long as you still had some left.

[b]- Slogfest[/b]
Many enemies require slow, parry and riposte playstyle. Some enemies take 20+ hits, can't be avoided or dodged through and are placed in multiple places along certain pathways that makes you slog through them for a long time. And if you get careless - you lose a lot of HP, so you have to take your time. Yawn.

[b]- Contact damage/unreliable dodge[/b]
I begin to hate lazy games having enemies do contact damage, especially when the game is also trying to be "difficult" first. But Hollow Knight also had contact damage and it didn't bother me too much there, so what's different here?

The difference is that Blasphemous's dodge is short, your hitbox is big and enemy sprites are also big. Unless you are perfectly close to an enemy when you dodge trough them - you will get caught by their hitbox as you leave your immunity frames from the dodge. The other, more important difference is that Blasphemous wants to be more focused on combat, but it simply doesn't have the variety of moveset to deal with defending/high-HP enemies well, unlike some proper combat-focused metroidvanias like Dust.

[b]- Non-story[/b]
Dark Souls style of storytelling and worldbuilding, but without the gameplay to back it up and motivate you.

Blasphemous has some story, but the context and goals of your actions are confusing to say the least. The game barely explains why is the world in the state that it's in or why you are supposed to do things that you do. The explanation is there if you put together all the conversations and item descriptions, but the problem is that it's not complex or interesting enough to warrant such obfuscation. Most conversations will feel like gibberish unless you reference a bunch of them together, because they use weird terminology and different names in a way that assumes protagonist's familiarity with them. I was not motivated to uncover the story, unlike games like Dust.

Proper story would be appreciated and you can still have worldbuilding on top of that.

[b]- Bad tutorials[/b]
One of the first tutorials in the game "teaches" you how to extend your jump by hitting an enemy mid-air. It says you have to press X+RT after hitting the enemy (X being the attack button).

This is simply wrong.

You are not supposed to hit the enemy and then perform the X+RT, just hold RT the whole time while hitting the enemy.

The game gives you 1 enemy to test this on, said enemy dies in 1 hit and doesn't return, so you can't even properly practice what the game just told you. AND you can't review past tutorials in any menu on top of all that.

This is stupidity of game design at it's finest. If you are going to teach a mechanic to the player, especially when the input method isn't immediately obvious, then let them practice it, better yet - keep the explanation on the screen and create an obstacle that can only be passed by using the mechanic correctly.

There are more examples of misleading skill descriptions, like downward slam, which says press down+X while falling, when the real input is HOLD down+X in the air.

[h1]Lowdown[/h1]
This review just turned out to be a lot of comparisons to the objectively better Hollow Knight. Both games are metroidvanias, but Hollow Knight focuses on being a good platformer, while Blasphemous tries to be more combat-centric, but ends up being too shallow to compete with proper 2D combat platformers like Dust or Odin's Sphere Leifthrasir.

Plus all the inconsistency.

It's difficulty comes solely from not motivating you enough to keep trying at it. I finished it, but I can't say I loved it at all.

I'd give Blasphemous a mediocre score of
[h1]5/10[/h1]

Here's a list of games I recommend instead of Blasphemous (with my steam review links for some):
[b]Hollow Knight[/b] - obviously
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197998873734/recommended/367520/
[b]Infernax[/b] - small, modern-feeling metroidvania with crisp, NES-style graphics

If you have a PS4 or a PS5 - [b]Odin's Sphere Leifthrasir[/b] - not a metroidvania, but a great 2D brawler with great story and voice acting as well as amazing, hand-drawn graphics.

And something that has far less attention than it deserves:
[b]Dark Devotion[/b] - bold, combat-heavy dungeon-crawler-platformer that succeeds in what Blasphemous doesn't - creating an interesting, fun and demanding 2D combat system. And it has NO lazy-ass contact damage to boot!

Blasphemous 2019 = 8/10.(played on a controller)
Its primarily a Metroidvania with a little bit of souls-like elements. The artwork is beautiful to look at and the level design is really good with a high emphasis on exploration.(Exploration which is both rewarding and ease the difficulty of the game).

Now for the combat, we use the same weapon for the entire playthrough, with upgrade to its damage and to unlock few special moves. The game also has magic which is called prayers in game, and few extra wearables that will lend its helpfulness for both some tough areas and bosses.

Since we are using a single weapon for the entire game, the gameplay feels more linear than it should have. The best example is all the boss fights, there are about a dozen in the base game , and are really creative, unique, and have interesting attack patterns but you deal with all of them pretty much the same way.
>dodge their bullshit attacks.
>do as much damage as possible when you got a chance.
>rinse and repeat until the boss has bean defeated.
I know dark souls pretty much has the same gameplay loop but you get more variety in playstyle and builds and it is way more rewarding when you defeat the bosses in them like you can get the boss weapons for yourself.

In This game some bosses yield cool weapons but you dont get any oppurtinity to get them so in my opinion boss fights are not really rewarding.
Evenhough bosses are well designed,but due to having a really similar gameplay loop coupled with way too much health bar(or you do so little damage to them),makes the boss fights longer, frustating and more of a tedious chore to complete.Platforming can also be frustating fuck in few levels.

Despite the few setbacks the game has, it is still an addictive game if Im being honest, if not I wouldn't have played for 30+ hours in last few days.  

If you are looking to play this game i recommend you to try the demo on its steam page first and purchase only if you liked it.
10/10 just buy it.
