Blasphemous is a game that could be a lot better if they didn't try so hard to make everything worse. The premise is that you have a hack and slash, platformer, metroidvania, but it's not particularly good in any of these.

For starters, everything is hidden. Everything. No quest items have any description on what they do, your only way to finding out is a) randomly stumbling on something, b) trial and error every NPC to see if they accept the item (doesn't even work most of the time) or c) going to the internet, but even then you realize you had to have used the item before killing boss X, so good luck next playthrough.

If you expect a good metroidvania, as in getting new exploration abilities and backtracking, forget it. There's only a couple of those skills, and you get them basically at the end of the game. They are hidden bonuses not required to finish the game in any way.

I didn't even do any of the "expansion" bits, because they are so hidden I never found them.

As for combat, enemies can one-shot you. Any fall is fatal, which is fine, but being hit will knock you half the screen away, and very often levels are designed in a way that this will kill you. Dodging is inconsistent, you never know if you can slide through an enemy or not. For example in the first boss [spoiler]you can't slide through, until he does an specific attack that requires you do so, it's very confusing[/spoiler]. There's no immunity frames, when you get hit you lose control for a significant amount of time, leading to stunlocks (rare but can happen). Another inconsistency is that you can reflect some projectiles, and some you can't (no indication). There's an upgrade that supposedly lets you reflect more stuff, but even then it dosn't work a lot of the time, so it's total trial and error.

Platforming is inconsistent. You can't grab most ledges, and again falling is instant death, leading to a lot of frustration.
It's a well rounded game that has a good balance of difficulty and entertainment wrapped up in a great story that you'll enjoy.

Of course it goes without saying the level of pixel art, sprite work, and overall visual impact is terrific. The enemies, backgrounds, 'cutscenes', boss battles, and even small interactions with items and shrines are all a pleasure to experience from an art point of view. 

The rest of the game will really come down to you. If slowly, methodically, and even a bit stressfully venturing through a wild, fallen world of Catholic themes and Gothic imagery appeals to you: go on. It will take a lot of time to master the timing and idiosyncrasies of the combat, lots of reading through lore and items; figuring out which prayers and upgrades to utilize for different chunks of the game. 

Personally, I keep coming back to Blasphemous in little chunks, drawn in by the amazing atmosphere they create and the ability to slow you down if you want and dive into a quirky set of menus and maps. Eventually after a few hours though I'm drained...too many deaths, repeating the same hallways again and again. I doubt I'll ever obtain the highest achievements but I also doubt I'll really ever put it down always coming back to take up my sword with a tear of blood...

Blasphemous is a great Metroidvania with a lot going for it and some small things, in my opinion, that hold it back from being modern a masterpiece. 
Pros:
Style: Art, Music, and General atmosphere of this game is impeccable. Beautiful looking sprites that are so detailed its hard to think how much time, and creativity went into each animation and background. The music follows this, and is fantastic, from Spanish influenced instrumental pieces, to religious chants, to more ambient sounding tracks, the games music composer(s) did a really great job at painting a picture of a cruel, but whimsical world. 
Progression: Blasphemous does a fantastic job at making your progression feel earned. Facing down bosses, and reaching new areas is all part of the journey, expectations of a reward are common for this genre, but Blasphemous has a real nice way of giving meaning to those rewards. 
Environment/Setting: This category has to stand out from style in my opinion. Their is just something so right about the places you go in this game. A giant dirt embedded inverted bell, to beautiful snowy monasteries, to downright standard but pleasant looking villages. Setting is a core part of this game, and this game actually feels consistent in that compared to many other in its genre. 

Neutrals: 
Story: As a souls inspired metroidvania looking at this game for rich story is a misstep. It is serviceable to get the character to progress, but know what you are playing. 
Difficulty: It's pretty hard. Not back breakingly difficult, but it asks a lot of its players.

Cons:
Combat/Movement: This is a soft con, some people might like the way kinetics feels in this game, I didn't prefer it. It feels just as stiff as Super Castlevania. Maybe that's the point, the PC isn't some floaty little bugman bouncing around, he is a revenant but still it can be a chore to move and that never feels fun for players, no matter how justified it is in universe. 
Backtracking: This is a staple of metroidvanias, it typically sucks, but it makes sense to pad out gameplay. I can't blame it too much, the spritework and enemy death animations are a treat to watch over and over but backtracking really is one of the worst sins of the genre and this game is guilty of it as well.
 
Overall I give Blasphemous an 8/10. It's beautiful and deserves much love, and despite my problems with it, it absolutely pushes the genre forward in a good direction.

Blasphemous is quite the hard game, a soulslike 2D platformer which I like a lot. I love the artwork and atmosphere in this game and it is stunningly crafted. But I guess the budget went all into that and just a minor part into development itself.

Some gameplay mechanics, which are really stupid, just make the game harder for no reason. The character cannot walk while attacking for example. It is simply very annoying and it doesn't even make sense. Why would you do that?
Hitboxes of enemies are very unprecise, especially when dodging. Fighting while climbing is completely useless because your attack is also used to climb. Many little things that could have been done better so easily.
I also upgraded my potions to a better version and all of a sudden I have only 1 potion instead of 2. Explanation? Nope. I rather have my two 50% potions back instead of one 100% heal. I even had to farm and pay for that crappy "upgrade".
No effort on animations of the character which you look at all the time. Would have been a good idea to give some variability but I guess that's too innovative and fun.

Also technically the game is limited to 60FPS, Vsync is an absolute catastrophe and the game has microstuttering in some areas and in some it doesn't. The game ran smoother in 4k than it did in 1440p which makes absolutely no sense. You don't even see a difference with this kind of pixelart. No borderless fullscreen and the rendering options: LOL (adds big fat horizontal stripes to imitate old TV-screens but basically just cuts out 30% of the imagery. Worst stuff I have ever seen)

It's disappointing in gameplay and programming due to some annoying decisions that really put me off.

Blasphemous completely surpassed my expectations and has been a joy to play. The Catholic-Gothic setting is awe-inspiring while shockingly grotesque and hauntingly beautiful. I feared this game would be a 1-dimensional gore-fest with chip-tunes metal, but this couldn't be further from the fact. The score, which includes classical Spanish guitar and piano pieces, is perfectly measured. The retro, low-res art style perfectly fits the subject and transported me to a place of joy from my childhood. 

The game does have detractors too. The most significant, I found, was the quality of the voice-acting. At least, until I changed the language to the original Spanish with English subtitles. This is a Spanish game and the Spanish voice-acting is great - play it no other way!

The story can be hard to follow at times, with a lack of quest information in the inventory screen, having me resort to online guides. The game's world is not as expansive as Hollow Knight, yet there is a lot to remember and understand. I did become lost in the Gothic technobabble, some of which is story-critical. The overall plot is fairly simple but filled with complicated, interesting ideas.

The platforming mechanics are good, but not seamless. The main flaw is that there’s no dedicated grab action, leading to much frustration with ladders and ledges, especially in the vicinity of enemies. The game was clearly designed to be played with a d-pad controller. I would have appreciated proper support for an analogue stick. These are fairly minor issues, though.

The player's casting and recovery times can be much longer than enemies' random attack cycles, leading to much frustration when you cannot respond quickly enough. Some of the controls would lead to a frustrating cascade of incorrectly executed moves. It's more fun if you can be nimble and react quickly without feeling like you're fighting the controller.

Personally, I was a disappointed that the game doesn’t let itself become properly blasphemous, avoiding all mention of Jesus, God the Father and Catholicism. The setting is a fantasy world, but I think the setting would be far more interesting as a biblical Apocrypha. It would have been an interesting push-of-the-envelope and a small joke on the Satanic Panic of the 80s and 90s.

If you enjoy metroidvanias, I highly recommend Blasphemous.

Blasphemous is a pretty good game, if only you know what to expect, or if you don't expect anything at all. Still, there's quite a few problems that detract from the experience that I feel should be addressed:

-For a game that focuses so much on platforming, there's not much imagination to it. I get what they were going for and I had fun with it, but the only thing that changes from area to area is a new unique-looking hazard that does essentially the same thing as the last, and how much it can screw your game by either just damaging you or throwing you into insta-death pits/spikes. Other than that, it's jumping and ledge-grabbing your way through the game. Because of this, I get why people were underwhelmed by this aspect of the game.

-Unbalanced difficulty. Early game is pretty easy, even too much so, then there's a sudden difficulty spike mid-game in both combat and platforming, but soon you can become so overpowered that both combat and bosses become harmless. Anyone going for the true ending in the late game will be disappointed by how easy it is to attain it.

-Some really terrible bosses. I don't know who had the idea for Expósito, but as much as that giant baby creeped the hell out of me, it just wasn't a fun nor very challenging boss.

-The story. The game throws a lot of information at you through cryptic dialogues and a huge amount of collectables with 'lore' attached to them, but frankly, it never gives us any reason to care about any of it. There were only a few moments where I felt interested in what was going on in the story and even fewer with the lore items.

-The voice acting. I know it was supposed to sound like this, but that kinda makes it worse. Jocinero and Crisanta were probably the worst offenders for me.

-The world design makes no sense. This is a nitpick, I get it's hard to make a game that's spatially sensible without sacrificing gameplay, but an elevator that goes down from a mountain cavern to a village that has a clear vision of the open sky is forcing my suspension of disbelief.

I know it sounds like I hated the game, but I genuinely liked it. I just don't think it survived the hype, but since I wasn't really sure what to expect, it was all a nice surprise for me.

I really enjoyed my time playing blasphemous, but the game is not without flaws. I feel like steam would benefit from a more robust review system, as I feel like this game is in-between a 7-8 out of ten rather than a ten out ten. There are a lot of really good things going for this game, the visuals are strong, the atmosphere is really incredible, and the movement/combat system on the players end is really fun to play. The enemies are varied not only in appearance, but also how they attack and operate, and the same could be said for the bosses as well.

For the negatives, I feel like the pacing and balance are a bit off in this game. The game is setup so that you need to beat 3 areas to progress, but it seems like no matter how you tackle the areas, the last one is guaranteed to be way less of a challenge than the other ones due to you the character being a little bit too overleveled. Some attacks that you have are questionable, the slide attack that you unlock later seems a tad bit overpowered. It does a ton of damage and is relatively easy to pull off, which allows you to melt through bosses that are stuck to the ground. The mana system that you have seems to be a little bit underdeveloped, and I rarely if ever used it since it never seemed to do that much damage. 
I also thought that the optional timed platforming gauntlets were kinda crap .
my final criticism is on the final boss: [spoiler] The final boss felt like the game ended on a slightly sour note. The main problems were that sometimes the platforms more often than not made it impossible to damage the boss, the sword often would go offscreen for 5+ seconds which feels like a slight bug, and also unskipable cutscenes (which is a criticism that I could levy against a lot of other bosses) made the fight a little bit frustrating [/spoiler]

Overall, I think it's a great game that's held back a tiny bit by some small issues. I would recommend this too most people who are into this kinda genre, and I think it's a slight shame that this game doesn't have a huge audience behind it, as I think that this game has a ton going for it.

I bought this because I'm a fan of metroidvania games, and I like  challenge. That said, I like my challenges more like hollow knight, and less like the first demon souls. I loved how it felt to control your character in hollow knight, and while the game absolutely kicked my butt it I never felt like I took a hit because of unresponsive controls, or clunky feeling interface. I always knew it was my fault, and figured I had to get better.
Demon Souls felt challenging, but not in a good way. Like the difficulty was largely dependent on incredibly deliberate and often incredibly clunky controls. It was fine for its time, but there's no excuse for that nowadays.

This feels more like you're controlling a derpy, slow, mannequin trundling along. While the controls themselves are responsive enough, you have to be very deliberate, but at the same time you have to be very reactive. It's like this game straddles somewhere between wanting the fluidity of hollow knight, but wanting to feel deliberate like the first demon souls. All in all, it makes the game largely a chore for me.

While I understand that a lot of people love that, I find that the most charitable review I can leave is that it's lackluster at best.

Blasphemous was by far the most mixed bag of a Souls-Like experience I've had yet.

The game takes place in your typical unwelcoming brash world, this time with strong themes of sin, punishment, pain, and the likes. Its early game is structured much like the first Dark Souls, with you having the complete specific objectives in any order to open the path to a major area.

These first 3 objectives were off to a pretty good start, save for one that was (in my experience) significantly harder to find than the others. Speaking of difficult to find, this game's progression can vary from steadily straightforward to cryptically unreasonable. I found myself fearing what I would get stuck at next once I started progressing after hours of figuring out where to go. I believe this was partially due to the sheer confusion induced by speech in this game. While I'm already used to Souls games having remarkably more complicated and vague dialog, this game exceeded my expectations. Almost all of the dialog in this game felt like reading an actual bible passage, which, while charming, really did not help with understanding the story or what i was supposed to do next. It gets even worse once you finish the 3 objectives, as you get at most 12 lines of dialog, those being only lore dumps and no direction whatsoever.

I'd say the game falls off the most progression wise during the halfway/end game point, as there's a specific puzzle where you need 3 masks to progressively go higher in an elevator, and the first two are very well placed and feel like you're progressing while finding them. but for some god forsaken reason the last one of them is so incredibly far away from the other two that it makes the puzzle incredibly frustrating, and made me resort to looking up what to do after 4 hours of searching, which i hate.

Atmosphere wise, that's one of the places where this game shines the most. The pixel art in this game has such an insane amount of detail that makes you feel truly immersed. Much of the imagery in this game is inspired by Spanish Christianity, and the religious imagery in this game really captures the idea of some sort of twisted divine punishment. Not to mention, the music perfectly blends with the style, having this melancholic desolate sound to it. The areas in the game are also quite varied, going from snow mountains up above to toxic sewers down below, though a few underground areas do look rather similar.

Combat wise, it's hard to judge the quality. Sliding felt painfully inconsistent with larger bosses and a few melee bosses, and i found myself many times sliding through attacks that many other times managed to damage me when i slid with almost the same timing. The hitboxes are also quite questionable, with many times me being hit while jumping over a spinning enemy and getting hit while clearly not being even close to being in contact with them, and somehow, the bad hitboxes were also beneficial, with attacks phasing through me while i healed for some unexplainable reason. But when the combat works, it really does shine. Learning parry windows can lead to a very fluid experience with some bosses, and slicing through them feels as impactful as you'd expect. There's also the option for magic attacks, which i didn't use quite often, but it helps add more variety to the combat from the few times i tried. There are also brutally delightful finishers you can perform when you damage an enemy enough, which were always a joy to watch every time.

Speaking of bosses, they were also rather inconsistent. I found most bosses where you had to either wait for them to expose themselves after dodging a flurry of attacks / hit them until they're exposed to be the most boring and frustrating, and there were a few beast bosses that felt impossible to parry or dodge through, and ended up feeling like a dps race. On the other hand, there are some remarkably good bosses, 2 of my favorites being near the end of the game. This game does one-on-one duels very well, and you both feel like equals. What you can't say about this game is that the bosses don't have variety, as all of them have a specific twist or gimmick that would keep me on my toes as i never knew what to expect.

Personally, i would say this game had a few minor highs, and some major lows, especially exploration wise. but i can absolutely see the passion and care put into this game, and im sure they'll expand on it once the sequel comes out. The word that best describes this game is [b] Potential. [/b]

After defeating the tutorial boss, as I entered the Holy Line, as the chaotic guitar contrasted with the fierce, condemning sawing of the strings, I knew this game would be significant. I could not have imagined what an intelligent game awaited though, from its excellent gameplay and phenomenal art direction, to the genius, searing critique of Catholicism which the plot levies. Anyone who was raised Catholic should play this game. It does not level a weak critique of God isn't real the church is corrupt etc. which we are used to from video games, but rather, it builds a laser-focused, idiosyncratic critique of Catholicism which anyone raised Catholic would understand. The game, developed by Spaniards, is interwoven with Spanish and Catholic culture in a way that allows it to express a certain grievance and angst which anyone who was ever dissatisfied by the Catholic Church will understand at once.

Intellectual in its takedown, Blasphemous focuses on critiquing the concept of "God's plan", and the guilt complex of Catholicism in a way which is cathartic to anyone who has ever doubted, as well as those who are still believers. In a manner which is neither hateful nor caricaturing, Blasphemous dissects these issues until the plot and the gameplay itself arrives at the final conclusion, the titular Blasphemy is the recognition that there doesn't need to be a Plan, that the arbitrary rules of the Church can be rejected, and that that is okay. Being anti-clerical without hate, again I insist, this is a game which anyone who has been raised Catholic must play.

Now, I'm fine with more slow-paced movement and combat systems that require more of a wait-and-strike approach than expecting you to quickly zig-zag around - but the one in this game isn't slow, it's outright clunky and bug-laden.
Sliding over ladders, auto-clinging to edges that works best when you don't need or want it to (especially in combat situations), a dodge and block/parry system that sometimes eats your inputs (furthermore, some enemies seem to hit you through a "successful" blocking animation by the very same attack that was supposed to be blocked).
Add to that the occasional rather game-breaking bug (like being trapped in an "enemy arena" room with an invincible enemy getting stuck in the floor on repeated tries, each time forcing you to die and respawn; or retrieval "gravestones" - the thingies that appear after dying - being generated in spike floors, essentially locking down part of your fervor/"energy" bar semi-permanently).

The boss fights on the other hand look like the game doesn't quite know what it's up to.
During most of them the attack patterns fit the player's movement really well, I genuinely enjoyed those; but in others attack signaling is too short to react with the input delay, homing projectile attacks sometimes mingle with subsequent moves by dispersing after a seemingly random amount of time (making one of those impossible to avoid since you can only choose between blocking or movement/jumping)... generally playing like they were built for a game with a more fluid movement system (see "quickly zig-zag around").
Getting sufficiently unlucky with a boss's move selection can lead to a failed attempt on its own - which doesn't prevent you from beating the boss eventually with a more lucky try, but it made it unnecessarily frustrating for me and significantly reduced the feeling of success once I was done (there's no accomplishment in getting lucky).


But doesn't the mix of said flaws fit Blasphemous's overall theme? Well, yeah, it does - but at least for me, what makes metroidvanias fun and worth playing is [i] challenging [/i] gameplay, not being [i] punished [/i] by clunkyness, bugs and other random aspects. And it makes me sad, because the game feels like it could've been way more than it turned out to be, with proper polish (especially after multiple years of, essentially, post-release community "testing").

Overall, 8/10 game.  It's so close to being perfect, yet marred by constant questionable design decisions.  If you're not a completionist and just want to play, you'll have a great time.  If you try to max out stats, get 100% map cleared, or in general like to do the things the game tells you to, you'll have to look things up.

Blasphemous is a game I wish I could love more.  I -want- to love it more.  If you could know one thing going in, it's this: don't be ashamed to look things up.  The game is just too cryptic to stand on its own without using internet help.  Once you do, however, the game changes into a series of challenges to complete, rather than one whole picture.

All this said, the game is beautiful- the art, the music, the bosses, the environments.  Everything.  The game should be played just to witness it all.  There's a LOT of backtracking, but it's not as bad because the areas are so often so marvelous to look at and listen to while traveling through the game.

However, you'll also see many paths you'll simply miss.  Basic upgrades and basic items are locked behind several series of chains of quests you can easily miss.  If you play the game blind, you will likely never reach max level on your weapon, health, fervor... ANYthing.  You probably won't even see half of the map, because you won't know how to get key mobility items.  To make matters worse, a lot of key items that are necessary upgrades have to be swapped out on the fly.  I don't know why they thought limiting the player to swapping out these key items would be "fun" or "challenging."  It becomes tedious quickly in the late game.

The game is a Metroidvania, but its difficulty comes from how cryptic it is.  Rather than combat being unfair, it's almost too easy, meanwhile the difficulty of the game boils down to the fact that you'll never get stronger or discover half of what the game has to offer without looking everything up.  If you have to use a guide for 50% of the game, it's just not as fun.

I do recommend the game, but know that most of the game will be hidden to you without guides.  This isn't like Dark Souls or Sekiro; Blasphemous is the most esoteric game I've played, where the core concepts of the game get muddled by trying to make it too many things and letting the "puzzle" aspect detract from the experience if you're a completionist.

There is a fine line to walk when creating a souls-like. While it is obvious a great deal of effort went into Blasphemous, it ultimately falls down. 

First and foremost, there is an issue wherein you can 'ruin' your save file and lock yourself out of the proper ending 95%+ of the way through the game. This occurs without warning, explanation, or (most importantly) confirmation. You still have and can continue to collect the quest items related to the proper ending, but the relevant NPC simply stops talking to you, leaving you wondering if you're missing something.

Secondly, there are some problematic rough edges with the controls and combat mechanics. Many of them are somewhat minor on their own. 
For one example, when you push down to go from standing to crouch, there's a transition animation that plays for a few frames during which you arbitrarily can't swing your weapon. If you tap the attack button during this time the input is just dropped. 
As a second example, the mantling and platform mechanics are a bit sloppy (which, for a side scrolling platformer, is pretty alarming!). You can only mantle if you contact the edge of a platform at about head height, but jumping won't land you on a platform unless your feet are completely above its plane (there is no 'step height' affordance at all). This means you can jump high enough to be too high to latch onto the mantle, but too low to land on the platform, so you just sort of go through the platform and miss the jump. 

There are roughly a couple dozen of these kinds of design issues / bugs / control ambiguities that intrude into the play experience, muddying it and distracting from the proper souls-like core of an execution challenge that demands from the player thoughtful, precise control inputs and reactions.

The combat is a chore, the damage you take feels weightless in a bad way (no indicator, for example, distinguishing high damage from low damage, so the only way to gauge how much health you have lost is by looking away from the enemies at your healthbar), the enemies are samey and repetitive, the platforming is clunky with slow and disjointed movement, and the movement upgrades might as well be nonexistent (they alter the environment, not the character, and need to be equipped in a slot which usually holds things like, say, a health boost). The places you need to visit for necessary progression are incredibly easy to miss; they are often, in fact, hidden at the edge of the map in rooms identical to lore and "inconsequential unsellable item pickup" rooms. Following a guide is a must, especially because there is no distinction between what is vague flavour text and actual information. Places give no indication when they have been changed by your actions, even when you are within those places at that time; you will often find yourself needing to leave and return to a room in order to refresh it (which would not bee too much of a problem if you, say, moved faster and *were given any clue that you needed to reload the area or that the area had changed at all.* This game suffers from a plethora of bad design choices from the combat to the terrible and omnipresent platforming to that *wind direction is a central mechanic in a certain platforming zone, a la Celeste, but unlike Celeste it is nearly impossible to see it*. Thus, I am saddened to say that while I desperately wanted to love this game, I could not find it in me to keep needlessly frustrating myself with the instant-death pits and attack, wait-for-parry, attack, wait-for-parry... (repeat 20 times) bosses. Maybe I will come back to this. Maybe I will chip away at it once in a while when I get the sudden urge to not have a good time for two hours. Who knows. But for now, I will play better games with a lower price tag, like Celeste and Hollow Knight, where the platforming is fluid, the game mechanics make sense, and the combat + damage have actual thought put into them and don't stink of "Dev's First Combat System".

The pixel art is nice, along with the general art direction. Everything is colorful and emotional; it's a wonder that 18th century Spanish artwork hasn't been plumbed for more content in video games. Do yourself a favor and listen to the Spanish dub, as it's much more pleasing to the ears than the English one.

Take that away though and [i]Blasphemous[/i] really doesn't have anything else going for it. I found most of the upgrades pointless (I can count on one hand the amount of times I used a Prayer powerup and you get, like, ten of them); the [i]Mea Culpa[/i] standard sword attacks are the most effective use of your weapon as upgrades are subpar and the ranged attack is functionally worthless; it's entirely possible to complete the game without using the advanced movement powerups (these aren't even that special anyway as they are only needed to avoid certain traps to grab pickups; there is nothing on par with a super run from [i]Super Metroid[/i] or any type of item to help you get around quicker); there are long stretches of terrain that are in desperate need of more warp points to avoid lengthy backtracking.

Movement as a whole is irksome: I found the dodge mechanic to be incredibly inconsistent, and with how long you're stunned-locked when hit you'll often find yourself hit two or three times more because you can't jump or dodge out of it when you have multiple enemies or attacks converging on you. There's a great deal of clunkiness felt in jumping, especially from ladders or when attached to walls. I often found that the Penitent One just wouldn't grab onto ladders consistently when he had to jump to them, or the momentum would be halted when attempting to jump from a wall he was attached to.

As this went on it was just more frustrating to finish, and with so little payoff from the story it wasn't worth it to even see what was different about NG+.

This game is like 90% of the way to being pretty great, maybe 95% even, but those last few percents are so frustratingly and bafflingly bad and all clustered together in such a way that I just can't recommend it.

It all starts out very solid but after the first few areas I started running into both really obnoxious intended things, like doorways that spit you out a pixel away from falling into a death hole to kill you if you forget to stop holding forward during the room transition, and somehow slightly less obnoxious unintended things, like lingering or disjointed hitboxes on enemies. I had one instance of what I think was an enemies contact damage hitbox completely detaching from them when I panned the camera to make them offscreen, causing me to continuously get hit every second or so with no visible enemies or attacks anywhere on screen until I panned the camera back over to where the enemy was and killed them. There's an area with some electric orb traps where the traps cause damage long before and after the visual for their activation is present making passing by them safely basically impossible. There was another area where in one room the camera just started going crazy like there was an earthquake going on even though every room around it was fine and nothing in that room made it seem like that should have been happening. That same area has enemies who shoot bouncing projectiles except sometimes their projectiles would just skip straight to their despawning animation the instant they were fired for no discernable reason. It's baffling just how many weird bugs like these I was running into in the second half of the game considering how well polished the first half had been.

Going back to intended things I don't like, there's a whole lot of waiting built into the game. Desynchronized platforms that force you to wait for their movement to line up for you to proceed, slow elevators operated by slow levers that need to be operated many times in a short period, enemies that will guaranteed trade hits with you unless you wait to parry them or that disappear or run away to force you to wait for them to be reachable. Almost every boss has a sizeable amount of that last kind of forced waiting while they run away or wind up something you need to parry, if you're generous you could say it's to give you time to use the lengthy healing move but some of the bosses force waits after every single one of their attacks, the game is generally on the harder side so I think I'd be fine with a few less healing opportunities making it a little bit harder if it meant less waiting when you're playing well. 

The second half of the game has a lot of fights that lean very heavily into projectile spam in ways that really aren't enjoyable to deal with considering how the player character controls. Your movement is pretty limited with a fairly slow walking and jumping speed and a very rigid feeling dodge that has very little invincibility if any at all and yet some of the projectile spam feels like it's designed around a much faster character with a much stronger dodge move. There are a lot of bosses who feel very fair and fun in their first phases who in phase two just start spraying semi-random projectiles on top of their previously fair moves and you end up in situations where avoiding a move from the boss would force you into a projectile which would juggle you back into the bosses followup attack into another projectile and then one hit that felt out of your control ends up taking away almost all of your health. There's a particularly egregious example of this right at the halfway point of the game with a boss who already has some awkward projectile spam in the first phase who summons a second enemy to spam pseudo-projectile moves in phase two, who then comes back three more times as a miniboss with a mostly unchanged moveset and random basic enemies thrown in on the side.

If the game had either just the intended stuff I don't like or just the bugs I think I'd give it a thumbs up, or maybe even if they were both spread out throughout the whole thing, but the fact that I got four or five hours into it and was starting to think it was going to all be great and then ran into an endless parade of both buggy and obnoxiously designed encounters makes it a thumbs down.

This game is worth a play-through, but I don't think I'll be giving it a second one myself.

GOOD:
- I love the "corrupted Catholic" aesthetic, and the world-building work was excellent. At least one boss is connected to a real-world historical figure, and not one you would have ever heard of (maybe if you're Spanish?) A lot of the background art is also based on real-world objects and locations. The designers did their homework.
- Enemy and boss art is very good, with fluid and expressive animations.
- Good boss fights in general. I especially liked the Exhumed Archbishop fight.
- The Rosary Beads system is well-developed.

BAD:
- Enemy variety could have been better. Many late-game enemies are just early-game enemies with new sprites and more hit points. In some cases, the enemy's behavior changes, but the strategy for defeating them doesn't. This is especially bad in Mother of Mothers, which doesn't have a single enemy you hadn't encountered in some form before.
- I'm not a fan of the music for the areas. (The only exception is in Mother of Mothers, where the music fits very well with the area theme.)
- There's only one place where it's ever necessary to take off two of the early Relics (Blood Perpetuated in Sand and Three Gnarled Tongues). You can equip up to three Relics, and you often need those two in combination, but except for this one place you never need a combination of any of the other Relics. I'm somewhat confused about why these are even Relics, as opposed to permanent abilities, and it points to an oversight in the Relic system or the level design.
- I unlocked the whole Mea Culpa skill tree, but found no use for some of the abilities. You could beat the game without using any of them, which seems... off? That's a legitimate design decision, sure - you can beat Hollow Knight without ever using a Nail Art, for instance. But Blasphemous puts so much emphasis on combat that not finding ways to get the player to use the Mea Culpa skills feels like a missed opportunity.

Here's my honest thoughts, this is one of those games that sets apart itself just enough from it's inspiration(s) to the point where the term "generic", "throwaway" or "copy" is no longer possibly applicable. At face value Blasphemous is just another wannabe Castlevania set in a medial-ish setting filled with mythological monsters, we all know the old tale. BUT, here the magic happens, the game incorporates countless elements of spanish culture, mainly that of the old medieval, inquisitorial spain, which are never truly represented in media and as such the wider audience is not familiar with and they (or we) take these age old stories, characters and inspirations as a new breath of fresh air, had it been another 2D Dark Souls with just generic ghost knights and witches the game would go unnoticed in a mass metrovania-adidas clones. The soundtrack, lore, chracter design and other such elements make Blasphemous one of the best games i ever played and this should say something since i've barely touched the game.

The Grievous Miracle has caused the faithful and the sinner to manifest their deeds physically, onto their bodies, turning the pious into angelic saints and the sinful into hideous fiends. Now, go forth, Penitent One, and complete your penance if you are worthy.

From the title screen to the animations, enemies, bosses and voice acting.. Holy! This game is in its own league and well deserves its praise. It's enveloping, challenging and disturbing in a good way with an insane amount of lore. The environments to explore are some of the best I've seen in a Metroidvania. Gameplay wise, it's not boring and just feels really good to play with a plethora of things to find and customize for your build.

If you're on the fence about this game, I strongly recommend it, especially if you're into occult, religion, or esoteric and philosophy; there's nothing quite like it that captures these themes and aesthetics.

Blasphemous is a mix between Metroidvanias and Souls-like games presented in extremely stylish and detailed pixel artwork and animations. This game can get hard, yes, but is almost never patience testing or downright unfair, save for one boss or one (optional) platforming section. It has the environmental and item description-told lore of Dark Souls, the exploration and secrets of a Metroid game, and the platforming and combat of most Metroidvanias you can find out there, with possibly a bit more depth to it with regards to equippable charms/runes and "prayers", AKA abilities (think Hollow Knight). 

The best thing going for this game by far it its art style and atmosphere, which is apparent right out of the gate with the first cutscene, and the gameplay is enjoyable and tight enough to where it can supplement the 15-20 hours you'll spend beating it the first time around. The bosses are unique enough and challenging enough to keep you for a bit, but not annoyingly long amounts of time, which I can appreciate, but some might find it too easy for their tastes. I personally did not. Story wise, that's up to how much you care to look into it, though if you do it's interesting enough although not super unique.

The music is nothing I would personally write home about, it's your typical dark fantasy affair, though some songs do stand out among others, if only just by a little.

The thing that sucks the most and that I find annoying is that some quests and DLC content is event-gated, as in if you do some specific things (which are not warned about prior) before trying to do those quests/DLC, you'll be locked out of it until your next run. That is just plain stupid. Be sure to look at the wiki or on forums for what to temporarily avoid before doing that content.

TLDR: Amazing art style and fluid pixel animations, solid Metroidvania-Soulslike combat and platforming, semi-difficult and unique bosses, serviceable soundtrack, and some annoying gates regarding specific quests and DLC content. I would recommend giving it a shot if you're into games like these, or at the very least wait for a sale.

I would say that describing this game as a "souls-like" is not really true to it's nature.
Even though it is obvious that the gameplay and some elements were heavily inspired by Dark Souls, for me the religious context and theme of the game as a whole are approached a lot better here.

In Dark Souls I often felt like the designers did not really understand the objects they were trying to capture - the gothic architecture, the style and culture of medieval Europe. 
It was as though they were explorers in an uncharted land, making drawing of things they encountered along the way.
Really beautiful and complex drawings, sure, but with little deeper meaning.

In Blasphemous, the context of religion is approached on a more cynical, but still very mature level.
There are no jokes, but I often felt that the absurdity of some situations was so sad, that it felt almost humorous.

As a person who was raised in a very religious country, Blasphemous spoke to me a lot louder and clearer than Dark Souls or Elden Ring ever did.

It's a 2D "souls like" metroidvania (sprawling map with lots of doubling back) with excellent art/visuals, music and atmosphere, truly one of the most creative games I've seen in decades.
I'll use dark souls as a comparison for ease of explanation, since people should be largely familiar with that franchise and its mechanics. 

1. How is it similar to Dark Souls?
You have shrines that act like bonfires, which save your progression, refill your flasks and reset enemies. 
You collect "Tears of atonement" (souls) to upgrade your moveset, your flasks and to buy items. 
Upon death you don't lose your souls but you leave behind 'regret' which limits your "fervor" (mana) bar and how much you gain. You can have your 'regret' forgiven at certain points instead of retrieving it where you died.
You have a dodge button (roll) but rather than make you invincible you need to time it to pass through enemies and their attacks. You have a parry button which only works on light attacks.
The game has literal traps and inconveniently placed enemies that will either knock back your progression or push you off an edge to your death. 
Enemies attack in inconvenient ways that are timed to be inopportune as often as possible.
The game is vague in what things do/where you do them and choices have consequences that are not obvious.
You interact with NPC's multiple times in order to give them things (or not) which causes things to happen (or not). 

2. How does it differ from Dark Souls, mechanically?
Your progression regarding what you buy with the souls equivalent currency is nowhere as complex or openended. 
There are no classes and no meaningful choices, what you buy are minor upgrades and move unlocks.
You can buy beads for exorbitant prices that give you minor resistances or you can unlock moves that are hard to use or not that useful/powerful. 

Two examples: 
Plunge Attack - Fairly straightforward, you attack downwards while falling. While the game tells you what to do, it doesn't explain how to do it. Rather than just pressing down and attack while falling, you have to wait until you are at your zenith and then hold both buttons down and it only works when  you've fallen a certain distances. This is not a "hard to use" attack as much as it's a frustratingly useless one.
Charge-up attack: Stand still and hold down the attack button until you've gone through two visual queues to unleash an attack that's as good as just attacking twice. While it's not useless, it's only useful against predictable enemies that walk towards you. Anything quicker and you'll be hit before you do your attack. 

While not all moves are as bad, they don't feel useful and they're all clunky to use. 

3. What's wrong with it, why am I not recommending it?
It's not a fun game and it's challenging in the sense that you don't need to just do the right thing, but you need to do it pixel perfect, hampered by how the game plays. 

While it's not terrible, there are some quality issues and poor design, such as having to be in the near exact center of a ladder to grab it in midair. If this is intended, it's a built in annoyance meant to screw over the player for no other reason than the developer going "because I said so".

Enemies have too much health/take too many hits. A consistent theme throughout is that you need to avoid things repeatedly, which is not a challenge as much as it's just having players jumping through hoops until they fail. 

You have to have your vocabulary on point and know a large array of religious terms and words for objects in order to understand their significance. 
A lot of what you actually have to do is very vague, as are descriptions of items and what they do or what you do with them. 

Having to go outside the game to understand is rarely a good thing, yet it's increasingly necessary with games like this one.

After three hours of this, I gave up and just used a trainer to fix the damage I took in unfair places, which makes the game bearable. At this point I just want to see what happens and couldn't care less about playing it on the developer's premises. It's one thing to play hard games, it's another when it's all about restricting what the player does and hmapering them in unfair ways repeatedly for a miserable experience that leaves you wondering why you bothered in the first place, once you beat the current challenge.

One could fairly accuse that the game just isn't for me, but reality is that if it had half the BS design I'd be plenty happy with it and have an enjoyable experience, but this is way too much, especially when I've already gone through similar games like Hollow Knight, Dark Souls and so on. It's gotten tedious and the mechanics mimicked in 'Blasphemous' are used poorly.

----------

Update:

I've now beaten the game with a nearly 100% (I'm locked out of one part due to an item being unequippable). I've gone on and off of using cheats and I still find it intolerably poorly tuned.
There are a few bugs that are horrible, the worst one being that you will lose your ability to dodge and move in the air. You fix it by exiting the area, but I got this bug during a long boss fight and thought it was a part of it.

There are parkour parts to the game towards the end ala the white palace in Hollow Knight.
These are exceptionally poorly tuned and several factors will work against you, out of your control, such as fireballs sometimes staggering you and sometimes not, ladders not being hung on to, platforms that you land on and then fall through, ledges that your character arbitrarily will or won't grab on to, lamps that will shoot away from you that you need to sword jump on and many other issues.

You can still beat these parts, but they are not fun to play and you are unlikely to feel accomplished doing them, I certainly did not. 

I can't recommend this game in good faith, it's just not a good comprehensive experience, it's far too set on being frustrating for frustration's sake. There's a difference between learning how to play a game and then trial and error gameplay where you'll have to go through a set of 'I wanna be the guy, gaiden' annoyances until you get the sequence right and reach the next checkpoint.

The fact that anyone will defend this on the developer's behalf speaks volumes of the low quality gameplay that people are used to. 

If you want a fun and comprehensive/consistent experience, this is not the game for you.

I’m going to start out by saying this game isn’t going to be for everyone for a couple reasons: it has a souls-like sense of difficulty, and as with many dark fantasy properties it revels in its grotesque aesthetic.

Both the platforming and the gameplay generally feel good. Movement is simple but precise, and while the required platform isn’t too punishing, getting optional items can often be very challenging. Combat requires good timing to dodge and attack, but also rewards players for utilizing the more challenging parry mechanic.

The pixel art is extremely detailed and the animations are often quite complex. The designs of enemies and the world are steeped in the darkest parts of Catholicism, including a great deal of torture and self-flagellation, complete with the blood and gore that accompanies that. It’s not for the faint of heart or the squeamish.

My biggest problem with the game lies in the signposting for the sidequests. While the main quest is easy to follow, the sidequests required for the true ending often require some convoluted leaps of logic or sequencing that most wouldn’t reach without a guide.

If you are a part of the niche that enjoys the aesthetic and challenge of the game, I’d highly recommend picking it up. It delivers on what it promises.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
+ Awesome 16-bit visuals that lend themselves perfectly to the classic metroidvania genre.

+ Eerie, religion-based horrors pervade the world and its many characters; a beautiful mix of Catholic themes/icons and Spanish Gothic aesthetics. Each character faces their own trials in the form of punishment or penance for their sins; as the Penitent One, you can choose to help these characters be rid of their sins (in exchange for rewards) or ignore them completely. The world building is fantastically done through interacting with these characters and is optional in most cases for those without the time or patience.

+ The game puts equal emphasis on combat, platforming, and exploration, all of which are really fleshed out and can be developed upon with mechanical skill and a bit of creativity. The various items, equipment, passives, and powers you find throughout your journey can/will help you in the other aspects of the game.

+ Plenty of enemy variation and unique bosses keep the game challenging and fresh; there's never a dull moment. For those that like a good platforming section, there are even timed jumping puzzles tied to a side quest that offer a nice change of pace.

+ Map design is well-done with varied regions, each with their own environmental challenges and themes. Furthermore, there are many points of added interconnectivity hidden away that allow for easier/faster traversal, as well as a balanced fast travel system.

+ The game offers NG+, as well as a boss rush mode, to add some replayability.

+ The soundtrack helps sell the religious tones with scores consisting of angelic choirs, booming organs, and tingling chimes mixed with lovely strings clearly influenced by Spanish tones.

+ You can pet the dog.


[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Since you are able to pause and change prayers (powers) mid-combat, it would be nice to instead have a menu to cycle between a subset of pre-selected prayers to eliminate some pausing. The combat would keep flowing, and the player could feel more inclined to switch between prayers to suit their needs.

- Occasionally, ladders can be finicky; either you will get stuck on one mid-combat when trying to attack upwards or you will seemingly miss the ladder completely and fall to your death when trying to jump to it. It's not a huge problem, but it happened enough to be a point of frustration in certain sections of the game.

[h1]Amazing game with climatic world[/h1]
After getting 2 endings , beating NG+ and getting all achivements i decided to write a review. edit: now i got  all 3 endings.

[h1]Short version[/h1]
If you like games like Hollow Knight and you are not scared of blood, then you should definitely buy this game, you will like it.

[h1]Longer version[/h1]
I have to tell, this game is not for everyone, there is lots of blood and twisted bodies. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]: Gameplay feels very similar to Hollow Knight but i really like it. But unlike Hollow Knight where you could dodge enemies attacks, here you can dodge OR parry attacks. In Blasphemous you can collect colectibles (bones) to get money [spoiler]and unlock secret boss[/spoiler]. I liked the amount of hidden things in this game, hidden items or just even bones. The game also has NG+ that makes the game harder and adds few optional bosses.

[b]Graphic[/b]: I really liked it, this game from the start shows you how bloody it is. All enemies look unique and have thair own attacks. And of course bosses really look like bosses. In blasphemous you can also unlock skins for your character.

[b]Music[/b]: Climatic and always perfectly matched to the situation. And my favourite [spoiler]when on NG+ you talk with NPC and they make the bronze sing[/spoiler].

[b]Story[/b]: The amount of lore in this game is amazing. Every item has it's own story, if you want, you can read it but if you don't want, it doesn't stop you from enjoying the game. You will meet lots of NPCs. Some will ask you for help and will give you rewards. Blasphemous has 3 endings from which 2 will give you achievement.

[b]Difficulty[/b]: Blasphemous at first looked like difficult game but you will quickly get the hang of it. Once you learn how to use parry, all enemies will be easy to beat (even bosses). Sometimes parkour will be harder than some enemies.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
Blasphemous is worth buying, mechanics are fun to learn and the amount of lore will satisfy everyone.
Also it's not that hard to get all achievements.

What a masterpiece. It's not just another Castlevania-Metroid-DarkSouls mix: it's a improvement over those games. The art is beatiful, the soundtrack is great and unique and matches the "medieval Spain" theme of the game.
The story it's about a religious country that believed so much that pain could cleanse their sins, that it caught the attention of some eldritch...thing that turned them in all kind of monsters, giving them all the pain they asked for. It has a deeper meaning than that, but you have the experience it to understand.
The voice acting is really good, and coupled with the well written dialogs, make for cutscenes you will not want to skip.
The difficulty is, for me, well balanced: it never felt like a chore or a walk in the park. Parring is easy, but not all attacks can be riposted. You only have one weapon, but combat was never boring because of the enemy diversity and sound effects.

It has the "Souls-like" system, where the enemies only respawn when you use shrines to recover health, but instead of losing money/xp, a part of your fevor bar (used for magic) gets locked every time you die. You need to go back to the place you died or pay to some statues to recover it.

The game starts really hard but gets easier as you find the upgrades. It has a lot of collectibles, a new game + with a "true ending", new challenges and boss-rush. It also has skins for the character that you can unlock.

The teleport system starts with only a few points, but by donating tears to the church you can teleport from/to save spots.

NG+ is actually a whole different experience the first time, which I recommend, but doing all of the different penitence options looks a bit grindy as the only thing that changes is character mechanics. I've done all of them and the key is to speed run with some of them instead of doing full playthroughs otherwise it gets repetitive. The game also encourages you to use different builds for different occasions by swapping prayers, beads and hearts but some of them you would probably never use as they have little impact compared to others. There is also a good feel for progression as you actually feel more powerful the more your character gets upgraded but you still need to learn to use all of the new mechanics to fully unlock your potential. The true nature of the game is in NG+ where everything seems like a challenge.

It is a decent game. It is not great by any stretch of the imagination. It was enjoyable enough for me to beat it, but my impression of the game is that it’s just decent to good. It has been likened to both a Metroidvania and to being a Soulslike. And I wouldn’t really describe it as either. 

I do not think it is all that much of a Metroidvania. It is much more akin to an early Castlevania, like Super Castlevania, than it is anything like a Metroid or any of the post Symphony of the Night entries. You do not get any new abilities that alter the way you traverse the world. Instead, you get relics that alter the environment. Frustratingly, you have a limited amount of slots to equip these relics and must constantly switch between them. I have no idea why they thought this was a good idea, but it wasn’t and only added tedium. There are no abilities  that offer new dimensions to how you play as you might expect in a Metroidvania. You won’t get any new abilities that make getting around faster (with the exception of a tiny, tiny buff to movement speed) or more enjoyable The game pretty much plays the same in the beginning as it does at the end, except for the addition of some new combat techniques. These things don’t really fundamentally change the game or alter the flow. It isn’t Hollow Knight where you are continually getting new abilities that greatly alter how you get around and how you interact with the world. 

As far as the Soulslike comparison, I am not sure how apt that is. The combat simply doesn’t have the depth to be on par with any Soulslike. It’s okay at best. It is very floaty and lacks any weight at all. And the hitboxes can be atrocious at times. You will get hit by things that are nowhere near your character’s sprite, particularly environmentally. The enemies are largely just obstacles in your way that you casually swat aside. And this includes the bosses. You are not going to walk away from this game thinking about a battle you had with some enemy or boss. They’re completely forgettable. As I said before, it is much more akin to an old Castlevania in this regard. 

The game’s platforming is very finicky. I cannot count the amount of times the game screwed me over in combat or jumping around by either inexplicably grabbing onto a ledge or not grabbing onto a ledge when I wanted it to. Thankfully, it isn’t a constant issue, but it will be an issue you face and you will get frustrated when your character dies because they inexplicably fell through a platform. 

Visually, the game is gorgeous. Most of the time. The world and its characters are generally really well done. And that is the part of the game in which I have the highest praise. On occasion, you will encounter cutscenes of the characters and at times they look abysmal in comparison to the world around them. It was as if two entirely different people did them. On the whole, though, the game is a visual treat with some gorgeous vistas in particular.

I ignored the story because it didn’t interest me at all. I’m not into religious mumbo jumbo. And I’m an idiot, so maybe take everything I say with a grain of salt. My first few hours of this game were fairly underwhelming. The combat felt stiff and the movement wasn't nearly as crisp as it is tends to be in the best metroidvanias. Even after multiple playthroughs and almost 50 hours, those criticisms  still remain to an extent, but I very quickly found that Blasphemous has it's unique strengths that more than make up for any shortcomings.

The enemy and boss designs are nearly all outstanding, which eventually made it easy to overlook the mechanics themselves being perhaps a bit undercooked. The game is also filled to the brim with secrets, and does a fantastic job of rewarding those who are curious and investigate every corner of it's brilliantly designed areas. There's also a significant amount of quality content that is only accessible in NG+ cycles, giving a great incentive to play through the game a second time. Also have to commend how much post launch support this game has recieved in the form of numerous free updates and some excellent DLC content.

I suspect that many who start off this game will have some of the same reservations as I, especially if you've played other games in this genre, but Blasphemous does more than enough to stand out on its own as a memorable metroidvania experience that is well worth enduring  a bit of jank for.

Pros:
Like a mix of Dark Souls and a Metroidvania in all the best ways
Gameplay is tight, where if a mistake is made it's almost invariably your own fault
Makes you fear minor enemies at the start, but has great payoff once you master their movements
Bosses are fun, usually well designed (see below), and are tough but fair 
World is interesting and lore is solid, albeit kind of hard to follow sometimes (Can be the same when initially getting into dark souls so whatever)
Good variety of powerups, each with advantages and disadvantages 

Cons:
I've played through many metroidvanias and this one has had a few moments (either for plot progression or powerups) that definitely didn't make any sense to me to do, to the point where I looked up what I had to do in order to progress, and even afterwards I didn't feel like I was missing some obvious hint or logical line of thinking.

Lack of payoff for some of the challenges: Like for the speedrun sections in the stained glass rooms, the reward for completing these very difficult challenges is a VERY underwhelming power that get's outshined by 5 other powers in the base game. The same can be said for the extra boss in the ossuary, which didn't give much of a reward at all (besides a skin I think), despite again being very difficult. 

The penultimate boss on the bridge is really unfun. Like "EXTREMELY boring" unfun. From what i've seen they changed her up from her old version which was more exploitable, and it seems their solution was to not allow you get more than a single hit in (maybe) after a successful parry due to the new knockback and attack patterns, where in past bosses your risk of going for a parry was strongly rewarded with good damage. What this leads to is a very dull boss where you dodge for a very long time before getting a number of chances to do damage you can count on one disfigured hand, before again waiting and dodging for what feels like an eternity (Imagine if the moonlight butterfly from DS1 required extreme focus to dodge and you could only hit it once every cycle). *This boss straight up ruined the game for me and made me stop playing due to boredom before i got to the final boss, which I bet would have been fun.* 

It just feels like they patched this boss to be less exploitable, but absolutely destroyed its balance and fun in the process, and I beat every other boss in this game barring the final one (including the extra bosses) so it's not a "git gud" skill issue, it was legitimately just that boring of a fight.

I'm an enthusiast of 2D platformers. I've always enjoyed playing them on a number of different systems, and the metroidvania subgenre became particularly appealing to me. The perspective works nicely, in my opinion — it allows for ample exploration and engaging combat mechanics, and it rarely poses difficulties for camera framing and movement. Even with all the positive reviews, I bought this one alongside a few other titles while not expecting much of it, and I'm glad to say that my experience playing it was satisfying, despite a few minor flaws. If you share the same predilection for simple platformers, Blasphemous certainly warrants at least one playthrough. Let's talk a bit about it.

The visuals of this game are probably its most striking feature. I'm not an expert on art, but it's obvious to me that the artists made a marvelous job here, given the task at hand. The portrayal of a grim, violent and downtrodden world marked by suffering and despair necessitaded the creation of a pixel art that is rich in details, animations and colors. Blasphemous is inspired by catholic dogmas and gothic architecture, and its graphics effectively depict buildings, characters and creatures with a distinct, imponent and morbid quality that resembles the stuff you'd see in surrealistic paintings. All assets came together to form a unique world that constantly defied my expectations, and I have to applaud the artists for their imagination.

Not delving into specific details, the story of Blasphemous occurs in Cvstodia, a world cursed and punished by the presence and will of a supernatural entity named The Miracle. This force has warped the inhabitants of the land, transforming them into hideous creatures, each according to a specific sin or penance. The protagonist is a warrior of some religious order who embarks on a pilgrimage to hunt and kill the papal figure of a church. The storyline is kept vague and obscure, but can be pieced together somewhat by talking to friendly NPCs and reading the descriptions of most itens and collectibles found in the game. To complete the main objective, the player will face a horde of minions and battle numerous grotesque and giant bosses. I gotta say that I wasn't bored by the enemy department — there's no lack of variety here. Moreover, optional sidequests can also be pursued for additional story bits.

Given that this is a metroidvania, exploration is a significant element of gameplay. Most areas of the game are connected to at least two others, forming a sprawling maze of rooms, paths and corridors. The player has a certain level of freedom to visit these places in the order they prefer, and beating a set of levels eventually gives access to a new set of locations. Secrets and collectibles abound in all areas and serve as good reasons for backtracking because they can actually provide useful boons for the player. Many of these secondary places are initially inaccessible and require special itens to be reached, so checking and marking the worldmap with waypoints may quickly become a frequent procedure. Exploration is not straightforward, however, which brings us to the issue of traversal.

Movement in Blasphemous is rather slow and the game's environments are heavily structured as platforming segments. To arrive at your intended destination, you'll have to cross multiple rooms at a slow pace, jumping over numerous platforms, avoiding countless pits, while also fighting pesky foes. I felt that the occasional shortcuts found between certain areas didn't help much in this endeavor. There is a fast travel system in place, but it doesn't offer many portals, so one will still have to walk quite a bit after teleporting. Some vertical levels can be frustrating if the player screws up — get hit by an enemy or a gust of wind at the wrong time and you'll fall all the way down to the bottom of the mountain. Traveling through the lands of Cvstodia is a penance, indeed. You will visit varied locations, though, which is quite nice.

Combat is rather simplistic, but it does work reasonably well. Players have access to a sword as the primary means of killing foes, alongside a number of spells that either inflict damage or provide temporary buffs. The sword can be improved in terms of damage potential and variety of techniques by finding large altars in the world, while the spells may be looted from specific rooms. There are no wearable armor pieces, but the player may discover and insert into a rosary magical beads which confer small bonuses. The health and mana bars can be improved by certain upgrades, and a few relics will activate special abilities required to reach elusive places. Don't expect to find a deep customization system here a la Dark Souls, as there is no way to construct elaborate builds in Blasphemous. Action revolves around hacking and slashing with your sword and casting some spells for added effect, with the occasional parry and slide to avoid enemy attacks. Completing sidequests is important because they offer many of the upgrades, itens and spells used to fortify the protagonist.

While most common enemies are nothing but a minor hassle to deal with, the bosses battled in this game can be moderately challenging, especially if you refrain from improving your sword and health bar. I have some experience with platformers, so it didn't take long for me to dispatch them. With a bit of practice and preparation, spells become unnecessary and the sword is all you'll need to beat Blasphemous. This might be disappointing for those seeking some variety of gameplay, but I found the swinging and killing to be visceral and satisfying. I must commend the developers again for their creativity in designing their bosses. You'll find a bunch of weirdly entertaining creatures in Cvstodia, and they'll all demand some degree of adaptation. A NG+ playthrough is required to face them all, though.

To end my text, I guess the sound effects were decent enough, but I'm no audio expert to provide an educated opinion about them. I didn't notice anything major missing, at least. The voice acting seemed fitting for the game's setting and tone, with characters using archaic grammar and vocabulary. I did enjoy some of the soundtracks, but most of the songs were forgettable. Finally, if you are a completionist, Blasphemous may offer some tricky achievements to unlock, but none of them are time consuming. With some practice, however, they're perfectly feasible for the average player.
A masterpiece for sure.

This game is amazing.

It's a Metroidvania-Soulslike fusion, with a stronger emphasis on the vania part. It is a difficult game that will test your patience and reaction. However, I found the gameplay fun, especially after you get over the initial learning curve. The platforming is slow but precise, which fits well with how the levels are designed. 

The biggest strongpoint however, is how good the game looks, the atmosphere, the music, and the world building. It is definitely not for everyone, as it does contain some graphic imagery. Amongst those themes, some are potentially triggering. The one that disturbs me the most is [spoiler] Suicide [/spoiler]. Definitely not for every age. 

Other than that it has a lot of replayability, a lot of secrets, cool but ambiguous lore, multiple endings based on your playthrough, challenging but fair bosses [spoiler](Except you Tres Angustias, you have no right being so difficult that early in the game)[/spoiler]. 

Some of the downsides:
- The game is not very intuitive with many quests and items, it's almost imposible to get/understand everything without checking the wiki. 
- Some quests are missable and will force you to do multiple playthroughs. Don't expect to get everything in a single run.
-Progression is relatively weird, it's hyperbolic, meaning that once your character starts to get upgrades, most bosses won't be as challenging as the earlier ones with very few items. But more importantly, movement won't get many significant upgrades, don't expect Super Metroid levels of movement as you go through it. (There are collevtibles that you will need to backtrack to get, but they'll open up through items rather than movement.)
-Some enemies can stun-lock you with abilities, leading to deaths that feel rather unfair. 
-Occasional bug, not often but some of them can force you to reload your save.

All in all, the game is really fun.
Final Rating: 8.5/10

Overall, I would rate Blasphemous as a 5/10. On a positive note, the story of the game is interesting. The religious element in the story offer a haunting, yet beautiful, story as the game unfolds. I almost exclusively play metroidvania style games, but I find the pixel art tiresome. If the player is going to have to traverse the same caverns repeatedly, at least the developers could make the game visually enjoyable. Unfortunately, this game is not artistically striking and borders on boring. Moreover, a few hours in, I found exploration to be tedious and not enjoyable. It certainly does not have the qualities of the more artistic metrodvania games (e.g., Ori, Ender Lilies, or Hollow Knight), nor is the game play particularly fast paced (e.g., Metroid Dread or Guacamele 2). I simply could not get lost in the beauty of the game as I explored. I do, however, enjoy the dark story line, which is what kept me playing. For those players who enjoy metroidvania games with a dark story, I would turn to Grime before I played this game. If you are looking for pixel art games, and are new to this genre, I would turn to the classics first (e.g., Super Metroid). 

Those players that enjoy pixel art may find this game enjoyable. But, for players who are looking for a contemporary metroidvania that combines story telling and more visually captivating art, this game may not be for you. If you like pixel art, and are looking for a similar game, I would suggest Dead Cells before this game. Dead Cells requires less time investment, and the rogue like aspect makes Dead Cells repeatedly playable. I cannot make the same argument for Blasphemous. At $6 I would consider the game worth a shot, but I would pass at full price.

I just got the true ending on new game plus, and what a ride!

The pixel art is gorgeous. The enemies are grotesque but look like a lot of creativity has been implemented while designing them. The animation is fluid, the movement is smooth and the action, brutal. When enemies are stunned, you can execute an even more devastating, visceral finisher, with blood and guts spilling everywhere, heads split open. The environments look good, and some of the bosses are just horribly good looking. 

The sound design is excellent. Carlos Viola is the second person after Christopher Larkin that has become one of my favourites after experiencing his music for the first time. The boss music that plays during the four Amanecidas, is just sublime. What a tremendous job. Kudos!

Exploration is rewarding. There are characters that you meet throughout the game, riddled with guilt, trying to achieve penitence in their own way. The rosary beads work well when you customise them based on your requirement. While not all the prayers are useful, some of them are, and they really helped me in dire situations.

I can't talk about Blasphemous without talking about the boss fights. The game is tough, but some of the boss fights are something else. They are so well rendered, with the punishment of the Miracle creating these absolute monstrosities. While a few of them might not be challenging on the initial run, on NG+ they become enemies that will kill you over and over. I had my heart racing by the time I killed them after multiple deaths, and only a bit of my life remaining. But the rush that came was amazing.

A con or two. When enemies hit you and you fall or stagger, they can hit you over and over, which makes it difficult for you to recover, and can be a bit frustrating. The story is scattered throughout the game, and can be a bit obscure. The idea of sin feels heavy handed sometimes, though the people in the game being fanatics,  it's kind of believable.

This game will stay with me, the way Silent Hill 4: The Room stayed with me after it ended. The imagery, the memorable boss fights, the atmosphere, the idea of guilt and sin, and the way it takes different shapes and forms for different people, the music, the artwork. I could go on and on. It's a difficult game when you start, and it remains difficult till the end, with all you upgrades and stats maxed out, but it doesn't feel unfair, most of the time.

I highly recommend anyone to play it, and then play it again.
