Blasphemous is a confusing game, I have bounced off of it many times but have come to appreciate the artistry and beauty of the design. The trouble is that the gameplay is not nearly as refined as the art style. But it's not merely that the developers couldn't execute the level of gameplay required, it's that they made many baffling design decisions which take away from the game. 
A huge problem I was constantly bouncing off of is that a majority of enemies are huge hit sponges, unlike in Dark Souls where special parry mechanics and backstabs are available but not necessary, your regular attack in Blasphemous is not powerful enough to kill most of the enemies without hitting them 8 or 9 times. While the parrying in this game is pretty forgiving and fun to do, it's in my opinion a very bad decision to make your regular attack do so little damage. In addition, this really slows down the pace of the game by forcing the player to use special attacks instead of allowing them to approach encounters the way they desire. 
At the same time, I realize that I do like Blasphemous but I wish the designers had slightly different ideas of what a good game was.

This is my first time playing a Metroidvania game, and it was a very memorable experience. 

The game's combat is centered around managing your equipment, using the apropriate sword technique, using a spell that suits your loadout and fighting style, and complex movement/dodging. Not only does this make the combat very challenging, but it also offers you a lot of way to approach a fight. And so fighting your average fodder enemies will always be fun and challenging, but always fair.  And the boss fight uses all of these mechanic fully and combined with their creepy/gothic aesthethic makes fighting them really thrilling.

Platforming is challenging and sometime punishing but it is very fun, and the game highly encourages exploration because there is many hidden path that leads to important upgrade and interesting tools. 

But the best part of this game is easily it univers , it arts and it characters: it makes each encounter ( especially with boss fight ) , friendly or not, really memorable : this is definitely one of those game that you will think about for a week after finishing it. 

After finishing it, my only complain of this game is that it has many ending, and aside from the "basic" ending route, figuring out by yourself the step to take to achieve a different can be really criptic : which isn't a good thing when the lore is complex and scattered across many items description.

But overall, a very good game. And the game has a very nice lenght, so go for it.

[h1] This game is better to look at than to actually play [/h1]


The art style is amazing. The way enemies look, the small cutscenes they made, the animations for executions, the overall visuals during gameplay, they are all great.
But speaking of gameplay:


[olist]
[*] Sometimes the controls are a bit janky which is frustrating because it punishes you for a mistake you didn't make.
[*] The hitboxes are [i] way [/i] too unprecise. You frequently take hits or miss a jump because of this.
[*] As a result the platforming sucks. Especially jumping from one ladder to another with a spike pit below is really annoying. Elements like these are used too often in the level design.
[*] The movement is a bit lacking. Double jumps or mid air dashing would have been really nice things that could have improved the flow of gameplay by a lot. But they don't exist.
[*] Someone decided that waiting should be a gameplay mechanic. This doesn't happen often but it's just extra aggravating. You don't just waste time trying to regain progress which was lost due to poor hitboxes. Sometimes you just sit there and get to do nothing.
[*] Some boss fights are nothing but projectile spam. Combine this with shitty hitboxes, sometimes weird controls and the lack in movement and it becomes [i] very [/i] annoying [i] very [/i] quickly.
[*] Being stun locked to death is a thing. Everything that hits you will shortly stun you. However, you become vulnverable again [i] before [/i] you can move again. With bosses spamming stuff at you or multiple enemies at once this means you can die with no chance left to do anything about it.
[*] The game is very secretive when it comes to information about anything. As a result you can either waste a lot of time just screwing around with stuff until something works or you end up playing with the wiki open. This sucks. It doesn't have to shove everything into your face right away but it doesn't even bother telling you the stats of an item. The super cryptic story doesn't make it much better. 

Overall the gameplay is just too unpolished. For a game which has been out for 3 years this must not be a thing. It frustrates you too often which sucks the fun out of the game. I assume this is also why only half of all players obtained the achievement for killing the second boss. 
I only paid a bit over 6€ and even for that it is ... meh. It's surely not worth the full price of 25€.

Art style and music are some of the best I've experienced in a 2D game but the things the player actually interacts with aren't fun. Most areas are large and some have gimmicks that make them annoying, as are the one-note enemies which are both made worse by the backtracking you have to do; these lead to you running past enemies and trying to get through areas as quickly as possible after your first encounters. Combat is decent but you feel really vulnerable until you get a couple upgrades, after which old enemies can barely tickle you while new enemies take big chunks out of your health bar. I haven't finished the game but the [spoiler]church area, especially the churchtop[/spoiler] is just a slog with a lot of spongy enemies you have to fight through to progress with few rest areas, which made me put down the game. I did like the bosses but I ended up running through them pretty fast and returning to the annoying exploration and non-boss combat phases too quickly.

The story was hard to follow and it didn't seem like there would be anything to spice up the game's narrative, and that kind of bleeds into the gameplay what with it being really repetitive and the upgraded abilities not changing that, especially since most of them aren't that practical. Some items you find do change how you fight or traverse but given most world items are useless and almost all require backtracking to get I just stopped caring about them halfway through my playtime.

The platforming is easily the worst part of the game, especially given how many death pits and spike traps are put into the map. I thought the worst offenders were the [spoiler]painting and icy mountain areas[/spoiler], and ladder puzzles were always a pain. Especially on the blood platforms, I would seemingly fall right through them unless I made sure the jump was perfectly set up. 

I didn't really encounter any bugs save for a fight in a locked room with the [spoiler]floating death ghost and lance lady[/spoiler] enemies with temporary platforms: the fight was hard but right as I was about to clear the room one of the enemies bugged out on two separate occasions which was insanely annoying.

Ultimately I think the game is alright, it just requires a really specific taste and the understanding that it's not 2D Dark Souls, which initially drew me in, but its own thing that has a lot less nuance and polish but some unique elements as well. If you're still interested then check it out on sale, because despite the beautiful art direction, the game is definitely not worth full price if you're anything like me.

A genuinely great game with loads of replayability.
-
The combat is so well done, enemies all have their own way to deal with them effectively, yet this doesn't make fights drag at. Not only that, but the some of the boss fights are the best fun I've had in a game for a while.
Hidden rooms, fake walls and ability upgrades feel interspersed just right in a way that makes scouring previous zones feel more like rediscovery with fresh eyes and less like busy work done to pad for time.
It should probably go without saying, but the art for every part of this game is gorgeous, really solid pixel art, and the soundtrack really helps capture the feeling of travelling and fighting through Cvstodia.
-
The one complaint I have is that at times the platforming can feel a little hit-or-miss. Thankfully it doesn't have too much of an impact, but in an optional quest you have to work your way through a number of agility courses, complete with insta-kill spikes and a timer.
For me, these rooms were the only truly frustrating part of an otherwise brilliant game, and despite this I honestly can't recommend this game enough.

The whole concept that the game presents literally gives me chills. I never thought I'd see a game inspired by the catholic "mithology". And boy, the game's artist managed to get it VERY well. The amazing, spanish-inspired OST also helps a lot. 

And as amazing this game is, I feel like that, in the end, such awesomeness could be better executed.

In the artbook, you can see how some arts were a bit too greedy, full of details and symbols, and applying them into a pixel-art game didnt work very well. 

I also saw some badly done graphic patterns, felt like a lazy design decision.

Also, I have a bad feeling that such vast place as Cvstodia is just so... empty, with so many repetitive enemies. 

The gameplay is also very nice, but also a bit too clunky at some parts (unecessarily difficult parts, useless items and powers, some things are never explained etc.).

But I love this game regardless, and that's why I demand so much from it. Expecting nothing but a masterpiece from Blasphemous 2!

Blasphemous falls victim to a very common concept: "Style over Substance".
The art style is pretty unique and forms a strong picture with the accompanying music. It manages to invoke and balance a strong grimdark tone and it lays the foundation for an outstanding setting.
That being said, the most important key component, the gameplay, crumbles. The combat is basic and restrictive, platforming feels unresponsive and ends up being more like a chore. Everything gameplay-wise just feels artificially slowed down by a lot. Even the level design suffers from many annoying hoops the player has to jump through.
Unfun mechanics are implemented too often. Therefore, no real flow can establish itself. The gameplay suffers from a sluggish feeling and was not enjoyable at all.

[i]"I curse you forever in name, I bless you forever in death..."[/i]

I can't believe i put off playing this absolute masterpiece of a game for so long... I'm always a bit nervous when it comes to soulslikes because i'm not the best at games (not horrible either), so when i heard that blasphemous was REALLY hard i thought i'd get my ass whooped. Suprisingly i found the game to be the most fair soulslike i've ever played. NONE of the enemies or bosses feel unfair, once you got their strategies down it's really quite doable. This is thanks to the quick, snappy and responsive combat and movement controls. I don't know what it is in this game but it just feels so good to play. From platforming to combat it was just a joy to navigate this dark and desolate world throughout the entirety of my 25 hours with it. The flow of the entire game is just so good, you're making constant progress and it's just awesome.

The biggest reason i had such fun, apart from the good controls is the absolute masterclass in map/level design. This is the textbook definition of a metroidvania map, with TONS of shortcuts, secrets and landmarks. The map is absolutely massive and filled to the brink with tons of different and more importantly meaningfull collectibles. From health, mana and flask upgrades to charms, quest items and prayers. There's so much to find and do in this game that it'll keep you occupied for atleast 20 hours if not more. I could not stop playing as my mind was racing with all the things i could still do or explore.

Combat apart from being responsive and fair is also super varied. There's a ton of enemy variety and different attacks that you can use to take them down. Regular enemies are very well balanced, striking that golden line of health & damage. It's a shame that the bosses are not quite as perfect (still very good though!) They're suprisingly easy because they don't hit very hard/don't have that much health but their attacks are relentless so if you want a real challenge you could try to do them hitless. Longest i got stuck on a boss was 30 minutes but much of that was me not understanding their mechanics at first. So while i would have loved the bossfights to be just that little bit better designed i'm glad that the game flow never came to a halt due a boss acting as a roadblock. 

The setting/worldbuilding and narrative is also all around awesome. This game has such a unique atmosphere to it, that really can't be found anywhere else. A lot of games try to show a desolate and melancholy world, but blasphemous does it better than anyone. The whole mood is just hopeless, but in a good way. Even the small acts of kindness that you do by helping npc's have this feeling of not making a difference because the world is doomed. The story also sells this very well. The overal narative is just a masterclass with some of the greatest voice acting in the scene. It's a consistent, immersive and believable package that just draws you in. This is complemented by the best pixel art to have ever graced gaming. The background and designs of everything in this game, down to the smallest detail, is just perfect. Add to that the a score that just fits the game perfectly and you've got the most well rounded package of worldbuilding in recent memory.

Lastly performance and polish are stellar, i did not encounter a single crash or framedrop in 25 hours of playing, while bugs were only few and barely noticable. The game is really polished and just al around one of the best games i've ever had the luxury of experiencing. So i'd recommend it to anyone, even those that feel like they're not that good at soulslikes, just because everyone should experience the world of blasphemous, at least once! I'd give it a 9.5/10. Could've been a ten had the bossfights been a smidge better but still a super solid game! Needless to say i'm super excited for the sequal in 2023, which means you still have some time to play this masterpiece ;)

GRIM. This is a True Black Metal world of Renaissance Christian Misery. It's a well-made and designed game. Very playable. Difficult, but not painfully so. The thing that sets this apart from all the other metroidvanias (and yeah I've played a million of them) is the atmosphere. It's so well done, and it's NOT ANOTHER GOTHIC HORROR game!! YAY! This is far more disturbing-- the ambient sound, the sinister stories behind the bones, the dialogue is like something ripped out of the dreams of those who got left behind after the rapture and end of the world, and the art is detailed enough, but really gets your imagination going. The executions are a nice touch. Without being too wordy, this is one of the better games I've played in a long while. It's not as beautiful as the Ori series (which you should have played by now), but it dodges being another Castlevania copycat with fluid movement and a surreal world that makes you uncomfortable to see whats around the next corner, but compels you to do so. It really piques your morbid curiousity... ENJOY.

I wanted this to be either more Catholic or less. It's like a weird edgelord Catholicism without Christ that cuts out anything about life or resurrection or forgiveness and just leaves all the gothic bits about sin and suffering. And so self-serious! Everything about this game owes more to [i]Symphony of the Night[/i] than any other non-Igarashi Metroidvania I've played, and yet it neglects to borrow any of that game's campiness. It all gets a little tiresome?

That's just talking about aesthetic, worldbuilding, and [i]vibes[/i] though. What about the gameplay? It's... fine. I had fun. And there's more than enough upgrades and easter eggs and assorted goodies to keep you busy. It doesn't really innovate too much on the classic "Igvania" template—more just gives it a [i]Dark Souls[/i] coat of paint—but it also does a decent job living up to that standard, which is in-and-of-itself a pretty high bar. Having yet another [i]Castlevania[/i] clone isn't necessarily a bad thing when it's done this well. Just don't go into it expecting much more than that.

While Blasphemous isn't quite as huge and expansive and deep in Gameplay and world as, for example Hollow Knight, it still has one of the best Gawddam artstyles and atmospheres I've ever seen in a game, and while it's definitely not without flaws, such as the parkour, and spikes just out of sight meaning death and quite a long plod back to where you died, I still loved this game. The atmosphere is soaked in dread and blood and music which perfectly complements the religious world steeped in horror and sin and penance. I can't wait for a sequel, that's for damn sure, and recommend it to anyone who's itching for another Soulslike experience.

I have a few minor gripes with Blasphemous, but the majority of those are overshadowed by how enjoyable the game is. The controls could be tighter at times, I'm not a fan of purposely using 16-bit pixel art with all its limitations, and there were plenty of "wow this is total BS" moments between enemy attacks, hazards, and recovery time. That all being said, the map layout was great, the story and world were both interesting, and the soundtrack had some bangers. I got through the game in about 13 hours, and there is still plenty I missed and lots of options for replayability. If you're into this type of game at all, you will certainly enjoy Blasphemous.

This is truly a beautiful looking game. Along with the music, it's easily one of the better presented games I've seen in quite some time.

That said, the game kind of controls terribly. More often than not, you end up making mistakes simply due to how the game sluggishly controls or simply doesn't respond to inputs at all. While running through areas you'll grab onto ledges despite not attempting to, jump back up to levels you were just at when trying to drop/jump off of ladders, descending ladders when just trying to crouch, getting stuck in an enemy attack loop because it takes so long to recover and hitboxes are often not very well represented on the sprites.

(Also, there seems to be some bugs in the current build. Having returned to the game after a few months, many enemies are now getting caught on ladders or gaseous clouds, completely changing how they are meant to act.)

Avoiding modern controllers and using one with a decent D-Pad helps alleviate some issues, but sadly the problems are build inherently into the design they've created. So I doubt there is much hope in fixing them. Worth a try if you like old school, more challenging games and Souls titles etc, but it's got a lot of problems that sadly hold it back and stop me from recommending it.

Short thoughts: a 2-D take on a Dark Souls style game that I'd rate an 8/10.

Longer thoughts: I bought this game soon after it came out due to its striking aesthetic, but didn't do a full playthrough until shortly before the last DLC update came out. That has given me an appreciation for how much has been added to this game (all for free) to truly make it something worth experiencing.

Despite the clearly Dark Souls inspired vibe, the game actually is not that difficult outside of the bosses and the instant death spikes. So that makes it more accessible for those who enjoy a dark, interpretive world rich with lore. The art style borrows a lot from Spanish religion and gives the game a distinct look. And the soundtrack is top notch as well.

Some of my only sticking points with the game are that the combat is a bit basic for a game where you're taking out monsters with big health bars. The moves you can do look cool, I just wish there more of them to give the game more strategy options. This is also hampered by abilities that can only be changed by going into a menu whenever you want to try something different. Having to constantly stop and pause breaks the flow of the game, and I wish they had streamlined it more so you could cycle through your special abilities using the shoulder buttons.

That aside, I still love this game and will absolutely be playing more of it. Every boss fight is a fun spectacle. And the free updates improved the game tremendously, giving it a much more satisfying ending. You have multiple endings to find, secret bosses, hidden items, and a world that can often be explored in nonlinear fashion. if you're looking for a Metroid or Hollow Knight style game with darker world tones, you will probably enjoy Blasphemous a lot.

This game has awesome visuals, atmospheric soundtrack and interesting setting. If that is enough for you to like a game - please skip this review, you'll have loads of aesthetic fun with Blasphemous. This review is for those who play games and not watch/listen/read them.

Gameplay-wise, Blasphemous tries to combine Castlevania: Symphony of the Night with elements from Dark Souls. About 80% of it consists of SotN elements, and 20% - of DS elements. It is a metroidvania - an explorative platforming genre, which was perfected back in the 90s with games like Super Metroid and, well, SotN, was polished even more with Aria of Sorrow and Cave Story, and then perfected again with Hollow Knight, which blended Metroid and Castlevania principles into something completely unique. Souls, on the other hand, was blended into 2D platformers before with games like Salt & Sanctuary, and it was done well, too. What I'm getting at is, [b]there should be no excuse for blending SotN and DS poorly[/b].

But Blasphemous does just that. Developers didn't think enough about what elements from SotN and DS actually make these games awesome and how would they combine. They just mixed whatever they saw. The worst offender is, of course, bottomless pits, that are in DS, but not in SotN. Why weren't they in SotN? Because that was the whole point of the game: in classic Castlevanias, pits would bring you death; in SotN, pits would lead you to new locations, and it made the game so much more fun and rewarding. The whole genre works this way, and there is no good reason change that. But Blasphemous does it: there are so many bottomless pits and instant death spikes, that half of your deaths will be from them. Granted, there is a relic that allows you to turn bottomless pits into new passages, but you will probably get it close to finishing the game.

Ah, yes, let's talk about relics. Remember how in any metroidvania you find spells that allow you to access new locations and it is how game progression is structured? Well, not in Blasphemous, because here these spells (called relics) are [b]secrets[/b]! And the only reason for you to collect them is to find [b]new secrets[/b]! And they are far from being as good and impactful as in... Well, again, any other good metroidvania - [b]you don't even have a double jump here[/b]!!! In SotN, you could fly as a frickin' bat - and it was far from the strongest upgrade in the game! What happened here? Why is here not even a double jump - because Dark Souls had no double jump? Well Dark Souls isn't a platformer!

Most of the items in the game, that upgrade your character in any way, are useless, and you can equip limited amounts of them too - yes, even relics are limited to 3, whilst in "any other metroidvania"© you can equip as much of new abilities as you want! You could say "well its just different, it doesn't mean it's bad" - but when you have a game that is designed as a metroidvania, looks and feels like metroidvania, but it twists and breaks every single principle on which this genre is based on just to be "like Dark Souls", it [b]does[/b] conclude in a game that is at the very least not good.

Again, I can understand people who fell in love with this game for artstyle, atmosphere and setting alone - it's [b]that[/b] good. But when people write stuff like "the best metroidvania after SotN", I just have to wonder: how much did standarts fall over the years? Buy yourself Castlevania Advance Collection, see how SotN's ideas developed in future titles of the series; try Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night (which you can actually buy in the bundle with Blasphemous), see how the creator of SotN himself developed the idea even further; look at similair games, like Dead Cells, Record of the Lodoss War or Touhou Luna Nights; at the end of the day, beat Hollow Knight if you haven't already: it's one of the best metroidvanias ever released, and it, while being very unique, resembles everything - from Metroid and Castlevania to Zelda and Dark Souls.

This review is a bit hard to write. I did enjoy the game and the boss fights overall but it lacks in a lot of things. 

[b]Gameplay[/b] was pretty good and crisp. The parry is slightly OP but it doesn't ruin the game. There is a wide variety of prayers to try out. 

[b]Map design[/b] was phenomenal. Discovering shortcuts, NPCs, and items was always rewarding. The world was really well interconnected.

[b]Level design[/b] was horrible. By my first 8-9 hours of my game, I had only fought like 2 bosses (of which one is the tutorial boss). The levels are way too big with way too many enemies. Now I admit I was exploring every bit of the map before progressing to the next area, and clearing levels IS fun, but it becomes really tedious due to the sheer size of the map.

The items in the world should have been distinguished at least to some extent. For example, the "bones" that you collect have little short-term rewards and the long-term reward is [spoiler] unlocking a skin and a boss fight [/spoiler]. I would have preferred avoiding spending time on collecting bones in the game.


[b]Enemy designs[/b] were interesting and fun. There was some repetition in enemy types but for the most part it wasn't a problem. 

[b]Boss designs[/b] were really good. Though, I felt many boss fights were dragged on for too long. That wouldn't be an issue if the boss had a large moveset but that wasn't the case. If you didn't clear the boss in your first attempt, the following attempts felt a bit like a chore.

I loved the [b]art style[/b]. I'm not much of a lore guy so I didn't explore much of lore but I've heard people say that the lore is very interesting..

[hr][/hr]

Overall I would give this game a 6.5/10 (taking 5 as an average/mediocre rating, so it is a positive score). If you are hankering for a souls-like metroidvania, and you have a good chunk of time to spare, I think [i]you will enjoy it[/i]. Otherwise, I would say there are other games that will be a better use for your time.

So to date, I've played through the game once on my own, and a second time with the aid of a walkthrough for the purpose of unlocking all the achievements and goodies I had missed in the previous run. All in all, I will give the game a 9.5/10. The missing half point I leave purely for the purpose of allowing the opportunity to maintain dialogue about the game, as we all know not everyone enjoyed the title as much as the next person. The upgrade system is very straightforward; lots of unique and interesting attacks available that follow a standard platformer formula. The story itself is pretty straightforward. I was a big fan of the grim, dogmatic atmosphere the game cultivated, with each enemy seeming to follow that style. Unlocking all of the achievements, which required you to really dig deep into the game's content was incredibly rewarding, and when I managed to achieve the witnessing of the miracle I must say I was blessed. Absolutely solid title, would strongly recommend to anyone looking to try something new.

I have some minor criticisms with the platforming (looking at you spikes), level design (mourning & havoc, wtf), and boss AI; but overall, this is an excellent game that manages to set itself apart from a lot of other action platformers. It's not a terribly long game (took me ~20h to get 100% in the game), but there is plenty of endgame content and a bunch more content in NG+, courtesy of the multiple free DLCs.

The art direction paints a horrifically grim world that intrigues you at every corner, making exploration throughout the world to be quite captivating. The music is also fantastic. Every area and boss has their own distinct theme, each making terrific use of various instruments. I would've liked to see a few more moments in the game that make you gasp in awe and wonder, but that could just be because I played this after Elden Ring (which has an enormous amount of "wow" moments). Nonetheless, the world of Blasphemous is still incredibly memorable with its disturbingly dark and heavily Catholic undertones.

The combat is heavily focused on parrying, for most enemies, and thus is immensely satisfying. Each enemy has their own Execution animation (essentially a parry-triggered riposte) that is always cool to see, rendered in the pixelated artstyle of this game. Barring a few exceptions, boss fights always felt very calculated, requiring a lot of focus and skill to get right so that once you managed to beat them, the victory would feel incredibly rewarding.

Excellent game, possibly the best Metroidvania out there, very combat focused, beautiful art, skill based gameplay and a very interesting story, can't wait to play the sequel.

GRIM.  This is a True Black Metal world of Renaissance Christian Misery.  It's a well-made and designed game.  Very playable.  Difficult, but not painfully so.  The thing that sets this apart from all the other metroidvanias (and yeah I've played a million of them) is the atmosphere.  It's so well done, and it's NOT ANOTHER GOTHIC HORROR game!!  YAY!  This is far more disturbing-- the ambient sound, the sinister stories behind the bones, the dialogue is like something ripped out of the dreams of those who got left behind after the rapture and end of the world, and the art is detailed enough, but really gets your imagination going.  The executions are a nice touch.  Without being too wordy, this is one of the better games I've played in a long while.  It's not as beautiful as the Ori series (which you should have played by now), but it dodges being another Castlevania copycat with fluid movement and a surreal world that makes you uncomfortable to see whats around the next corner, but compels you to do so.  It really piques your morbid curiousity...  ENJOY.

Visually stunning, brutal and challenging metroidvania-like

Presentation   9/10

The art style is gorgeous pixel art, some set pieces just let you sit on that screen for a while and take it all in. Warning though: This game is intensely graphic and morbid, lots of blood and mutilation. Boss design in particular is very good, in some of those you will die because you still try to grasp what you are actually seeing on the screen. 
The Soundtrack is very catchy though it's basically x variations of the same theme. A few more themes wouldn't have hurt, though it never gets on your nerves.
I highly recommend turning on the Spanish voices with subtitles. The English voice-over is lacks a lot and feels almost phoned in. The original voices carry a lot of the dark and oppressive atmosphere.

Gameplay   8/10

It's basically a metroidvania with a key difference. Progression is not limited by items found but by bosses overcome. That's why it also often called a soulslike. You have a little choice of way in the beginning, where you can basically tackle the first bosses in any order you like before there is a chokepoint and then again a bite of choice where to go before the final part of the game. That said, the damage and health pools of enemies in different areas do direct you a bit in a linear way, except if you choose to overcome the higher difficulty for certain rewards. So it is a bit similar in structure to the first Dark Souls.

Combat is simple but challenging, though you can get a bunch of abilities through exploration and quests, these are more of an optional way to ease up on the difficulty. Basic gameplay is very much that of an action platformer and works very well. I think Hollow Knight's core gameplay is comparable.
Most enemies are very well to read after a couple of encounters, most bosses are very hard but also well to read and won't take hours to overcome if you are used to these kind of games.

Exploration is the key mechanic and really fun. There are only two areas that can be a bit frustrating. Mostly this comes from the controls that are a bit too imprecise for a few jump passages in the game. My main issue with the gameplay is that the game does very little to explain certain elements of it to you, so it is easy to feel lost in the beginning.

Story   7/10

The story is quite vague though not as much as in other soulslikes. It's all based in spanish catholicism though it leans heavily towards Miura's Berserk, as From Software did with Dark Souls. NPCs are well designed and interesting the overarching story though won't be the main thing that pushes you through the game. There are some interesting questlines though, some of them easy to miss. There are 3 endings (which you can all get in one game, if you know how) ranging from vague and rather anticlimactic to "WTF did I just see?" It hasn't quite the same immersion and feeling of dread that the original Dark Souls had though.

Overall an absolute recommendation for everyone who enjoys games like Hollow Knight or From Software games which lean towards a glum and dark setting, challenging but rewarding combat and exploration without an openly linear path to follow. A bit of frustration resistance is needed though I guess that is obvious seeing what games it get's compared to.

I went a few years thinking I wasn't going to enjoy this game. Like all GOOD metroidvanias, the tone of the game changes as you get stronger and can breeze through and not worry so much about taking damage anymore, but certainly in the early stages you've got to navigate carefully - I still think the controls aren't as responsive as they could be (the dash attack is great but doesn't always execute 100% of the time I want it to).
Music is very good (not quite excellent but the OST as a whole is extremely harmonious which shows real craftsmanship) and the atmosphere overall is great. 

I love exploring the zones and the game rewards you for it - so much so that I ended up bypassing a boss accidentally and will have to replay to do it properly lol The better levels are in the middle of the game, so I do think players starting out might find the pace a bit unbalanced at the start until they get stronger/better loot. By far the best thing you can do is donate 20000 tears to the Albero church and get the teleport ability, it saves HOURS of backtracking vs the standard teleports and it's instantaneous!

With the right equipment setup and getting better at knowing when to block/parry, the majority of bosses are a lot of fun. Isidora and Quirce were highlights (screw Sierpes!) and there is a good spread of in-game collectibles and secret rooms to keep you achievement-hunting.

Overall, not the best metroidvania, but very very good and the slow-paced, somber voice acting (though sometimes mispronounced i.e. "betrothed") set a great and CONSISTENT tone throughout the whole game, it's just very well put together and challenging but not impossible (spike traps are an instant 1 hit KO btw!). Would compare it to Salt and Sanctuary meets Spain in the dark ages lol

If you enjoy a nice metroidvania and darksouls fusion this is a good game for you.

Art: The game overall oozes style, the high gothic/Catholic mixed with horrific elements really creates a wonderfully unique look for this game. Most of the bosses and zones felt unique from each other and set their respective atmospheres well.

Difficulty: I don't consider myself overly good at souls-like/metroid style games like this, but with that being said I found the game pretty "easy", meaning that for all but maybe 2 or 3 bosses I was able to beat them in 3 tries or less. I haven't started the True Suffering new game+, which I imagine will be harder, but for the base game it was pretty easy to beat boss wise. The more difficult element was often navigating to the boss as a lot of the room obstacles posed more of a challenge for me.

 Story: Overall I enjoyed the story, it's obviously very religious in nature and focuses around the central theme of suffering and atoning for sin. I rather enjoyed the somewhat mysterious way things unfolded through the game, very much in keeping with it's Catholic inspirations. There are several areas in the game with shrines and religious sites which reveal new elements of the world and help to enrich the lore experience. Through the game you also encounter a wide variety of characters, most of them suffering from some sort of extraordinary affliction, these characters help you in a variety of ways with side quests, upgrades, and items. Pretty standard. A few of the characters stood out to me, I won't spoil anything for the review, but overall I wouldn't say the characterization was the strongest point of the game.


Mechanics: (Slight spoiler warning for relics in the game) The mechanics of the game I would say are simple but effective. You can unlock a number of moves and improve them as the game goes on, which combo in with the jump, dash, and attack you start with. I found that the combat with these simple mechanics flowed nicely and allowed a nice flow in combat. I thought the use of relics to reveal new ways of moving around the map rather than introducing a traditional double jump was a fun innovation and allows for some unique game play experiences not found in other similar games I've played. 

On the negative side there are some occasions were things got a little wonky, mostly around hit boxes. Sometimes I would dodge a projectile visually, but I would get hit. Sometimes I would definitely get hit by something visually, but would not actually take the hit. Overall I'd say this is a minor complaint though.

Overall: 9/10
I would have liked things to be more challenging first time around, but overall I really enjoyed the game.

[b]This review has had a full section removed due to Steam's prohibitive character limit, all of which is in regards to the DLC areas, I'll post this in the comments since it's important.[/b]

Blasphemous is a 2D Platformer in the Metroidvania genre with an absolutely stunning art style and very solid gameplay, it's sort of like Metroid mixed with Dark Souls in that it takes cues from both games and uses them to great effect. The map is vast and darkly beautiful, filled with numerous NPCs, enemies and environments that culminate in thrilling boss battles; I enjoyed almost every moment of this game from start to finish!

The country of Custodia is one of hopelessness, fruitless penance and constant violence. The entirety of the remaining populace has been thoroughly indoctrinated into worshipping a being known as "The High Wills", which bestows those who hold guilt in their hearts with "miracles" that almost exclusively result in perpetual torment in some form or another; to receive such a horrible punishment is considered the utmost of blessings and a sign of divine favour. The world is filled with these Penitents who are nearly all visibly marked by their penance, deformities and conversion into self sustaining biological torture devices being the norm; many of Custodia's citizens willingly live in a state of eternal torment that they themselves asked to receive in order to punish them for their misdeeds. There are many parallels to Catholicism both in the lore (which is very good) and in the architecture, but the faith of Custodia is utterly without redemption and their God knows no mercy.

The art direction of this game is nothing short of phenomenal! Every single area of the map is beautiful to look upon with heavy Gothic inspiration and stunning enemy design, many of the Penitents have disturbingly well thought out designs that left me saying "wow" way more than I expected to. The punishments that afflict them are really cool and the excess of gore only furthers the initial shock of seeing a new enemy for the first time, there are some truly awesome enemy and NPC designs! There's tons of satisfying and gory deaths for enemies and even their designs incorporate violence in very imaginative ways. This is easily one of the best looking games I've ever played, the pixelated graphics don't hold it back at all and everything looks incredible.

The gameplay is pretty similar to other games in the genre, with a dodge, basic attacks that can be turned into combos, upward and downward strikes and stabs, a ranged attack and spells that are called Prayers which have various effects that range from damaging enemies to returning to your last rest point. The checkpoint system is essentially the same as in Dark Souls, although the Prie Dieus are typically far more scarce than Bonfires. Blasphemous also uses a death system that's very similar to Dark Souls, in that you drop a mark wherever you die that you need to return to in order to recover fully; but you don't lose currency, you lose maximum Fervour (mana) each time you die instead. There are also several statues located around the map that can remove your built up "guilt" for a price. Personally I like this system a lot and never felt the need to use the statues, dying and reclaiming my mark rarely felt like a chore and you aren't severely punished for dying unless you leave a ton of marks unclaimed. The enemies are quite varied and require different strategies and moves to take on, many of them reward experimentation and proper timing which makes the combat much more interesting.

The bosses of this game are really cool, if a bit easy; I beat every single boss in the game in a single try except for the second one due to sloppy play and the DLC bosses which I will talk more about later. They provide a challenge but never an insurmountable one, there were several fights where I was left with no healing flasks and a tiny bit of health but none of them were extremely difficult to beat despite me being pretty bad at platformers. I don't consider this a negative however, because all of the bosses are visually amazing and the difficulty was just right for me to enjoy a harder fight while still being able to appreciate their design. There are seventeen of them scattered across the world and I enjoyed all of them with the exception of one from the DLC area.

The map is very well designed and really large, with many varied locations that are a joy to look at and countless hidden walls and floors that lead to shortcuts and loot. Every area had a ton of secrets to find with short puzzles mixed in to break up the action, making exploration of the map really fun; I'm not an observant person but I found lots of cool stuff just by being thorough. Fast travel locations are few and far between but rarely take a long time to reach and can take you wherever you want to go within a few minutes. Backtracking is present but not to a massive degree, I went back to old areas a handful of times to use new items and abilities to find loot but it wasn't a constant thing that I had to do. I never felt lost and the areas connect to each other pretty seamlessly, despite the size of the map it's very easy to traverse once you have an idea of where things are.

The story is very interesting and the lore is pretty deep, much like Dark Souls you'll get most of your knowledge of the world from item descriptions and conversations with NPCs. There are quests that require you to think outside of the box to complete and almost none of them have a happy ending. This is a very dark setting but it never feels edgy for the sake of being edgy, it's a mature and well written tale of religious extremism and humanity's need for retribution and punishment. I won't spoil the details but I enjoyed this aspect of the game a lot, this is a great setting and I've love to have it expanded upon.

Now for the bad parts, thankfully most of these aren't major. The biggest issue with this game is that Rosary Beads (think Rings from Dark Souls) don't have a noticeable effect most of the time, outside of quest related Beads most of them are tiny bonuses that you'll barely notice; there are no stats shown in game so you just have to test them for a while to see if they're worth using and most of them aren't. Some are far better than others, they give things like better dodging and big resistance or damage boosts while the ones you find by exploring are usually very minor effects that you wouldn't notice if you weren't specifically looking for them. Mechanically, there are some very annoying instances where you'll be trying to drop down a platform or climb up a ledge and nearby enemies will prevent this from working properly, sometimes it'll work just fine and other times you'll get stuck getting hit until they move away or die. Sometimes the controls can feel a bit clunky, they usually work very well but I've had several times where it felt like my inputs weren't going through and it can be frustrating to die when you know you hit the button to dodge or block but it didn't happen on screen.

I realise that I've written a rather lengthy section of negatives (check my comments for more), but don't let those issues prevent you from playing this game because it's really fun and a real gem! Overall the postives far outweigh the negatives and Blasphemous is an incredible game, it's my second favourite game in the entire Metroidvania genre and in my opinion it's only surpassed by Super Metroid; this game is far more visually and thematically interesting to me though so it's a very close choice. The world is vast and beautiful, the enemies are very macabre and mechanically engaging, the lore is grim and melancholic, the bosses are really cool and the exploration is very satisfying. That checks all the boxes for me and I wholeheartedly recommend this game! I'm looking forward to seeing what The Game Kitchen has for us next as this game was a truly fantastic first impression!

TL;DR  Solid 7 out of 10, could have been higher but it lacks polish in core areas of the gameplay bringing the overall score down.  Beaten the game 1 time with about 90% map exploration. This game is unforgiving if you're platforming is weak.

This game has a wonderful blend of breathtaking artwork paired with a cryptic narrative both of which promote a thirst for uncovering more of what this game and story has to offer. If you love piecing together the story versus having it force-fed to you then this game is right up your alley. 

The gameplay, however, could use some polishing and as a result, affect the score overall (could have been an 8!) Clearly the devs were inspired by the early Castlevania titles and it seems they have inherited some of the shortcomings from that series that effect the gameplay quality of life. 

Let's take a look at some examples: 

1. This game does not respect your time: You need to un-equip and re-equip "relics" that will grant you map exploration benefits such as immunity to poison or hidden climbable walls, most games in this genre (uhh like Symphony of the Night that released on the PlayStation decades earlier?) will have these relics equipped at all times but in Blasphemous you will find yourself toggling these relics on and off in your equipment window which needlessly interrupts your gameplay.

Another time waster: Roadblocks will appear in your way, in order to get around it you have to go through a door that is in the SAME ROOM, go through a jumping puzzle maze and pop out on the other side of said obstacle only to destroy it and create a shortcut, why?

2. You have enemies that will stunlock you to death if 1 happens to smack you into a group, huge unfair LINGERING hitboxes that betrays the animations on screen (looking at you sniper ghosts), and outdated enemy ai design such as flier types of enemies that will zip off the screen into the invincible void and stay there until you move away. 

All those complaints aside I had a lot of fun and thoroughly enjoyed the pixel artwork and exploring the world of CVSTODIA. If you love metroidvanias in the same vein as Bloodstained, Castlevania, and the like then you will enjoy this. Bear in mind there will be suffering even on the default mode for Sorrowful be the heart, Penitent one.

[h1]Nostalgia overload. Lets goooo!!![/h1]

Ok...im a huge fan of Castlevania, being Symphony of the Night my favourite platform game.
The thing is, for my sadness, i never saw that classic honoured the way it should. 
Until now, that is. 
Bear with me for a minute...

If you put Symphony of the Night on a level, you can put Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night as a its spiritual successor (its from the same mastermind of a creator, Koji Igarashi) what game do you choose to be on par with SotN? In my opinion its...[b]Blasphemous. Its bloody, its dark, its gritty, what more can you ask for? [/b]

Made in all its pixel art goodness, Blasphemous is a visual work of art, although i admit, for the religious and conservative type of players out there, this title can be a huge "No No". The important thing is not to take things as you see it. Its a different world with different beliefs and morals. And in this case, being good is worse that choosing the lesser evil, and some choices will affect the endings you get. [b]Be warned!![/b] 

On the sound department i have nothing to say apart from the fact that the music and sound effects are simply marvelous.

Gameplay wise, its has a neat feature (common these days on similar games), to make sure you stay alert, like the fact that everytime you die your "ghost" stays on the place you fell, and until you recover it you will be debuffed...oh...and it adds up. But, "to ease the agony", you got the good old weapon upgrades that make the game a bit more easy but not that much (gotta find them first though). Other features come straight from the classic i mentioned earlier like the map layout with various "biomes" and portal rooms that let you travel instantly to anywhere on the map (if you unlocked portal rooms through the world that is). There´s also a number of challenging bosses to be fought and armies of different mobs, each one with its own attack routine and ocasional defensive ones.

As for its difficulty, its not Dark Souls difficult but its not Super Mario easy. Its challenging...true, but its fair, you just need to keep in mind not to rush into a fight, thats suicide, and remember the old saying..."Know thy enemy".
Its even harder if you play on keyboard, believe me. [b]A controller is highly recomended.[/b]

Incidently, The Game Kitchen made a crossover with Bloodstained which resulted in a welcome addition to the game map, with a number of new rooms to discover, each one containing a frenetic level in a obstacle course type of run or a cage type of match. Bragging rights included if you can clear them all. [b]Note that this doesnt have any impact of the core story.[/b]

If you are looking for a great and atmospheric Metroidvania type of game with a rich story and good challenges, give Blasphemous a try.

Dont worry, it´s heresy free...for the most part.

Holy f. This game is unrelenting and unforgiving very nearly from the get go. It began with a boss that quickly killed me. At first I thought I was fighting a Ridley style tough boss who was meant to kill me, but no, he's just the first thing you fight and have to kill. The enemies get hard fast, you can barely heal, and you are pretty guaranteed to take hits. The skill floor is high and I'm not confident mastering fighting some of these minions without taking hits is possible. In other words, I felt like the mistakes I was making were not really preventable errors on my part.

The storytelling is difficult to understand, I've played half an hour and been told quite a lot and have no idea what is going on. The atmosphere it puts you in is very good, this is a dark dark world and the game does a good job of putting you in it. The items I've picked up make absolutely no sense. One of the first item you get is called a "thorn" and the game explains hat it is in a way that doesn't make any sense at all. If you pause and look at your inventory for a better explanation, it gives you a similarly bad description, and you can press Y to read lore. Hang on, wasn't what I just read the lore? No, there is more lore behind the lore-based description, and I still have no idea what it does. 

Every item I came across was like this. At one point it showed me I had a bunch of stuff in my inventory that I didn't even realise I'd picked up. And there are so many menus that I couldn't find where all of them were. And when you come across all of these items that the game doesn't want to tell you how to use, especially so early in the game, you stop caring.

Now I didn't play very much of this. But even 30 minutes in, even after accidentally finding a secret passage by hitting a random wall that led to a very very open area, I just wasn't having any fun. I bought this at 75% off thinking even if I don't really want to play this game I'll hang onto it anyway, but the experience was so poor and I was having absolutely no fun with it that I've changed my mind. This game could have turned me off all metroidvanias if I didn't know any better.

After completing this game once I have to say is a masterpiece! The game's story is really interesting and it has a lot of depth. 
Regarding the good aspects, I can list some such as 
-Really meaty and satisfying combat, that, at least during early game, is slow and metodical, with every enemy having a different approach
-The artstyle is beautiful, with a lot of detail in both characters, enemies and backgrounds
-Level design is interesting, and will have you backtracking a lot descovering new stuff in every zone
-(At least in spanish) The voice acting is absolutlely stellar, and increases the immersion of the game.
-A lot of the bosses have really cool and interesting designs and approaches, bosses like Tres Angustias, Melequíades and Crisanta come to mind.
-You can specialize in different playstyle approaches by changing your rosary beads, sword hearts and prayers, and while the game core remains the same, you will notice a difference and min max your build to fit your preferences. 

The game is not perfect, however, and regarding the bad aspects of it I can say things such as:
-Insta death traps can get frustrating, specially in enemy heavy zones like Jondo or the Archcathedral rooftops
-Some bosses (and even some enemies) can stunlock you, dealing a considerable amount of damage. Bosses like Esdras and Our Lady of the Charred Visage come to mind.
-By starting with the wrong zone, you can make the game stupidly hard, I made that mistake and almost dropped it
-The way to obtain some of the hearts and relics is really unintuitive, making this game a "wiki heavy" one if you care about getting everything

To new players, I can give you some recommendations that will make your gameplay much smoother:
-DON'T start by going up to the snowy zone in the wasteland of the buried churches, instead, go foward until you find the entrance to a church to enter a zone called Mercy Dreams, that path has a really organic progression that will give you a better introduction to the game.
-Don't try to rush the game, you will get yourself killed and end up frustrated. take your time to learn the enemies' attack patterns and learn the games movement mechanics and you will be dying a lot less
-Pay attention to items' descriptions and NPC's dialogues, a lot of really relevant information can be found on those.
-Always mark on your map the location of items out of your reach, so you can retrieve them once you've aquired the tools to do so
-Once you have the money to spare, donate 20,000 tears to the church, you won't regret it! :)


That would be all, hope you have fun and Merciful be the heart, Penitent one!

So this is my second time playing Blasphemous (originally 100% completed on GOG) and I've gotta say it kinda doesn't hold up to a second play through. Don't get me wrong, it is a spectacular game especially when it comes to atmosphere, but there is a fine line between challenge and just dicking the player about. I love a good hard boss fight but when the save point is so far from each boss that you spend 30 seconds getting mushed into a rich creamy pate by an interesting new monstrosity and then two minutes trudging all the way back to said monstrosity through samey irritating mobs, it rather kills the pacing. Spikes being an insta kill only adds to this problem, especially with how clunky the platforming can feel.

I was going for the true ending on my run and (without wishing to spoil) there was a point where my ghost glitched to where it was literally impossible to reach and I had no way of getting it back. This would be fine if it reset when I died without collecting it but, alas, no such luck.

That being said, most of the time Blasphemous plays exceptionally well and I would highly recommend you pick it up, but if you get easily frustrated by back tracking, maybe give this one a miss.

For the uninitiated, first play Castlevania: Symphony of the Night.  Then, play either Bloodbourne or Dark Souls. 
 It's the exploration of Metroidvania meets the punishing difficulty of Soulsbourne.

The first boss you meet(well, first enemy, period) is a giantic thing wielding a humongous cross.  That should set the scene for the rest of this game.

The art style?  It's a gorgeous game.  Can be a bit disturbing at times, but what do you expect from a game called "Blasphemous"?  The environments really send you.  Enemy variety is nice; some can be a bit obnoxious, but they're few and far between.

Controls aren't bad, but they can be a bit clunky at times.  You'll jump to a ladder and it's 90% land your jump and 10% "Whoops!" instant death on spikes.  Jump to a moving platform?  Oops, you're a ghost and you'll fall right through oh wait you're not a ghost WHAM instant death on spikes.  Then it's backtrack 14 screens because the save points are few and far between.  Things I would change...falls and spikes shouldn't be instant death(as in, land on spikes?  it takes a chunk of health, and sends you back to the entrance you used to the room you're in.  Same thing with bottomless pits.  Will make this game MUCH less frustrating).

1 word...patience.  If you don't have a lot of patience, I would not recommend this game. It can be punishingly(even frustratingly) difficult at times(well, most of the time); instant death is everywhere.  Some insane(almost unnecessary) difficulty spikes with a few mid- and endgame bosses can frustrate someone enough to deter them from wanting to finish the game.  It was months(literal months) in between when the midgame boss defeated me 200 times and me picking up the game again.  Learn how to use your parry really early on.  It will be the literal difference between life and death.

All of this being said, and as hard as this game is, I've put over 50 hours into it.  It's an incredibly well-done piece of art, and incredibly fun and rewarding when you finally do defeat a boss you've been working on forever.  It has to be; There is no other way one would want to see it through to the end.

Again, highly recommended, but beware...this game can be very very hard at times.

UPDATE: I have finally defeated this game.  The Wounds of Eventide DLC is awesome.  2 new bosses(which are quite a healthy challenge), new ending.
ADDENDUM TO UPDATE: DO NOT PLAY NEW GAME+ UNLESS YOU ARE A MASOCHISTIC GLUTTON FOR PUNISHMENT.  You keep all your rosary beads, abilities, prayers...your sword is the same level it was when you beat the game, and it's still a huge slog.  NG+ makes all enemies and bosses needlessly tanky, damage-spongey, and they do 14 times the damage.  So be prepared to hate yourself.

I love this game. But I also hate this game.

Blasphemous is easily described as a souls-like metroidvania, akin to games like Hollow Knight. You have consumable healing items that are recharged at rest spots, enemies drop currency, and you lose said currency when you die. The combat is fine - fluid and customizable through different special attacks and items.

What really sets Blasphemous apart from other games in the genre is the incessant dark tone. The game has a very "Dark Souls" story, taking place in a dying/decaying world, but there is a very religious angle to everything that makes it unique. Beyond this, everything is BRUTAL. Combat has you executing enemies. The bosses are Gothic abominations from the Pope's nightmares. Cutscenes are traumatizing. To top it all off, the pixel art is absolutely stunning, enhancing the grotesqueness of the world around you. Blasphemous has succeeded in taking this very dark, oppressive religious tone and making it very cohesive and captivating. 

Overall, There isn't anything in Blasphemous's combat or exploration that is going to blow you away, but it is still fun. What Blasphemous does succeed in, however, is creating a fully realized world wrought with religious death and decay that is riveting to experience.

A metroidvania. Or more like a meh-troidvania. It's decent but nothing memorable or must-play. I mean the bosses are a big disappointment, they're not even hard or interesting in any way. The game runs out of steam halfway and starts reusing enemies and giving you enemies with really lazy attack patterns, usually just awkwardly lunging at you. Though the pixel art is very nice, I don't get a sense of atmosphere from the levels the way I do from, say, Super Metroid or Hollow Knight. They just feel like random backdrops. Part of the reason is because the music is not all that interesting or memorable. The other issue I have to bring up is the story and lore, and usually I can ignore this in an action game, but there's so much put into it here thats I just have to comment out how negatively it impacts the experience when I cannot follow what is actually going on--and a lot of it is supposed to contextualize the enemies and NPCs, but it doesn't do a good job of it at all, so you lose out on a lot. Like there's this guy in the library level who tells you he wants you to "stop the noise". Ok; what noise? what is making it? how do I stop it? I just don't get why they went with the "let's not tell the player what's going on" approach. The combat is super simple, you have some moves like parries as well as magic that you will quickly forget exist because the most reliable thing to do is just jump to avoid enemies and swing until they're dead or use your OP slide attack.

Another issue is design as a Metroidvania. You meet all sorts of NPCs who will tell you they need stuff, and unless you are playing the game with a wiki open, you will not remember who needs what, and many of the quests are time sensitive. A walkthrough is mandatory if you want to see the true ending. Unlike most Metroidvanias, you do not receive any real mobility upgrades, just a few optional ones that come from the aforementioned NPC quests that let you access other areas. These are basically just keycards that let you access new areas, rather than changing the mechanics of the game in any interesting way. This means the backtracking will be super tedious because there is no way to change the default speed or rush through an area. Yeah you get stronger physically but more or less you're still approaching the areas the same way and killing the enemies the same way.

The level design is ok. Overall I think this should have just been a linear game like the older Castlevania games. There is almost nothing Metroidvania about this game and the few elements that are, make the game worse by having to use a wiki to figure out what to do because of the time sensitivity and large number of NPCs, coupled with the tedious backtracking. Oh and here's the really funny thing, there is actually a way to make the backtracking super trivial via teleporting but it's obscure and you will not realize how to do it unless you read the wiki. How about instead of waxing poetic about guilt and miracles, the game's NPCs tell me how to use save points as teleporters? Just wtf-tier design. 6/10

There are a lot of things that Blasphemous miss on
- Level design: The first few dungeons are okay, not great but passable. Then the dev pretty much drops the ball and stops designing levels and instead start designing "boring walks to the boss"
- Combat: It's serviceable, but considering it has neither extensive customization nor advanced movement mechanics, it's not great. Boss designs become a lot simpler to acommodate these limitations too.
- Exploration: not rewarding/metroidvania enough, feels more like level select approach.
The game is more or less only carried by its artstyle and nothing else. Don't get me wrong, there are so many more worse "metroidvanias" on steam that this might just be worth picking up during a sale ... but I don't recommend this if you haven't played the best ones (which are imo Hollow Knight/Ender Lilies which hit all the marks above) or the better ones, like Salt and Sanctuary (offers real customization and a lot more contents), Astalon (offers real level design and platforming), Dark Devotion (offers a fun curse/blessing system that makes exploring fun).

Blasphemous is probably comparable to Death's Gambit, both games have enough contents, neither too great at any of the metroidvania aspect. Blasphemous is probably better if you enjoy the art style, but that's kinda it.

[h1]A 2D action metroidvania heavily inspired by Castlevania and Dark Souls[/h1]

Blasphemous's tone is serious, dark and religious as the title implies. If you've played Souls series before, you will notice lots of similar element in this game; from upgradable healing flasks, grotesque enemy designs, something drops when you dies, obscure ways of storytelling etc. Despite those similarities, the game managed to shine on its own and i had a great experience playing.

The greatest strength of this game lies within [b]combat and exploration[/b] just like Souls series. The combat is challenging yet very enjoyable. Every hits felt impactful and satisfying. You can also perform executions, which look totally brutal yet ridiculous sometimes, on some enemies. There are many aspects which enhance the gameplay such as character upgrades, beads, relics and sword hearts which can be found throughout the vast world making exploration worthwhile. Some of these upgrades are also required in order to progress to some areas.

It's not possible to not mention about the game [b]design[/b]. Many enemies and NPCs look absolutely grotesque and disturbing yet they are very cool and artistic. I felt like many of them is based on beliefs and religion in some ways. The designer(s) made sure to have them stuck in your head. 

I will not talk about the [b]lore/story[/b] since it was too complicated for me to understand. The game has a way of telling story through NPCs and items just like Dark Souls and i'm quite unfamiliar with the vocabulary used. You have to piece things together to get the whole idea of what was going on. It's not mandatory to understand the lore to enjoy this game, however, i'm sure you will have a better experience if you do.

[b]In conclusion[/b], Blasphemous is the game i recommend for anyone looking for a Souls-like Castlevania game with strong combat, exploration and beautiful bizarre design. [b]Final score : 8.8/10[/b]

Do you want a difficult and violent action platformer with a setting rarely explored by media? This is the game for you. Coming in under a gigabyte you play as the Penitent One, a mute sociopath with a penchant for self-flagellation of the sort both literal and metaphorical. You are in a world touched by the Grievous Miracle, an event that has turned the land into a decaying body kept in the ideal stage of suffering where it is just alive enough to feel the worst effects of its sickness and dead enough where it cannot do anything about it. It's a violent, rotten, and religiously fanatic world. Everyone self-punishes in some way or worships at the feet of disgusting alters of bloated flesh, all gifts and consequences of the Grievous Miracle. Your sword is wrapped in a rose vine that pushes a thorn into your hand. You heal with bile flasks that you rub onto your metal face plate. You die and die and die in horrifically violent ways. It's bleak, as God intended.

As for a plot you are given practically no sense of what is going on, the best you get is that you may or may not be the last member of some order of monks or pilgrims as everyone recognizes you on sight as the Penitent One and that you woke up and chose violence. You kill sewer monsters, knights, cherubs, angels, and abominations taken directly from the dreams of a early-Medieval Christian peasants on a quest to kill the Pope. Or, at least that's what you end up doing.

But don't let the player protagonists' implied guilt, monastic vow of silence, and willingness to help those who suffer from the worst effects of the Grievous Miracle make it seem as if he'll shy away from violence because the combat is brutal and unforgiving. You carry a sword which has a standard attack, a charge attack, and a parry mechanic that if timed correctly on certain enemies will allow you to unleash a plethora of over-the-top finishing moves as the Penitent One rips heads from spines, cuts limbs, and curb stomps enemies with violent rage. You also get access to a few magic spells, or blessings, that let you attack from a distance. There's also equippables that buff certain aspects of your character, giving you more damage or increasing resistances. It's a Dark Souls style affair in its gameplay: you'll go from room to room killing enemies and avoiding damage where you can and healing with a limited supply of items that refill upon resting at a save point. Bosses are tough as nails and liable to kick your ass the first time you fight them but the real challenge comes from having to balance the combat with the surprisingly difficult platforming. It's a Metroid-vania in its level design, having you traverse and backtrack across a large map as you discover new items that make you groan as you think about all the possible places it could open up for you.

To summarize: the game is good. Get it if you like hard platformers and want a setting inspired by a period of history that nobody seems to remember or want to talk about. It's a breath of fresh, bloodied, pus-filled air. Praise be to the Grievous Miracle.

This game is a brutal treat, a gem really, that will have you simultaneously praising the gorgeous art and visceral gore while pulling your hair out as you try to fight the same boss for the 15th time.  It almost feels like a 2d Dark Souls game.  When you finally do figure out how to beat a boss though it's very rewarding and each one has an awesome death animation. 

Gameplay is engaging and fun. with a traditional 2d side scroller fighting game feel to it.  Timing matters and blocking an attack to perform an execution is rewarded with sick as fuck animation and guts and blood.  This game is gorey in all the right ways.  As the game goes on you'll unlock new move sets and grow your character and yourself into a more effective fighter.

The story is captivating but it is quite odd, twisted and not linear as most of the story has to deal with what brought about the world your character inhabits.  All of the voice work is superb and hits the right notes.  There are multiple endings and you can make choices in the game that will lock you out of stuff.  The choices and their consequences are subtle, perhaps only story related at times, and you may not even know you're making one at the time. 

The "rogue-like" elements do appear, you can use items to build your character and gain power ups in an order of your choosing but usually you'll find some items of particular use to the boss or area you are in.  I don't believe the levels are randomly generated, though I haven't played enough yet to generate a second world, but I'll try to correct this if I am wrong.

"Sorrowful be the heart, Pentinent One."  Go forth and slay.

I think the game started pretty rough and the first 3 hours in particular were pretty boring, but once the game gets going it it comes off as a very solid experience. The areas become better, the combat becomes more solid with new abilities and better enemies, and the overall experience ends up being pretty good. It has Metroidvania elements but I don't think it qualifies as one, it's mostly a 2D side scrolling action game imo. Some controls were clunky and some boss fights were a big difficulty spike but overall it's doable.

Worth it at any good sale.
